Deep down below the surface, the Swedish capital Stockholm offers up a cultural attraction that is truly unique. It‚Äôs known as the longest art gallery in the world and boasts 110 km of art across nearly 100 metro stations spread across the city.
Stockholm is built on an archipelago, with over fifty islands crisscrossed by bridges and waterways. The islands themselves are granite and gneiss, which often poke their forested heads out of the water showing their dark, shining cliff faces.
So when the city‚Äôs subterranean metro system was built in the second half of the 20th century, it necessitated the creation of stations deep underground with dark, cavernous walls ‚Äî the so-called ‚Äòcave stations‚Äô.
On a cold Friday evening at the end of a busy week of work travel, I found myself with a few hours to kill in the Swedish capital. So, armed with a digital guide and a sense of eager anticipation, I plotted a course through several metro stations on the Blue Line.
I‚Äôd been promised that each station‚Äôs art and theming was unique. I was told that every station is someone‚Äôs favourite station. What I found was that each station‚Äôs art usually relates to‚Ä¶

Title: Project for a Trip to Sweden: 48 hours in Stockholm
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I visited the Swedish capital on the 23rd of May 2025, the weekend before my 37th birthday, and this piece was scheduled for the 1st of June 2025. However, due to some back-to-back travelling and personal drama (a dramatic choice of words), I decided not to interrupt your popcorn-munching while watching the third and messiest divorce of the leader of the free world. I know there are other things worth your attention now, like WW3, but bear with me; I will be brief.
I landed at Stockholm Arlanda Airport at around 23:00, after an uneventful 2-hour and 20-minute flight. From the airport, the easiest way to get to Stockholm is by train; the yellow Arlanda Express takes you to Stockholm C (the central station) in 18 minutes and runs around the clock. It is promoted all over the airport (big, yellow banners) as the fastest and most environmentally friendly way to get to Stockholm (truthful advertising). One adult ticket costs 340 SEK (around 32 EUR).
I arrived at Stockholm C at 23:30. After a 25-minute search for the metro (it‚Äôs not the city, it‚Äôs me) and a four-minute metro ride, I arrived at Gamla Stan, the medieval centre of Stockholm, where the boat-hotel where we were lodging was. This adventure would‚Äôve been a ten-minute walk, and I don‚Äôt want to talk about it anymore.
On Saturday morning, we went for a walking tour of the city. My friend chose a local, born and bred Stockholmer as a guide. Agnes is friendly, a good storyteller, and obviously very passionate about her city. We walked past the Swedish Parliament, the square where Greta Thunberg was holding her ‚ÄòFridays for Future‚Äô protests, the Stockholm City Hall, where each year, on the 10th of December, the Nobel Prize banquet takes place with or without Bob Dylan, the Nobel Museum, the Stockholm Cathedral, and the red building that allegedly inspired all those bucolic Swedish red cabins with white trims. What I learned: the Swedes are very straightforward, almost on the nose when it comes to names (if something sounds as-if‚Ä¶ it probably is), Sweden has nearly 10,000 lakes (I googled the number afterwards; I just remembered it was astronomical), it is the European country that has been the longest at peace ‚Äî including Switzerland, not being involved in a major conflict for over 200 years, and that between the 19th and the 20th century, financial hardship and lack of religious freedom generated mass migration, with 1,3 millions Swedes leaving the country and settling in the Midwest of the United States, especially Minnesota (same climate, loads of lakes). The newly formed communities kept their traditions, hence giving us the Golden Girls‚Äô Rose Nylund and Fargo. Thank you, Sweden! The guide explained the already legendary governmental liquor stores and the Swedes‚Äô relationship (and bumpy history) with alcohol. The information was received without much surprise, but ‚Äòfree will‚Äô was mentioned.
This list is not exhaustive ‚Äî if you are curious for more, go see Agnes.
After the tour and a stroll through S√∂dermalm (the ‚ÄòHipsters Island‚Äô) we had some fabulous coffee (it is actually very difficult to find a lousy brew) with a cardamom bun (a close cousin of the more famous cinnamon bun), and we headed to the Nationalmuseum for some fine arts.
The gallery hosts a well-curated collection of Swedish and international art in their permanent collection, following a 500-year timeline. As my friend noticed, for a national gallery, it shows an impressive number of non-Swedish artists alongside national household names like Carl Larsson and the contemporary Ernst Billgren. While strictly speaking, only the former qualifies ‚Äî in Sweden and abroad ‚Äî as a household name, Ernst Billgren has been a fantastic discovery. A well-known figure in the Swedish contemporary art scene, Billgren is a born-and-based Stockholm artist. He rose to national fame in the 1980s. His works are currently exhibited at the museum in a solo exposition titled New Memories. From the 10th of April to the 28th of September 2025, the gallery shows Billgren‚Äôs 25 re-interpretations of classical paintings in the Nationalmuseum‚Äôs collection. The exhibition has a marine feeling to it, with the sea and ships being recurrent themes, and I am a sucker for anything that involves the sea. Plus, I find an image of a boat sailing in the interior of a Gothic Cathedral irresistibly attractive. Nevertheless (but clearly in the same registry), my favourite painting in the collection was Eugene Jansson‚Äôs Riddarfj√§rden, Stockholm, 1898, showing a night cityscape from across a body of water. It captures perfectly the mesmerising light of the Scandinavian summer nights.
Caveat: the museum closes at 17:00 on Saturdays, so plan ahead carefully. We did not, so 17:30 found us on the sidewalk, buying a Swedish newspaper (me) and tickets for a public transportation boat to an unknown island. If you do not like to plan ahead, don‚Äôt fret; the boat ride was great. However, you might want to ask questions and decide beforehand on which island to get off. If you wing it as it comes, you will end up hearing, ‚ÄòGo back; this is a private island, and you will freeze to death‚Äô (very direct and practical people, I am telling you).
As I did not freeze to death and lived to see the mesmerising light of my second Swedish night, I had dinner at Bl√• d√∂rren (‚Äòthe blue door‚Äô), a resto-pub in S√∂dermalm, and the only place where the literary what-you-hear-is-what-you-get of the Swedes disappointed. Due to city regulations ‚Äî the menu explains ‚Äî the place does not have a blue door. What it does have is excellent elk meatballs, Swedish beer and Sm√∂rdegsknyte ‚Äî a pastry filled with salty cheese, covered in apricot sauce and paisley. The music is straight out of the Helsinki Playlist (Rod Stewart still does not want to talk about it).
Sunday morning, after another excellent coffee, we headed to what‚Äôs probably Stockholm‚Äôs most famous tourist attraction, the Vasa Museum (that huge, heavily adorned wooden boat that you keep seeing in your Instagram feed). The ship draws her moniker from an ample carving of the coat of arms of the House of Vasa (below), the royal dynasty that ruled Sweden from 1523 to 1654 and the Polish‚ÄìLithuanian Commonwealth from 1587 to 1668. Built in the 17th century to fight in the Polish-Lithuanian war, the Swedish warship sank on her maiden journey on the 10th of August 1628, after sailing for about 1,300 meters. History notes that what destabilised it was a gust of wind, as the ship was too tall. The Vasa was built to instil fear and respect in the enemies, with her 64 guns and countless colourful sculptures, many of them poking fun at the Polish (like the merman wearing a cardinal red hat, as Catholicism was the official religion in Poland, and the effigy of a Polish man fearfully crawling under a bed). Nowadays, the vessel is not inducing fear (provided you are not a 17th-century Polish soldier), but let one think that this is what happens when hubris and engineering fight and hubris wins. To Gustavus Adolphus‚Äô credit (the Swedish king who commissioned the boat), hubris was exacerbated by hurry (at the time, Sweden was involved in ‚Äî or recovering from ‚Äî multiple conflicts), and engineering was precarious, at best. One of the wall texts of the museum explains that, at the time of the building, ship drawings were unheard of, and the ship master builder was working exclusively on expertise and dead reckoning. A tribunal inquest followed the sinking. No one was found guilty. After recovering the bronze cannons, the ship went into a 300-year forgetfulness.
The Vasa was recovered in 1961. The highly polluted (low in oxygen, preventing wood-attacking fungi and bacteria from surviving), low-salinity waters of the Stockholm harbour kept the wreck nearly intact. After undergoing a series of very elaborate conservation procedures, the Vasa was towed to her current location in 1988. The museum was officially opened in 1990. About three or four years later, I was learning to read in a small Romanian town from a comic book featuring a cute bear in a yellow and blue onesie who gained supernatural powers by eating a certain kind of honey. He had a bunch of friends, including a rabbit and a turtle, and was ‚Äî of course ‚Äî using those powers to fight the bad guys. His name was Bamse, the strongest bear in the world. ‚ÄòWhat does this have to do with a 17th-century shipwreck?‚Äô you will correctly ask yourself. Well, Bamse and I parted ways when I turned 7 and went to school. We meet 30 years later, in the Vasa museum shop. It turns out he is Swedish (the onesie should have been a hint), and he is still a big thing out there, having his face on trams and a special edition of the comic book titled Bamse and Vasa the Ship (I did not buy a copy).
The Djurg√•rden island, where the Vasa is, hosts a long list of museums; among them ABBA: The Museum. Book ahead if you want to visit this one; we did not, and we ended up having more coffee and buns in the museum‚Äôs cafe, with probably the most famous Swedes (if we are not counting IKEA‚Äôs Billy) playing in the background. A loss from which I can recover (unlike the Bamse comic book), as, to my mother‚Äôs chagrin, the Swedish Eurovision legend has never really floated my boat (see what I did there?). Even the ironic fondness that EU-bubble karaoke singers show for the band has eluded me.
As time was too short for the Photography Museum, we took a long stroll back to the city centre and went for the last lunch of the trip. Tacos! ‚ÄòWe Swedes are obsessed with tacos. And with summer,‚Äô was one of the things Agnes told us. While it is easy to understand (also, she explained that one) why they are obsessed with summer, the tacos part felt like a mystery worth of Scooby-Doo (bear with me, I just took a trip down the cartoon characters memory lane), so I started typing into Google ‚Äòwhy are Swedes‚Ä¶‚Äô. The suggestions indicated that the taco dilemma was not very popular. The first one in the list of query suggestions was ‚ÄòWhy are Swedes so hot.‚Äô I guess some really are into the tall, blonde, blue-eyed, perfect-smile type. Go figure. Going back to my anthropological research: from its beginnings, in 1956, to the late 1980s-early 90s, Swedish television was governmentally-run and ad-free. In the early 90s, it was privatised, and when commercials became legal, the first ones instantly became legendary and urban folklore. ‚ÄòPeople in their 40s still quote Gillette and Libresse,‚Äô a Swede told me. ‚ÄòOne commercial was about having tacos on Fridays, and Swedes ‚Äî used to do as we‚Äôre told ‚Äî picked up on it, and then it just became a thing, alongside stuff like watching Disney on Christmas Eve and Ivanhoe on New Year‚Äôs Day,‚Äô he continued. Having experienced this phenomenon first-hand in my own country, this makes sense. Who knows what culinary traditions the Romanians would‚Äôve developed after the fall of the Iron Curtain if we only had been able to do as we were told (a biased and generalising joke based primarily on the writer‚Äôs shortcomings).
Right before taking the Arlanda Express to the airport, we had another round of Fika (a break involving a cup of coffee and a pastry)-more excellent coffee and sweets. Once arrived at the Arlanda I realised my flight was delayed, and I exercised my half-free-will with a Swedish lager.
In a nutshell, go to Stockholm. Pack a sleeping mask if you go during the summer, and warm clothes, even if you go during the summer.
Pictures by my talented friend, who also happens to be an excellent travel buddy.
--
--
Rookie writer. Brussels based.

For my flight from Bergen, Norway to Amsterdam, Netherlands, I flew with SAS Airlines and had a 6 hour layover at the Arlanda airport in Stockholm, Sweden. I had heard rumors of Stockholm‚Äôs easy breezy 20 minute express train (Arlanda Express) into the city center, and after much encouragement from Swedish locals I met whilst in Norway, I decided to take on the challenge of paring down Stockholm highlight lists I found online into something even more compact.
Knowing it would take approximately 1 hour to traverse from plane seat to the city center and another 2 hours to get from city center, through security, and to the gate (I like to be safe), I set out to explore as much of Stockholm as I could in 3 hours.
And so it goes‚Ä¶
Arlanda Express is easily navigable from the Arrivals gates, and it‚Äôs the fastest way into the city center (~20 minutes)
To take the Arlanda Express, directly proceed downstairs after exiting baggage claim and purchase tickets to the Stockholms Centralstation (Stockholm central station) at the platform. I like talking to humans, so went to the info desk where they sold me a round-trip ticket. It‚Äôs priced at 300 SEK for a round-trip young adult ticket (18‚Äì25 years old), and it‚Äôs the same as purchasing 2 single-ride tickets there and back (and same price as purchasing at the platform downstairs).
NOTE: When navigating back from the airport, be sure to check which terminal your flight departs from so that you can get off at the appropriate stop.
I found the architecture on this street quite interesting‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa mixture of new and old world styles
On the day I was here, there was a Thai cultural celebration so there were an array of Thai food stalls and a stage for performances set up.
The Royal Swedish Opera House, known as the Kungliga Operan in the local language, was built in the Neo-Classical style.
On my way to Gamla Stan (the old town), I crossed the Str√∂mbron bridge. On the way back, I took Norrbro bridge to take in a different view of the city.
If you have more time, you too could sail to Dj√ºgardeb (for the Vasa Museum & Gr√∂na Land amusement park) or islands beyond. There are 14 islands on the surrounding archipelago, so there‚Äôs plenty to explore.
Clearly I didn‚Äôt have time, so I settled for this view.
Within the cobblestone roads and colorful buildings. of the old town Gamla Stan, there are many hidden gems‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääincluding the narrowest alleyway M√•rten Trotzigs Gr√§nd, and delicious snacks too (more on my favorites in the ‚ÄúBites‚Äù section). This part of Stockholm was originally built in the 14th century, and the buildings that still exist today originate from the 18th and 19th century.
The Royal Palace is situated on the northeast side of Gamla Stan, and this is the official royal residence of the Swedish monarch. Although their names aren‚Äôt plastered across the tabloids in the states like the English monarch, from the postcards lining the streets in Gamla Stan, the Swedish royal family looks quite beautiful.
Because I had visited the Nobel Peace Center while I was in Oslo, Norway and thoroughly enjoyed that exhibit, I knew I wanted to visit the Nobel Museum whilst in Stockholm.
There‚Äôs an informative English-guided tour every hour at the quarter-hour mark, lasting approximately 30 minutes.
Fun facts about the Nobel Prize:
Similar to Oslo‚Äôs Nobel Peace Center, tickets here are 120 SEK for adults and 80 SEK for students.
I didn‚Äôt have time to go up close to Stockholm‚Äôs City Hall, much less to tour the courtyard/inside. Stockholm‚Äôs City Hall is especially significant because the annual Nobel Prize ceremony and subsequent banquet are held here every year on December 10th. I prioritized visiting the Nobel Museum over the venue this time.
Because hello, it‚Äôs Sweden üá∏üá™
Specifically, I‚Äôd like to go to the IKEA museum, which is actually in IKEA‚Äôs founding city (√Ñlmhult, Sweden)
Food, in my opinion, is a gateway into a country‚Äôs culture. Obviously, I couldn‚Äôt very well leave Gamla Stan before having lunch and an afternoon fikka (the coffee culture is v strong here)
Apparently, Swedes love herring. So what did I eat? Herring of course. From a street cart. And it was bomb.
Imagine: buttered rye toast topped with fried herring, onions, and dill. I‚Äôm usually not a fan of half these items, but somehow this Swedish creation was delicious.
NOTE: There‚Äôs an option to try pickled herring (even more of a local favorite) instead of fried herring, but I was not so adventurous.
The Swedish love coffee enough that they have turned their word for coffee break ‚Äúfika‚Äù into a verb. So it seemed only appropriate to grab a pastry and latte and relax‚Ä¶for a hot second‚Ä¶
No really, when I said hot second earlier I really meant hot. It was nearly 90 degrees when I was in Sweden, therefore a latte was not particularly pleasing. So I hopped next door for a cold ice cream cone‚Ä¶ Fika, my way ‚úåüèº
Scandinavians seem to really like the Kit Kat, as both local manufacturers (Marabou and Cloetta) have created candy bar copy cats of the Chocolate wafer bar, albeit with a few extra flavors.
And there you have it y‚Äôall, my 3 hours in Stockholm, Sweden.
I‚Äôm curious to know, have you ever done a quick stopover in any city? Feel free to message me on Instagram @deannadarlingg!
Travel on, friends,
Deanna

Title: Stockholm: Finding Home in a Place I‚Äôve Never Been
Content:

Sign in

Share
A weekend in Sweden that felt less like visiting a new place and more like finding a piece of home.
‚ÄúTravel far enough, you meet yourself.‚Äù ‚Äî David Mitchell, Cloud Atlas
I didn‚Äôt go to Sweden expecting a life-changing experience. But standing on the train, surrounded by people with blonde hair and long legs, I had a strange feeling ‚Äî one I‚Äôve never really had while traveling.
For once, I think I might fit in.
It‚Äôs not that I feel like an outsider in Barcelona, but let‚Äôs be honest: I do stand out. At 5‚Äô10‚Äù, I‚Äôm used to towering over people in Spain, in the U.S., even in most places I‚Äôve been. But in Sweden, I was just one of the many. Walking through Stockholm, it was the first time I didn‚Äôt feel like I had to shrink myself, like I didn‚Äôt have to be aware of how much space I took up.
Maybe that sounds dramatic, but if you‚Äôve ever felt out of place, you know what I mean. Sweden wasn‚Äôt just another stop on my study abroad adventure ‚Äî it was a place that felt familiar in a way I didn‚Äôt expect. A place that made me feel connected to a part of myself I‚Äôd never really thought about before.
But before I could romanticize it too much, I had to survive hostel life.
In my head, I booked a female-only dorm in my Stockholm hostel. In reality, I walked into a room of four men and me.
I‚Äôd love to say I was unfazed, that I confidently strolled in and claimed my bunk, but the truth is, I was nervous. It‚Äôs not that they weren‚Äôt nice ‚Äî if anything, they seemed too nice, which somehow made me even more uneasy. I stayed in bed, waiting under my covers until they all left in the morning before I got up. So much for being a fearless traveler.
But if that first night was uncomfortable, the second was downright painful. Paige, my best friend from Florence, was supposed to meet me that morning, but instead, I woke up to a disaster of texts explaining how she forgot her passport, missed her first flight, booked another, then realized she booked it for March 14 instead of February 14. Poor girl. By the time she actually made it to Sweden, I had spent an entire day solo in a city I had never been to before.
And I loved it.
I spent the morning exactly how I wanted to ‚Äî sitting in a cozy caf√© with a book, watching the snow fall outside, taking my time.
Then I set out to explore Gamla Stan, Stockholm‚Äôs old town, and it felt like I had walked into a storybook. Narrow cobblestone streets, colorful buildings, charming shops ‚Äî everywhere I looked, it was picture-perfect. But it wasn‚Äôt just about how it looked. There was a feeling in Stockholm, something I couldn‚Äôt quite explain. It felt calm. It felt familiar. It felt like a place I could live.
Maybe that was because of the people. I blended in, surrounded by people who looked like me, people who moved through the world the way I did. And every time someone spoke to me in Swedish, assuming I understood, I had to awkwardly smile and nod before admitting I had no idea what they were saying. I would have killed to respond, even just a few words, instead of immediately exposing myself as an imposter in the land of my ancestors.
Still, even without the language, there were other ways to connect. Standing in the cold for the changing of the guard at the Royal Palace, I watched the ceremony unfold with zero feeling in my toes, but completely absorbed in the tradition of it all. Then, stepping inside the palace itself, I felt an entirely different kind of connection ‚Äî one rooted not in the present, but in history. I spent hours roaming the halls, reading every plaque, admiring every gorgeous room, tracing the lineage of Swedish royalty like I was piecing together a past I had never taken the time to learn.
And maybe that‚Äôs the best part of travel. Not just seeing new places, but finding new parts of yourself in them. I never thought I cared about my Swedish heritage beyond a fun fact, but suddenly, I wanted to know everything. Suddenly, I wanted to trace my roots.
And that‚Äôs how I know a place really meant something ‚Äî when it makes me want to keep learning.
After spending far too much money at Zara (I know, I know, I can shop at Zara anywhere, but its SWEDEN), I ended the day at the Avicii Experience before Paige arrived.
Walking through the exhibit, I found myself completely absorbed ‚Äî the music, the footage, the stories of his life. I already loved his music, but I had no idea how much he had shaped modern electronic sound, or how deeply he wrestled with the pressures of success and expectations. Or even that he had an interest in Buddhist teachings, something I‚Äôve recently been exploring myself. It was a side of him I had never known before, making his work feel even more personal, even more profound.
It‚Äôs weird, the things that connect us. How you can listen to someone‚Äôs music your whole life and only later realize how much you actually have in common. His song ‚ÄúThe Nights‚Äù will always be my favorite. Maybe because it‚Äôs the kind of song that makes you want to chase experiences, to say yes to things you never imagined yourself doing. It‚Äôs the song I hear in my mind every time I travel, the soundtrack to moments I want to remember forever. It‚Äôs even the song I edited my skydiving video to.
Of course, this moment of deep reflection ended with my phone dying, leaving me to wander Stockholm in the dark, hoping my Swedish instincts would kick in and guide me home. They did not. I eventually had to charge my phone at a hotel just to make it back.
By the time Paige arrived, she was exhausted, so we had a chill night, saving our energy for our very stressful plans the next day ‚Äî a three-hour spa session.
I am not someone who relaxes easily, or at all, but for once, I let myself. I sat in a heated outdoor pool overlooking Stockholm, rocked back and forth in a chair designed to make you feel like a baby, and finally felt all the tension from travel disappear.
We continued our day on a boat, freezing to death on an archipelago cruise, warming our hands with mulled wine. It was the kind of cold that gets into your bones, the kind that makes you feel alive. And right as I thought I couldn‚Äôt handle it anymore, it started snowing.
It was one of those rare travel moments where you stop thinking about how cold you are, stop worrying about your walk home, stop analyzing what‚Äôs next. You just sit there, frozen, watching the snow fall on the water, knowing that this is a moment you‚Äôll remember forever.
The weekend ended with a 6 AM RyanAir flight from hell, the kind of flight that makes you question if travel is ever worth it. But even through my exhaustion, all I could think about was how much I didn‚Äôt want to leave.
Sweden wasn‚Äôt just another trip. It wasn‚Äôt just a checklist of things to do. It was the first place I‚Äôve been in Europe ‚Äî outside of Barcelona ‚Äî where I could actually see myself living.
Maybe it was the snow. Maybe it was the city. Maybe it was the feeling of blending in, for once.
Or maybe it was the realization that travel isn‚Äôt just about discovering new places.
Sometimes, it‚Äôs about discovering where you already belong.

Title: Adapting to Life in Stockholm: Finding My Place in a New City
Content:

When I first set foot in Stockholm, everything felt new and exciting. The weather was nice, nature was abundant, and the quiet peacefulness of the city was a stark contrast to the bustling streets I was used to back in Singapore. Beneath the surface excitement of being in a new place, however, I found myself facing a mix of emotions ‚Äî there was excitement, of course, but also a fair amount of uncertainty and challenges.
For context, I am here in Stockholm as part of the NUS Overseas College (NOC) program, which is designed to expose us to internship and entrepreneurship experiences abroad while we take courses at partner universities. It‚Äôs an incredible opportunity, but it‚Äôs also been an experience that has challenged me in ways I didn‚Äôt anticipate ‚Äî pushing me out of my comfort zone. Now that I have been here for 3 months, I‚Äôve had time to reflect on these experiences.
Allow me to share some of my humble reflections and learnings ‚Äî about living more independently (and interdependently) as well as exploring both the professional and physical worlds around me.
Coming to a new city without my family meant that I had to settle all the domestic chores and cooking on my own. While I cooked a little back home in Singapore, those were more for fancy cooking, not weekly sustenance. Here in Stockholm, with the significantly higher food prices, my NOC batch mates and I quickly realized that cooking most of our meals was a necessity, not an option. To be able to meal prep, while making sure you are getting enough nutrition is a whole different ball game. Learning to manage my nutrition, cooking efficiently, and budgeting my time for groceries and meal prep was something I had to pick up quickly in the first month. While I wouldn‚Äôt say I fully enjoy my own cooking yet, I‚Äôm working on it! My friends have also inspired me to try out different recipes to keep things interesting, which has added a bit of excitement to the routine.
Thankfully, I did not have to navigate all of this on my own. My NOC batch mates and seniors were right there with me, sharing in the experience. Beyond helping each other with the practicalities of daily life, we‚Äôve built a network that has been incredibly supportive in navigating the professional world here as well. We often share information about tech and entrepreneurship events, upcoming hackathons, and professional opportunities. Each of us brings our own network, knowledge, and insights to the table, creating a combined support system that‚Äôs far more powerful than what any one of us could manage alone, and it‚Äôs something I‚Äôm deeply grateful for.
Aside from networking, there‚Äôs so much to learn from one another. No matter how skilled you are, there‚Äôs always someone with strengths in areas you‚Äôre still developing. Here, I‚Äôve learned to sharpen my business acumen and networking skills simply by observing how my friends navigate these spaces. It‚Äôs been inspiring, and I‚Äôm grateful for the chance to grow alongside such talented peers, reminding me that learning can come as much from our peers as from formal experiences
Reflecting on all of this, it‚Äôs the power of interdependence that has stood out to me most. I first encountered this idea in a book called 7 Habits of Highly Effective People, where interdependence is described as the strength of a team surpassing the sum of individual strengths. These past three months have shown me exactly how valuable interdependence can be, especially in a new environment. It‚Äôs been a humbling reminder that independence is not the end-all-be-all ‚Äî it‚Äôs often the connections we make and the support we share that truly help us thrive.
And of course, my intention in coming to NOC Stockholm was about more than just experiencing work in a local startup (My work is cool though maybe I will write about it in another post!). I wanted to dive into the entrepreneurial activities and atmosphere of the city, to learn by immersing myself in Stockholm‚Äôs dynamic ecosystem. Over the past few months, my batchmates and I have attended an array of events ‚Äî from networking sessions hosted by Stockholm School of Economics and KTH to hackathons like the Gradient Descent LLM Hackathon, as well as company visits and pitches to venture capitalists. Each event has opened up new perspectives, provided valuable insights, and left me with so much to process every week. It feels as though there‚Äôs always something exciting going on, and each experience leaves an imprint.
These experiences have stretched us in unexpected ways, pushing us beyond the daily tasks of our internships and exposing us to the broader world of innovation and entrepreneurship. Through this journey, I‚Äôve strengthened my ability to connect with others, navigate professional conversations, and approach new opportunities with confidence. The consistent exposure to industry professionals and diverse ideas has been invaluable in helping me develop both professionally and personally.
The hackathons and projects, in particular, have tested our limits, demanding not only technical creativity but also the resilience to tackle complex problems under pressure. I still vividly recall the night we stayed up until 7am, racing against time to complete a hackathon project, fueled by sheer determination and maybe a little too much caffeine. Each event has challenged us to think outside the box, to innovate, and to search for solutions to real-world challenges, often on tight timelines. We‚Äôve poured countless hours into brainstorming, coding, refining pitches, and collaborating, and while we‚Äôve sacrificed more than a few hours of sleep to make it all happen, I wouldn‚Äôt trade those experiences for anything.
Through these events, I‚Äôve come to realize that true learning often comes from stepping out of your comfort zone and engaging with the unknown. While we may not bring every idea to fruition, the lessons learned from each experience are worth every bit of effort we invested. The late nights, the excitement of each pitch, and the satisfaction of collaborating with passionate individuals are experiences that have shaped me in profound ways. It‚Äôs not just about the projects themselves, but about developing the resilience, adaptability, and drive that will stay with me long after this program ends.
This was my first time in Europe, and I know for a fact it won‚Äôt be my last. From the mountain ranges to the history-rich buildings, everything felt fresh and exciting, filling me with a childlike joy that I rarely experience. One moment that sticks with me is the time I went up a mountain in Salzburg. Standing at the summit, I looked out at the surrounding cities and mountain ranges, and my worries seemed to melt away. It was a perspective shift ‚Äî feeling like a tiny speck in the vastness of the world, realizing how small my day-to-day concerns truly are against such breathtaking beauty.
As a nature lover, these are the moments I live for, where I feel connected to something larger than myself. Being surrounded by such grandeur reminded me why I love being outdoors, immersed in landscapes that make me feel at peace.
As my friends often say, ‚ÄúWhen else will you be X years old and able to experience the beauty of Europe at a fraction of the cost of a flight from Singapore?‚Äù This really is a once-in-a-lifetime experience, and it‚Äôs opened my eyes in so many ways ‚Äî embracing spontaneity, appreciating the diversity of perspectives, and seeing the world with fresh wonder. Travelling through Europe has been about more than just sightseeing; it‚Äôs been a chance to rediscover a sense of awe and curiosity that reminds me to look at life with new eyes.
As I look back on the past few months, I realize how much the small, everyday responsibilities added up, especially on top of adapting to a new workplace and immersing myself in Stockholm‚Äôs unique culture. At first, I brushed off the cognitive load, thinking, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done more than this back in Singapore ‚Äî this is nothing.‚Äù But soon enough, the weight of these seemingly minor tasks started to accumulate, leaving me feeling mentally drained, wondering where all my time had gone. (I‚Äôm a huge anime fan, yet I went a record-breaking two months without watching any anime at all!)
Adjusting to a new environment is hard work, and it‚Äôs not just the big challenges that take a toll ‚Äî it‚Äôs the daily, unnoticed demands that quietly pile up. That is when I learned to make space for these ‚Äúsmall‚Äù tasks and, more importantly, to be kinder to myself instead of expecting to handle everything effortlessly. I can‚Äôt, and that‚Äôs okay.
It‚Äôs a lesson in self-compassion and balance ‚Äî one that I didn‚Äôt expect to be part of this journey but has become a key part of it. These experiences in Stockholm, both large and small, have taught me the importance of pacing myself, embracing support, and recognizing the power of both independence and interdependence in navigating life‚Äôs changes.
--

Historically rich, the dynamic Stockholm is the capital of Sweden. Founded in the 13th century, built over more than 14 islands connected by no less than 50-plus bridges, this fortified town is now an important trading center during the Hanseatic League and a critical player in the Great Northern War. The Industrial Revolution then managed to push this into even further growth, shaping the dynamic city we see today, where historical architecture meets modern design and sustainability.
Early one bright morning, I started my adventure, boarding the famous red tour bus with eagerness in my heart to see what Stockholm had in store for me. As we rolled down the cobblestone streets of Gamla Stan, its charming old town, the sun spilled gold upon the pastel-colored buildings and brought the history of the area to life. Each of these stops had a spell on me, with narrow alleys whispering stories of quaint cafes and shops that would call me to stop and smell the roses.
The bus then took us along the tranquil waters of the archipelago. I could perceive people sitting by the shores, fika-ing-a tradition of coffee and cake dear to the people. The chuckles and worldly gossips of families sitting in parks seemed to combine with unimaginably distant tunes of street musicians. It was as if Stockholm beckoned to me and filled my heart deep inside with a sense of acceptance.
Standing on top of the bus, the backdrops were truly striking: proud, ancient palaces stood among sleek, modern edifices, each monument telling its story. Lush greenery‚Ä¶

You know that moment when you glance at the clock, and it‚Äôs 11 PM, and you‚Äôre still hunched over your laptop?
Yeah, I didn‚Äôt think it would happen to me either!
I‚Äôd heard so many stories of burnout, tales of people overworking, but I thought, Not me. I love my job! I was managing exciting AI projects with brilliant teams, and every milestone felt exhilarating.
But suddenly, I found myself in the grips of what I can only describe as Stockholm Syndrome with Work.
It all started pretty innocently. I was leading a high-stakes AI project, and it was exciting. I was in charge of multiple teams, coordinating every detail, responsible for every success.
My team? Absolutely stellar. My manager? Supportive and genuinely invested in my growth.
The feedback? Glowing enough to light up a small city.
At first, I thought I was simply committed. My job was exciting, important, worth the extra hours. But, as anyone who‚Äôs fallen for Stockholm Syndrome with Work will tell you, it‚Äôs never obvious when it starts. It crept up on me until I couldn‚Äôt see where my work ended and I began.

Title: Unexpected Stockholm
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When I visited Stockholm for the first time, I had low expectations for my trip. It‚Äôs not Paris with the Eiffel Tower and Louvre, Florence with its great art and delectable cuisine or Athens where visitors can see living history around every corner.
The most I knew about it, except for the fact I had a friend who lived there, was that it had a museum dedicated to a pop band and another museum dedicated to a ship that sank during its maiden voyage. With so much of the world for me to explore, Stockholm wasn‚Äôt on the top of my check list.
I underestimated Stockholm. and this is why you should move Stockholm to the top of your travel ‚Äúto do‚Äù list too!
My husband and I decided to visit Stockholm to visit a friend from there who we met in the States several years before. Over the years we also met his brother, wife and children so by our first visit to Stockholm, we viewed them as our family.
We stayed in Gamla Stan, the old town. This is a beautiful cobblestone neighborhood on its own island. Stockholm is a city made up of many separate islands connected by bridges and ferries.
Stepping into Gamla Stan makes you feel like you took a step back in time. We stayed at a hotel called the Victory Hotel which is dedicated to Stockholm‚Äôs strong maritime heritage.
Our friend could not meet us until later in the evening on our first day so he directed us to a nearby restaurant that focused on Swedish cuisine. Although I watched some YouTube videos on the Stockholm food scene, I didn‚Äôt have high expectations for the city‚Äôs culinary offerings. Another mistake on my part.
This first meal was at a restaurant called Ardbeg Embassy. It felt very Nordic and like walking into someone‚Äôs home, so it was the perfect spot to start my Swedish adventure. We started with Toast Skagen, of course, which is essentially shrimp on toast. One bite and it was my new favorite appetizer. My husband had reindeer tenderloin and I had salmon with hollandaise sauce and potatoes. It all felt very Swedish and, after that meal, I decided I needed to dive into the city‚Äôs culinary scene more. In America, I can only get hollandaise sauce on top of poached eggs and in Sweden they put it on fish for dinner. When can I move?
Although some travel writers will disagree, when in Europe I always chose a hotel that offers breakfast in the morning. I love waking up to a breakfast buffet of fruit and charcuterie whenever I am in Europe. No matter which country I am visiting, I always know I am going to start my day with fruits, cheeses, meats, various juices, and, the best part, an automatic coffee machine which will make me a cappuccino, macchiato or espresso at the push of a button. I wish American hotels would jump on the European hotel breakfast bandwagon!
During day 2 in Stockholm, we decided to simply wander the city like tourists and then meet our friend later in the day to go to the ABBA Museum. The ABBA Museum was the one and only place that I did not want to miss. At the museum, I learned a lot about the band and its fascinating journey to stardom. We planned a low key day to save our energy for what we expected to be an epic night with our friends at a restaurant called Punk Royale.
Punk Royale‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthink Michelin quality fine dining but in a punk rock bar. My husband decided to go all in and showed up in an AC/DC shirt and black sunglasses. Since he has long hair, the outfit, which I thought was a gamble since this was a $300 per person restaurant, worked and he immediately received praise from the staff for showing up in costume.
The menu is a 20 course tasting menu and many courses were served with a different alcoholic beverage. The food is innovative and the atmosphere is lively and immersive. It was one of the most interesting and fabulous meals I have had.
After our wonderful meal at Punk Royale, we found ourselves at a ‚Äúshot‚Äù bar called Shotluckan. I have never experienced anything like it, which appeared to be the trend for the evening. When a shot was served, it was an interactive experience. For our first shot, my husband and I found ourselves in a wedding ceremony with the bartender acting as the wedding officiant. Apparently, we even received a marriage license, which I promptly lost. For our second shot, we were instructed to put on ski goggles and compressed air was blown in our faces while we did the shot.
Needless to say, we lost the entire next day as we recovered from a Swedish night on the town. We used this development as an excuse to extend our stay one extra day. This city was so much better than I expected.
Because Stockholm is made up of many islands, ferries are part of the public transportation system. Once we recovered from our night on the town, we decided to try the ferry system to travel to an island called Fj√§derholmarna for the day for a scenic ride through the archipelago and to have lunch. When we arrived on the island, I immediately felt like I was transported to seaside Maine with the forest meeting the sea and red wooden buildings dotting the coastline. We ate oysters and drank champagne and ordered more Toast Skagen while watching boaters enjoying the beautiful weather.
A visit to Stockholm would not be complete without enjoying Fika which is not a snack per s√©, but a tradition of taking a break during the day to have a coffee with a baked good. The Swedes know how to make bakery items! The cinnamon rolls were delectable everywhere we went.
As our long weekend in Stockholm progressed, we became very comfortable using the public transportation system throughout the city. It was fairly easy and all done through an app on our phones. We did not have time to explore the art installations that can be found in many stations, but we intend to do that on our next visit. We never felt unsafe, but of course we remained cautious at all times.
When traveling to Stockholm, visitors should not miss the Vasa Museum. Before going to the museum, I could not understand why a museum that glorified a ship which immediately sank during its maiden voyage was a must do, but then we went. The Vasa is a preserved 17th-century warship with 98% of the original structure intact. It sank during its first voyage because it was simply too heavy to float. It was salvaged after over 300 years underwater fully preserved in the brackish water and offers a rare, time-capsule view into naval architecture and craftsmanship of the early 1600s.
My first trip to Stockholm was unexpectedly amazing and I am so glad we went. Stockholm rewards curiosity at every turn. It‚Äôs a place where history and innovation quietly collide. Venture beyond the expected, and you‚Äôll find Stockholm is a layered and intriguing city just as I did!
.

Content:

Me and my wife were fortunate to became parents in 2019 with a baby girl. At the time we were living in California and I worked at Google as a Software Engineer. While enjoying free lunches at Google with collegues we talked about various topics. Sometimes about social problems, hobbies old Google stories from veteran Googlers and rarely technical topics. One day it was a story about Finland and how they send a box of things for new born babies and parents buy nothing but diapers during the first year. This has been a tradition in Finland for 75 years. He happened to read about this in a book called Nordic theory of everything.
As a new parent I was interested in reading this book and fascinated about the culture in nordic countries and their approach to life. Following this book I read a couple of more books like The Almost Nearly Perfect People, There‚Äôs no such thing as bad weather. Of course I read hundreds of Quoara posts and watched tens of youtube videos about nordic countries. I was convinced that the Nordics have a very interesting thing going on in their countries. I was intrigued by the childcare and the freedom kids were given in their childhood. Playing outside all day long, spending time in the forest, less home work and less ranking and competition. Occasionally I asked myself should we also move to one of these countries ? I felt that it would be an interesting thing to do but part of me was convinced that They have a great culture but it is probably great for the natives but not for the foreigners who move there. Would this really work out well for a brown kid, let alone her parents who were born and raised in a tropical country.
My life continued with reading here and there about the nordic culture but nothing serious happened. Then the pandemic hit and we were stuck in our newly bought house in California. Not having to spend a lot of time for commute, I finally got some time to think. Like so many other people who made life changing decisions during the pandemic, I thought this would be a good time to move to one of the Nordic countries. It is a bold thing to do but interesting. As a person who gets bored of things easily and person who likes excitement, this felt good.
On the other hand my wife was not very interested in this move. After struggling to save money for 5 years we finally bought our own home and lived there for only a couple of months. Everything was finally stable and she wanted to relax in our new home with our newborn. She is a person who can be satisfied with a very little. She is not a person who would think too much into the future. Sometime I envy her approach to life where her highest priority is to be happy with her family and live a calm peaceful life. While me reading a lot about macro social economic problems, Climate change and how they affect us and affect my child‚Äôs upbringing. May be this a good blend for a more sustainable longterm family life.
Somehow I managed to convince her that it was the right thing to do given it is important for Surali to spend her early days in the best environment. Also I convinced her it will be very interesting for her to find work in a nordic country where our salary difference will be a lot less than what we have now.
I boldly applied for a job within Google and requested for a transfer. My transfer was accepted and I was given an excellent relocation package to move to Sweden. We gave our house keys to the real estate agent, sold our car, said good bye to our close friends and left San Francisco. I am good at saying good bye to old places, either because I have less attachments to them or I am too much focus on the future and the next step. I did not regret it when I left my hometown Galle(2010), Sri Lanka(2011), Indiana (2015) or when we left USA to Sweden(2020). I am sure one day I will leave Sweden without much regret. Hard thing with the every move was leaving behind the friends and family. I still keep in touch with friends and family from each place.
Retired person picked up my car, bought it for 22,000$ and sold it for 12,000$ after 5 years of use. This was a mistake, I should have donated this car to our buddhist temple.
We arrived at SFO and the airport was almost empty and we had our flight to Europe and there were a couple of people in the flight and the crew had little to no work to do because the flight was empty. I doubt we would ever have a long haul flight like this.
In 2020 October (Fall in Sweden) we arrived in Arlanda airport and I was visiting Europe after many years (In 2009 I visited Amsterdam while I was studying in college). Arlanda airport is located middle of no where, it almost felt like landing in a forest. From the sky there weren‚Äôt any buildings visible, no perfectly created neighbourhoods lines visible from the sky, no roads spanning all possible directions, and we spotted a massive archipelago with thousands of islands.
We picked up our bags and prepared our documents ready to answer all the questions from the border control and continued to walk towards customs. If you travelled to the US you would know how the drill goes. We were pushing our carts with lots of bags and walking towards the exit and nobody asked a single question and a bunch of police officers gave us a slight smile (later I got to know that this is called Swedish look) and that was it. This is not because Sweden doesn‚Äôt have a border control but we flew through Netherlands and all the border check was done there and nothing was required at the Swedish border. But my thought was Hey, we are moving to Sweden for the first time, don‚Äôt you want to cross check us, check our papers, check our bags, what if we bring something harmful to the agriculture.
We have booked an apartment in the east of Stockholm (√ñstermalm) and my new manager at Google told me that this area is one of the nicest places in Stockholm, so I had lots of expectations. I expected to see perfectly manicured plants with lots of flowers by the streets, nicely cut grass everywhere and skyscrapers. But it wasn‚Äôt the case, to me it felt like an average neighbourhood in San Francisco but with lots of greenary. I noticed the huge park right in front of our hotel with a forest skyline. Now I know that in Sweden beauty kept at it‚Äôs natural state compared to the extreme human intervention in America. √ñstermalm has it‚Äôs own beauty with the water close by and forest and lots of walking paths. If I have the money, √ñstermalm would be one of my favourite areas I‚Äôd like to live. Now I get what my manager meant when he said it‚Äôs one of the best places in Sweden.
We moved to our apartment and it was a nice spacious apartment at the top floor and I noticed the high quality of construction inside the apartment compared to our old place in the US. Wooden floors, high-end kitchen equipments and the lovely view of Stockholm through the kitchen window. Same night I stepped out of the balcony and saw something I haven‚Äôt seen for a long time. I saw the man wearing a suite and waiting for the bus with bags full of groceries. This is not a common scene in America where people always drive for groceries and put them in the trunk and drive back home. This is one of the moments that I felt, oh my god, things are really different here and it is real. After seeing the grocery man I thought there must be a store close by and then I figured it is actually in the same building ground floor. How convenience is that ? You simply have to take the elevator down and you are at the store.
When I think about our move now, it was definitely a bold move, I should have done many things before moving here. I should have come for a short visit, but I couldn‚Äôt because it was in the middle of the COVID19 pandemic. I should have waited a few more years so I would save more with less taxes in the US, but then my kid wouldn‚Äôt have the great experience in Swedish preschool system. But all in all we are doing fine in Sweden now. Sometimes bold moves might bring you the greatest experiences in life. When we moved here we lived alone and barely knew anyone except one family whom we couldn‚Äôt meet for a couple of months due to pandemic rules. But what kept me going was not to over think and stay positive. I‚Äôm pretty sure lots of my friends and family questioned our decision to move to Sweden, but I still believe it gave us a different perspective to our life. It of course didn‚Äôt improve all aspects of our lives but it improved the things we value the most as a family.
Now after 3 years from our move I‚Äôm writing this article in my room in our apartment in Stockholm. We live 5km from the central Stockholm close to a small forest with 15km of bike/running paths. Since the move I have changed a lot as a person and I think I have a more balanced life than ever before. I no longer work for Google, a few weeks ago I joined a small startup with ten engineers.
After living in Sweden for 3 years, I think it is a good time to write about our experience here in the nordics. I will be writing more articles about Sweden and our life in the nordics.

Follow up with the part 1 about 10 things I love about Stockholm, here are five more things that I love about Stockholm:
As I arrived in Stockholm, carrying my luggage through the city‚Äôs bustling streets to my rental apartment, I couldn‚Äôt help but notice something remarkable ‚Äî every time I approached a crosswalk, the cars would stop and the drivers would kindly wave me across. It was a small gesture, but it made a big impression on me.
As I settled into my apartment, I quickly realized that this was just the beginning of Stockholm‚Äôs pedestrian-friendly culture. The city‚Äôs well-designed streets and sidewalks made it easy and enjoyable to explore on foot, with plenty of green spaces and parks to relax in along the way.
But it wasn‚Äôt just walking that was a breeze in Stockholm ‚Äî cycling was also a popular and efficient mode of transportation. The city‚Äôs network of bike lanes and paths were well-marked and separated from motorized traffic, making it safe and convenient to pedal my way around.
Exploring Stockholm‚Äôs inner city doesn‚Äôt require a car, thanks to the city‚Äôs efficient and convenient public transportation system. From buses to trams, trains, and the famous Stockholm Metro, there are plenty of options for getting around. During the summer months, ferries are also available to take you across the city‚Äôs waterways. With well-placed stations throughout the city and frequent services, navigating Stockholm is a breeze. The system is easy to use, with clear signage and ticket machines that accept both cash and card payments.
Plus, there‚Äôs even a mobile app called SL to help guide your travel, check schedules for different transportation options, and purchase tickets on-the-go. Say goodbye to traffic and hello to stress-free exploration in Stockholm with their convenient public transportation system.
You might be surprised to learn that one of the most convenient and innovative features of the country is its BankID system.
BankID is a digital identification system that allows Swedes to securely access a range of online services, from banking and government services to shopping and entertainment. You can use BankID to login your bank accounts, verify transaction, login Skatteverket (Swedish Tax Agency) to check your tax payment, login 1177.se (Swedish Health and Care) to book doctor appointment, login Pensionsmyndigheten (Pension Authority),‚Ä¶
In order to obtain a BankID, you must have a Swedish Personal Identity Number, be a customer of one of the banks that issue BankID. With BankID, I was able to quickly and securely authenticate my identity, without the need for clunky passwords or authentication codes. It made the process fast and hassle-free, and I never had to worry about my personal information being compromised.
Since I moved to Stockholm, I don‚Äôt use cash anymore. There are tons of benefits of that.
Firstly, I don‚Äôt need to carry around pockets full of coins and notes, worrying about losing or misplacing them.
Secondly, I also don‚Äôt need to worry about fraudster that use counterfeit money in the black market or worry about pickpocket.
Lastly, it is more convenient to control my personal finance with all the transactions are recorded in the bank account, categorise my activities so I don‚Äôt need to write down my transaction anymore.
Instead, I can pay using credit/debit card, or pay via my mobile using Apple pay, or I can may via Swish (mobile instant payment).
One of the most striking things about Stockholm, as a foreigner living here, is the locals‚Äô fluency and friendliness in speaking English. From restaurant servers to shopkeepers, bus drivers, and security guards, nearly everyone seems to be bilingual. This ease of communication makes getting around and making connections in Stockholm an absolute breeze, and I always feel welcomed and at home here. I‚Äôve had some truly delightful conversations with locals who were eager to practice their English skills and share their insights into Swedish culture and traditions. The friendly and fluent locals truly embody Sweden‚Äôs welcoming and inclusive spirit.
Of course, I still made an effort to learn some basic Swedish phrases and customs, out of respect for the country and its people. I appreciate how the city‚Äôs bilingualism has made my life in Stockholm stress-free and enjoyable.
I have travelled to several cities in the world, but in the end, Stockholm is and will be the city I would choose to settle long term. Whether you‚Äôre interested in history, culture, or simply enjoying the outdoors, this city has it all. With its efficient public transportation system and welcoming atmosphere, Stockholm is a perfect destination for travelers looking to explore Scandinavia? You‚Äôre sure to fall in love with Stockholm, just like I do.

Content:

Today wraps my last day in Stockholm, Sweden ‚Äî The middle leg of my scandinavian holiday that I‚Äôm taking while on sabbatical. Stockholm has been great, with loads of museums, picturesque walks and today we had some snow!
I can‚Äôt help but compare Stockholm to Croydon in the UK. When we arrived at Stockholm Central station from the Airport we walked to outside √Öhl√©ns where we got the tram to the area that our hotel is based. If I replaced √Öhl√©ns with Allders then I‚Äôm basically talking about Croydon so it‚Äôs been hard to move away from that framing.
What‚Äôs also made it hard to not compare Stockholm to Croydon has been the people, who from my eight days of being here are just as rude, although not as loud as people from London (although Croydon being in London is something some will debate).
Compared to Copenhagen there‚Äôs a lot more cars and less bikes on the road in Stockholm but that‚Äôs a little more understandable due to how cold it gets here. Public transport wise it‚Äôs similar with the addition of the tram, the trains here I would say have better signage than those in Denmark with a screen showing the next 4 stops which was useful for when we headed out of the city centre.
Our first full day in Stockholm was on a Sunday so we stayed local as things were closing early and we had a lay in to sleep off getting up early to make our flight the day before. Luckily the Vasa Museum was right by our hotel so we had a wander over there and was blown away at the scale of both the ship and the craftmanship that was put into it.
On Monday we took a stroll around Stockholm‚Äôs old town (Gamla Stan) and found a really cool comic / gaming shop which had some cool D&D displays.
On Tuesday we went to Skansen which for me has been the highlight of my time in Stockholm. It‚Äôs an amazing open air museum and zoo which had a really cool mix of crafting workshops, gardens and animals. The enclosures in the zoo were massive so I was really happy to see the animals not being closed in like in some zoos, there was also a really fun monkey area you could walk through with them running around.
On Wednesday I dragged my other-half to Skogskyrkog√•rden, a cemetry about 25 mins outside of Stockholm that was used for a picture in the liner notes (remember those) of Entombed‚Äôs Left Hand Path. Being a massive Death Metal fan I had to go see the cross there and get a picture.
On Thursday we had a boat tour of the Stockholm Archipelago booked so we went aboard and enjoyed a two and a half journey to Vaxholm and back while taking in the sites. It was around this time that the temperature dropped and I came to realise how my Barbour Ashby jacket works well for UK winters but nordic winters would require an extra layer so I decided to go buy a liner for the jacket which has proved worthwhile.
Friday saw a trip to the Toy Museum but I was a little disappointed in it. There were a few cool displays but there was nothing that really told the story of how toys changed over the years and more just collections of toys with similar properties (like cars, planes etc). I think they could have improved it by showing the evolution of toys from wooden to plastic to electronic and how the business behind toys changed too (like the 80s tie-in TV show boom).
Today (Saturday) it snowed so instead of going to see anything in particular we had a walk around some of the area in the snow as the UK doesn‚Äôt get snow in the same sense so the novelty was still there.

Title: Solo Traveling in Stockholm
Content:

Ever since I relocated to Amsterdam, solo traveling has been one of my preferred activities. This enables me to have some personal time to ponder on life and also puts me in a vulnerable scenario that encourages me to explore the world alone while making new acquaintances in an unfamiliar city. Following the semester‚Äôs conclusion, I opted to travel to Stockholm, Sweden, and embark on a 3-day expedition.
Coming along with me is my Fuji film camera loaded with a Fuji 200 film roll, a non-fiction book, my journal with a cover featuring Amsterdam houses, a black pen and highlighters from MUJI, a carry-on containing a makeup bag, and overly-packed clothes (because it‚Äôs important to look stylish while traveling, don‚Äôt you agree?), and an open-minded attitude.
Naturally, my journey began with a mad dash to the bus station in order to catch the final bus to Schipol Airport for my early flight, as is typically the case. Rushing is never enjoyable, but ironically, I feel an added sense of excitement whenever I commence my travels in this manner.
To kill the waiting time before boarding on Boeing 737‚Äì800, I chose a perfect seat with a good view, put my headphone on with my travel playlist playing in the background, and waited for some interesting airport romance incidents to happen (this is part of the reason that I love flying alone). Luckily enough, early July is the peak season for all the (hot) Dutchies gathering in the airport, wearing those linen shirts, paired with shorts and light-coloured sneakers to get ready for their holidays in southern Europe.
After landing at Stockholm Arlanda Airport, the first thought that came up to my mind was, Wow! I‚Äôm in freaking Stockholm!! I‚Äôm so ready for this city!!
Without even realizing it, I found myself standing in front of Caf√© Pascal, eager to indulge in my daily dose of caffeine and Swedish pastry as my first meal in Stockholm. Situated near Odenplan and Observatorielunden, the caf√© offers a warm and inviting interior design, along with a stunning terrace. In addition to a wide selection of coffee, there are also plenty of sandwiches and Swedish pastries to choose from.
As Gamla Stan was introduced on the travel website, visitstockholm.com,
Gamla Stan, the Old Town in Swedish, is one of the largest and best-preserved medieval city centers in Europe, and one of the foremost attractions in Stockholm. This is where Stockholm was founded in 1252.
As I strolled through Gamla Stan, I couldn‚Äôt help but be captivated by the narrow winding cobblestone streets and charming houses, each with their unique character. I kept my film camera at the ready, eager to capture the beauty of this old town and the occasional glimpses of the harbour view that peeked out between the alleys. It was heartwarming to see elderly couples walking hand-in-hand down the street.
Amidst the steady influx of sightseers, the quaint streets and souvenir emporiums brimmed with activity. Yet, I derived solace from the tranquility and geniality of the medieval city center. Instead of hastening to snap up iconic photographs at tourist landmarks, I relish taking in the sights, sounds, and scents of the city‚Äôs breathtaking scenery. Additionally, I take pleasure in engaging in conversations with shop proprietors to glean more insights into the region‚Äôs rich history and vibrant local customs.
When I was dining at Fika & Wine, I inquired about the meaning of Fika culture from one of the baristas in Fika & Wine.
‚ÄúFika is one of those words that can be difficult to translate. Essentially, it means enjoying coffee, tea, wine, and Swedish sweets with nice company. The best part? You can have as many Fikas as you want in a day!‚Äù she said.
Fika is a Swedish tradition that encourages slowing down and savoring the moment. As a coffee enthusiast, I couldn‚Äôt resist embracing this wonderful culture.
During my visit to Stockholm, I made it a point to fully immerse myself in the Swedish lifestyle by partaking in the delightful tradition of Fika time twice a day. I was fortunate enough to discover a charming little spot in the S√∂dermalm neighborhood called Drop Coffee Roasters, which quickly became my go-to destination for this delightful pastime. The ambiance was cozy and inviting, with an airy and bright interior that exuded warmth and comfort.
As for my Fika order, I opted for a cappuccino made with creamy oat milk, which was simply divine. The coffee was expertly brewed and had a rich and robust flavour that perfectly complemented the sweetness of the pastries. Speaking of which, I indulged in two of the most popular Fika treats, the classic Kanelbulle, which is a hall-of-fame pastry in Sweden, and the delectable Chokladbollar, a chocolatey treat that was simply irresistible.
Overall, my Fika experience at Drop Coffee Roasters was nothing short of exceptional. The baristas were friendly and willing to share their favorite cafes. I highly suggest this spot for visitors to Stockholm who desire to immerse themselves in authentic Fika culture while enjoying some of the best coffee and pastries in town.
Since returning from my trip to K√∏benhavn in late April, journaling has become one of my favorite hygge rituals. Initially, I began journaling as a private outlet to express my thoughts and romanticize life amidst the intensity of my studies. However, it has since evolved into a unique way of documenting the little moments that occur during each trip.
During my stay in Stockholm, I made it a point to take a leisurely walk during the golden hour. Starting from Kungstr√§dg√•rden, I would traverse the path that led me through the picturesque Skeppsholmsbron, and eventually arrive at Kastellholmen. Once there, I would find a cozy bench to sit on, gazing out at either the charming Gamla Stan and S√∂dermalm or the enchanting Djurg√•rden. The gentle breeze would caress my skin, evoking a myriad of emotions that would stir within me, bringing back fond memories of the past and inspiring hope for a bright future. It served as a wonderful reminder to appreciate and cherish the present moment.
‚Äú ‚Ä¶ tomorrow will be the last day of this solo travel journey in Stockholm. I asked myself how was I feeling earlier today. To be completely honest, I‚Äôm not so sure and life has been quite choatic in the past few weeks. So, I would say it‚Äôs like a mix of all kinds of emotions, it‚Äôs difficult to articulate, but mostly relief ‚Ä¶‚Äù as it was written in my journal.
This journey ended with the style of experiencing my very first airport romance while waiting for my flight back to Amsterdam. This unexpected romance occurred at the Stockholm Arlanda Airport and involved a charming Swede who was en route to Florence via Amsterdam and a Taiwanese girl who was headed back to Amsterdam.
It was the perfect finale for my solo travel journey in Stockholm.
As I reflect on my solo travel escapade in Stockholm, my heart swells with gratitude and a profound sense of fulfillment. This journey wasn‚Äôt merely a series of adventures, but a soul-enriching odyssey that allowed me to establish a profound connection with myself and the world around me.
Each and every second of my journey, starting from boarding that early morning flight to setting foot in the captivating Gamla Stan, left a deep imprint on my soul. The sheer pleasure of strolling through the winding cobblestone streets and capturing the city's exquisite charm with my faithful Fuji film camera was indescribable. However, it was the small yet significant conversations with the amiable locals and fellow voyagers that truly added a unique and meaningful touch to this unforgettable trip.
Discovering the Swedish Fika culture was a revelation. Slowing down, savoring coffee, pastries, and moments with lovely company ‚Äî what a beautiful way to appreciate life‚Äôs simple pleasures! Drop Coffee Roasters became my haven, where the aroma of expertly brewed coffee mingled with the warmth of human connection. For a coffee lover like me, in particular, Fika time enriched this entire journey with an extra touch!!
While journaling during the golden hours became a cherished ritual. Pouring my thoughts onto paper, I found solace amidst life‚Äôs challenges. The picturesque spots in Stockholm became the backdrop for my reflections, reminding me to cherish the present and embrace the beauty of each moment.
And then, there was the unexpected airport romance ‚Äî a serendipitous encounter that reminded me of the magic of travel. A charming Swede and a Taiwanese girl crossing paths in Stockholm ‚Äî it was a heartwarming finale to my adventure, leaving me with a newfound appreciation for human connections that transcend borders.
As I bid farewell to Stockholm, I carry with me a treasure trove of memories, insights, and newfound friendships. This solo journey has reaffirmed my belief in the transformative power of travel ‚Äî the way it opens our hearts and minds to the world‚Äôs diversity and beauty.
Now, back in Amsterdam, I‚Äôll continue to cherish my Amsterdam house-covered journal, eager to document my reflections and plan future escapades.
Solo travel has become a soul-enriching way of life for me ‚Äî one that fosters curiosity, self-discovery, and the courage to embrace the unknown. May we continue to explore this beautiful world with a spirit of wonder and compassion.
Until our paths cross again, dear Stockholm, I will hold you close in my heart. And as I eagerly await my next adventure, I‚Äôll keep my mind and heart open to the wonders that lie ahead.

Title: Stockholm Symmetry
Content:
Sign up

Sign up

Share
The first time I came to Stockholm, things weren‚Äôt going well. Back home I‚Äôd been following all the rules, but the expression ‚Äúmy life is passing me by‚Äù was talking about me. Pushed from the complacency of obedience, I bought a one-way ticket to Europe. I started in Germany but didn‚Äôt know what to do and felt like I was messing everything up, so I took the overnight train to Copenhagen, where I didn‚Äôt know what to do and felt like I was messing everything up, so I took the overnight train to Stockholm, where I walked to a couple hostels and found them all full.
‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt you know you need to book ahead during this season?‚Äù the man asked me.
‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I could have answered. ‚ÄúBecause I don‚Äôt know what to do and am messing everything up.‚Äù
Embarrassed and overwhelmed, I walked on into the cold light of an October dawn and found a little park. An old lady was walking her shivering dog. Puppy and I looked at each other in mirrored misery. Giving up, going away, I walked to the harbor and caught the overnight boat to Estonia.
The very next day an egg hatched and the travel bug that crawled out bit me so hard I must have bitten it back. From there my life took an unexpected path that felt better than anything before it, though it took some years to notice. Today that path has me back in Stockholm to lead another tour of the job I love. Every time I come back to this city (any city) I enjoy getting to know it better, but I never considered that park, held in my memory but lost to a long-ago lack of a map, much less a clue.
Until tonight, meandering home to the hotel, when I crossed a little park and felt the shock of recognition in the soft summer air. I sat on the bench where I rested my overloaded pack those many years ago, and marveled at all of it. An old lady was walking a dog. Puppy and I looked at each other with mirrored playful joy.
Travel has always taken me forward, in more ways than one, and I applaud the universe with great claps of gratitude. But travel is not an accomplishment. It‚Äôs just something you do if it‚Äôs right for you. I smile the insider smile with any of you who already know that.
Now, questions of privilege demand answers, the zeitgeist of our age. But I think a lot of people are too convinced by the burdensome ‚Äúyou can‚Äôt travel now, you have to work work work.‚Äù And it has to be said that human beings are good at staying within our comfort zones, to our own detriment.
Do you know anyone who needs a little push? Perhaps someone snug in the complacency of obedience, for whom the sound of that stamp landing in their passport will forever after echo as the starting pistol to run into a fuller experience of life? Is it you?
That pistol sounded for me, and looking back at it from that park bench, 16 years into my marathon, I am so glad it did. Nice to see you again, Stockholm.

Title: Stockholm City Hall
Content:
Sign up

Sign up

I could see Stockholm‚Äôs famous city hall and tower across Riddarfj√§rden bay from my island of Gamla Stan. Completed in 1923, the complex is famous for hosting Sweden‚Äôs Nobel Prize banquet each year in December.
Tours were provided in English on the hour so I hiked across the Centralbron (central bridge) and joined a small group headed inside. The building was still the working hub of Stockholm municipal services so the only way to experience the interior was through the tour (pretty sure I‚Äôm not going to win a Nobel Prize any time soon).
We walked through the Blue Hall where the Nobel Prize banquet is held for 1,300 guests including that year‚Äôs winners, their invites (each winner gets 15), the Swedish Royal family and Sweden‚Äôs Prime Minister.
The Nobel Foundation awards prizes in the fields of Physics, Chemistry, Physiology/Medicine, Literature and, most famously, Peace as depicted below. Can you guess which figure represents which award?
I appreciated many of the Swedish historical details within the building but there were many I didn‚Äôt quite grasp. Unfortunately the tour moved quickly so I could only snap a few pics and plan on researching later.
I especially liked the R√•dsalen where the city council worked. The architect back in the 1920s had planned for a formal ceiling but when he saw the exposed wooden beams during construction, he changed course and capped the chamber in a striking Viking theme:
The most impressive room was aptly named the Golden Hall. Eighteen million gilded tiles covered the walls and formed mosaics depicting Swedish history. There were plenty of Vikings, medieval characters and creatures from Nordic lore. It was interesting that secular and not religious themes were expressed.
The centerpiece was a massive mosaic covering the back wall dominated by a seated woman. She represented the city of Stockholm with the region‚Äôs midnight sun above her head and waters at her feet.
Stockholm is depicted at the center of the earth with the western world on one side and the eastern world on the other. You could see how 1920s Swedes idealized America complete with skyscrapers, the Statue of Liberty, the Stars and Stripes, Native Americans and the White Star Line:
The weather had improved dramatically from the blustery conditions yesterday so I took the opportunity to explore more of the city. Many Stockholmers evidently had the same idea and were out walking, ice skating and enjoying their traditional Fika.
Hiking back toward Gamla Stan, I passed Sweden‚Äôs Parliament building, the Riksdag, guarded by Egyptian lions. Traditionally-neutral Sweden is a member of the EU but chose against using the Euro. However, I probably won‚Äôt touch any Swedish kronor since this is basically a cashless society. You use your card everywhere, even for a coffee.
‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.
Thanks for coming along on the trip. If you have questions or suggestions, tweet @JasonRMatheson. Missed an entry? Click here.
