Title: What to Do in Stockholm, Sweden (According to an Italian, U.S. American, Dane and Some Swedes)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Most Italians head to the stunning seaside for their summer vacations, but we were looking to add not shed layers, so we headed north to the land of cinnamon buns and paternity leave. Hej, Sweden!
In the weeks leading up to our trip, it appeared we might not get the cool breezes and leg-shaving respite that were so desired. Perhaps due to that #FakeNews climate change conspiracy, Sweden had its hottest July in at least 260 years. Wildfires were raging, stores sold out of fans (we had multiple Stockholmers tell us of the Great Fan Sell Out of 2018), and farmers struggled to feed their animals.
This seems especially unfair to people like the Swedes who are notoriously eco-conscious. Our Airbnb hosts said the country actually ran out of trash at one point and had to purchase foreign rubbish to continue heating homes.
Then, the day after we arrived, we were grateful to be shivering in a downpour and inhaling that fresh Nordic air of 65‚Äì75 F (18‚Äì24 C) throughout the week. So, putting aside worries about our planet for a moment, here are a few tips from our week-long Swedish vacay, should you pop over there one day or merely wish to have some mild distraction until your toothbrush vibrates at the two-minute mark.
Watch Welcome to Sweden, an unjustly cancelled TV series that features cross-cultural misunderstandings, family drama, expat shenanigans, and transatlantic love ‚Äî gee, I wonder why we connected with it. Bonus: guest appearances by Amy Poehler, Aubrey Plaza and Will Ferrell.
On this trip, four years after watching the series and one day after re-watching it, we see one of the actors get off at our bus stop in Stockholm. I am starstruck and briefly consider shouting, ‚ÄúBirger! Welcome to Sweden!‚Äù But I can only squeeze Alberto‚Äôs arm and breathlessly say, ‚ÄúOh my god, guarda, guarda,‚Äù and then Alberto‚Äôs eyes bulge, too. I turn into a paparazzo and take pictures of him as he walks away. Thank you, Claes M√•nsson, for being a literal one in a million Stockholm encounter.
I did some more digging after we got home and found that Swedish fathers indeed have the highest use of parental leave in the world and that in 1974 Sweden became ‚Äúthe first welfare democracy to introduce paid parental leave (f√∂r√§ldraledighet) to both parents. This law signals that fathers should take greater responsibility in caring for their young children, that children possess the right to have access to both their parents, and that fathers should facilitate mothers‚Äô return to and involvement in paid work after having a child.‚Äù Read this Slate article to swoon (and bemoan your own country) some more: Americans Love Seeing Swedish Dads Out With Their Kids (ICYMI blog post: Motherhood from Italy to Taiwan
We stayed in an impeccably styled and clean Airbnb just south of the city center in Gamla Enskede and about a 10 minute walk to the subway. It‚Äôs located in a residential area across the street from a park and has some nice restaurants nearby with no English menus ‚Äî which means you‚Äôre unlikely to be in a tourist trap but the very kind server will have to read everything off to you lest you spend 15 minutes in Google Translate before deciding you actually don‚Äôt want to eat there at all. #Awkward
We walked or took public transportation (subway, tram, bus, boat) everywhere. Public transit was very clean, reliable and convenient; a week pass is about 30 euros. It would have been cheaper and more ambitious of us to rent bikes, as recommended by many people, but the combination of rain, laziness and cinnamon buns was a deterrent.
We did three free Stockholm walking tours ‚Äî Stockholm City, Gamla Stan (Old Town) and Stockholm Subway Art, and they were a great way to get acquainted with the city as well as learn more about Swedish history and culture. Tips are encouraged (in any currency) at the end of the tour.
Pro tip: Don‚Äôt withdraw any cash in the local Swedish Krona (SEK). Stockholm is on its way to going cash-free and some places will only accept cards anyway.
As mentioned above, Stockholm‚Äôs subway system is an art gallery in itself. You can go with a tour group (here‚Äôs the offical SL tour; we did a different one) to see a few of the hot spot stations and get a brief explanation, or you can go admire them on your own. Our tour guide suggested the following stations but 90+ of them have artwork, so you‚Äôre bound to run into a few even accidentally:
Blue line
Green line
Red line
Our guide said the art was commissioned as a way to lure apprehensive Swedes underground (post World War II) to use this new, potentially dangerous form of transportation. I later read on several sites that this underground exhibition was the result of a political and cultural movement in the late 1950s to make art more accessible to your average citizen and not just the Swedish elite. The official SL site notes the following motivations: beauty, safety, station identity/navigation, and vandalism reduction. Whatever the reasoning for bringing more art into the world‚Ä¶
It‚Äôs the same old story: a guy wanted to prove he had bigger balls than another guy ‚Äî and then his hastily constructed warship sank on its maiden voyage; King Gustav just had to wave his mast in the air. Now, you and I can go gape at a massive 17th century ship that was underwater for 333 years.
Pro tip: Dress in layers. It seems sub-zero temps are necessary to preserve the artifact.
This was an interesting, well-designed photography museum and a perfect place to spend a rainy afternoon. It also has a nice cafe/restaurant upstairs with a great view of the city.
Since this royal castle from the 1600s is the king and queen‚Äôs permanent residence, they don‚Äôt grant you full access, making the interior visit shorter than expected, but it‚Äôs beautiful and the palace gardens and Chinese Pavilion are a peaceful place to amble around or have a picnic.
It was free, there were very few tourists, and the woman who founded it was doing things that a woman of her time was not supposed to do, because it interfered with duties like embroidery and shutting up. So obviously, I liked it. Or, as the museum put it, ‚ÄúAmong women during the 1890s, Wilhelmina was quite alone in her pursuits, and she walked a fine line of what was considered appropriate for a woman of her station to devote her time to.‚Äù Cheers, Wilhelmina von Hallwyl.
Famous for being the venue of the Nobel Prize banquet plus for its grand ceremonial halls and artwork (the gold mosaic room was my favorite), the City Hall offers tours (mandatory) in several languages. It‚Äôs a popular place to get married and has a six-month waiting list; supposedly Swedes can choose between the short (two-minute) or long (four-minute) ceremony.
I was hoping to learn more about Nordic culture and history but the exhibits failed to engage us (or maybe we were coming down from a sugar high). Like, I couldn‚Äôt look at one more antique Swedish chair; I have been to IKEA five times this year already. It was interesting to learn about the Sami in Sweden, an indigenous people who have lived in the Arctic region for thousands of years.
It was our last day in Stockholm and we had limited time and attention spans left, but it‚Äôs a free museum so we popped in for an hour (only enough time to walk through the Vikings exhibit and a few others) and then ran to get one last cinnamon roll before the airport bus left.
If you‚Äôre an indoor cat who doesn‚Äôt like bugs or being wet, below are some ‚Äúoutdoorsy‚Äù activities we suggest. If you‚Äôre into fishing, camping, swimming, deep hiking or kayaking, we are useless to you. But, Sweden is not! They have the Right of Public Access (‚ÄòAllemansr√§tt‚Äô) which means you have ‚Äúthe right to walk, cycle, ride, ski and camp on any land with the exception of private gardens, near a dwelling house or land under cultivation.‚Äù
The medieval city center where Stockholm was founded in 1252 might be annoyingly crammed with tourists in the summer, but it‚Äôs a picturesque area to roam about.
This is a World Heritage Site cemetery where the designers wanted nature ‚Äî majestic trees and rolling hills ‚Äî to shine rather than the headstones. Going back to that theme of equality, it‚Äôs ‚Äúimpossible‚Äù to have giant burial monuments, like you‚Äôd see in Italy, for example. The legendary actress Greta Garbo is buried here; her tombstone is modest, but they gave her quite a respectful perimeter, not laying anyone to rest nearby.
Pro tip: There‚Äôs a free audio guide via your phone, so you don‚Äôt need to pay for a tour if you‚Äôre interested in its history.
Vaxholm is an archipelago town you can reach via boat from Stockholm ‚Äî a nice, leisurely water ride that‚Äôs an attraction in itself. There‚Äôs the Vaxholm Castle/Fortress and the nearby Bogesunds Castle, but we didn‚Äôt tour either of them. It had quite a sleepy vibe when we were there, and we didn‚Äôt do anything except have a nice lunch at the waterfront Boulangerie Bageri & Caf√©. The archipelago is made up of 30,000 islands, so have your pick.
This Stockholm city island is full of museums and sights, but it also has great nature areas and paths. Have a cinnamon bun and coffee on Helin‚Äôs terrace overlooking the water and then take a walk on the path leading east. Go to the garden behind Rosendal Palace and you might see dogs herding sheep along the water below. Adorbs.
Wear good shoes, and bring a bottle of wine and some snacks to watch the sunset on this rocky hilltop overlooking the water and city.
Another popular lookout point/path for your 360 photos, one Stockholm resident confirmed Monteliusv√§gen was one of his go-to date wooing spots.
A tranquil place for a stroll where you can peer at ducks and kayakers, near the end of this path you can grab a bite or drink at Solstugan, which has a nice deck with a view of the sea.
Look, I loved my time with you, Sweden, but I‚Äôm coming from THE Land of Food, and I never expected for you to delight me as much as the Italians do with their delicacies, so I‚Äôm not mad at you or anything. You did great with what you had and what I could stumble upon as a clueless tourist. Also, it‚Äôs my fault I don‚Äôt like salmon or herring. Phew, glad we got that out of the way.
That being said, here are a few traditional Swedish foods and places that did delight us. Plus, Swedish bars and restaurants don‚Äôt make you buy water like they do in Italy ‚Äî yay for free, delicious tap water!
They say the Swedes invented cinnamon buns, so we thought it culturally sensitive that we eat 1‚Äì2 per day. They are a bit less dense and creamy than the ones in the U.S., no globs of frosting on top, and typically also contain cardamom in the dough. Our favorite buns were at Grand Cafe on the water in Blasieholmen and Caf√© Kronan in Gamla Stan, but we weren‚Äôt disappointed with any of the other buns, except at a place a British tour guide recommended. Did Brexit bust your sense of taste too, bro?
We accompanied most of these buns with a cup of Swedish coffee, which was almost always delicious. Did you know Swedes are the second biggest coffee drinkers after the Finns?! We definitely perfected the art of the Swedish fika, a mandatory (for good life balance) coffee break accompanied by sweets like kanelbulle. Over the dark winter days when Nordic folk get so little light or warmth, one can easily understand why such a cozy, caffeinated tradition exists.
Kryp In Restaurant Pr√§stgatan 17 (Gamla Stan)
Any loyal IKEA shopper knows that Swedish meatballs are a thing, but I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever actually eaten them there. In Stockholm, I only ate them once, and they were paired with the traditional lingonberries and mashed potatoes. My mom‚Äôs meatballs are better (she‚Äôs Italian American after all), but I was satisfied nevertheless.
‚ÄúWhat?! Santa‚Äôs little helper?!‚Äù I exclaimed when Alberto said he was ordering the reindeer. ‚ÄúYeah, he helps you survive the Nordic winter!‚Äù
I can‚Äôt remember the name (Swedish is hard, y‚Äôall), but we were also served a delicious ‚Äúdelicacy bread‚Äù prior to the meal, that included ingredients like potato, cardamom and syrup.
So, this first lunch was probably the most traditional, and after that, we felt some freedom to not eat ‚Äúauthentically Swedish‚Äù for the rest of the trip, aside from the daily buns of course.
We stumbled upon this place in the midst of a chilly rain shower and frantic Google Map search for dining options. The friendly server guided us into a cozy cave-like corner lit by candles and deep red walls. I later read in our host‚Äôs Lonely Planet Pocket Stockholm guidebook that it was a recommended spot. Score!
Our host also recommended Meatballs for the People as the best place in town for this traditional dish, but we couldn‚Äôt get a table. Or, if you don‚Äôt want to bother at all with being ‚Äúauthentic,‚Äù I present the following: ‚ÄúSwedish meatballs are actually based on a recipe King Charles XII brought home from Turkey in the early 18th century.‚Äù
Hej hej + tack very much, Sweden!
Originally published at minnitaliana.com on August 24, 2018.

Title: A Culinary Journey Through Stockholm: Exploring Rich Flavors in Every Season
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Stockholm, the vibrant capital of Sweden, is a city that offers more than just stunning architecture and picturesque waterfronts. For the food enthusiast, Stockholm is a haven of culinary delights waiting to be discovered. A culinary journey as varied as its seasons awaits you in Stockholm, where you can find everything from modern, inventive food to centuries-old, traditional meals.
Stockholm‚Äôs weather plays a significant role in shaping its culinary landscape. The city experiences four distinct seasons, each offering a unique bounty of ingredients that inspire chefs and home cooks alike.
Spring (V√•r)
As winter recedes, Stockholm awakens with a burst of fresh flavors. Spring brings a sense of renewal, reflected in the dishes that grace tables across the city. Look for dishes featuring the tender, young shoots of asparagus, the first harvests of flavorful wild garlic, and the delicate sweetness of freshly sprouted peas. In restaurants and homes, you might find classics like ‚ÄòV√•rk√§nslor‚Äô (Spring Feelings), a dish celebrating the season with new potatoes, pickled herring, and sour cream.
Summer (Sommar)
Stockholm summers are a time of abundance, with long days that seem to stretch endlessly into twilight. This season brings a bounty of berries ‚Äî lingonberries, blueberries, and the coveted wild strawberries. These berries find their way into jams, desserts, and savory dishes alike. Seafood shines in the summer, with crayfish parties (kr√§ftskiva) a beloved tradition. Imagine tables filled with boiled crayfish, V√§sterbotten cheese pie, and crisp, fresh salads.
Autumn (H√∂st)
As the leaves turn golden and the air becomes crisp, Stockholm‚Äôs forests offer a treasure trove of mushrooms and game. Chanterelles, porcini, and the elusive ‚Äòblack gold‚Äô of truffles make their way into hearty stews and creamy sauces. Autumn also marks the beginning of the apple and pear season, with orchards heavy with fruit. Indulge in warm apple pie topped with vanilla sauce or explore the savory side with pork dishes accompanied by tart apple compote.
Winter (Vinter)
Winter transforms Stockholm into a winter wonderland, with snow-covered streets and a cozy atmosphere. It‚Äôs a time for hearty, warming meals that fortify against the cold. Classic dishes like ‚Äò√Ñrtsoppa med Pannkakor‚Äô (Pea Soup with Pancakes) are a comforting staple, especially on Thursdays, a tradition dating back to the 15th century. Rich, meaty stews like ‚ÄòK√∂ttbullar‚Äô (Swedish meatballs) served with lingonberry sauce evoke cozy evenings by the fire.
While exploring Stockholm‚Äôs culinary landscape, one encounters a blend of tradition and innovation. The city has a deep-rooted respect for its culinary heritage, evident in dishes that have stood the test of time. Yet, Stockholm‚Äôs chefs are also at the forefront of culinary innovation, constantly pushing boundaries while maintaining a focus on local, seasonal ingredients.
Sm√∂rg√•sbord: A quintessential Swedish dining experience, featuring a vast array of dishes from pickled herring to cured meats, cheeses, and savory pies.
Gravlax: This cured salmon dish, typically served with dill and mustard sauce, is a celebration of the city‚Äôs abundant seafood.
Surstr√∂mming: For the adventurous, this fermented herring is a pungent delicacy best experienced outdoors due to its potent aroma.
New Nordic Cuisine: Inspired by the principles of using local, sustainable ingredients, this movement has put Stockholm on the global culinary map. Restaurants like the renowned ‚ÄúF√§viken‚Äù and ‚ÄúOaxen Krog‚Äù epitomize this ethos.
Foraging Culture: With access to pristine forests and coastline, foraging plays a significant role in Stockholm‚Äôs cuisine. Chefs and home cooks alike venture into the wild to gather ingredients like wild herbs, berries, and mushrooms, adding a fresh, earthy dimension to their dishes.
Exploring Stockholm‚Äôs cuisine goes beyond just tasting the food. It‚Äôs about immersing oneself in the culture that surrounds it. Visit local markets, such as √ñstermalms Saluhall or S√∂derhallarna, where vendors proudly display their fresh produce, meats, cheeses, and seafood. Engage with locals to learn about family recipes passed down through generations, or join in seasonal celebrations like Midsummer, where traditional foods are central to the festivities.
No exploration of Stockholm‚Äôs culture would be complete without experiencing ‚Äòfika‚Äô. More than just a coffee break, fika is a cherished tradition of pausing, savoring a hot beverage (usually coffee or tea), and enjoying a sweet treat. Indulge in cinnamon buns (kanelbullar), cardamom-scented cakes, or almond tarts as you join Stockholmers in this daily ritual of relaxation and socializing.
In conclusion, Stockholm‚Äôs culinary scene is a tapestry woven with the threads of tradition, innovation, and the rich bounty of its seasons. Whether you‚Äôre savoring the tangy sweetness of lingonberries in summer or warming up with a steaming bowl of pea soup in winter, every bite tells a story of this beautiful city. So, pack your curiosity and appetite, and embark on a culinary journey through Stockholm ‚Äî you‚Äôll discover a world of flavors waiting to be explored.

On Stairs, Frescoes, and the Art of Rewriting
If you ever find yourself wandering the streets of Stockholm, do what I did ‚Äî look up.
On a recent visit, I found myself standing before the stern, red-bricked silhouette of Stockholm‚Äôs City Hall. From the outside, it‚Äôs all weight and authority, but step inside and you‚Äôll discover a world of meticulous design and unexpected artistry.
The Architect‚Äôs Obsession ‚Äî Stairs Fit for a Queen
The story goes that Ragnar √ñstberg, the mastermind behind City Hall, was obsessed with getting every detail right. Not just the grand arches or the towering spire, but even the stairs.
He wanted the queen to descend them with absolute grace during the Nobel banquet.
So what did he do?
He had his wife walk up and down different prototypes of the staircase, again and again, until she was utterly sick of it.
All so that, on that one night, the queen (and every guest after her) would glide, not stumble.

Title: Stockholm‚Äôs Early-Stage Edge, and What‚Äôs Missing
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Stockholm doesn‚Äôt try to compete with Europe‚Äôs biggest tech hubs on volume or visibility. It doesn‚Äôt need to. Underneath the surface, the city has built one of the continent‚Äôs most efficient and credible early-stage ecosystems, and one that‚Äôs already outperforming on density, deal quality, and network speed. But while early-stage momentum is real, there‚Äôs a catch: scale is harder. And the late-stage gap is starting to show.
Start with the fundamentals. Stockholm has around 2,500 startups. That may not sound impressive next to London‚Äôs 25,000 or Berlin‚Äôs 6,000, but raw numbers miss the point. With just 2.5 million people, Stockholm has one of the highest startup densities in Europe. Only London and Amsterdam are higher per capita. The city is tied with Berlin and well ahead of Paris, Zurich, Munich, and Madrid. This isn‚Äôt an ecosystem chasing scale for its own sake, but one that is focused on concentration, repeatability, and results. It also produces some of the most successful start-ups, as it ranks #2 in unicorns per capita in Europe (only behind Estonia)
It helps that the basics are sorted. Sweden has one of the lowest corporate tax rates in the EU at 20.6%. R&D incentives are real. The visa process, while imperfect, is smoother than in many neighboring countries. Founders can incorporate, hire, and launch without running into structural friction. That‚Äôs not true everywhere in Europe.
But regulation is only part of the story. What really makes Stockholm work is the network. The ecosystem is compact and layered. Founders, angels, VCs, private organizations (like Nordic Angels) and public-sector players operate in close proximity, quite literally. Relationships are short-range and high-frequency. Two intros are usually enough to reach anyone. It speeds everything up: hiring, fundraising, product feedback and decision-making.
Especially the angel community is functioning well. According to the recent Nordic Angels & BCG report I co-authored, Stockholm leads the region in both deal activity and investor depth. Nearly 600 active angels operate in the city, and many of them repeat founders or early operators from companies like Klarna, Spotify, and iZettle. That experience compounds. New teams benefit from old playbooks. Capital comes with context.
VC behavior reflects the broader market shift. Global dry powder is high, but deployment is cautious and conviction-driven. That suits Stockholm. The companies being built here tend to be leaner, more international, and capital-efficient. Local funds like Creandum, EQT Ventures, and Northzone are still writing early checks. And when the metrics are strong, international investors are showing up (like Accel, Sequioa, et. al.). The pipeline is healthy. The bar is high.
But not everything is working.
The late-stage environment hasn‚Äôt kept up. Series B and C rounds are regularly led by foreign investors (e.g., recently for Legora), often requiring founders to relocate teams, shift strategy, or change how they operate. When the capital isn‚Äôt local, neither is the upside. Value leaks. Talent disperses. Ecosystem effects weaken. Some of Stockholm‚Äôs most promising startups are scaling in other geographies. Not by choice, but by necessity. The ecosystem in Stockholm hasn‚Äôt quite caught up to this yet.
Capital is one challenge: Unlike in some neighboring countries, Sweden doesn‚Äôt have a strong state-backed co-investment model at the Series B and C level (but Sweden does have them in earlier stages). There‚Äôs no domestic equivalent to Finland‚Äôs Tesi or Denmark‚Äôs V√¶kstfonden. Those institutions actively anchor larger rounds and keep value creation local.
Senior talent is another challenge. While the city has no shortage of strong engineers and early hires, there‚Äôs a gap in commercial leadership. Experienced sales, product, and executive operators are in short supply and current stock option tax rules don‚Äôt help on retention either (the stock option tax rules are beneficial for early-stage startups, but less so for later stages). It‚Äôs workable, but it‚Äôs not competitive with ecosystems like London or Tallinn.
Diversity is still lagging. Female and underrepresented founders raise a small fraction of total capital (all-women teams represented 6.1% of all funding rounds in the Nordics in 2022 and 2023, but received only 1.2% of the total capital). It‚Äôs not unique to Stockholm, but it‚Äôs persistent. Progress is being made, but slowly. It‚Äôs an area where the city could and should lead but hasn‚Äôt yet. Diversity isn‚Äôt just social, it‚Äôs strategic. Stockholm risks missing out on market upside without more inclusive capital flows and accessing the full breadth of ideas.
And cost of living is creeping up. For junior hires, early-stage teams, or international founders trying to get started, Stockholm is no longer cheap. It hasn‚Äôt hit London levels, but it‚Äôs moving in that direction, and that friction is already starting to show.
Still, the early-stage engine is real. Stockholm‚Äôs ecosystem isn‚Äôt built on noise. It‚Äôs built on high-quality inputs: credible talent, disciplined capital, and a regulatory environment that mostly gets out of the way. Founders here are building with focus, and investors are backing with precision. That‚Äôs rare in any cycle, and especially in this one.
Stockholm‚Äôs AI startup scene is also starting to show depth. Early movers like Sana didn‚Äôt just secure funding and traction, but they helped define what AI-native startups can look like in B2B and infrastructure-heavy verticals. More importantly, they trained talent, validated use cases, and proved that it‚Äôs possible to build globally relevant AI companies out of Sweden. That groundwork is now fueling a second wave of startups, with emerging players like Legora (legal AI), Lovable (AI-powered app development platform), and others are coming to market with sharp focus and strong teams. The ecosystem‚Äôs early bets are compounding. What started with a few AI-first companies is evolving into a broader, more durable platform for applied AI innovation. Stockholm may not be chasing scale at any cost, but in AI, it‚Äôs starting to set the pace.
For investors, especially at the growth stage, this is a signal. Stockholm‚Äôs early-stage pipeline is functioning. But the gap in late-stage capital creates an opening. Companies that are raising follow-ons are often forced to look outside. That introduces pressure on geography, on strategy, and on exit dynamics. For funds willing to lean in earlier, build local relationships, and back high-quality teams before they cross borders, Stockholm is exactly where to be looking. For funds willing to underwrite scale on local terms, Stockholm might offer an arbitrage in talent, timing, and trust.
What‚Äôs missing isn‚Äôt ambition or ideas to create the next unicorns, but some infrastructure. And unless more of it develops, Stockholm risks exporting the very companies it helped create.

Title: An Honest Guide to the Stockholm, Sweden Startup Life
Content:

Share
In the north part of Europe, surrounded by hills, endless forests, and a never-ending coastline lies the city of Stockholm, capital of Scandinavia. The whole of Scandinavia agreed on that name by the way. Technically we didn‚Äôt ask Norway, Finland and Denmark if it‚Äôs okay that we‚Äôre the capital, but we‚Äôre like 99% sure they‚Äôre okay with it.
I have lived here all my life. I love it here. It‚Äôs like being in San Francisco but with fewer unicorns and less sun. Since I'm recruiting people from all over the world and convincing them to move here I get a lot of questions about life here:
‚ÄúShould I work there?‚Äù
‚ÄúCan I fly to London over the day?‚Äù
‚ÄúWill ABBA ever reunite?‚Äù
So here is my experience. I hope I can give an authentic look into what our cold, dark corner of the world has to offer.
My day begins when I wake up in my apartment on Kungshomen. Kungsholmen is one of the three main islands in Stockholm. From there I stroll along the water to work in the city center. It takes about 25 minutes. Unfortunately, the housing market here is a bit of a disaster, so unless you enjoy changing which apartment you sublet every month or have $350k to buy your own place you are stuck taking the bus or a train into the city center like a regular peasant.
Speaking of water, Stockholm is surrounded by it. Anywhere you go you will see water. The water is supposedly clean enough to drink. I have not tried it myself since I value my life, but there are YouTube videos of people doing it.
Nobody takes the car. Thanks to some of highest taxes in the world, cars are expensive, and besides, people here believe that if you drive to work you hate the environment and wish all animals a slow and painful death. Biking to work is a good choice. There are biking lanes everywhere. Apart from saving the planet and giving you daily exercise it also signals that you live inside of the city. Preferably get a colorful bike to maximize the attention as you ride down the city streets.
Your most important decision of the morning is where you stop to buy your caf√© latte. I don‚Äôt drink it myself since I do paleo, but the way I understand it, it‚Äôs coffee flavored hot milk. If you work at a startup you can buy coffee at any place: both Il Caf√© and Johan & Nystr√∂m are acceptable choices.
Our office is based in an area called city center. It‚Äôs named so because the people naming it were officially out of ideas. Nearby is the cultural house which was built as a tribute to Soviet communism.
I work out of a startup hub called ‚ÄúSUP46‚Äù. SUP is Swedish for ‚Äúdrink excessive amounts of alcohol‚Äù and 46 is the country code of Sweden. So the name literally translates to ‚Äúget drunk in Sweden‚Äù. Something many people have taken to heart.
SUP46 is not just an office but also a community since it has an ‚Äúevent space‚Äù. During evenings, there is often free food and beer in the event space. Sometimes someone is talking in a microphone and showing powerpoint slides while you eat which can be distracting. But I‚Äôm sure people are working on fixing that.
There are a few other startup hubs, the most prominent being THINGS, which as the name implies, gives you free things.
Most people, yours truly included, work in an open office space. Your choice of clothes is important since people will be seeing you walking back and forth to the coffee machine. If you are male you should probably grow a beard.
Choice of laptop also says a lot about you.
Other companies at SUP46 are Fishbrain, which based on the name must be working on creating sentient fish and Sparta which I believe are organizing a live event where they re-enact Sparta the movie.
The most famous company in Stockholm is called Spotify. They play music and collect your personal data. It is also Europe‚Äôs most famous startup. If your CV contains the word Spotify it means you can get a job at any company at any level in Europe because you are now an expert in ‚Äúdigital‚Äù. There is also a company called Mojang. Nobody knows if it is an actual startup or if it‚Äôs just one guy that created a game called Minecraft and sold it to Microsoft for $2.5bn or a practical joke played by the guys behind King. Either way, we‚Äôre counting it as a unicorn.
Apart from Spotify and Mojang there are five other unicorns: Mysql, Skype, King.com, Klarna and Truecaller. Technically you could also count Russian auction site Avito.ru which was founded by two Swedes in Moscow. Before starting Avito the founders had started and sold the largest European auction site Tradera to Ebay. As part of the transaction the nice people at Ebay said ‚Äúlook guys, you are on your own now but don‚Äôt go start a new company or our lawyers will hunt you down‚Äù and they were like ‚Äúoh but COME ON, we have to do SOMETHING, you guys are not in Russia so at least let us start a company there?‚Äù. Ebay went ‚Äúlol, enjoy Soviet Russia you commies‚Äù and the rest is history. It is incidentally also the reason why Ebay‚Äôs employment agreements have changed the term ‚Äúnot start a competitor anywhere in the world except Russia‚Äù to ‚Äú not start a competitor anywhere in the known universe‚Äù.
The fact that Stockholm has seven unicorns while London, a city with ten times the population, only has twice the number of unicorns is basically Swedish socialism‚Äôs subtle way of giving the middle finger to the British labour party. Some people argue that Sweden has unicorns despite being socialistic not thanks to it, but I digress.
Stockholm is a special place. In the summer we swim in the warm water, in the winter we ice skate on it. We remain a thorn in the side of free market theorists by producing the highest number of unicorns per capita after San Francisco despite offering free schools and universal free healthcare.
We also love everything US and have one the biggest country subreddits to prove it. The most upvoted post last year was a picture of an Ukranian literature professor who looks like Swedish football hero Zlatan Ibrahimovich.
If you want to experience it for yourself several companies are hiring, including myself, that help with relocation. Or as ABBA said:
‚ÄúIf you change your mind, I‚Äôm the first in lineHoney I‚Äôm still freeTake a chance on me‚Äù
If you already work here, stop wasting your time reading this and do something productive like paying more taxes.
(Big thanks to the guys over at Padlet.com for inspiring me to write this. If you decide to work in SF you should probably work for them).

‚ÄúStockholmers call their city ‚Äòbeauty on water‚Äô. But despite the well-preserved historic core, Stockholm is no museum piece: it‚Äôs modern, dynamic and ever-evolving.‚Äù (Lonely Planet)
14 islands and 57 bridges. But what should I visit?
Before describing my 48-hour experience, let me introduce you to the history of this marvellous city by the hand of localhistories.org:
The great city of Stockholm began in the 13th century. At that time trade and commerce were increasing across Europe and many new towns were founded. In 1252 the regent of Sweden, Birger Jarl founded Stockholm. The new town grew rapidly. In 1289 it was described as the largest place in Sweden, although it would seem very small to us. By 1500 Stockholm was a flourishing town of about 6,000 people.
Then in 1520 came the Stockholm Bloodbath. The king of Denmark invaded Sweden in 1519. In 1520 he captured Stockholm and he had more than 80 Swedish nobles executed for heresy. However the Swede Gustav Vasa recaptured Stockholm in 1523.
During the 17th century Sweden was a great power in Europe. Stockholm grew rapidly and by the end of the century it had a population of around 50,000. Riddarhuset, The House of Nobility was built between 1641 and 1674.
However in 1710‚Äì1711 there was an outbreak of plague in Stockholm which killed many people. Yet Stockholm recovered and it flourished during the 18th century. Tullgarn Palace was built about 1720. The Royal Palace opened in 1754. The Obelisk was erected in 1799. Also in 1799 the statue of King Gustav III was sculpted.
In the late 19th century Sweden was transformed from an agricultural society to an industrial one. In 1850 Stockholm had a population of 93,000 and it continued to rise rapidly. By the beginning of the 20th century it had reached 300,000.
However in the mid 19th century Stockholm was an unhealthy place. There were no sewers or piped water supply. But all that changed. Stockholm gained gas light in 1853. In the 1860s a piped water supply was created. The National Museum was built in 1866. Stockholm Central Railway Station was built in 1871. Horse drawn trams began running in Stockholm in 1877. The first electric trams ran in 1901. Meanwhile Stockholm University was founded in 1877. The Swedish Army Museum opened in 1879. Skansen open air museum opened in 1891. The Biological Museum opened in 1893. Stockholm Music Museum was founded in 1899.
During the 20th century Stockholm continued to flourish. The Postal Museum opened in 1906 and the Nordic Museum was built in 1907. The Museum of National Antiquities opened in 1943. Meanwhile Parliament House was built in 1905 and City Hall was built in 1923. Stockholm escaped damage by bombing in the Second World War but in the mid 20th century a program began to modernise the city. Many old homes in Stockholm were demolished and replaced by new ones.
Today tourism is an important industry in Stockholm. The Museum of Dance opened in 1953. The Medieval Museum opened in 1986. A ship called The Vasa sank in 1628 but it was recovered in 1961 and is now on display in a museum. Today the population of Stockholm is 942,000.‚Äù

There‚Äôs no better way to see the sights of Stockholm than with a free Hop On Hop Off bus, which we used to get us to the following places we chose to visit on Saturday taking advantage of the Stockholm Pass.
A way to quickly explore the three islands that compose the city center.
One of the biggest cultural treasures in Sweden ‚Äî the warship Vasa that sank in 1628 on its maiden voyage from Stockholm.
Nordiska Museet (idea for next time)
Founded in 1891, Skansen is the world‚Äôs first open-air museum. Located on the island of Djurg√•rden and close to the Vasa museum, Skansen offers a fascinating look into historical Swedish life. Recreates the life of the 19th century.
The palace dates back to the 18th century and is one of the most interesting historic buildings in Stockholm. The biggest royal palace in the world with 600 rooms. Changing of the guards take place daily at noon.
Get familiarised with the stunning scenery of Stockholm‚Äôs archipelago on a guided 3 hour boat tour. Experience the city from the water, learn about the history and be inspired by the beauty of Stockholm‚Äôs natural landscape.
Lovely cafes, restaurants, souvenir and antique shops.
Aifur Krog & Bar
We said yes to the Viking dining experience at this underground traditional live music restaurant. Candle-light warm atmosphere, big shared tables and exquisite Swedish specialities: mussels in a creamy sauce, baked salmon and venison steaks with veggies and potatoes.
Having traditional ‚ÄúFika‚Äù, a Swedish coffee-break with fresh baked cakes and pastries at Vetekatten.
Sunday morning Market at H√∂torget (Haymarket Square): fresh fruits and vegetables, new and second hand crafts and clothes.
Yes, again to see the rest of the city and learn some more of its history.

‚ÄúKnown for inventing dynamite, Nobel also owned Bofors, which he had redirected from its previous role as primarily an iron and steel producer to a major manufacturer of cannon and other armaments. Nobel held 355 different patents, dynamite being the most famous. After reading a premature obituary which condemned him for profiting from the sales of arms, he bequeathed his fortune to institute the Nobel Prizes.‚Äù

‚ÄúSweden is a country that has taken its culture and turned it into a brand.‚Äù ‚Äì Bjorn Ulvaeus
I am exchange student with Geography background and I had always been fascinated by the unique culture and landscapes of Sweden. In January 2011, I arrived in Stockholm to begin a six-month adventure that would take me through the coldest winter days and the longest nights I had ever experienced.
At first, the darkness and the cold were a shock to my system. Coming from a tropical climate, the idea of walking to class in -20¬∞C temperatures was daunting. But as I settled into my routine and began to explore the city, I found myself falling in love with the Swedish way of life.
One of the things that struck me the most about Swedish culture was the emphasis on sustainability and environmental stewardship. From the public transportation system to the recycling system in supermarkets, it was clear that sustainability was a top priority amongst the Swedes. As a Geography student, this was particularly inspiring, and I found myself incorporating these principles into my own daily life.
Another aspect of Swedish culture that I appreciated was the emphasis on work-life balance. Swedes take their time off seriously, and it‚Äôs not uncommon to see people taking a midday fika (coffee break) or leaving work early to spend time with family and friends. This was a refreshing change of pace from the workaholic culture that I was used to, and it allowed me to prioritize my own well-being and mental health.
Of course, as an exchange student, I also had my fair share of funny and memorable experiences. One of the highlights was celebrating Christmas with my Swedish host family, who introduced me to traditional Swedish delicacies like julbord (Christmas buffet) and gl√∂gg (mulled wine). I also had the opportunity to explore the city‚Äôs many museums, parks, and cafes, and to meet other exchange students from all over the world.
My six months in Stockholm were a transformative experience that allowed me to immerse myself in a unique culture and to learn from the people and landscapes of Sweden. From the coldest winter days to the warmest moments of connection, I will always cherish the memories and insights that I gained during my time here.

Sweden is famous for well-designed furniture, beautiful women and functional socialism. A sub-scale barren country which has somehow produced iconic global businesses like IKEA and H&M. As a tourist destination, I wasn‚Äôt sure what to expect, but assumed the place would be easy on the eye.
In early February, the sky is glum and the hours of daylight reduced, but the prettiness of Stockholm remains striking. It was cold, but not intolerable, hovering between -2 and 2 degrees Celsius. The thing to do in Stockholm in winter is drink coffee (fika in Swedish). The locals spend their days lazing in the warm, well designed Espresso House cafes. Think Starbucks with better furniture, a more nuanced color scheme and better coffee. You can‚Äôt escape them. ‚ÄúWhy are there so many Espresso House cafes, is it a Swedish brand?‚Äù I asked the teenager behind the counter. ‚ÄúYes, there are six of them on this street I think. Some Germans bought the company, and they are expanding into other Scandinavian countries, Germany and the Netherlands, it‚Äôs like another war plan‚Äù he responded, in a mocking German accent. Funny, but unlikely to be awarded Employee of the Month by his new paymasters.
If you go to Stockholm expecting to see wall-to-wall knock-out barely dressed Shield Maidens, you‚Äôll be disappointed. Stockholm is a very multi-cultural place, filled with practically dressed typically dark haired women. The stereotypical well-tanned blue eyed, blonde, knee-buckling knock-out exists, but they are uncommon.
Stockholm is brimming with museums and galleries, exploring everything from Vikings and Sami culture to design and human rights. A highlight is the Vasa Museum in Gal√§rvarvsv√§gen, visited by 1.4 million people each year. The Museum was purpose built around the Vasa, a 69 metre-long 17th century wooden ship. A 1,200 tonne war machine, with 64 cannons over two levels, ten sails and 120 tonnes of ballast. A brutal expression of Sweden‚Äôs desire to conquer new territories. ‚ÄúF&$k me‚Äù I muttered too loudly when I walked into the cavernous museum and saw the ship for the first time. An immense killing machine covered with hundreds of wooden sculptures. ‚ÄúHow the hell did they build this back then?‚Äù I was thinking as I waited for my free guided tour to start.
The awe in which I held the 17th century ship builders was quickly diminished. The Vasa was a dud. The three year effort to build the ultimate war machine led to a twenty minute maiden voyage of 1.3km before it toppled in a light breeze. A colossal, embarrassing and undoubtedly expensive failure for the King.
The inquest following the sinking, brought to light that many people knew the ship was a dud, but it sailed anyway. The most shocking anecdote involved the captain overlooking the construction ordering thirty men to run back and forth along the deck in front of the Vice Admiral, when the ship was still in the port. The terrified Vice Admiral called a halt to the demonstration, as he thought the ship was going to sink. The ship was top heavy, badly proportioned and sat too high out of the water. Yet, no-one wanted to tell the King that the years of hard work and treasure had all gone to waste. Despite the loss of thirty lives, no-one was punished. The Dutch ship-builder had died during construction, and his widow who completed the project had already been paid. The King just wanted to forget about the debacle.
Swedish food is as basic as the Vasa is impressive. Meatballs and potatoes, plus a bit of fish and a few miniature prawns. Hearty food. Good for plundering, less so for the sedate modern lifestyle. Given the frigid winter and heavy diet, you‚Äôd expect the Swedes to be fatter.
The downside to travelling in Sweden is that it is frighteningly expensive. The Arlanda Express, a twenty minute train from the airport to the centre costs US$30. Take the cheaper forty minute bus ride with Flygbussarna and you are still shelling out US$13. Getting a basic meal below US$15 is tough, unless you want to eat hamburgers. I got charged US$3 for a glass of tap water when I ordered a steak.
But don‚Äôt let the jarring prices deter you. Stockholm is a must-see destination, even during the winter months.

by Sam Smith ‚Äî Kiss House
Few things are cooler than tremendously hip Stockholm. Design centre and self-proclaimed capital of Scandinavia.
If cities were boyfriends (or girlfriends for that matter) then Stockholm is a keeper; successful, stylish, intelligent, fun yet super considerate. Marriage material for sure.
I recently spent the weekend here with my husband Ben and discovered that zipping about the city on two wheels like a local is the only way to get about. But I don‚Äôt mean on bicycles, I‚Äôm talking scooters, electric scooters.
Let‚Äôs be clear, we are both well into our 40‚Äôs but these are not for kids. Strictly over 18s only (ha!). Our kids had their own ‚Äúmini-break‚Äù to Grandma‚Äôs house (happy face).
It is without a doubt the most fun I‚Äôve had since turning adult and simply the BEST way to get the most out of a place. Admittedly, I need to work on my lefts and rights and remember that if you‚Äôre heading towards oncoming traffic, a bus is beeping at you and your husband is shouting at you, you‚Äôre probably on the wrong side of the road, but it was a great experience and I implore anyone to try it.
You may have seen pay as you go scooters popping up in various European cities. They first appeared in the US but Sweden is an early adopter and you can now find them in most Swedish cities. Never have London‚Äôs Boris (Santander) bikes seemed so dull. These are dockless so there‚Äôs no hunting around to locate / park, you literally jump on and off. A handy app finds them for you and signs you in and out with a simple scan.
Of course, it works well in Stockholm, with their spacious roads, pavements and seriously impressive route of cycle paths. Whizzing around at 20 kph, you see way more than you would on foot without missing a thing. There‚Äôs so much to love here. Where the old meets the new (and some interesting 70‚Äôs structures in between). There‚Äôs a lot of building work going on. The place is buzzing.
Effortless. Like it comes easy to them. But a city‚Äôs worth of cycle lanes takes a hell of a lot of planning and foresight. If we had the same in the UK I‚Äôd cycle (or scoot) everywhere and encourage my children to do the same ‚Äî it‚Äôs just too dangerous, so we don‚Äôt!
We love Swedish design at Kiss House because so many of it‚Äôs values and principles align with ours. Known for its minimalism, simplicity and use of natural materials. The Swedish build quality, placing value on functionality as much as aesthetics with consideration to the environment, surely the cornerstones of all great modern design? They‚Äôve long embraced ultra low energy builds. In fact, the two Professors responsible for developing the Passivhaus performance standard were a German physicist and a Swedish scientist.
Everything feels progressive here, considered. The air feels clean. It doesn‚Äôt surprise me that Stockholm is ranked one of the most eco-friendly cities in the world and Sweden one of the most sustainable countries.
Back in 2014, The Guardian reported on an innovative city funded high-rise project in the southern Swedish town of V√§xj√∂ where two high-rises were built to the Passivhaus standard to help the country realise it‚Äôs goal of eliminating CO2 emissions by 2050. ‚ÄúTaking this route works very well for us as a municipality, since we want to become CO2 neutral, and homes account for 30% of energy use‚Äù explained Henrik Johansson, the city‚Äôs environmental coordinator. He added ‚Äúeven though the city has endured three extremely cold winters since the buildings went up, the apartments have not been cold‚Äù.
It‚Äôs the city‚Äôs most ambitious project but it‚Äôs no stranger to Passivhaus builds and even boasts a Passivhaus house style tennis complex built by former world no.1 player Stefan Edberg. V√§xj√∂‚Äôs city planners now face the dilemma of how to deal with the vast amounts of energy used by poorly insulated 1960‚Äôs and 70‚Äôs buildings, and how to make them more energy efficient or Passivhaus retrofit them. ‚ÄúJust another challenge to overcome‚Äù says Johansson (source: Elisabeth Braw: The Guardian).
The Swedes clearly know how to create great cities. Stockholm is a joy and is testament to their foresight and people centred design.
Whilst there zipping around, we had the benefit of recommendations from locals (because my husband is fortunate enough to spend time there for work). Below is our Top 10 things to See and Do.
2. Check out ‚ÄúThe Future Starts Here‚Äù exhibition at Ark Des (in association with the V&A London) until 4th August 2019, a fascinating and thought-provoking exhibition about the world of tomorrow shaped by the designs and technologies emerging today.
3. Visit Fotografiska: A centre for contemporary photography housed in an old brick-built customs building
4. Check out Sn√∂s√§tra Graffiti Wall of Fame one of Europe‚Äôs largest graffiti exhibitions
5. Take a day cruise and experience the best parts of the beautiful Stockholm archipelago
6. Eat amazingly good Bengali Street Food at Gossip Shanti (be warned when the waiter says it‚Äôs hot, it‚Äôs HOT!)
7. Sample local cuisine in a Foodhall such as √ñstermalms Saluhall
8. Visit one of the city‚Äôs Roof Top bars such as Tak Stockholm
9. Mooch around cool independent boutiques and homeware stores, plus enjoy a stop-off in one of the eclectic cafes and bars in laidback S√∂dermalm or SoFo
10. Stay in Downtown Camper by Scandic: A new first-class hotel with award winning design, rooftop bar, spa and rooftop pool as well as an excellent restaurant, Campfire.

Title: 10 Things I Love about Stockholm (Part 1)
Content:
Sign up

Sign up

Listen
Share
‚ÄúLife is always full of surprises‚Äù
For an Asian girl who never traveled to any European country before, the fact of moving from Ho Chi Minh City (Vietnam) to Stockholm (Sweden) to live was never in my plan. However, life is always full of surprises, there are decisions we have to make, and some decisions are made for us. Moving to Stockholm has opened a brand new chapter of my life. Although I have been living here for just 11 months, there are so many things in Stockholm that I just fell in love with this city at first sight (and I‚Äôm sure you will).
After landing from the flight, I took the bus from Arlanda airport to Stockholm city. It took around 55 minutes from Arlanda airport to Stockholm City via Flygbuss with ticket price is 99 SEK (~10.3USD) for 1 round.
Firstly I was really impressed with how the city manages to preserve all the historical buildings. From churches to museums, government offices to schools, and even regular houses, Stockholm‚Äôs architecture is stunning
My friends told me that, in Stockholm, it‚Äôs very common to see houses which were built in 1900s (100 years old). These houses can survive such long time thanks to the high quality materials as well as careful maintenance. If you want to explore these building yourselves, Gamla Stan should be your must-go of Stockholm owing to its unique Swedish architecture.
My second impression was that I can drink the water from any tap in the city. My landlord proudly told me that ‚ÄúStockholm has some of the purest water in the world in its taps. It has way better quality than bottled water, so yes, it‚Äôs completely safe to drink.‚Äù
At first, I did not dare to drink the water directly from the tap as it‚Äôs not common for Asian people to do so. However, seeing my landlord tried it himself, I also wanted to try. The result was a big surprise for me. I‚Äôd never tasted such fresh water before. I started searching for information about water in Stockholm and here was what I found:
‚ÄúEvery day Stockholm Vatten och Avfall produces 360,000 m¬≥ of drinking water in the two water treatment works of Lov√∂ and Norsborg, and distributes it to 1.5 million people in Stockholm.The water is retrieved in Lake M√§laren. To maintain a high quality of drinking water, measures are continuously taken to protect the source of water supply; Lake M√§laren as well as the reserve water source Bornsj√∂n.‚Äù
Thanks to this work, we can save a lot of money on boiling water to make it drinkable. This also helps to reduce the number of plastic bottles consumed. Imagine that travellers don‚Äôt need to buy water bottles but can just simply fill the bottle with tap water. Bravo Stockholm!!!
Living in Stockholm, we don‚Äôt need to drive miles away to get into the wild because Stockholm is surrounded with a lot of lakes and green trees. There are almost 300 nature reserves around the greater Stockholm area, two national parks, one national city park and plenty of lakes that attract both wildlife and locals. Every suburb has numerous green areas, both small and large, and there are several green parks in the city. In other words, you‚Äôre just a short subway or bus ride away if you feel nature calling.
If you are lucky (like me), you might encounter some European hares happily enjoy their grass on your journey. Some of my friends live in the far north of Stockholm sometimes also see moose, deers, or even bears on the train to the inner city. There was a time, my boss nearly hit a moose while driving to Arlanda airport in a gloomy morning because the moose just suddenly jumped into the middle of the street (lucky him). So prepared yourself to meet some surprise friends on your way in Stockholm!
When it comes to air quality, there are many components to measure it including the level of pollutants like ammonia (NH3), carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2), sulfur dioxide (SO2), ‚Ä¶ and the level of particulate matter (PM) like PM10, PM2.5. However, in this post, I won‚Äôt talk about scientific facts but how I feel when breathing the air in Stockholm.
I am living in a small apartment in southern Stockholm, around 12km from the city central so surrounding me are a lot of trees, flowers and lakes. Everyday, as long as I step out of the house, I always look up in the sky, take a really deep breath to get as much cool fresh air as possible to feed my lung. I never feel tired of doing that. Every breath I take, I can feel like the air in flowing in my body and it keeps refreshing my mind. I wish I could pack those air and ship it to my home country so that my family can enjoy it with me.
Fika is one of the most popular keywords you will hear when you are in Stockholm and it is a very traditional Swedish thing people do almost everyday. Fika basically means to meet up for a coffee and a piece of cake. Sweden enjoys a highly developed culture when it comes to baked goods, they are so in love with cake that they even have national days for some cakes.
Semla is two-layer bun made of wheat and cardamom, stuffed with almond paste under a cover of thick layered whipped cream. This is definitely the must-try item in your list when you are in Stockholm.
Every year on a Tuesday that lies on the seventh week before Easter, is where the so-called ‚ÄúFat Tuesday‚Äù or ‚ÄúSemmeldagen‚Äù (the day of the Semla) falls.
Princess cake contains layers of light sponge cake, pastry cream, and a dome of whipped cream all covered by green marzipan and marzipan pink roses. You can find it in every bakery store with different variations, in round-shaped or in roll-shaped.
This is my most favourite cake ever! Kanelbullar is made with a perfectly soft and chewy cardamom dough, a buttery cinnamon-sugar filling, and twisted into cute little knots. Every year on October 4th, the Swedes celebrate Cinnamon Bun Day. All you need for a chilling afternoon is cup of coffee and a cinnamon roll. It is the ultimate symbol of Swedish home cooking and, as any Swede will tell you, the smell of newly baked cinnamon rolls is best smell in the world.
I usually warm the bun in microwave a little bit (30 seconds) to feel the smell of cinamon but you can try without heating it. Once you try it, you will love it forever!
‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî
Yay, there you go, the list of 5 things that made me fall in love with Stockholm. I really hope this list will inspire you to go to Stockholm one day. If you have been in Stockholm before or are living in Stockholm, please let me know what are your favourite things about this beautiful city.
Stay tuned for Part 2 of my top 10 things to love about Stockholm!
--

Born in Vietnam, live in Sweden, love data analytics, yoga, travelling

It all began with a single goal: to make Stockholm my new home. However, I quickly realized that the key to achieving this dream lay in securing a job in the Swedish capital. With limited funds and a burning desire to make my migration a reality without draining my savings, I embarked on a relentless quest.
For seven months, I tirelessly scoured professional platforms like LinkedIn, navigating through countless applications and attending numerous interviews. But amidst the rollercoaster ride of hope and disappointment, I confronted a difficult decision: should I risk quitting my current job to focus solely on this pursuit? The financial strain weighed heavily on my mind, urging caution when it came to advising others.
Yet, from the depths of my own experience, I discovered a valuable lesson that would shape my journey forever‚Ä¶
Embarking on my migration journey to Stockholm, finding a job became the crucial first step in realizing my dreams without depleting my savings. For seven long months, I tirelessly scoured platforms like LinkedIn, submitting countless applications and attending interviews. It was a challenging period, as I had taken the bold step of quitting my job to focus on this pursuit. Financial strain tested my resolve, making me hesitant to advise others to follow suit.
However, I learned a valuable lesson: once an offer arrives, swift action is vital. Initiating the notice period promptly and commencing the visa application process without delay can help secure a smoother transition, avoiding the prolonged financial hardships I faced. By sharing this experience, I hope to guide fellow migrants toward a more stable and successful path in their own endeavors.
Let us start with the time I started the interview process. As an iOS applications developer, the interview process consisted of IQ tests, coding tests, and several rounds of interviews related to my tech stack and my 10 years of experience in the industry. The interview process started at the end of December 2022, and I was offered a new opportunity to work with them in the first week of February 2023.
With the elation of securing a job offer, I eagerly signed the employment contract, understanding that this was the first step towards my new life in Stockholm. Little did I know that the journey ahead would require additional support. My new employer introduced me to a reputable visa processing agency, a third-party partner entrusted with navigating the intricate procedures involved in obtaining a visa. (Note: Specific names of the employer and third-party agency have been omitted for privacy reasons.)
The first thing they asked me to do was to fill out and sign a power of attorney form so that they could handle the application on my (and my wife‚Äôs) behalf. We also provided several pieces of information about us to the agency, such as passport data and marriage certificates. We were provided with two control numbers for me and my wife, which would help us keep track of the process on their website. You can check the status of your application using your control number here.
After waiting for about a month, I was informed by the agency that the Swedish Migration Agency had approved our application! The next process was to get the work permit card from the Embassy of Sweden. In order to obtain this, we needed to submit our biometrics to the Embassy. I swiftly booked flight tickets to New Delhi, where the Embassy of Sweden was located. You can find the details of the Embassy of Sweden in New Delhi here. The allotted time for submitting your biometrics is between 8:30 am & 10:30 am IST.
A few tips for your visit to the Embassy of Sweden:
Once inside, you will need to get a token and wait for your turn. The whole process took about 10 minutes for me and my wife. Afterward, we returned home and patiently waited for someone to reach out to us about the arrival of the permit cards.
Two weeks later, I received an email instructing me to collect the permit cards from the Embassy. The process for collecting the cards was between 11:00 am and 12:00 pm IST, and it was a swift affair, taking about 15 minutes.
As soon as I obtained my permit card, I informed my new employer, and they promptly booked my tickets to Stockholm. The next week, I found myself standing at the airport, clutching my boarding pass tightly. It was a moment of reflection on the incredible journey that led me here.
Part 1 of my migration tale had been a rollercoaster of perseverance and uncertainty, but it was just the beginning. Little did I know that the real adventure awaited me on Swedish soil. With a newfound job, a promising future, and dreams that seemed within reach, I stepped onto the plane with a mixture of excitement and apprehension.
The next chapter of my story, ‚ÄúUnlocking the Essentials,‚Äù would take you on a journey through the practicalities of settling in Sweden. From registering for a personal number to navigating the intricacies of the banking system and embarking on the quest for a place to call home, Part 2 reveals the essential steps that awaited me in building a life in this beautiful country.
Join me as we unlock the doors to a new chapter, where dreams become reality and Swedish adventures await. Stay tuned for ‚ÄúUnlocking the Essentials‚Äù in the next installment of my Sweden migration blog.
I would like to express my gratitude to ChatGPT for its invaluable assistance in generating content and providing insights for this blog. ChatGPT is an AI language model developed by OpenAI, and it has played a significant role in helping me shape my thoughts and ideas throughout the writing process. I am thankful for the capabilities of this remarkable AI tool and the contributions it has made to this blog.
Dear Readers,
I would like to emphasize that the information shared in this blog, including the insights and experiences described, is based solely on my personal journey of migrating to Sweden. While I have made every effort to provide accurate and up-to-date information, please note that individual experiences may vary.
Migration processes and requirements can be subject to change, and it is essential to consult official government sources, relevant institutions, and legal professionals for the most current and accurate information regarding migration to Sweden. I encourage you to conduct thorough research and seek professional advice to ensure compliance with all applicable laws and regulations.
The purpose of this blog is to share my personal perspective and provide insights into my own experiences throughout the migration process. It is not intended as professional advice or a comprehensive guide.
Thank you for joining me on this journey, and I hope that the information I share can be helpful and inspiring as you embark on your own migration adventure.
Best regards,
Chandrachudh K

Celebrating the Unsung Heroes Behind Every Great Achievement
I visited Stockholm recently and couldn‚Äôt help noticing how much history fills the city.
I wandered through the Vasa Museum, then ended up at Stockholm‚Äôs City Hall, that red-brick landmark standing quietly over the water.
Inside, a guide led us through the halls where Nobel laureates have dined.
I stopped at the grand staircase, amazed by every curve and step. Ragnar √ñstberg, the architect behind it all, was known for obsessing over every detail, not for himself, but for the queen and her royal guests.
√ñstberg‚Äôs attention to detail was legendary.
He made his wife walk up and down different versions of the staircase until every step felt right. He wanted the queen, and every guest after her, to glide down without a stumble. But even as he worked for royalty, he never forgot the people who helped bring his vision to life.
His team ‚Äî the builders, craftsmen, and artists ‚Äî were honoured in a way that surprised me.
Instead of the mayor‚Äôs own bust above the office, you‚Äôll find the faces of these collaborators, a daily reminder that nobody succeeds alone.

Matein Khalid
My generation were teenagers in the late 1970‚Äôs and thus passionate fans of Sweden since Abba dominated the Top of the Pops (God, how I hated the ghastly Dancing Queen since every girl in high school thought this syrupy pop tune was written specifically for her!) and Bj√∂rn Borg dominated Centre Court at Wimbledon as the Men‚Äôs Champion until the trophy was wrested from him in 1981 in a five set marathon by the awful but brilliant American John McEnroe. As I grew older, I learnt to love Sweden‚Äôs amazing social tolerance and cosmopolitan culture, its democratic values, welfare state, its beautiful lakes, ancient cities and effervescent young women whom I met in my fave Hellenic beach resorts like Ayia Napa in Cyprus and Mykonos in the Greek Aegean.
However, in 2025, I have a special reason to love Sweden and it is definitely not the ugly furniture of Ikea my Gen-Z twins adore. The Swedish kroner has been the best anti-dollar FX hedge of 2025 and is up an incredible 17% in the last 6-months. As I expect the Trump Buckeroo to fall 20% before the Big Guy leaves the White house, I hope my Swedish kroner stash rises another 20% and offsets the already exorbitant cost of a Scandi holiday. Since I prefer the Med to the Baltics at any time of the year, why not revert back to the 1980‚Äôs watering holes in the Cyclades and meet nice Swedish people in the Scandinavian love shack rather than actually flying to Stockholm Gothenburg or Malm√∂.
Sweden is also one of the world‚Äôs most successful case studies in innovation and entrepreneurial capitalism, the reason Nasdaq‚Äôs Old World hub is in Stockholm. This $900 billion economy is one of my favourite countries to invest for the next 5-years as long as Putin does not invade Estonia and try to usurp King Charles XII‚Äôs role as the supreme war lord of the North with a blockade of the Baltics. After all, Putin is from St. Petersburg, a port founded by Tsar Pyotr Alexievich to fight the Swedish empire, the superpower of the North in the first decade of the 18th century.
This IT/green tech/export colossus is a goldmine for investors who love corruption free economies dedicated to innovation and talent, a natural for any refugee from Planet Dollar like moi!

Title: How to enjoy Stockholm without breaking your bank Part 3 ‚Äî getting around and my thought on Stockholm Pass.

Travel diaries, tips, foods, people and thoughts. instagram: #travelwithsara / #eatwithsata

Share
Worrying about getting around? getting to and from the airport? want to check out the archipelago but do not want to join an expensive tour?
Public transport is great in Stockholm but it is not cheap. On average, a single ride costs SEK35. As visitor, you can buy a 7 days pass at SEK315 (there are other options if you are staying for only a day or 2, check here for information).
The best thing about this card is, you can actually go to and from the airport with it without paying extra if you do not mind a slightly longer (like 20 mins) commute!
If you go to the train station, they will tell you you need to purchase a SEK120 ticket to go through (which is true). However, we were lucky enough to encounter a staff who is nice enough to tell us the alternative that saved us SEK280/pax (2 more lunches!).
When you are at SkyCity in the airport, go out (and down) from the escalator, you will see a bus stop, get on bus 583 (you can check their schedule here) and ride to the last stop at M√§rsta station. At M√§rsta station, you will get on the train that go all the way to Stockholm City.
The bus ride is about 10‚Äì15 mins and the train ride is about 30‚Äì40mins.
M√§rsta station is the end of the train line, so you can‚Äôt really get it wrong.
(photo credit: Brorsson)
Apart from going to and from the airport, you can also go to (some part of) the Stockholm Archipelago with your Travelcard which easily saves you hundreds of SEK.
Stockholm is made up of 30,000 islands (subject to dispute :P), and it is a large part of Stockholm Swedes‚Äô life to go to the Archipelago during summer/vacation. (To hide away and to not talk to anyone.)
If you want to do some island hopping, you can actually do it with the public ferry which is free with the card. Since I was there in autumn (and didn‚Äôt have time), I did not explore that. However, if you have any specific island in mind, you should check the website of waxholmsbolaget for more information.
It would be a pity to visit a city without seeing it from the water. If you do not have enough time to enjoy that, a short ride on the public ferry maybe a good way to do that. We took a short ride on the number 80. My only advice is don‚Äôt do it after dark. That‚Äôs what we did and we didn‚Äôt really see much.
Stockholm metro station is renown for its artistic decorations (you can see my Part 1 post for some picture and links to plan your trip ;)).
When we were in Stockholm, weather was not the best. With the card, we can easily hop on the train/metro/bus and kept ourselves from the rain.
You know what I think, a Travelcard is well worth it I will urge you to get it. You can get the card in the train station/convenient store in the airport.
Stockholm card is different from the Travelcard. It is a card that gives you free access/discount to paid museums, sights etc.. Different from visitor pass in many other cities, it does not include public transport (you need to buy a Travelcard) on top of that.
The card comes in 3 options, from SEK 595 (1 day) to SEK1295 (6 days). I ended up not getting it and not regretting it.
As mentioned in Part 1 of this post ‚Äî most of the museums have free hours, if you plan accordingly, you can easily save a SEK200‚Äì300; as for transport (which is the most expensive items on their list), the only offer they have is the hop-on-hop-off for one day. The route is basically covered by public transport, and Stockholm is a pretty walkable city without the rain.
Another draw back about thePass is that you can only get your money‚Äôs worth if you plan very carefully. Sometimes, you may end up just seeing everything but paying attention to nothing, not to mention the interesting thing that you might see if you‚Äôre not in a rush.
Lastly, when I took a look at the items, a few of them are very similar (tour around similar places), which you probably would not need to do them all.
The Verdict
I do not think it is worth it to get the pass, unless you are dead set to see all the paid museums (potentially giving up on some of the awesome free museums) and is very strategic about that.
Stockholm is not cheap, but definitely not crazy expensive like people say. I did not have a lot of time to research for the trip, and started looking when I was flights/commute, and I still managed to make the whole trip rather affordable. Doing my research, I found these blogs/site super helpful, hope you can benefit from them too:
And remember, Google is always your best friends and ready to help :)
Have a good time in Stockholm. Follow me here or on instagram @eatwithsara for more posts about food and travel!

Here at All About Capital Cities we aim to give you an overview of all the 196 capital cities in the world.
Stockholm, the capital of Sweden, has a history that spans over 700 years. It was officially founded in 1252 by Birger Jarl, a Swedish statesman who sought to protect Sweden‚Äôs interior from sea invasions and to control trade along the Baltic Sea. Its strategic location on 14 islands where Lake M√§laren meets the Baltic made Stockholm ideal for both defense and commerce.
The city quickly became a vital trade center, especially during the Hanseatic League era in the late Middle Ages. German merchants and craftsmen played a major role in shaping its early economy and architecture. In the 16th century, under the reign of Gustav Vasa, Stockholm became the political and administrative capital of a newly unified Sweden, marking the start of the Swedish Empire.
During the 17th century, Stockholm flourished as Sweden emerged as a European great power. The city expanded significantly, with grand palaces and government buildings constructed to reflect its growing prestige. However, this golden age was followed by a period of decline in the 18th century after Sweden lost much of its territory.
The Industrial Revolution in the 19th century revitalized Stockholm, transforming it into a modern city with railways, factories, and growing suburbs. It continued to evolve through the 20th century, becoming a hub for innovation, culture, and diplomacy.
Today, Stockholm is known for its beautiful mix of medieval and modern architecture, its progressive social systems, and its role as a leading city in technology, sustainability, and Scandinavian culture.
Stockholm is famous for its stunning natural setting, rich history, and modern innovation. Spread across 14 islands connected by over 50 bridges, the city is often called the ‚ÄúVenice of the North.‚Äù Its blend of medieval charm and cutting-edge design makes it one of Europe‚Äôs most attractive capitals.
The city is also renowned for its well-preserved Old Town, Gamla Stan, where cobbled streets and colorful 17th-century buildings surround landmarks like the Royal Palace and Stockholm Cathedral. Stockholm is the cultural heart of Sweden, home to world-class museums such as the Vasa Museum, which houses a 17th-century warship, and the ABBA Museum, celebrating Sweden‚Äôs iconic pop group.
As the home of the Nobel Prize ceremonies, Stockholm is a global symbol of intellectual achievement and innovation. The city is also recognized for its sustainability and environmental efforts, often ranking among the world‚Äôs greenest cities.
In addition, Stockholm has a vibrant food scene, cutting-edge fashion, and a strong tech industry, earning it the nickname ‚ÄúUnicorn Factory‚Äù due to its high number of billion-dollar startups. With its mix of history, nature, and modern living, Stockholm stands out as a unique and influential European capital.
Greta Garbo ‚Äî Iconic silent film actress of the 1920s and 1930s
Avicii (Tim Bergling) ‚Äî Influential electronic music producer and DJ
Alfred Nobel ‚Äî Inventor of dynamite and founder of the Nobel Prizes
Ingrid Bergman ‚Äî Oscar-winning actress (Casablanca, Gaslight)
Benny Andersson ‚Äî Member of the pop group ABBA, who were formed in Stockholm
Gamla Stan (Old Town) ‚Äî Historic heart of Stockholm with cobbled streets and colorful buildings
Vasa Museum ‚Äî Maritime museum showcasing a fully intact 17th-century warship
Skansen ‚Äî Open-air museum and zoo with traditional Swedish buildings and animals
The Royal Palace ‚Äî One of Europe‚Äôs largest palaces, still in official use
ABBA The Museum ‚Äî Interactive museum dedicated to the iconic Swedish pop group
Fotografiska ‚Äî Contemporary photography museum with exhibitions and a top-floor restaurant
Djurg√•rden ‚Äî Green island full of museums, parks, and family attractions
Stockholm City Hall ‚Äî Host of the Nobel Prize banquet and home to the beautiful Golden Hall
Moderna Museet ‚Äî Sweden‚Äôs top modern art museum
The Archipelago ‚Äî Explore by ferry or boat; popular islands include Vaxholm and Sandhamn
If you‚Äôre planning on travelling to the city then make sure you‚Äôve got some travel insurance in place. Our partner EKTA offer travelers health insurance for worldwide destinations for all travelers.
If you‚Äôre keen to visit soon, then head to Trip.com and plan your visit.

From Abidjan to Zagreb, Abu Dhabi to Yerevan, capital cities are great places to visit, whether for a weekend break or a longer stay.
