In 1973, there was a huge bank robbery attempt in Stockholm, Sweden. The robbers held four bank workers hostage for six days. On the sixth days, the police broke inside, trying to arrest the robbers and save the hostages but the said hostages tried to protect the robbers from the police. Later on, the hostages refused giving testimony against the robbers and they even started collecting money to defend them. Within six days of captivity, the hostages had started developing a deep sympathy for the robbers.
As a result, the incident in which captives start developing positive feelings for their captors was named Stockholm Syndrome. This intriguing and paradoxical bond between captors and captives was also found amongst prisoners of war and those being kept in concentration camps as well. But in time, it‚Äôs seen that Stockholm Syndrome is not all about literal captors and captives. For example; Stockholm Syndrome can be found between parents and children or spouses as well as in narcissistic relationships, which is the main topic of our article.
In what conditions do we see Stockholm Syndrome?
Stockholm Syndrome requires four important elements:
Judging by the first one, you might think that Stockholm Syndrome happening in a narcissistic relationship is very unlikely. You might feel like a narcissistic relationship cannot exactly be life threatening. After all, not all narcissists resort to physical violence. On the other hand, living with a narcissist can mean that your life is indeed in danger. This danger can be physical, emotional, psychological or spiritual. Besides, narcissists can throw violent temper tantrums when they can‚Äôt get something they want or when they‚Äôre losing control over someone (narcissistic rage). People on the receiving end of this rage (even if their partners have never abused them physical in the past) may find themselves fearing for their lives or well-being in general.
And the second case is about isolating the victim. Isolating the victim is a typical abusive behavior. In some cases, the victim can practically turn into a hostage due to being completely alienated from the outside world. And in some others, the victim avoids the point of views of other people when under the influence of feelings such as jealousy, paranoia and fear fueled by the narcissist. The isolated person fails to notice the abuse they‚Äôre being put through due to not being able to consult to other people, and they also feel like this small, artificial kindness shown by the abuser is all they have now so they cling to it.
Another reason is that the victim is unable to escape, or so they believe because they were convinced by the abuser. In the Stockholm robbery, it was found out that one of the hostages got a chance to escape and yet she did not. The reason to that may be the fact she believed she could not succeed, perhaps she was simply afraid of the danger this attempt might bring. In this situation called ‚Äúbehavioral despair‚Äù, the victim feels so hopeless that they resign to their fate. In narcissistic relationships, if the victim is financially abused as well, or if they‚Äôre in a relationship where there are children involved, they can be convinced that there‚Äôs no way out for them. And if the abused person also has a narcissistic parent, it‚Äôs quite likely for them to show signs of behavioral despair. Babies are dependent on their parents in order to survive. But when it comes to children who grow up in problematic environments where their needs are not met; the fact they feel dependent and not strong enough as well as the ‚Äúsmall favors‚Äù granted by their abusive parents every once in a while may cause them to develop a sympathy for them.
In our last condition, in order for the Stockholm Syndrome to emerge the abuser should display a certain amount of kindness. A desperate and hopeless person who‚Äôs already in a life threatening situation and utterly at the mercy of the abuser can start trying to rationalize the situation when they‚Äôre shown some kindness by the abuser. These attempts at rationalizing the situation may start with ‚Äúit‚Äôs not that bad!‚Äù and end in deeply positive feelings for the abuser in time. After a while, the abuser stops being a bad person in the eyes of the victim, they‚Äôre simply misunderstood and turned into what they are today due to certain circumstances.
At this point, the abuser clings to the exaggerated versions of the few good memories they had with the abuser and starts seeing them the way they want them to be, not the way they actually are today.
Reasons of Stockholm Syndrome
Stockholm Syndrome is a product and natural result of systematic abuse, and it‚Äôs practically a survival mechanism. People try to save themselves from dangerous situations with ‚Äúfight or flight‚Äù instincts. But running away or fighting it may not always be possible. If we consider the Stockholm robbery, the hostages cannot really overpower armed robbers, and their chances of getting shot are pretty high if they try to run away. As a result, the victim experiences stress and wants to protect themselves, but that doesn‚Äôt seem possible. Also, our brains and bodies are not fit for long-term and continuous stress. Therefore, eventually people tend to focus on the ‚Äúpositive aspects‚Äù instinctively in an attempt to reduce the stress they‚Äôre experiencing. This is practically something that protects them from going utterly insane and it helps them cope with the trauma. People suffering from Stockholm Syndrome have faced something so traumatic that the only way to reduce it was to do this.
The first instinct of the hostages might have been to pretend like they‚Äôre on the robbers‚Äô side in order to avoid angering them rather than ‚Äúfocusing on the positive‚Äù. They can try to please the abuser to avoid violence. In bilateral relationships, if one of the parties is prone to violence and sudden, aggressive outbursts; the other party may instinctively try to keep them satisfied just to avoid their wrath. But after a while, once the hope for escape has completely faded, this situation goes beyond just pretending and the victim can find themselves feeling a genuine sympathy for the abuser.
Long story short, when there‚Äôs no hope for escape and that there‚Äôs no other options (or so you think), you try to fit in and adapt to the new conditions in order to survive. Besides, once you embrace the abuser‚Äôs point of view, you‚Äôre no longer a victim. This situation makes one feel less inferior and more in control of things. As long as the danger of maintaining the relationship isn‚Äôt much higher than the risk a breakup might bring, it‚Äôs quite hard for the victim to acknowledge the situation they‚Äôre in.
All these situations serve the abuser well, because then they‚Äôve successfully created a voluntary victim. Especially for the emotional manipulators, keeping the victim completely under their control is not enough; they want the victim to be willing as well.
Despite all this, you might still find Stockholm Syndrome illogical. You might be having trouble understanding a hostage getting attached to their captor, or a child loving their abusive parent, or a person being unable to leave their violent partner. But do not forget that people who have suffered traumatic things cannot always make reasonable choices. Traumatic incidents are exceptional conditions and desperate times call for desperate measures.
What to do in order to get rid of Stockholm Syndrome in narcissistic relationships?
Breaking the trauma bond on your own might be too difficult, so it would be wiser to get psychological help if possible. You need to make sure the person you‚Äôre consulting to has enough knowledge and experience about narcissistic personality disorder, codependency and narcissistic relationship dynamics.
You need to cut all ties with the narcissist for good and follow the ‚Äúno contact rule‚Äù. In this way, you‚Äôll be able to establish yourself a safe zone.
And in relationships, you should always focus on the big picture rather than small details. These ‚Äúsmall favors‚Äù other people grant you may cost you much bigger things in the long run.

24‚Äì25 Sep remembered on 8 Oct
Writing memories is like racing with time. From the Hong Kong 18 days ago, to the Bangkok 16 days ago, to the Copenhagen 13 days ago, theoretically, I am catching up with time, but as I caught up, I found remembering what happened harder and harder. Shouldn‚Äôt it be another way around? Or just the memories of Sk√∂vde, as a new place, are replacing the old ones faster? Or simply, I am tired of remembering?
‚ÄúI arrived at Stockholm airport at about 0:30am, in the dark of the new moon, on the coldest day of the year. The Swedish officials had been notified of my arrival, and I had no travel documents on me. I did not use the Japanese passport to avoid committing the offence of forgery and waited for all the other travellers to clear customs before I went to the officer, telling them that I had no documents. A young officer guided me to his office to talk, and I cleared customs in about ten minutes. At the airport, Mrs. Gawell and seven or eight other members who were in charge of my case at Amnesty International came to pick me up. The temperature was -25 degrees Celsius, and they brought a jumper, long boots, gloves, a scarf, and a leather hat for me. They probably thought that I came from the subtropics, that I must have been wearing only a flimsy southern jacket. They insisted that I wear all of these things on the spot. I am sure that I must looked ridiculous. The police simply took my name and then asked me to return the next day back to the airport to complete the formalities. I felt that I was truly in another world.‚Äù ‚Äî ‚ÄúA Perfect Escape‚Äù by Peng Ming-Min
Here we arrived at a city without memories.
I had never been to Stockholm. This was my first time. I arrived at the Arlanda Airport in the evening. Since I was travelling from Copenhagen, I did not need to go through the border control. The public transportation was easy. I managed to reach the hotel smoothly.
The name of the hotel was Hotel Expo. It was slightly out of the city centre, around 30 minutes by public transportation. However, for someone who used to live in London, anywhere that can reach the centre within 30 minutes, is included in the concept of centre and considered convenient. In conclusion, I love the hotel, and I would recommend it to anyone who‚Äôs visiting, especially if you‚Äôre on a budget. It‚Äôs right in front of a commuter‚Äôs train station, √Ñlvsj√∂. (Like you can literally see the hotel as you leave the station.) I spent 1250 SEK for 3 nights. It was the friendliest price I found. What I booked was a single room with shared toilets. The room was small but with everything one would need, including a clean towel and extra movable spaces (unlike the room F and I stayed in Hong Kong). The toilets were clean and close to the room. My favourite part was the breakfast, which was included in the price. And not only it was included, it was fancy, with everything one could expect from a four-star hotel breakfast buffet ‚Äî various cold cuts, cheese, breads, coffee, juice, milk, yoghourt, eggs, fruits, oatmeals, cereals, jams‚Ä¶etc., I can continue listing. And what was crazier was that the gym on the ground floor was also included, that as a resident of the hotel, I could use it for free. Free laundry was also available. The surrounding environment was not massively exciting but convenient, with a huge supermarket, Co-op (I almost tried with my old British membership, wondering if it worked.), along with Subway, restaurants, bars, Chinese food‚Ä¶etc.
The checking process was slightly odd. The man behind the counter checked me in, but said I hadn‚Äôt paid for the room. I checked the booking record, and made sure that I had. And then he said, ‚ÄúOh, then don‚Äôt worry about it, I will check it again tomorrow.‚Äù That was it. He didn‚Äôt come back to me afterwards.
After my joyous breakfast the next morning, I started visiting my long list of places related to Peng or Hedin.
My first stop was Norr M√§larstrand 66. The seemingly ordinary address was where Sven Hedin used to live. The walls of the entryway were covered with murals of a world map, as well as a Chinese-style temple to honour him. I was dying to go in, so after taking some photos from the glass door outside, I decided to sit on the staircases, hoping to bump into someone leaving or entering. After 15 minutes or so, I realised that the day was not my lucky day, so I moved on to what was next on my list, Adolf Fredriks kyrkog√•rd, where Hedin was buried, with a 30-minute walk from where he used to live.
On my way there, I realised that I was in need of a toilet. This might be something to confess ‚Äî I believe that I had this ‚Äúpink bubble‚Äù filter when speaking of Scandinavia. I was imagining public toilets everywhere, clean and free, public Wifi, water cooler, power outlets, free at every corner. However, a free public toilet seemed to be harder to find than I expected. It was almost 11:00am. It took me a while until I found one, an isolated one on the street. It was free, so, hurray! However, it was not as clean and well-maintained as I expected. But well, that was on me. I am the one who chose to wear the pink goggles, and to be honest, comparing it with the ones in London or Paris, it was a tiny heaven on the street. I happily finished what I needed to do, and moved on with my day.
When I arrived at the Adolf Fredriks kyrkog√•rd, it was around 11:15am. I realised that the church was closed. (It was closed between 11:00am ‚Äî 11:45am daily.) Luckily, the garden, where the cemetery is, was opened. It was a small yard, with, I would say, a bit more than 100 tombstones as far as I could see, which means, it shouldn‚Äôt be difficult for me to find the one of Sven Hedin, especially him being a famous figure. I started to stroll around, one side at a time, one roll at a time, carefully trying to locate his name. Unexpectedly, I failed. I kept wondering why and how, thinking probably Hedin did not want me to find him, that probably he did not not approve of my project, or my criticism towards the concept of explorers and what he did.
Do you remember my internet drama? So, once I arrived in Stockholm, I changed my sim card from the British one to the Taiwanese one, and bought some credit so I can have internet access here in Europe. It was slightly more expensive than usual, so I decided that I was not going to use it unless it‚Äôs necessary.
After almost half an hour of trying to locate Hedin, I gave up. I sat down on a bench, turned on the internet on my phone, googling the images of the tombstone of Sven Hedin. From using the housing in the background as a clue, I found it. Turned out that it was covered by a van, the only car parked inside the cemetery. I stood in front of him, explaining the project, and apologising, hoping to have his approval. I told him that I am aware that I am not in any position to judge, and I know it was a different time. The project is not about him, not personally at least. Through talking to him, I started to ask myself why I wanted to do this project. What is it for? I suddenly realised that in a way, migration can be a privilege, even for the ones who were forced to. Peng had to escape, otherwise he would have been killed or imprisoned, but again, how many activists at the time couldn‚Äôt, ended up in jails or some random cemeteries in Liu Zhang Li. Refugees had to leave, but again, we all know that more of them didn‚Äôt make it. So, it‚Äôs a privilege, but it doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs not hard. It doesn‚Äôt mean living in a foreign place, learning a new language, facing unfamiliar environments is not something hard. If I can offer something, some sharing, some talks, so we can feel a little bit better, with our lives, with our choices, probably the whole thing would be worth it? That there could be some meanings in all these?
After talking to him, I looked at my phone, it was 11:45am. The church would be opened by now. I suddenly realised, probably he did it on purpose. If I found his tombstone easily at 11:15am, would I have the patience to sit for 30 minutes to wait for the church to open? I might have decided to move on with my day. Feeling grateful at the coincidence, I walked into the church. It was beautiful. I was the only visitor in the church, however, someone started to play the organ. Not sure if it was a regular performance, or the person was practising, it was magnetising either way. I found a bronze plaque dedicated to Sven Hedin on the wall. I guess probably that was the reason he invited me to come in. I also found a LGBTQIA+ friendly rainbow pin at the souvenir store. How sweet. I guess that would fit in the pink bubble goggle that I was wearing. After a short stay, I moved on to my next spot ‚Äî Historiska Museet.
I actually can‚Äôt remember why I put Historiska Museet on my list. I guess probably at some point I read something saying that part of Hedin‚Äôs collection was in the museum. When I arrived, I noticed that on Wednesdays, which was the day I visited, tickets were half priced after 5pm. So I decided to come back later.
Where I went next was the US embassy in Stockholm. This was where Peng applied for his US visa. Even though it sounds like an insignificant part of the story, he actually visited a number of times, detailedly remembered and documented in his book. It was also kind of the turning point for him to move on with his journey from Sweden to the USA. From what I found online, the one I visited should be the same one Peng visited. It was launched in 1955.
I was surprised when I arrived. I was expecting a house, or a building at most, like most of the embassies are. The US embassy in Stockholm took up the land of the size of a university campus, composed of buildings and a huge yard. And as expected, it was barricaded. I started to take photos of the entrance, and of course, caught the attention of the security guard. He gestured to me to go over in a friendly manner, and I believed it was time for me to play the innocent, Asian girl, the tourist card. I said, ‚ÄúOh, I am not here for anything. I just want to have a look, is it okay if I take some photos?‚Äù He gave me a positive answer with a smile. And without anything else to do, or could do, I moved on soon after.

Earlier this year I quit my job as the VP of Platform at SoundCloud and moved back to Stockholm. Working at SoundCloud was a hell of a ride which began back in the summer of 2009. At the time, I‚Äôd just graduated from KTH and was doing some work at Propellerhead. I was dreaming about starting my own company after falling in love with entrepreneurship during my time at SSES. Through SSES, I‚Äôd also met Eric who‚Äôs the SoundCloud co-founder and CTO. We have a lot of shared interests and became great friends.
Knowing Eric was a good reason to frequently visit Berlin where SoundCloud is headquartered. I fell in love with the city and was lucky to experience one of the legendary rooftop parties in SoundCloud‚Äôs first office. The team was starting to grow and eventually I got an offer to join. The opportunity was perfect; a chance to join a music tech startup I really believed in, work with people I really liked, and finally make the move to Berlin. We agreed over the phone on a Wednesday and started working the week after.
When I joined SoundCloud, we were less than ten people in a scrappy office and the whole company was doing daily stand-ups together. My job was to build relationships with other companies, mainly music software makers, and get developers to hack on our API. There was so much to do and so much to learn. I loved it and was so excited about getting stuff done that I was almost running to work every day.
We thought we were the coolest thing since disco, but in the beginning it was really hard to convince other companies to partner with us. After all, we were just a small startup from Berlin with rapid growth but uncertain future. However, sending thousands of emails, doing hundreds of calls, taking tons of meetings, and traveling to as many conferences as possible, eventually started to pay off.
As we got bigger, things got a lot easier and eventually we reached a point where we couldn‚Äôt even handle all the incoming requests from potential partners. I learned the hard way that it takes time to build good relationships and get people to buy into your ideas, and that timing is super important when it comes to closing deals, so you have to be patient and persistent.
Since I was doing partnerships with other tech companies, I traveled a lot to the US. At a certain point, we needed to establish a permanent presence in the Bay Area, and it was natural for me to make the move to San Francisco and setup our new office there. I was of course stoked about the opportunity to work in SF and get a chance to build a small office from scratch.
It took some time to get things in order, but eventually we got the paperwork sorted, found a great space, and started bringing on new people. I got to obsess with things like office furniture, culture (introducing Friday fika), finding the right people, maintaining the connection to our other offices, and evangelizing SoundCloud in the bay area. It reminded me how naturally passionate I am when I get to coordinate things and craft them down to the details. In the end, things worked out great and I‚Äôm really proud of having brought the SoundCloud culture overseas and established so many great relationships in the US.
Over time, we expanded the platform team and scaled up our efforts, and over time we managed to connect the vast majority of music apps and a ton of different web services. We launched partnerships with companies like Apple, Twitter, and Facebook, and created a big developer community who built hundreds of hacks on the API. I was also part of the management team and an active contributor to the overall company strategy work.
Starting a company has always been close to my heart, and as things were running smoothly in SF, I felt the timing was right to leave and build something new. I can‚Äôt help loving to build things from scratch and I‚Äôm constantly looking for new challenges. In addition, taking some time off would give me a chance to charge my batteries and think about my longterm goals in life.
I‚Äôm super proud of having contributed to building a such a great company. Building a startup is an amazing experience that I really recommend. I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs a better way to try and learn new things. I‚Äôve learned so many great startup lessons along the way and now I want to take that experience and create something on my own.
A massive thanks to Alex and Eric for giving me the opportunity to support their mission and the freedom to do a great job, and to all the awesome people I‚Äôve worked with along the way! I‚Äôve had so much fun and learned so much.

Before I go on with these holy thoughts, I must mention ‚Äî Everything in KFC is overpriced. I think they are doing child trafficking for the chickens they serve their customers. So small, you start to wonder if they even allowed the chicken to walk before cooking it.
I even battled a bit of food poisoning in the end. What a way to start the week.
That said, if we stretch it far enough, it‚Äôs not hard to see how the whole Stockholm Syndrome narrative could be pushed into some rather unholy territory. I find myself thinking about how people grow up loving the very parents who used to beat the living daylight out of them.
If you‚Äôll allow me the looseness, it doesn‚Äôt feel like a huge leap to draw a parallel with those who stay in abusive relationships, covering bruises with excuses and clinging to the people who hurt them.
Few things unsettle me more than watching a person tenderly unpack the logic behind getting brutalized by the very hands that claim to love them. It feels like a kind of demonic possession ‚Äî something ancient, cruel, and crawling beneath the skin. And if we‚Äôre ranking horrors, this one isn‚Äôt coming in second.
I think it's Stockholm Syndrome, just nuanced a little.
I‚Äôm beginning to understand that there are some gentle themes to healthy living, and it‚Ä¶

Title: Itinerary for a long weekend in Stockholm, Sweden
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Home to the famous pop band ABBA and furniture giant IKEA, Stockholm is the second most visited Nordic country. Built across fourteen islands, the city is known as Europe‚Äôs first ‚Äúgreen‚Äù capital and boasts the longest life expectancy on the continent. ‚ÄúFika‚Äù, the afternoon tradition of indulging in a coffee and pastry break, might also be contributing to the high life expectancy. Be sure to participate in this ritual during your time in Sweden.
This guide outlines a possible itinerary for a long weekend in the city. Below is a quick overview of the proposal:
Most US phone companies do not enable free European service. Check with your phone company before leaving to confirm your plan‚Äôs allowance.
Debit/Credit Cards are widely accepted everywhere. I never used cash. No need to take out any Swedish kronor (SEK), but if you feel so inclined, visit your local bank before you leave to get the best conversion rates.
It is important to note that Sweden (along with all of the Nordic countries) is an expensive country to visit, so plan to spend more here than other places in mainland Europe.
Stockholm experiences mild annual temperatures, with lows in the winter around 30 degrees Fahrenheit and highs in summer around 70 degrees. Its sunlight hours, however, are more interesting. During the winter, the sun rises around 9am and sets just after 3pm, making it a long, dark span of months. The summer is drastically (and thankfully) different, with the city averaging around nineteen hours of sunlight per day. Unless you plan to visit up north for winter activities, visit Stockholm from May through September for ideal temperatures and light.
The city offers numerous hotel, Airbnb, and hostel accommodations based on price. STF af Chapman & Skeppsholmen Hostel is a budget friendly, clean hostel on a quieter island conveniently in between Gamla Stan and Djurg√•rden (the museum island, as I affectionately call it). Instead of walking (which is still very convenient), take the Skeppsholmen ferry that leaves every twenty minutes to visit main points of interest.
Gamla Stan, the old town section of the city, is another great area to stay in. The Collector‚Äôs Lady Hamilton Hotel in this neighborhood is a Victorian-style hotel with modern updates. In addition, Hotel Tegnerlunden is an affordable option in the Norrmalm District, a busy downtown neighborhood home to many iconic landmarks.
To get from the Arlanda Airport to downtown (near Gamla Stan), skip Uber and take the Arlanda Express. Purchase a ticket at the airport for $27 USD one way and arrive at the Stockholm City stop within twenty minutes. The ride includes WiFi and clean bathrooms. A walk to Gamla Stan from there takes another ten minutes.
Once in the city, utilize the SL ferries for an easy and quick system that locals and tourists alike enjoy. Purchase a ticket at every ferry station for less than $2 USD one way. Walking between each island via bridges tends to take time, so this is a better option, especially when going from Gamla Stan to Djurg√•rden.
We got lazy and ended up Ubering to further neighborhoods like Sodermalm from our hostel (with prices averaging that of mainstream US cities). However, we wish we had taken advantage of the metro system. Clean and accessible, it holds the title of the ‚Äúworld‚Äôs longest art gallery‚Äù so I‚Äôm kicking myself for skipping it.
Start your day with fresh squeezed orange juice and a deliciously lite breakfast at Caf√© Schweizer in old town Gamla Stan. This neighborhood is one of the best preserved historic districts in Europe, so take your time sipping coffee while wandering the cobblestone streets in the early morning.
Next, experience a free walking tour to better understand the history of Gamla Stan. The guide will point out key points of interest such as the Stockholm Royal Palace, Stora Nygatan (a lively street with music), and the Swedish Parliament where environmental activist Greta Thunberg began her global protests. If time permits post-tour, stop by Tasty America for a good laugh at a large collection of the over-processed foods popular in the United States. This grocery store was both intriguing and embarrassing, as it really outlines the absurdity of American food culture.
For lunch, pop over to Restaurant Tradition to taste traditional Swedish and Nordic fare. The Hairy Pig, a pub, is another great option for good food and beer. Try the Swedish Meatballs ‚Äî you won‚Äôt regret it. If not quite hungry yet, take the ferry from Gamla Stan to Djurg√•rden and head straight to one of the most popular museums on the island, the Vasa Museum.
At only $18 USD/adult, this is arguably one of the coolest museums I‚Äôve ever been to. Vasa displays a well preserved warship from 1628 that sank twenty minutes into its maiden voyage, drowning all but thirty people out of its 300 passengers. It took 333 years for the Swedes to retrieve the ship from the bottom of the harbor. Visitors can now view the ship from four different stories, along with numerous artifacts and skeletons from the wreckage. The experience typically takes one hour. Do not miss this.
Stockholm has numerous other museums scattered throughout Djurg√•rden and the city in general that you could hit after Vasa. The Viking Museum showcases 9th century Viking ships and artifacts along with a Disneyworld-like Viking ride. The ABBA Museum, a well marketed but somewhat superficial excursion, outlines the rise and success of the famous band. The Nobel Prize Museum highlights key Nobel prizes and laureates. The one museum I would NOT recommend, however, is the Skansen Museum. Although it is the world‚Äôs oldest open air museum and is supposed to showcase Sweden pre-industrial era, it completely lacks signage and guides to teach and clarify what you‚Äôre looking at. Skip this.
If you plan on visiting several museums, consider purchasing the All-Inclusive Stockholm Pass which will give you discounts and ‚Äòfree‚Äô access to many city landmarks and galleries.
End the evening with dinner at Restaurang Kryp In back in Gamla Stan for more traditional Swedish fare and a great espresso martini. Then, head to Winstrom‚Äôs Pub or O‚ÄôConnell‚Äôs Irish Pub for drinks and live music.
Stockholm is home to a massive archipelago with over 24,000 islands. These island chains create plenty of options for fun day trips. Stora Fj√§derholmarna, Grinda, and Vaxholm are all small islands within a 90 minute boat ride from the main city center.
I had a really hard time determining which island to visit. Stora Fj√§derholmarna is charming and only thirty minutes by boat, but does not allow one to truly experience life deep in the archipelago. Grinda takes approximately 90 minutes and has gorgeous views with many adventure sports to take part in, including kayaking and swimming. I‚Äôm a bit regretful that we didn‚Äôt stop here. The island we did select, however, was Vaxholm and I am both happy and disappointed in our choice.
Considered the capital of the archipelago, Vaxholm is known for idyllic roads and quaint fisherman cottages. To get there, choose from one of two main ferries. The cheapest option utilizes the public ferry, Waxholmsbolaget. Located next to the Grand Hotel and operating year round, the ferry does not allow pre-purchasing tickets so simply purchase on arrival. The trip lasts an hour or so.
The second option, and the one we selected, involves the Cinderella ferry and a history tour. With a restaurant, bar, and guided cruise, this ferry is a bit nicer and lasts approximately 90 minutes each way. It leaves from a different location (Strandv√§gen berth no 14) and only runs from May through September. If planning to visit Vaxholm and appreciate history, choose this option.
One can also drive or bus to the town as there is a small bridge connecting it to the mainland ‚Äî but you‚Äôd be remiss to skip exploring the archipelago via water.
On land, explore the little town for an hour or two with its boutiques and waterfront parks, especially Johannesbergsparken. When ready for food, indulge in a tasty burger on the docks at Winbergs K√∂k & Bar or down the road at Vaxholms Hembygdsg√•rds Caf√©. The latter was closed when we visited, but we stopped by to sit on the picnic tables and enjoy the view. I would have loved to eat here ‚Äî the location was idyllic and the menu looked delicious.
If you have time, take a quick water taxi to the Vaxholm Fortress Museum, a site that was once the Citadel for Swedish defense in the 19th century.
My day trip to Vaxholm was great, though I wonder what it would have been like to explore a different island with perhaps more to do. The tour allowed for four or five hours on the island, which was too much for what the island offered for activities. I would have preferred to take the Cinderella ferry there for the history and the public ferry home so we could have returned faster and on our own time.
Alternatively, discover additional island tours through Get Your Guide or simply get out on the water with a RIB tour.
Once back in Stockholm, spend the rest of the evening exploring Norrmalm, a modernized downtown neighborhood next to Gamla Stan. Be sure to walk through Kungstr√§dg√•rden, the city‚Äôs oldest park, and H√∂torgshallen, a local food market. Grab drinks at the Lydmar Hotel outdoor pop up bar, then dine alongside locals at Restaurant 1889 Fast Fine Pizza. Known for its ritzy decor yet laid back atmosphere, this restaurant simplifies ordering with a QR barcode and no true waitstaff.
Spend the last day in Stockholm choosing from a handful of excursions:
Regardless of what you decide, enjoy the afternoon/evening in Sodermalm, the ‚ÄúBrooklyn‚Äù of Stockholm. Visit S√∂derhallarna, a modern shopping hall with gourmet food stalls and restaurants, or try Mosebacketerrassen, a beer hall with gorgeous views of Stockholm‚Äôs skyline. Skinnarviksparken, a park with hills overlooking the city, is another great place for views and people watching. For a casual dinner, head to gastro-pub Honey Honey. We visited during the Eurovision competition and had a great time watching countries compete while chowing down on pork schnitzel and Swedish meatballs with lingonberry sauce. Later, stop by H√§ktet for lively drinks with a younger crowd.
After four nights in Stockholm, my next stop was Helsinki, Finland. I purchased a one way flight for $200 USD that was quick and easy. However, I wish I had taken the overnight ferry with either Viking Line or Tallink Silja that would have allowed me to see more of the archipelago and saved the cost of a hotel for a night.
For suggestions on nearby Helsinki, Finland, visit my post here.

The first museum I visited in Stockholm (I am a museum enthusiast) is the Nordiska Museum, also known as the Nordic Museum, located in Djurg√•rden, an island in central Stockholm. This museum mainly displays the traditions and lifestyle of Scandinavians from the 16th century. It has over one and a half million pieces! The exterior of the museum is fascinating. It was designed in the Dutch-Danish Renaissance style by Isak Gustaf Clason. Founded in the late 19th century by Artur Hazelius, a Swedish scholar and museum director, who also founded the Skansen open-air museum in Stockholm.
üí∞Free admission with Go City Pass
Regular admission: SEK 170 by 2024 and free admission for children
Opening Time: Almost open every day, even on Christmas from 10:00‚Äì17:00
Once you enter the museum, get your tickets with your Go City Pass and you will see an enormous sculpture of King Gustav Vasa. Gustav Vasa (born Gustav Eriksson of the Vasa noble family, also called Gustav I) was King of Sweden from 1523 to 1560 and the founding father of Sweden. He brought Protestantism to Sweden and outmaneuvered the power of the Catholic Church. Every year on the 6th of June, Gustav‚Äôs name day, is celebrated as the Swedish national day to honor the electron of King Gustav Vasa.
Besides the sculpture, there are multiple exhibitions you can explore in the museum including:
The Arctic (Arctic Traces: Nature and Culture in Motion), exhibits the tools used in the Arctic and how people have lived in the Arctic through the years. It also brings up the topic of climate change and global warming. Notably, this exhibition is based on 3 years of research under Lotten Gustafsson Reinius, a visiting professor at Stockholm University.
On the right side of the lobby, you can see another exhibition: Strinderg vs. Youssef. It was created by an artist Daniel Youssef with inspiration from August Strindbuerg‚Äôs autobiographical novel Inferno. Inferno was written in French from 1896 to 1897. The book talks a lot about Strindberg‚Äôs obsession, e.g. occultism, alchemy, and shows signs of paranoia. The story behind the exhibition is interesting, but I am not going to lie, I indeed find the exhibition confusing and hard to interpret the display.
Worth mentioning that there are audio guides available in multiple languages for free!
Another exhibition is called British ‚Äî Ever So Nordic. It displays the Nordic fashion, clothes style, and lifestyle that was influenced by Britain. One exhibition that I found quite interesting is the ‚ÄúTraditions‚Äù located on Level 3. The exhibition constructs the scenes and details of how Nordics celebrate Midsummer, Christmas, and Easter, and the history behind it. Next to this exhibition is the ‚ÄúTable Settings‚Äù. Basically, this exhibition shows the interiors and the table setting from the 16th century to circa 1950, including coffee and tea parties, tables for aperitifs, aquavit, and banquets. (You can also see a ‚ÄúSwan‚Äù in the exhibition).
The last exhibition that I went to was on Level 2 (Lobby) right next to the Children‚Äôs Playhouse. It demonstrates the setting of a traditional Nordic family and most of the displays there are interactive. However, I did not see any description on the official website, but it is worth taking a look!
Before leaving the museum, go to the museum shop and see if there is anything that you want to get as a souvenir and maybe have a real Swedish ‚Äúfika‚Äù in the cafe on level 2.
Recommendation: üåüüåüüåü/ 5
A must for those who love Nordic history!

Title: That Day in Stockholm Still Stays With Me
Content:

Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--

I just finished my 5 km run. The sky was grey the whole time, but it didn‚Äôt start raining until the moment I stopped ‚Äî like the weather had been holding back, waiting for me. As the first drops landed on my skin, I stood there, catching my breath, and suddenly I was somewhere else entirely.
Do you remember that day in Stockholm? Outside the Vasa Museum, the first snow of the week had started to melt into rain. We didn‚Äôt have an umbrella ‚Äî of course we didn‚Äôt ‚Äî and we just walked, laughing at how unprepared we were. I was giggling the whole time, remember? It was my first time experiencing snow. I must‚Äôve looked ridiculous ‚Äî eyes wide, hands out like I could catch the whole sky. But you just smiled and let me take it in. It was cold, but you didn‚Äôt complain. I think we were too caught up in the quiet magic of it all.
I closed my eyes today in the rain, and for a second, I could feel your hand in mine again. That desperate little run we made, slipping on cobblestones, trying to find shelter ‚Äî we never really cared if we found one. Just being there, soaked and smiling, was enough.
I miss the way you looked at me like you wanted to say something, but didn‚Äôt. Like the silence between us held more than words ever could. I miss how we didn‚Äôt need to explain anything. Everything felt full already.
It‚Äôs strange how the body remembers. A cold wind, a wet sleeve ‚Äî and suddenly I‚Äôm there again, with you.
Where are you now? Are you somewhere it‚Äôs raining too?
Always,Me

Title: 6 months of working at a Stockholm based Startup.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
If I have to sum up 2024 it has to be ‚Äòadventure‚Äô!
In the quest of making a pivot in my life, I made more than hundred new contacts this year. Every time I spoke with someone, I was looking for a match of vibration. And it actually worked like a story!
I clearly remember the morning when I stood outside a building in central Stockholm, inquisitive about what to expect in the meeting that was about to happen. The door opened, I was welcomed in. A nice lounge, then a kitchen with bananas on a plate. I asked if I can have one. I ran in the morning after breakfast and was exhausted of energy. The urge to have a banana overpowered my self-consciousness. Exchanging a few more sentences, it felt like here I am welcome to be who I am. It was encouraging to leave self-consciousness at the door.
The interaction with a group of people running this new AI firm was particularly positive. I met them again in a few days and it felt like they are brimming with passion to make something work. They have just started a venture and they are looking for someone sharing the vision. And it felt good.
They were fast, it took 3 weeks from the first meeting to the decision. They said this was one of the longest process! I had many questions in my mind, but positivity the company protruded overpowered it all. I matched their vibe, I felt genuinely welcome. The CTO promised me a laptop by the end of my first day. Little did I know that he literally meant it, in the evening while I was out running, I got a call from him, he was standing outside my door.
Working at an AI startup means quite a lot of new information to process everyday by everyone. We don‚Äôt have time to sit an ponder over frictions. We chase a common goal and try to resolve issues fast, that means talking more, opening up and showing earnest interest in the goals, finding what will make it work without triggering each other. Feedback loops are faster, tighter and effective. We are always learning and sharing.
There is a high intensity of external communication. We reach outs to people across the industry, write articles, active on social media, give credit to one another. My colleagues were happy to act as photographers, editors and writers to engage with the public, creating a strong thought leadership that draws visitors to our website without any external marketing help. And we pick up the phone and call! We gather most of our leads through our contacts, we make sure to present ourselves as who we are and present the strong determination to make AI agenda work, and our enthusiasm is contagious. There is a touch of genuinity in our proposals, we are a young company, innovative, ready to work, flexible. And we keep those promises that we make. No BS.
Some days are full of self doubt, prospects disappear suddenly, makes one feel small. The internal chat channels are saviors, its a lively space with messages, memes and regular business updates. We keep track of each other, not chasing hours, rather than putting in efforts to collaboratively build the brand. Its rare to have a day without a roller coaster of emotions from ‚ÄòYayyy‚Äô moments to existential doubts. Our salaries includes a fat portion of ‚ÄòResilience‚Äô which is unmatched in numbers. And it just grows, and the best part it I can cash out in any situation of my life, the ‚ÄòResilience‚Äô is the best fund to invest in, it will be with me through thick and thin and will be passed on in generations!
A startup business requires scaling down on lot of aspects. Conferences are silent time eaters, the more you go, the more time you need to process the information and to realign the offset it brings in schedule is weighed by the impact it brings. We don‚Äôt ditch it altogether but we are extremely choosy on what to attend. Post work gatherings on the other hand are so exciting and lively! We look forward to it, take turns to organize, sit and talk passionately about our lives and challenges. The conversations fuels the energy needs for the next couple of weeks, reloaded with laughter.
Its been 6 months, the company has grown more than a 100%. Its a dynamic environment yet quite simple, non-pretentious. Everyone brings their own self at work, with their creativity and ideas flowing beyond their roles and titles. If you work at a startup or know anyone working at one, verify if my claims. I am all ears for ‚Äòadventures‚Äô !

Content:

Sign up

Following on from part one of my Stockholm trip at the Vasa Museet, this post reflects on my visit to Nationalmuseum ‚Äî Sweden‚Äôs museum of art and design ‚Äî and a conversation with Lena Eriksson, Head of Education.
Unlike my earlier visit to the bustling Vasa, this experience offered a quiet contrast. I met Lena on a Monday, when the museum was closed to the public. So instead of wandering the galleries, I had the chance to sit with Lena over coffee for a visit filled with insights rather than artworks.
Nationalmuseum is not just a museum, but also a government authority. Our mandate is to preserve cultural heritage and promote art, public interest in art, and knowledge of art. This mandate is set out in an annual letter of instruction from the Swedish government.
We want to put social development in perspective and be an active player in contemporary society.
This made me wonder: how different is a government-funded museum like this from a university museum? One key difference Lena highlighted was how shifts in government can directly impact priorities, including decisions around accessibility and entry fees. At the time of my visit, admission was 160 SEK (around ¬£12.50), free for under-20s, but with no concessions for older adults or disabled visitors. Navigating such changes with each new administration must be complex, especially when core principles like accessibility can shift with political tides.
Lena also shared insights into the museum‚Äôs education programme, which, like many institutions, focuses heavily on children, families, and schools. Their website features a dedicated page for families, with free studio sessions every Sunday, the Oculus Walk ‚Äî a self-guided family tour ‚Äî and Villa Curiosa, a playful, sensory exhibition designed to spark curiosity and philosophical questions in children.
Naturally, my own research interests led the conversation towards older audiences. I was curious about the museum‚Äôs engagement with older adults and community groups.
As is so often the case, Lena explained that while some great work has been done ‚Äî including sessions for people living with dementia, inspired by Meet Me at MoMA ‚Äî these projects are often reliant on short-term external funding. Engagement with older adults still isn‚Äôt widely seen as a core part of museum work, despite Sweden‚Äôs super-ageing population.
One standout project during the pandemic connected older adults in Sweden and Japan through creative online dialogue ‚Äî a beautiful example of how digital innovation can support inclusive, cross-cultural exchange.
Before wrapping up, I took a moment to check out Nationalmuseum‚Äôs accessibility information online. I was pleased to find it easily ‚Äî just one click from the homepage ‚Äî and even more impressed by the friendly, human tone of the opening message:
‚ÄúWe want Nationalmuseum to be open to everyone and are always working to improve our accessibility. If you have any questions or suggestions, we would be happy to hear from you.‚Äù
A small but meaningful sign that the museum is open not only to visitors, but to conversation and change.

Title: Exploring Stockholm on a Budget: A Winter Wonderland Adventure
Content:

Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
With my other daughters occupied by their own half-term adventures, I opted for a city getaway to Stockholm; the bargain ¬£29pp return flights played a huge part in my decision. When I‚Äôm on the lookout for affordable flights, I make it a habit to browse Skyscanner daily. Despite having to drive from the Midlands to Stansted Airport, the journey proved financially viable as we got cheap flights. Thanks to clear skies over Northern Europe, the flight itself was a mere two hours.
Stockholm in February unfolds like a fairytale, its cobblestone streets dusted with snow and its historic buildings adorned with twinkling lights. For travellers seeking an affordable escape, surprisingly this Scandinavian gem can offer a treasure trove of experiences without breaking the bank.
Embarking on a Winter Boat Trip
No visit to Stockholm would be complete without experiencing its beautiful winter scenery from the water. Despite the cold, a boat trip around Stockholm‚Äôs archipelago allows you to capture stunning views of the city draped in snow. Wrap up warmly and sip on hot beverages from the onboard caf√© as you, immerse yourself in the tranquillity of Stockholm‚Äôs winter wonderland.
Discovering Stockholm‚Äôs Cultural Marvels
Delve into Stockholm‚Äôs rich cultural tapestry with visits to its renowned museums, including the ABBA Museum and the Vasa Museum. Dive into the pop phenomenon at the ABBA Museum, where interactive exhibits and karaoke booths bring the iconic band‚Äôs music to life. The Abba silent disco was hilarious, and my daughter and I made lasting memories. For a more educational visit then, journey back in time to the Vasa Museum, marvelling at the remarkably preserved Vasa ship that sank centuries ago in the harbour on its first voyage.
Indulging in the Culinary Scene
Stockholm‚Äôs culinary scene offers something for everyone. Don‚Äôt miss the chance to savour meatballs, a Swedish classic, paired with lingonberry sauce and creamy mashed potatoes or fermented herring. I follow a vegetarian diet, but there were plenty of delicious alternatives available. From mouthwatering vegan meatballs to falafel wraps and the comforting tradition of Fika ‚Äî a hot drink paired with something sweet for a boost in cold weather ‚Äî Stockholm offers an abundance of tasty dishes that won‚Äôt break the bank.
Unique Accommodation Aboard the Red Boat Hostel
For an unforgettable stay, book a room aboard the Red Boat Hostel, a floating haven nestled in Stockholm‚Äôs heart. Enjoy cosy rooms and breathtaking views of the city skyline or tranquil frozen waters surrounding the boat. With its budget-friendly rates, the hostel is the perfect choice. Plus, it‚Äôs impeccably clean, cosy, and offers a fantastic buffet breakfast.
Embracing Free Attractions
Maximise your budget with free activities, such as the brilliant and informative walking tour of Gamla Stan, Stockholm‚Äôs captivating Old Town. Wander through narrow alleyways and picturesque squares as your guide shares stories of the city‚Äôs medieval history. The knowledgeable guides generously volunteer their time, so show your appreciation by tipping them at the end of the tour. Sweden is a cash-free society, even the guides accept card for their tips.
From exploring world-class museums to indulging in culinary delicacies and embarking on free walking tours, there‚Äôs no shortage of affordable experiences awaiting you in this Scandinavian gem. Pack your bags, wrap up warm, and prepare for a memorable excursion filled with culture, cuisine, and adventure. #stockholm #citybreak #budgettravel #wintercitybreaks #copysella

Title: The Stockholm Syndrome In An Abusive Marriage Is Real AF.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
4
Listen
Share
Because it strikes the chord between kidnapper and captor for meeting the needs.
The primal pangs of hunger are often the driving force of human bonds. Hunger for us, is more than growling stomach.
Maslow‚Äôs Hierarchy of Needs explains that a humans are motivated by five basic hungers.
a) Physiological hunger for air, water, food, shelter, and sleep.
b)Security hunger for health, property, employment.
c) Connection hunger for family, love, intimacy, friendship.
d)Psychological hunger for esteem, respect.
e) Metaphysical hunger for self actualization.
Being the head of the community vocational program designed for providing employment opportunities to girls, I‚Äôve come across some baffling cases of marriages. No matter what the degree of abuse, these women never fail to patronize their husbands.
After listening to few girls, I decided to take an inventory to write and see that NEEDS can be irrational and self-deprecating at times.
I talked to more than 10 women from abusive marriages apparently. And to my utter shock they were point blanc unwilling to walk out of the marriage because they thought that however barbaric, they were protected from outer terror-fueled world.
Besides safety, they had one more thing in common ‚Äì strong attachment.
Just like the victims of Stockholm syndrome. As they fell for their captors and develop a soft bond of connection with them. Because mostly the captors are the one‚Äôs who fulfill their basic needs like food and medicine and often physical intimacy when the require to process the trauma of being hijacked or kidnapped.
This is not very common, to fall in love for your kidnapper or captor but happens with people with low self esteem and history of abuse.
When I talked to these women, they were rude and said ‚Äì better worship one man than be a raw piece of meat to wolves out there.
One of the girl who‚Äôs hardly 25 years, told me that her husband after thrashing her hard, treats her with sex and restaurant food. After beating the shit out of her when she is in pain, he doesn‚Äôt allows her to cook food. Even takes her to the doctor for treating all the bloody bruises. In this situation when she is being treated so well, she thinks of him as an emergency God. Especially when there is no support from the family.
Psychologists says that terror-bonding and feeling empathy rather than rage towards your captor is the classic example of Stockholm Syndrome. It can also develop between abusive parents and children. Where the child may feel protective toward the parent and try mending the ways to keep the parents happy, unsuccessfully.
When I tried to educate these girls on the psychology of the syndrome, they were reluctant to understand.
As they feel that bonding with their captors( read husbands) after years of intimacy is their survival strategy and looking for normality within the framework of chaos and distress.
What‚Äôs wrong in choosing bad when you have the worst? Saying this one of the girl slaps her butt and walks off to stich a new pattern of dress she‚Äôs learning under the program.
Psychological abuse is much deeper than we can imagine. It becomes the way of life when the victims have never seen the other side.
Listening to some of the girls ‚Äì and coming from non-psychological background ‚Äì there were times I was compelled to see their POVs.
No financial independence and emotional part of the brains shackled tightly.
I believe in rewriting these narratives women needs exposure, life skills, and independence of all nature.
Education on self-esteem, respect. But on top of all education on self-discovery, non-reliance and then finances.

In January of 2019, I started at a new company, which has its headquarter in Stockholm. It was clear that I would ‚Äî at some point ‚Äî travel to the capital city of Sweden to pay a visit to the main office. The first opportunity for this was an internal two-day-workshop. There were several options for the date I could choose from. I decided for the Wednesday and Thursday directly after Easter. This way, I could do use the public holidays plus only two additional vacation days to have a ten-day-travel. Two of those days, of course, for the workshop. The remaining days were free for visiting Stockholm. But with eight days at disposal, I decided to spend the first few days (Good Friday until Easter Monday) in the Norwegian capital instead.
As my company also has an office in Oslo, the idea was to meet up with some colleagues for a coffee or lunch. What I wasn‚Äôt aware of is that the Easter days are used by the Norwegians usually to spend their time skiing in the mountains. So nearly no one was even in the city and my plan to meet the local colleagues didn‚Äôt work out as planned.
20.473 steps.
To get from Oslo-Gardermoen Airport to the central station, there are basically two options: the Flytorget express train (196 NOK; 22 min) and the regional trains operated by NSB (105 NOK; 23 min), such as the R10. I chose the latter. Due to the cancellation of the flight by EasyJet I had intended to take to Oslo, I had to travel a few hours earlier than planned. Which also meant to arrive more prior in Oslo. But as the hotel I booked only offered check-in from 15:00, I had to come up with something to kill time. Unfortunately, this also meant to carry my backpack around the city as well, weighing about eight kilograms. During my first walk through the town, I already visited the Munch museum, but the famous scream was not on display, unfortunately.
One of the things I usually try to do is having a walk around the neighborhood of my hotel on the first day. This gives me quite a good feeling about the area, and I can check out where I can get some snacks for the evening and more importantly: bottled water. It‚Äôs not about not trusting the hotels tap water. But when I‚Äôm walking around the city for sightseeing, I avoid buying food or drinks in places crowded with tourists, as the prices are a bit higher there. My recommendation is to walk the narrow, little side streets and try to take a different route each time. I usually start in a general direction and find the path as I go depending on which way look more appealing. This method will give you a better picture of the city, and you will find the restaurants where the locals eat. These typically serve good quality for more reasonable prices compared to the restaurants located directly at the usual tourist routes.
28.984 steps.
For the first full day in the city, I decided to book the Oslo Pass for 24 hours using their Android app, which was very convenient. This pass already included public transport. Using this, I took the bus 30 to the peninsula of Bygd√∏y for visiting the Viking Ship Museum, the Holocaust Center, the Norwegian Maritime Museum, the Fram Museum, and the Kon-Tiki Museum. The Fram Museum got built around the ship of the same name, which was used for polar explorations and the museum included many stories of exploratory expeditions for the north and south pole. All of the mentioned museums had excellent exhibitions and are also suitable for tourists as items are mostly labeled in Norwegian as well as English. I originally planned to include the Norwegian Museum of Cultural History while being in Bygd√∏y, but instead decided to take the ferry back to the central city. After leaving the boat, I headed for the Akershus fortress, where I wanted to visit Norway‚Äôs Resistance Museum and the Norwegian Military History Museum, but both were closed for Easter. Continuing the tour of museums, I took a streetcar to Frogner Plass, to visit the Vigeland Museum about the work of sculptor Gustav Vigeland. Oslo‚Äôs city museum is just around the corner, displaying the history of Oslo or Christiania, as the city was named between 1624 and 1924. After I had to leave (as they were closing), I went back with the streetcar and having my last stop for that day, the Nobel Peace Center. This museum was designed very nicely and worth a visit.
After being afoot for more than ten hours that day, I arrived back to my hotel. Although I already knew there was a high rate of electric cars in the Nordic countries, I was still really impressed by seeing at least one Tesla in every single street. There were electric cars of other brands as well but less prominent. Furthermore, there are also quite a lot of electric scooters in the city. Problematic in this context is that they seemed to be allowed on the sidewalks, which I think is pretty dangerous. In fact, Austria just banned them from the sidewalks for this reason, and France plans to do the same.
20.236 steps.
For Easter Sunday, I booked a boat tour around the Oslofjord in the week before traveling. This tour lasted about 2 hours and might have been one of the main factors for my sunburn that I took from Oslo as a souvenir. This tour also included some facts about the buildings at the shores of the fjord and some local history. The Oslofjord is distinctive among the fjords of Norway, as it is one of the oldest, and was not formed by a moving glacier but being part of the Olso rift. After returning to the harbor, I headed to the Royal Palace, as the changing of the guard was going to happen at 13:30.
Although the park around the royal palace is quite lovely and open to the public, I went to Vigelandparken afterward, to see the sculptures, of which I had only seen the models in the museum the day before. I wasn‚Äôt the only one with this idea that day. The sun attracted a lot of people, who wanted to enjoy the beautiful sunny weather in the park. There were also some people around which seemed to me as they would be geocaching. And after looking at the map of caches around, I also started to visit some of them in the park as well as outside, while walking back to the city center. The downside was I got so distracted with geocaching, that I left my DSLR camera on a bench next to one cache. As James May would say: C**k!
C**k!
‚Äî James May
So I walked back the route I just walked as I was trying to remember when the last time was I had the camera in my hands. Fortunately, a Norwegian couple walked towards me, while I was approaching Vigelandpark again. The guy is carrying a DSLR camera around his neck. Hm, that looks exactly like the one I just lost. It even has the bubble level on it. Wait. Is that mine? It was. He handed it over and explained that they left a note where I lost it, stating they would bring it to the next police station. After having a short chat, I thanked them again, and we split up. As this was enough stress for one day, I decided the next thing I would do is to have a burger and a beer. For this, I stepped in at ‚ÄúThe Scotsman.‚Äù Like other Norwegian places, you have to get a table first, remember the table number, and then walk up to the bar for ordering. In the background, I could watch the Premier League, as Everton vs. Manchester United was ending, followed by Cardiff vs. Liverpool. A friendly way to end this day.
8.563 steps.
On Easter Monday it was already time to leave Oslo and get on the plane for Stockholm. Somehow, I thought my flight would take off at 10:30 in the morning. Therefore I tried to be at the airport at 9:00, which worked. But somehow I had the wrong time in mind, as my flight was actually scheduled for 12:40. Well, time to find a seat and continue reading my book. But first, let‚Äôs find a pharmacy to get something to treat my sunburn. As I don‚Äôt speak any Norwegian, I took some time and was switching between shelves back and forth. In the end, I settled for a product which seemed suitable and was small enough to take on the plane. At the cashier, I didn‚Äôt have to pay anything. I was confused. The clerk pointed to a sticker on the product, which explained (in Norwegian of course) that I just found an Easter egg. This kind of ‚Äòhide and seek‚Äô seems to be a common thing in some Norwegian shops. It reminded me of some chocolate hidden in the Akershus fortress I noticed when I was there two days before.
After arriving at Stockholm central station, I looked for a supermarket to get bottled water and some lunch/dinner to eat in the hotel. I found a coop with a nice salad bar. And as I was in Sweden now, I couldn‚Äôt resist buying about two kilograms of Swedish candy which I emptied over the next couple of evenings at the hotel.
26.940 steps.
As the hotel I stayed at in Stockholm is named ‚ÄúHotel with Urban Deli,‚Äù you can imagine that the breakfast you get here is not standard. Italian-style salami, fresh bread, fruits, yogurt, smoothies, a good selection of loose tea. There was nothing I missed and nothing I could complain about. Everything was fresh and of high quality.
After the great breakfast, I walked a bit around the neighborhood, without a specific destination in mind. While walking towards Gamla Stan, the old city, I came by the Mediterranean Museum. It has a broad selection of items from different cultures around the Mediterranean Sea, including Egypt, ancient Rome, etc. It mainly showcased the evolution of beliefs for life after death and corresponding funeral rituals. After a short stop for a chat and coffee at my company‚Äôs main office, I visited the Swedish Army Museum. Showing the history of the Swedish military equipment in the context of the timeline of wars Sweden fought.
As it was already too late for visiting the Swedish History Museum or the Royal Armory, I decided to have a short break at the hotel, before attending a 1,5 h guided tour through Gamla Stan. The tour named ‚ÄúThe Ghost Walk‚Äù explained some of the darker aspects of Stockholm‚Äôs history and was presented by a guide, who was loving his role and tried to send chills down our spines. If you do one guided tour in Stockholm, do this!
Combined: 13.259 steps.
Here it comes, the reason I planned to travel to Stockholm in the first place. A two-day-workshop about communication and personalities. There was a lot of input I received here and lots of things I have to recap after the travel. We were eleven people in this workshop including the facilitator, most of which Swedish. Apart from having fun during the workshop doing some role-plays, we also got to know each other during joined breakfast, lunch and dinner on both days.
17.878 steps.
As the workshop days were a bit exhausting, I started this day a bit later. The breakfast in the hotel was again a great way to do this. But I passed on coffee at the hotel, as I had an appointment for coffee with someone at the company‚Äôs office again. Even though this was during my official vacation days, I took to opportunity to have coffee with some colleagues I usually would not meet (as we work in different cities).
While walking to the Royal Palace, I already noticed military marching music playing somewhere. The royal music corps was already on the way to the palace half an hour before the changing of the guard would take place (scheduled for 12:30). I wasn‚Äôt the only one having the idea of watching this today. People flooded the area in front of the palace, barely being contained by a few guards to secure the ceremony would have enough room to take place. Although I didn‚Äôt understand a single word they said via the public speaker system, it was still quite a show to experience. As the same ceremony in Oslo didn‚Äôt contain a music corps, a comparison would be unfair.
One of the most famous landmarks of Stockholm is the city hall though, the Stadshus. The Nobel prizes are awarded here, except for the Nobel Peace Prize which we spoke of before. And there are also some geocaches around. After having spent the majority of the day in parks, I headed back to the office, where an event for new hires was going to happen including Swedish student‚Äôs drinking songs, occasionally interrupted by some 15-minute talks. Another opportunity for mingling with colleagues I usually wouldn‚Äôt meet.
26.420 steps.
All the things that usually would cost an entrance fee were left for today. Firstly, because I planned to use the Stockholm pass this day, which even gets cheaper if you buy it online and then use the QR code from the mail. Secondly, because of the Stockholm Kulturnatt. Between 18:00 and midnight, a lot of museums and other places were free to visit and offered special tours or exhibitions. But the first thing I had planned for this day was to take the ferry from Klara M√§larstrand to the Royal Domain of Drottningholm to visit the palace and its surrounding park which are part of UNESCO‚Äôs world heritage list. The richly decorated palace and its park are worth a visit. In contrast to my boat tour in Oslo, I was prepared with some sun blocker this time.
After arriving back to Klara M√§larstrand, I walked towards Gamla Stan to revisit the Royal Palace. This time also from the inside. With the Stockholm pass, I could directly walk up to the entrance without the need to buy a separate ticket at the desk located in a side wing. At the admission checkpoint, you will be asked to wear your backpack in front of you. I forgot to ask why. In nearly every room, there is a little sign explaining the purpose and history of that room, from bedrooms to audience rooms. As the monarchs introduced a few different orders of chivalry over the years, there are also some rooms dedicated to them. There is a room for the Order of the Polar Star, another room for the Royal Order of the Seraphim, and so on.
Maybe the most prestigious award in the world is the Nobel Prize. Apart from the Nobel Peace Prize, the Nobel Prizes are awarded in the city hall of Stockholm. In 2001, the Nobel Museum opened in Stockholm, which was the next place to visit for me. In here you can find the history of the inception of the Nobel Prizes and temporary exhibition about Martin Luther King Jr. who received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1964, one year after his famous speech.
The probably most popular museum in Stockholm though is the Vasa Museum. The Vasa was a ship built in the 1620s by order of Swedish king for demonstrating the great power of his empire. As he was continually changing his mind about the design of the vessel and demanding to include a higher number of cannons every time, the ship‚Äôs buoyancy was put in danger. In fact, after being hit by a mild gust, she sank during her maiden voyage while still being in the harbor of Stockholm. 333 years later, she was recovered, and the museum was built around her.
As the museums had to prepare for the Kultunatt, they all closed at 17:00. During the one hour wait for them to reopen again, I went to eat real Swedish K√∂ttbullar with mashed potatoes and lingonberries at Sj√∂cafeet. Afterward, I was fit again to continue with the Kultunatt, starting back at the Vasa Museum, as I didn‚Äôt manage to see everything on the first visit. Of course, there was quite a queue for the museum building up. On the same island, there is also the Spritmuseum showcasing alcoholic beverages in the context of culture and society. It also included a temporary exhibition about food consumption and consumer behavior in general. Just a few meters further, the Nordic Museum waited to be visited, showing the history of Swedish culture. The focus for the Kulturnatt was put on how Swedish people dressed throughout the decades.
4.500 steps.
Two days before, I coincidentally read a mail from SAS stating that strikes might occur due to ongoing negotiations with their pilots. As my flight wasn‚Äôt booked with SAS directly, but via a travel agency, I had to talk to them for asking what was going to happen now. But my flight was not officially canceled yet. So I had to wait. On the next day, I rechecked the status of my flight and saw that it was canceled now. After talking to the agency again, they couldn‚Äôt book an alternative flight for me, for organizational reasons. So I had to see for myself how I would be traveling back home. I found a flight operated by a company I never heard of before, with a stop in a city I have never heard if before. And I started at Stockholm Bromma Airport now, instead of Arlanda, which in the end didn‚Äôt make any difference in my travel time though. But the 2,5 h stop in V√§xj√∂ did.
Unfortunately, the V√§xj√∂ Sm√•land Airport didn‚Äôt have a transit area, so after having walked from the aircraft to the airport building, I was already out of the security area. So I had to go through another security check for getting to the gate. THE gate. There was exactly one. As only five flights departed from that airport in total on that day, they don‚Äôt need more. It‚Äôs the smallest international airport I ever visited. But it was relaxing as well. I used the time to continue the book I was reading, and soon enough it was time to board the same aircraft again for the flight to Berlin. In the end, I landed safely at Berlin-Tegel Airport and was happy to be back home.

Title: Research trip: Stockholm, part four‚Äî ArkDes and Moderna Museet
Content:

So, it‚Äôs taken a bit of time to get this blog up‚Ä¶ but, in this forth blog post in my #StockholmSeries, I reflect on visits to two neighbouring museums in Stockholm ‚Äî ArkDes and Moderna Museet‚Ä¶
I came across ArkDes ‚Äî the Swedish Centre for Architecture and Design ‚Äî while I was exploring places to visit on this research trip.
I saw that ‚ÄúAdmission to ArkDes is free throughout 2025‚Äù which was fantastic, but I was also really intrigued by a project they‚Äôre running ‚Äî Unboxing, which runs every day for two hours enabling you to meet and chat to one of the museum‚Äôs curators.
Unboxing is the place where you, together with the museum‚Äôs curators, unpack and explore never-before-seen items from the museum‚Äôs underground archives.
I was interested by the concept of bringing the collection into a different space, giving visitors the opportunity to see behind the scenes, and the museum‚Äôs commitment to this being available to everyone, everyday. It blurred the line between exhibit and experience‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa quiet but clever way to shift how people relate to the space.
I went straight to the space, which was easy to navigate to from the front of the gallery. Unboxing provides the opportunity for the museum to engage with visitors in a different way, gives curators the chance to talk about their passion, and for visitors to experience objects from the collection‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfor me, this was seeing architectural drawings‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääin a different way.
Next door at Moderna Museet, the invitation to engage was everywhere: tables with drawing paper, sketchbook stations, scattered books and varied seating. Each space offered a different kind of welcome, always with a gentle prompt to pause, reflect or create. I loved the moments of rest‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääespecially a bench by a floor-to-ceiling window tucked behind a door marked ‚Äústaff only‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääan unintentional but beautiful in-between space.
I also met with staff from both museums, who spoke about the challenges (and small wins) of increasing access and inclusion, from updating signage to navigating funding and policy shifts. It was a reminder that innovation doesn‚Äôt always come from big gestures ‚Äî it often lives in the details.
