Stockholm. A city I had heard of since childhood.
I associated its name with major international agreements, particularly the Stockholm Declaration of 1972 ‚Äî the very first large-scale world conference to make the environment as a major global issue. It marked the beginning of international environmental governance and laid the foundation for what would later become the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). This conference shaped the world‚Äôs approach to sustainability and climate action, yet I never imagined that one day, I would walk its very streets where such historic discussions took place.
Never in my wildest dreams did I think I would experience this city firsthand. It still feels surreal that I am here.
What struck me the most when I arrived was the contrast ‚Äî the weather, the atmosphere, the way of life. Coming from Indonesia, where temperatures soar to 35¬∞C with high humidity, adjusting to Stockholm‚Äôs crisp air and freezing winters was a challenge. Even in summer, I find myself trembling while Swedes enjoy the sunshine in shorts and tank tops. The shift from tropical heat to below-zero temperatures was an entirely new physical adjustments and rhythm of life.
But despite the cold, I fell in love with this city. There is a sense of calm, an unspoken rhythm that blends modernity with nature. Stockholm moves at its own pace ‚Äî not too fast, not too slow.
And then, there‚Äôs Fika ‚Äî the Swedish tradition of taking a break over coffee and pastries. At first, I thought it was just a casual coffee break, but I soon realized it‚Äôs much more than that. It‚Äôs a moment of pause, of connection, of simply being present. In a world that constantly pushes us to be productive, Fika is a reminder that it‚Äôs okay to slow down. This ties into something else I admire about Sweden ‚Äî their emphasis on work-life balance. Here, taking a break is not seen as laziness but as an essential part of life. People respect their time off, and there is an understanding that rest is just as important as work.
The other thing that fascinated me was the language. The moment I heard Swedes casually chatting in their melodic Swedish, I felt a strange excitement. It was unfamiliar yet intriguing.
But, beyond the language, what truly inspires me about Sweden is its commitment to sustainability. Swedes don‚Äôt just talk about being environmentally friendly; they integrate it into their daily lives. Recycling, efficient public transport, and waste reduction are not just trends but ingrained habits. It‚Äôs no surprise that the world‚Äôs first environmental conference was held in Stockholm in 1972, leading to the establishment of the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP).
One of the biggest realizations I had was about landfills. My perspective on landfills was shaped by what I had seen in Indonesia, where waste management remains a major challenge. Landfills there often emit a strong odor, appear overwhelming, and lack proper handling. But here, it feels different ‚Äî the landfill doesn‚Äôt smell as strong, the area is well-managed, and waste is systematically processed.
I also learned a lot about organic waste. If we truly want to combat climate change, organic waste should never end up in landfills. Food waste releases methane, a greenhouse gas many times more potent than carbon dioxide. This realization made me see how small actions ‚Äî like composting or waste sorting ‚Äî suddenly felt much more significant.
Living in Stockholm has made me reflect on many things. It has challenged my habits, reshaped my mindset, and broadened my perspective. I‚Äôve learned to embrace silence and to enjoy solitude without feeling lonely. I‚Äôve come to appreciate the power of simplicity ‚Äî how less can be more and how slowing down can actually bring more meaning.
Nonetheless, this is just the beginning of my journey in Stockholm.
‚Äî Fingers crossed for what the future has in store! ‚ù§
--
--
A wonderer and wanderer, exploring life and sustainability in Stockholm.

Report of the Go Global Mission to Stockholm (25 - 28 October 2017)
As an entrepreneur, it is important to broaden your perspectives and keep an eye out on the world, even more so in this digital world we live and work in every day. Hence, I was very excited to join the Go Global Mission to Stockholm, an organization of startups.be and Jong VOKA Oost-Vlaanderen.
Sweden has been an inspiration for me ever since I became involved with technology and startups. The country has an impressive track record: after Silicon Valley, Sweden has the highest number of unicorns per head of population in the world. Iconic companies like Skype (sold to Microsoft), King (the maker of Candy Crush, IPO), Mojang (the company behind Minecraft, sold to Microsoft) and Spotify (you know Spotify), have all been founded in this Nordic country.
How is this possible? What are the reasons behind Sweden‚Äôs overwhelming success? Is this story future proof? 3 days in the country‚Äôs lovely capital Stockholm would provide all the answers.
A 2 hour flight from Brussels led us to Bromma, a cozy airport about 20 minutes from downtown Stockholm. Hard to imagine this is the main entrance to a European capital where so much value has been created over the past decade.
First stop on our trip was the Stockholm Fintech Hub, a huge co-working space located conveniently above Stockholm‚Äôs central train station. Besides the fancy decoration, I noticed a couple of interesting things here:
Off to a good start!
Our visit to Invest Stockholm gave us a lot of insights on the success of Stockholm. The seeds of the Swedish tech boom were planted in the 90s, when the government subsidized the required infrastructure for the digital age.
First, every household in Sweden was granted a personal computer. Every successful tech entrepreneur of today grew up with a PC! Digital natives avant la lettre.
Second, almost every household in Sweden has fiber internet access. Hard to imagine in Belgium, where to this day the public and private sector are still arguing who is going to make the required investments.
It is clear that government initiatives in the nineties have laid the foundations for the incredible success of the past decade.
The impact of these exits cannot be underestimated. As often happens with successful entrepreneurs, they do not rest on their laurels. After selling Skype, Niklas Zennstr√∂m went on to found Atomico, now one of the most famous venture capital firms in Europe. Same goes for the founders of King with their fund Sweet Capital.
As a result, there is plenty of capital available to invest in promising startups that might become the unicorns of the coming decade. Success often creates even more success. The future of the Swedish tech ecosystem seems bright.
Some (fun) facts about Sweden:
Day 2 started with the highlight of our trip: a visit to Spotify. The music streaming service has over 50 million paying subscribers and is valued at 16 Bio USD in the private markets. Even though it is still making a loss, it is reportedly preparing its long-awaited IPO for somewhere mid 2018.
Spotify is one of those iconic tech companies of this age. The company, led by the enigmatic founder Daniel Ek, has proven to be an exceptional innovator on multiple levels:
1) Business model innovation: in the wake of illegal P2P networks like Napster and Kazaa, Spotify sought to find a legitimate way to revolutionize the music industry.
2) Technical innovation: the secret sauce to Spotify‚Äôs early success was the incredibly fast loading of songs. This was an engineering challenge of enormous size and difficulty. The majority of people at Spotify are still deep tech engineers working to make sure load times stay at this amazing level, even at such a huge scale.
3) Organizational innovation: much has been written and said about Spotify‚Äôs organizational model. The concepts of autonomous teams (grouped in squads, tribes & alliances), the agile way of working, the flat organization, ‚Ä¶ have been widely documented and copied by other tech startups. Many attribute the success of Spotify to this special culture of continuous experimentation and improvement, cultivated by the founders from day 1.
It will be very interesting to see what happens to this culture when Spotify goes public. Not making a profit yet, investor pressure might force it to tighten reigns and start cutting costs.
Later, we paid a visit to Detectify, whose founder notoriously hacked Google and got access to a huge amount of customer data. He received a bounty of 10.000 USD and went on to start a successful company in ethical hacking.
I arrived at the hotel at around 10 pm. Having some energy left in the tank, I put on my running shoes. I really enjoy jogging in big cities. Since there is always something new to discover, you hardly notice you are running after a while.
I ran to the Gamla Stan island where I accidentally bumped into the changing of the guards routine at the royal palace. Quite hilarious and way over the top if you ask me!
This run wasn‚Äôt only for sightseeing, though. Last week, I decided I am going to run my first marathon in 2018! There you go, the word is out, no coming back to it now. I couldn‚Äôt really miss the second training on my schedule, right‚Ä¶
Day 3 started at Klarna, another Swedish unicorn, active in online payment processing. A couple of years ago, it also received a banking license. We got a presentation about the major branding exercise this company had undertaken earlier this year. The result was fascinating: from a dull banking brand to an extravagant colorful identity. Klarna wants to be a bank focused on the consumer‚Äôs experience, not on its own payments product. It definitely stands out in its sector with this bold and brave move I can only applaud.
Next stop was the Goodbye Kansas Gaming Studio. Stockholm has an enormous amount of talented gaming engineers, resulting in big hits like Minecraft, Candy Crush Saga, Angry Birds 2 and a host of other console and PC titles. We were told the long dark nights might have something to do with this.
Final stop was at EQT Ventures, one of the top tier venture firms in the Nordics. EQT Ventures is owned by Sweden‚Äôs wealthiest family, the Wallenbergs. Over the past century (!), the Wallenbergs have accumulated an enormous portfolio of global industrial players, including Electrolux, Atlas Copco, ABB, SEB, SKF, ‚Ä¶ to name a few. Add Volvo, Scania and IKEA to the Sweden‚Äôs list and you get a sense of how many successful international corporations this country produces. Same goes for its music industry: ABBA, Roxette, Ace of Base, Europe ‚Ä¶ and more recently Avicii, Robyn, Swedish House Mafia. Due to the small internal market, anyone aspiring a big entrepreneurial or artistic career just has to move abroad as soon as possible.
EQT Ventures is the venture capital firm of the Wallenberg conglomerate. Besides funding (with its 565 Mio EUR investment vehicle), it also offers active guidance to its entrepreneurs (growth, engineering, marketing,‚Ä¶).
EQT Ventures invests in scale-ups that have reached product market fit and about 100k MRR. It sweet spot investment size is between 8 and 10 Million EUR.
EQT gave us a demo of their internal data processing tool called Motherbrain. This platform gathers all publicly available data on technology companies (e.g. Crunchbase, Pitchbook data,..) and enriches them by adding trends in social media activity, number of followers, press coverage, ‚Ä¶ EQT believes this gives them a competitive advantage in discovering promising startups earlier and getting into deals faster.
4 startups had the opportunity to present their company:
The trip ended with a nice dinner in the city center of Sweden‚Äôs lovely capital.
My key takeaways from this Go Global Mission to Stockholm:
Looking forward to getting back into the action at Hyperlane on Monday, fully energized and inspired by 3 awesome days.

--
CEO & Co-Founder @ Hyperlane - Triathlete

Title: From Stockholm to Sinai: Jewish Conscience in an Age of Fear
Content:

This is not just a political reckoning. It is a personal one.
I come from survivors ‚Äî not only of the Holocaust itself, but of the moral disorientation it left behind. My father escaped Nazi Germany on the last Kindertransport to London. He later carried messages between generals after landing on Normandy Beach, speaking the languages of both the oppressed and the empire. My grandfather survived by finding refuge in Sweden. My lineage is braided with escape, resilience, and silence.
And now, I speak to honor them. To wrest history from the hands of fear.
To advocate for a universalist, justice-rooted Judaism in today‚Äôs climate is to invite pushback ‚Äî from within our communities. These pushbacks do not always come from cruelty. They often come from heartbreak. They come from those who believe they are defending Jewish life, when in fact they may be protecting Jewish trauma from healing and perpetuating animosity worldwide.
To walk into this conversation, we must understand the language of fear ‚Äî not to be manipulated by it, but to meet it with truth.
Here are five of the most common arguments used to reject a Judaism of shared humanity and prophetic conscience. Then we will reconstruct the machinery of propaganda as it is deployed, in order to disarm it with truth. Then a short and printable ‚Äúpocket guide‚Äù to help us return to our core teachings.
They are not caricatures. They are cries. And if we are to become the choosing ones ‚Äî not merely the chosen ‚Äî we must listen with clarity, respond with compassion, and never forget: Again and again and again, Never Again must mean never for anyone...for everyone.
Let us begin where our ancestors survived ‚Äî but refuse to end there.
Understanding the counterarguments made by fear-based ethnocentric voices ‚Äî particularly those within Jewish communities that resist universalist interpretations ‚Äî is essential for both refining your own position and preparing for meaningful dialogue.
Here are five of the most common arguments used by fear-based ethnocentrists to dismiss or dismantle the kind of covenantal, universalist Judaism I advocate:
1. The ‚ÄúSurvival First‚Äù Argument
Claim: Before we can worry about others, we must secure the survival of the Jewish people. We are always one catastrophe away from annihilation.
Key Points:
Response:
This argument exploits trauma to justify ongoing preemptive dominance. It conflates existential threats with political criticism and flattens time, as if Pharaoh, Hitler, and any current dissenter are interchangeable. It demands eternal victimhood even when Jews wield state or institutional power.
2. The ‚ÄúParticularism is Not a Sin‚Äù Argument
Claim: Every nation puts itself first ‚Äî why should Jews be held to a higher moral standard?
Key Points:
Response:
This argument deliberately ignores that Jewish ethics ‚Äî rooted in Torah, prophets, and rabbinic tradition ‚Äî do demand more. It erases the prophetic voice of justice. It also neglects the fact that being a light to the nations (Isaiah 49:6) is not optional in Judaism ‚Äî it‚Äôs core.
3. The ‚ÄúYou Don‚Äôt Understand Realpolitik‚Äù Argument
Claim: Your argument is philosophically interesting but politically dangerous. The world is not a yeshiva or a seminar. We must protect ourselves with strength, not sermons.
Key Points:
Response:
This response uses cynicism to neutralize ethics. It assumes power and moral courage are mutually exclusive. In reality, prophetic leadership has always been a countercultural phenomenon. Moses, Isaiah, and Heschel all spoke into power from a place of moral clarity, not political comfort.
4. The ‚ÄúWe Tried Peace, It Didn‚Äôt Work‚Äù Argument
Claim: We gave land for peace. We made offers. We withdrew. And what did it get us? Rockets. Stabbings. Terror. You‚Äôre asking us to endanger our children.
Key Points:
Response:
This is trauma talking ‚Äî but selectively. It collapses decades of failed diplomacy, settler expansion, and blockade into a single defensive narrative. While security is valid, it cannot be divorced from justice ‚Äî and justice requires that we confront the history we created, not just the history done to us.
5. The ‚ÄúSelf-Hating Jew‚Äù Accusation
Claim: Jews who criticize Israel or prioritize universal ethics over Jewish solidarity are internalizing antisemitic narratives. You‚Äôre aiding our enemies.
Key Points:
Response:
This is emotional blackmail disguised as community protection. It conflates dissent with betrayal. In truth, ethical critique is an ancient Jewish tradition ‚Äî from Abraham arguing with God to Jeremiah lamenting corruption in Jerusalem. To speak truth to Jewish power is not betrayal; it is fidelity.
If one were trying to design a manipulative, propagandistic narrative in support of a fear-based ethnocentric worldview, one would need to activate collective trauma, moral inversion, and identity loyalty. The goal is not truth, but emotional certainty, enemy construction, and justified power.
Here are 10 potent narrative devices ‚Äî some are outright lies, some half-truths, and all are repeated enough to feel self-evident.
They may sound familiar.
1. ‚ÄúWe are the eternal victim.‚Äù
No one has suffered like us. No one ever will. We are history‚Äôs permanent target.
2. ‚ÄúThey all want to kill us ‚Äî again.‚Äù
Scratch any critic, and you‚Äôll find a hidden antisemite.
3. ‚ÄúSurvival justifies anything.‚Äù
If we don‚Äôt do this, we won‚Äôt exist tomorrow. That‚Äôs just how it is.
4. ‚ÄúOur power is only defensive.‚Äù
When we act, it‚Äôs because we were provoked. When we strike, it‚Äôs because we had no choice.
5. ‚ÄúThere are no civilians among them.‚Äù
They are all complicit ‚Äî every man, woman, and child. They elected terrorists. They cheer death.
6. ‚ÄúWe already tried peace. They spat in our face.‚Äù
We offered everything. They gave us rockets. What more proof do you need?
7. ‚ÄúAnyone who criticizes us wants us destroyed.‚Äù
You say ‚Äòhuman rights,‚Äô but you mean ‚Äòour extinction.‚Äô
8. ‚ÄúWe are the West‚Äôs last line of defense.‚Äù
Support us, or terrorism wins. We are your moral outpost.
9. ‚ÄúWe speak for all Jews.‚Äù
If you oppose us, you‚Äôre not one of us. You‚Äôre self-hating or brainwashed.
10. ‚ÄúHistory has absolved us.‚Äù
After what was done to us, we‚Äôve earned the right to do whatever is necessary.
Repetition and Ritual
These ideas are not just said. They‚Äôre:
The Manipulation Goal:
Make it emotionally intolerable ‚Äî even existentially traitorous ‚Äî for someone to:
In case you want to have a conscious way to reject manipulation here‚Äôs a pocket-sized pamphlet ‚Äî concise, powerful, and portable ‚Äî designed to interrupt propaganda in real time and rekindle moral clarity when fear-based ethnocentric messaging is heard. Copy and print it and put it anywhere you want to remain a thinking and feeling human being, grounded in Judaism's highest teachings.
Spotting Propaganda. Reclaiming Conscience.
WHEN YOU HEAR:
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre the eternal victim.‚Äù
ASK YOURSELF: Is this invoking history to justify current harm?
‚ÄúThey all want to kill us.‚Äù
REMEMBER: Fear paints everyone an enemy. But fear is not truth.
‚ÄúSurvival justifies anything.‚Äù
TRUTH: Freedom without ethics is just a new kind of Pharaoh.
‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt value life like we do.‚Äù
DANGER: That‚Äôs dehumanization. The oldest lie used to justify violence.
‚ÄúWe tried peace. They gave us terror.‚Äù
PAUSE: Did we try peace ‚Äî or control disguised as peace?
‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs a terrorist over there.‚Äù
FACT: Blanket blame is genocide‚Äôs gateway.
‚ÄúCritics are antisemitic.‚Äù
NO. Ethics ‚â† hate. Dissent ‚â† betrayal.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre defending civilization.‚Äù
WATCH OUT: That‚Äôs colonial language. That‚Äôs empire talking.
‚ÄúWe speak for all Jews.‚Äù
YOU KNOW: No one speaks for all of us. Judaism is not a monolith. Never was.
‚ÄúHistory has absolved us.‚Äù
NEVER. No past horror gives license to inflict one.
INSTEAD, REMEMBER:
‚ÄúWe were slaves in Egypt‚Ä¶‚Äù Not to become Pharaohs, but to never be one.
‚ÄúYou shall not oppress the stranger‚Ä¶‚Äù Not once ‚Äî but 36 times. That‚Äôs covenant.
‚ÄúWe are not free until all are free.‚Äù That‚Äôs Judaism at its best. That‚Äôs how you know.
Carry this not as a weapon, but as an anchor. So when fear speaks, you remember:
‚ÄúJustice, justice shall you pursue.‚Äù
(Even when it costs. Especially when it costs.)
#JewishConscience, #NeverAgainForAll, #PropheticJudaism, #TraumaToTruth, #FaithNotFear

This is my 28-day journey of living a temporary life in Helsinki, Tallinn, Stockholm, and Copenhagen.
üá∏üá™ August 4, 2019
It‚Äôs very lucky to have a friend who lives in Stockholm. Jimmie was one of my classmates when I was in San Francisco. He is a writer and a freelance journalist. After leaving San Francisco, I‚Äôve kept in touch with him on Facebook. And luckily I had a chance to visit Stockholm and saw him again.
Thanks to Jimmie, I could visit a beautiful island, Vaxholm in Sweden. It is not far from Stockholm, but it is not easy to get there by public transportation. We went outside of Stockholm by car, arrived at a town with a small dock, and waited for a public ship that moves cars from islands to islands. Because there are no bridges between islands in some places, so the ship plays a role as a bridge. We got on a ship, crossed a bay and got to Vaxholm.
Vaxholm looks like a small town in the countryside. It was a military fortress in the 16th century like Suomenlinna in Finland, but now it is one of the tourist attractions for hiking, camping, or just relaxing. We stopped by a small cafe and had Swedish Fika(coffee) and cinnamon rolls. They tasted really good. We looked around the island by driving and walking.
Vaxholm, this is the place that I have been looking for!! A calm and peaceful place. There are some stores for convenience but not many. There are some people, but it was not crowded. I can go hiking, sailing, fishing, swimming or camping. Or I can just take a walk along the coast. It‚Äôs the best place to relax. I wanted to stay more, but I should go back to Stockholm for tomorrow‚Äôs new adventure. I just left my heart in Vaxholm.
The more I stay, the more I like Sweden, maybe more than Tallinn. Sorry, Tallinn.

Title: Great Runs in Stockholm
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Ultimate Guide to the Best Places to Run in the World's Major Cities and Destinations. www.greatruns.com @greatruns by Mark Lowenstein

--
Listen
Share
Stockholm is arguably one of the world‚Äôs most beautiful capitals. It is built on 14 islands around medieval city center and is located where the freshwater Lake M√§laren flows out into the Baltic Sea. Stockholm is the most populous city in the Scandinavia, with 2.2 million people living in the metropolitan area. Running in Stockholm is a treat, given the water, unique geography, and well laid out pedestrian and recreational paths. The Stockholm Marathon is claimed to have one of the most beautiful marathon routes in the world.
The best running routes in Stockholm are defined by scenic paths along the waterfront, across bridges to the islands, and some lovely green spaces. We also have some routes that combine some of the main Stockholm sights with some pleasant parks and urban highlights. Stockholm has an excellent public transportation system consisting of bus, tram, local train (pendelt√•g) and subway (tunnelbana; look for a T-sign).
One of the defining elements of running in Stockholm is its latitude. In summer, running late at night is a particular treat due to 18+hours of daylight. In winter, Stockholm makes up for short days in part by providing good lighting along most of its paths. Despite its northern location, Stockholm has relatively mild weather compared to other locations at similar latitude, or even farther south ‚Äî receiving more sunshine per year than Paris or London, but also precipitation on about half the days through the year. It can snow from November to April, and winter running will likely involve snow or ice so bring your Yak-Traks. Summers are mild but rarely warm. You‚Äôll almost always need an extra later for morning runs, even in July.
drive.google.c
5.5-mile loop. Accessible any point in downtown. MAP
This route covers some of the main sights of the city, with lots of folks out walking and running. Much of the route is along the water and over bridges to two islands. Start your run at Gustav Adolfs square, next to the Royal Opera House. Head to Gamla Stan (Old Town) and pass Riksdagshuset where the Swedish Parliament is situated, as well as, the Royal Palace ‚Äî His Majesty The King‚Äôs official residence. Enjoy the views of the idyllic Gamla Stan while you run south towards S√∂dermalm island. Head west along the waterfront all the way to L√•ngholmen, which is a former prison island, and currently one of Stockholm‚Äôs green oases. Cross the bridge to Kungsholmen island and head back east. You will pass another main sight, Stadthus (City Hall), which is also the venue of the annual Nobel Prize banquet. Complete the loop at Gustav Adolfs square.
7.2-mile loop. Access: several subways or buses to Slussen stop. MAP
S√∂dermalm, or S√∂der as locals call it, is an island in south Stockholm. The vibe in S√∂dermalm is relaxed and trendy, and it was selected as the coolest neighborhood in Europe by Vogue magazine in 2014. Running a loop around the island is a treat. Start your run at S√∂dermalm market square which is easily accessible by public transportation (Slussen stop). Head west and enjoy views in Montelusv√§gen ‚Äî a walking path looking over the waterfront to Kungsholmen. Continue further west and climb to Skinnarviksberget, a hill offering another breathtaking view over the city. Run to waterfront and make a loop around the island. Probably the most scenic parts of the loop are a path from Tantolunden in the west to Eriksdalsbadet in the south, and northeast area of the island when you run along the waterfront with Gamla Stan on your right.
5.2-mile loop. Start: Djurg√•rdsbron Bridge. Access: Bus 76 from downtown. MAP
Djurg√•rden is a green and idyllic island close to central Stockholm, offering a beautiful setting for running. Its official name Kungliga Djurg√•rden means Royal Game Park and it is one of the most popular recreation areas of the city. Start your run at Djurg√•rdsbron bridge and head east along the canal all the way to Lilla Sj√∂tullsbron bridge. Cross the bridge to south and enter Djurg√•rden island where you will pass scenic green areas and several historical buildings and monuments, the Vasa museum, art galleries, and the popular amusement park Gr√∂na Lund. In the interior of the island is Royal Djurg√•rden, which has gravel, more forested paths that can be a nice add-on.
8.1-mile loop. Access: bus 515 MAP
Hagaparken ‚Äî a lovely green park about 5km north of the city ‚Äî is a popular running destination any time of year. The park offers several scenic running paths. The best option is to make a loop along around Brunnsviken lake. Hagaparken is Sweden‚Äôs purest version of an ‚ÄòEnglish park‚Äô, and the surrounding area contains three royal palaces. Probably the most famous building is Haga Palace where Victoria, Crown Princess of Sweden, and her husband, Prince Daniel, Duke of V√§sterg√∂tland, moved shortly after their wedding in 2010.
5.6-mile loop. Access: any bus, tram or subway to Central Station MAP
Kungsholmen is a residential island where also the most prominent building of the Stockholm skyline and the venue of the annual Nobel Prize banquet, City Hall, is located. It is also another great running location. A good option to start your run is near Central Station. Head south and you will see Gamla Stan on the other side of waterfront. After passing the City Hall, continue west along the waterfront. Other highlights are a beautiful park called R√•lambshovsparken and the inner city beach Smedsuddsbadet on the south side of the island, and Hornsbergs Strand on the north side. Most of the run is along the water.
Hellasg√•rden is a nice recreation area offering several running trails in the woods and along the K√§lltorpssj√∂n lake. It is located about 20 minutes by bus from downtown Stockholm ‚Äî take bus 401 from Slussen to the Hellasg√•rden stop in √Ñlta. There are also excellent refreshment possibilities after your run, or options for a sauna or enjoying a sandy beach. See our 5.1 mile route here. Some of the trails have lights but note that in winter season, some of the trails are kept clean from snow while others are used for skiing, thus not suitable for running. See additional information here.
Stockholm has a wide selection of hotels in the downtown area and all of our iconic routes are located within a few mile radius. To have a fast access to the Stockholm Highlights loop, Djurg√•rden and S√∂dermalm routes, look for hotels in √ñstermalm and Gamla Stan areas. If you want to stay closer to Hagaparken route, then the Vasastan is a good option. It is still very close to Central loop and S√∂dermalm routes, but a bit further from Djurg√•rden. In addition to big international chains see also the following options:
Radisson Blu. Chain of well equipped hotels. Several locations in downtown.
Scandic. Another chain, several locations in downtown.
Nordic Light Hotel. A nice hotel with great location.
Runner‚Äôs Store is the biggest running specialty store in Sweden. Located downtown.
L√∂plabbet is another running specialty store with knowledgeable staff.
XXL. Price-driven big box retailer which has disrupted Scandinavian sporting goods retailers recently. One location in downtown on Hamngatan, another in Bromma airport.
Asics Flagship Store located in downtown on Hamngatan
Run With Me Stockholm offers a variety of private guided running tours covering main sights and attractions of the city. Has free group runs, too.
Stockholm Running Tours is another group combining sightseeing and running.
Nike+ Run Club offers several group runs to runners of all speeds.
Hash House Harriers is a Stockholm chapter of this globally spread ‚ÄúDrinking club with a running problem‚Äù. Meets every Wednesday night and every second Saturday afternoon for running, beer and fun.
Stockholm Frontrunners is running and walking group for LGBTQ people and their friends. Meets every Tuesday for group runs.
Stockholm Marathon is the main marathon race in the city, taking place annually late May or early June. Consists of two loops around the city and the finishing line is located on track of the Olympic Stadium.
Stockholm Half Marathon. September. This race has been in its current form since 2007 but its roots date to the 1920's.
Midnattsloppet. August. The ‚Äúmidnight run‚Äù, is a 10k race which has been run in Stockholm since 1982. As the name suggests, around 20,000 runners hit the streets of the city after the sunset. The same event is organized annually also in Malm√∂, G√∂teborg and Helsinki.
Women‚Äôs Health Half Marathon is the biggest half marathon exclusively for women in Europe. Offers also a possibility to run as a pair and split the distance with your friend. Website available only in Swedish ‚Äî to learn more in English, contact whhm@marathon.se

Title: Stockholm Syndrome
Parental Stockholm Syndrome
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Smart, accessible, and sometimes very personal writing on film and television, classical and contemporary. Written (mostly) by people who study this stuff for a living.

--
1
Listen
Share
By MATT PUSATERI
Five years ago, my brother sent me a link to a YouTube video. ‚ÄúThis is awesome,‚Äù he texted. When I clicked it, I was baffled: it was a clip of a song-and-dance number on a football field from Fox‚Äôs series Glee (2009‚Äì15).
I didn‚Äôt get it: why he loved it, or why he was sharing it with me. After all, this was my brother ‚Äî a first-born, take-charge, cut-the-bullshit engineer, and he really, really wanted me to see a clip from Glee? Maybe, I thought, he accidently pasted the wrong link?
What I didn't appreciate back then was that he was living at home with two teenage girls. He was outnumbered three-to-one by women. His view of the world, pop culture, and entertainment was distorted day after day to the point where he didn‚Äôt realize what had happened. He was a victim of Parental Stockholm Syndrome.
Classic Stockholm Syndrome refers to ‚Äúa psychological phenomenon in which hostages express empathy and sympathy and have positive feelings toward their captors, sometimes to the point of defending and identifying with the captors.‚Äù It was inspired by a Stockholm bank robbery in 1973, during which hostages inside the bank gradually came to defend the criminals who took them hostage.
Parental Stockholm Syndrome is the same thing, except instead of being victims of a bank robbery held at gunpoint, it applies to parents held captive to shows like Glee as well as TV channels like Disney Junior and PBS Kids.
This is a real condition. I know, because I suffer from Parental Stockholm Syndrome.
I've actually said these things in the past year:
If I didn't live with two little girls ‚Äî ages seven and five ‚Äî I wouldn't be able to distinguish Periwinkle, a brave Winter fairy, from Rosetta, a plucky gardening fairy with a classic Southern accent. I also wouldn't have strong feelings about the sharp decline in the writing of Dora the Explorer (2000- ) after season two. And I never would have walked around the gym humming to myself the national anthem of Enchancia.
You can resist, but it‚Äôs inevitable. When you become a parent, you don‚Äôt just bring children into your world; they pull you into theirs.
Try as I might to get them to love things I love ‚Äî DC Comics, Chicago-style pizza, Texas Hold‚Äôem, and North Carolina basketball ‚Äî they want me to sit with them and enjoy the things they love: Daniel Tiger‚Äôs Neighborhood (2012- ), Pinkalicious, and almost any movie about mermaids.
I might fight it, clinging to the adult world I left nearly eight years ago, struggling to maintain the illusion that I'm not captive to the passions and imaginations of two little girls. Or I can sit back, let go, and allow myself to tear up when Rapunzel is finally reunited with her parents at the top of the castle.
If you enjoyed this, please hit the green ‚ÄúRecommend‚Äù button below so others might also enjoy it.

Content:

So, I realise as I write this that my last blog post was about an ECR event at the University of Stirling, arranged by the British Society of Gerontology‚Äôs Emerging Researcher‚Äôs in Ageing group (ERA). Ironic then, that I am writing this blog post in a former prison in Stockholm, on an ERA Writing Retreat at L√•ngholmen!
The writing retreat, which I‚Äôll write up in a separate post, was scheduled for Wednesday to Friday, so my brain quickly went into planning a research trip around it. Who might I be able to speak to at museums or universities in Stockholm about my research and practice at the Fitzwilliam Museum? And what might I learn about Nordic practice? I did some desk-top research, wrote some emails, and before I knew it, I had conjured up a plan for a research trip! And again, I was visiting a place I hadn‚Äôt been to before, so this was exciting‚Ä¶
Arriving on Saturday afternoon, I was able to spend the weekend strolling around the city (which was freezing!), being a tourist in a new city. I took an archipelago boat tour on Sunday morning, followed up by a visit to the Vasa Museet ‚Äî the museum that I was told was one not to be missed! It was here that I was reminded that I am now unable to visit a museum without stepping into research mode‚Ä¶
The museum is vast ‚Äî with many floors, and a lack of clear navigation route. Whilst the ship itself (if you‚Äôre interested in the story, you can read more on the museum‚Äôs website) is impressive, I felt immediately overwhelmed, not knowing where to start, or where to go. I found myself looking for somewhere to sit!
I saw a station where you could collect a map (which was available in numerous different languages), as well as clicking on a QR code to access a FREE audio guide. A map on the wall showed the location of all the stories in the audio guide, which was helpful (although they were not shown on the paper map which you carried with you). I looked around me, and found a theatre style set of wooden steps, where I could sit, look at the ship, and listen to the audio‚Ä¶
The audio was quite interesting, but then I quickly became frustrated by the imitation waves that were added in for effect. Time to move on!
There were lifts, but often with a group of people already waiting, so I chose to use the stairs. I found it quite confusing to navigate my way around, and it was too dark to read the map, so I stopped trying!
The museum is very interactive, with a wide variety of displays, ways to engage, and a LOT of information. I realised I was finding the displays a bit overwhelming, and so decided to focus on the ship itself ‚Äî actually, as I write this, it‚Äôs probably how I usually navigate a museum. Focus on the object of interest!
This was the start of my trip, before I even intended to be focused on research. I‚Äôll add further blogs to this series (links to be added, as I write them):

Title: Stockholm‚Äôs 13 Best Places That Epitomize the City‚Äôs Iconic Style & Culture
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This article originally appeared on Confessions of a Boy Toy
Stockholm is a truly magical city. This spring, we traveled to Sweden‚Äôs capital to experience the fairy tale magic for ourselves. From getting lost through the cobblestone streets of charming Gamla Stan (Old Town) or boutique-hopping in the city‚Äôs super-hip SoFo neighborhood, Stockholm has enchanting surprises at every turn.
Here are some incredible places you‚Äôll be delighted to stumble upon shall you find yourself in Stockholm.
The clothes and furniture at Grandpa embodies everything we love about the SoFo district: Casual, super-cool and contemporary, despite its name. Grandpa focuses on highlighting Scandinavian fashion and furniture designers with a reputation for making things that are eco-friendly and sustainable, with materials sourced locally, organically or through fair trade.
Another quintessential SoFo shop, Coctail is like a Pedro Almodovar movie that‚Äôs come to life. No wonder it‚Äôs so popular with film location scouts. While most of Stockholm is still enamored with minimalism, this tiny shop aims for ‚Äúmaximalism‚Äù ‚Äî everything here is just the most, from the luchador masks, the Dia de Los Muertos figurines, the Frida Kahlo mugs, and other colorful, authentic trinkets shipped from Mexican street vendors.
Located in Gamla Stan since 1864, E.Torndahl is a tiny, family-owned boutique featuring the work of local Scandinavian designers and artists. Here, you‚Äôll find fascinating gifts in the form of jewelry, wallets, metallic hair-trimmers shaped like exotic birds, coasters with a bearded man illustration, a portable phone charger shaped like a river rock, and more.
Photography lovers should spend an afternoon ‚Äî especially if it‚Äôs raining ‚Äî perusing Fotografiska, a for-profit center for modern photography. This place is not afraid to exhibit controversial and provocative photos, so make sure to wear your open-minded goggles. During our visit, we saw work by African artists Samuel Fosso and Rotimi Fani-Kayode, as well as a special exhibition on French fashion photographer Bettina Rheims.
There‚Äôs no inch of Stockholm that‚Äôs not drenched in history and culture, even down in the subway. The city‚Äôs public transit system is said to be the world‚Äôs longest art exhibit, with 90 percent of the subway stations decorated with sculptures, mosaics, paintings and public installations by over 150 artists. Some of the most eye-grabbing subway art can be found at the following stations: Kungstr√§dg√•rden, T-Centralen, R√•dhuset, Solna Centrum and Tensta.
If you find yourself in Gamla Stan around noon, check out the changing of the guard at the Royal Palace. It takes place at 12:15 p.m. daily during the summer and on weekends year-round. The Royal Palace itself is a sight to see. You can take a tour of the inside and check out five museums, including the royal treasury, home to the crown jewels, an armory with knights‚Äô gear and the royal stable with coronation carriages and intricate coaches.
Are you a fan of Game of Thrones or Harry Potter or Star Trek or E.T. or Marvel superheroes or Buffy the Vampire Slayer or all of the above? You‚Äôre bound to find a book, graphic novel, or other gift for all your geek-related obsessions at this sci-fi mecca in Gamla Stan. Let‚Äôs just say this shop has everything you could ever possibly need to decipher every reference in Stranger Things.
If it‚Äôs sunny out, this lively terrace at the top of Sodrateatern, an iconic theater in the heart of Stockholm, has to be on your to-do list. And if the weather is not cooperating, Sodrateatern offers plenty of indoor festivities as well, including jazz-fueled dinners that turn into full-blown dance parties.
If you‚Äôre traveling to Stockholm during the summer, from early April to late September, make sure to catch the sunset at the hyper-scenic M√§larpaviljongen. This high-spirited, straight-friendly restaurant and outdoor bar is located on the waterfront barges along the Riddarfj√§rden bay. You can even arrive by boat after a day out on the bay to cap off your cruising adventures.
A gay-owned coffee shop painted mustard-yellow in the heart of Gamla Stan, Chokladkoppen serves delicious hot chocolate in a bowl. If you really want to indulge ‚Äî and why wouldn‚Äôt you? ‚Äî they also have chocolate cake that‚Äôs to die for. During the summer, enjoy the people-watching in the Nobel Museum plaza from one of the cafe‚Äôs outdoor tables.
Pharmarium Cocktail Bar
Located in Gamla Stan near where Stockholm‚Äôs first-ever pharmacy opened in 1575, Pharmarium serves a different type of modern remedy: exquisite craft cocktails. The Roses of Gold, the Pharmarium‚Äôs version of a French 75, was just what the doctor order, made to perfection with vodka, lemon, champagne, and just a sprinkle of gold powder. As if a champagne cocktail needed that extra flair.
You will find plenty of treats in Stockholm‚Äôs hip SoFo district, but nothing like the sweet-buttery deliciousness that can be found inside P√§rlans Konfektyra. This quaint confectionery looks like it‚Äôs from another era. It makes classic, organic caramels and caramel sauce in Scandinavian flavors like lingonberry and salt licorice.
You‚Äôd expect this Medieval-themed restaurant would be a tourist trap, but we were the only Americans there. Medeltidskrogen Sj√§tte Tunnan is a little hidden hotspot to find in Gamla Stan. Once you find the door you have to walk all the way to the back before going downstairs to a cavernous restaurant serving a menu inspired by 1300 A.D. cuisine. A feast perfect for a Viking king.

Title: Understanding the Stockholm Syndrome Phenomenon and Russian Propaganda: Exploring the Complexities of Captivity and Manipulation
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Captivity and manipulation are two intricate aspects of human psychology that have fascinated researchers for decades. One phenomenon that sheds light on this complex interaction is the Stockholm Syndrome. As discussions around the topic intensify, it becomes imperative to delve deeper into its causes and explore the role that Russian propaganda plays in shaping public opinion.
The Stockholm Syndrome refers to the psychological condition where hostages develop an emotional bond with their captors. Originating from a 1973 bank robbery in Stockholm, Sweden, the term has increasingly been used to explain instances of individuals identifying with their perpetrators and paradoxically defending their actions.
To truly comprehend this phenomenon, it is crucial to understand the dynamics at play during periods of captivity. When individuals find themselves in situations where their freedom is severely limited, they become vulnerable to the influence of their captors. Fear, uncertainty, and isolation create an environment where the captors can exercise power and control over their prisoners.
Interestingly, these circumstances can lead to a survival strategy known as ‚Äúidentification with the aggressor‚Äù or the Stockholm Syndrome. Victims might unconsciously develop empathy and positivity towards their captors as a means of self-preservation. This psychological defense mechanism aims to reduce perceived threats and increase the chances of survival within the confines of captivity.
However, it is important to note that the Stockholm Syndrome is not limited to scenarios of physical captivity alone. It can also manifest in situations involving emotional manipulation and psychological control. This is where the role of Russian propaganda becomes significant.
Russian propaganda, with its sophisticated tactics, aims to manipulate public opinion and control narratives. By leveraging psychological vulnerabilities, such as the fear of the unknown and the need for security, they can shape people‚Äôs perceptions and beliefs. This can lead to individuals sympathizing with and defending actions that align with the propagated narrative, despite their better judgment.
Exploring the complexities of captivity and manipulation, especially in the context of the Stockholm Syndrome and Russian propaganda, highlights the profound impact that external influences can have on the human psyche. By understanding these dynamics, we can develop greater awareness and critical thinking skills to navigate the intricate world of information warfare.
The Stockholm Syndrome serves as a harrowing testament to why societies need to punish criminals to deter crimes. Its intersection with Russian propaganda highlights the need for vigilance in assessing information sources and maintaining a healthy skepticism in an increasingly interconnected world. Only by questioning and seeking the truth can we break free from the invisible chains of manipulation.
Stockholm Syndrome is a psychological response observed in captive situations, where the individual begins to closely identify with their captors and even starts to sympathize with their agenda and demands. It is a complex phenomenon that has been studied and analyzed in various psychological research.
The term ‚ÄúStockholm Syndrome‚Äù was coined after a notorious bank robbery and hostage situation that took place in Stockholm, Sweden in 1973. During this six-day ordeal, the hostages developed a strong bond and emotional attachment to their captors, which baffled both the authorities and the public. This case became the unprecedented reference point for understanding the psychological dynamics of captor-captive relationships.
According to Britannica, the Stockholm Syndrome is a psychological response that occurs when hostages or abuse victims develop an emotional connection with their captors or abusers. This phenomenon is named after a bank robbery that took place in Stockholm, Sweden in 1973, where the hostages ultimately expressed sympathy and loyalty towards their captors.
The syndrome is thought to be a survival mechanism that kicks in when a person feels powerless and threatened, causing them to form an attachment to their perpetrators. In these situations, the victim‚Äôs survival instincts kick in, and they begin to identify with their captors, often developing positive feelings toward them. This may be due to the captors intermittently showing kindness or providing the hostages with small acts of compassion during their confinement.
This emotional connection can be perplexing to outsiders who fail to understand the intricate dynamics at play. From an outsider‚Äôs perspective, it may seem illogical for the victims to develop positive feelings towards their captors. However, it is important to remember that these individuals are enduring a traumatic experience that distorts their perception of reality.
The Stockholm Syndrome is not limited to physical captivity alone. It can also manifest in situations of emotional manipulation and psychological control. In these cases, the victims may find themselves trapped in toxic relationships or cult-like environments where their thoughts and emotions are manipulated to serve the interests of the abuser.
In such instances, the victims‚Äô identities become intertwined with their captors, leading to a loss of personal agency and an overwhelming sense of dependency. Breaking free from this psychological entanglement can be incredibly challenging, as the victims may fear retribution or believe that they are incapable of surviving without their captors‚Äô support.
One of the factors that can contribute to the development of Stockholm Syndrome is the captor‚Äôs ability to instill a sense of fear and helplessness in the victims. By controlling their access to basic needs such as food, water, and sleep, the captors can create a cycle of reward and punishment, fostering a state of emotional dependency. This dependence, coupled with intermittent acts of kindness or compassion, further deepens the victims‚Äô connection to their captors.
Furthermore, the victims may experience cognitive dissonance, a psychological phenomenon where conflicting beliefs and emotions create a state of mental discomfort. To reduce this discomfort, the victims may reinterpret the captors‚Äô actions in a positive light, creating a narrative that justifies their bond with their captors. This cognitive restructuring allows them to maintain a sense of coherence in their worldview, despite the abusive circumstances they find themselves in.
The intersection between the Stockholm Syndrome and Russian propaganda unveils another layer of complexity. Russian propaganda, utilizing sophisticated manipulation techniques, aims to shape public opinion and control narratives. By exploiting psychological vulnerabilities, such as the fear of the unknown and the desire for security, they can sway individuals‚Äô perceptions and evoke emotional responses.
In this context, victims of psychological manipulation may exhibit signs of the Stockholm Syndrome by defending and sympathizing with the propagated narrative, even if it contradicts their original beliefs or goes against their best interests. This underscores the immense power of psychological manipulation in shaping individuals‚Äô thoughts and behaviors, turning them into unwitting prisoners of false ideologies.
To combat the toxic influence of propaganda and break free from the grip of manipulation, it is crucial to foster critical thinking skills and media literacy. Developing the ability to analyze information objectively, question sources, and consider multiple perspectives can help individuals resist the allure of manipulative tactics.
By shining a light on the intertwined concepts of captivity, manipulation, and the Stockholm Syndrome, we can gain a deeper understanding of the complex mechanisms at play within the human psyche. It is through this understanding that we can strive to create a society that values freedom, autonomy, and the pursuit of truth, free from the shackles of psychological captivity.
Note: The term ‚ÄúStockholm Syndrome‚Äù is used to describe a specific psychological response and should not be used loosely or trivialized.
One of the most infamous examples of Stockholm Syndrome is the case involving Patty Hearst, a newspaper heiress who was kidnapped in 1974 by the radical group Symbionese Liberation Army (SLA). Initially terrified and coerced, Hearst eventually joined the group and participated in their criminal activities. This case generated significant media attention and captivated the public‚Äôs interest, sparking widespread discussions about the psychological mechanisms underlying Stockholm Syndrome.
The study of Stockholm Syndrome has provided tragic insights into the complexities of human behavior and the power of psychological manipulation. Researchers have attempted to unravel the underlying factors that contribute to the development of this phenomenon. Some proposed explanations include the captives‚Äô perception of kindness from their captors, trauma bonding, and a survival instinct that leads the captives to adapt to their circumstances.
While Stockholm Syndrome remains an obscure crime, its impact on the understanding of human psychology cannot be understated. By analyzing and comprehending the intricacies of such situations, psychologists and researchers hope to shed light on the various psychological and emotional processes that individuals may experience when faced with captivity and coercion.
It is crucial to note that each case of Stockholm Syndrome is unique, and individuals‚Äô responses can vary significantly. The understanding and treatment of this phenomenon remain areas of ongoing research, aiming to provide support and guidance to individuals who have experienced such traumatic situations.
The study of Stockholm Syndrome has also highlighted the role of empathy and the human need for connection in captive situations. In some cases, victims may develop a sense of empathy towards their captors, seeing them as complex individuals rather than solely as perpetrators. This empathy can create a bond that reinforces the captive‚Äôs identification with the aggressor.
Furthermore, the Stockholm Syndrome can have long-lasting effects on the psychological well-being of the victims. Even after their physical captivity ends, they may continue to struggle with conflicting emotions and a sense of loyalty towards their captors. Overcoming these psychological challenges requires a supportive environment where victims can receive appropriate therapy and support to reintegrate into society.
Cultural and societal factors also play a significant role in shaping the dynamics of the Stockholm Syndrome. The cultural norms and values of a society can influence individuals‚Äô responses to captivity and manipulation. For example, in societies that prioritize authority and obedience, victims may be more likely to develop the Stockholm Syndrome as a means of survival.
The media also has a responsibility in portraying and discussing the Stockholm Syndrome phenomenon accurately and sensitively. Misrepresentation and sensationalization can perpetuate harmful stereotypes and misunderstandings about the condition. Therefore, it is crucial for media outlets to approach the topic with empathy, ensuring that victims‚Äô experiences are heard and understood.
It is important to remember that Stockholm Syndrome is a complex psychological phenomenon that arises in captive situations, where victims develop an emotional bond with their captors. This response stems from a survival instinct and the psychological mechanisms of identification with the aggressor. It is crucial to continue studying and understanding the Stockholm Syndrome to provide support and guidance to individuals who have experienced such traumatic situations. By doing so, we can strive to create a society that values compassion, empathy, and freedom from manipulation.
A study conducted by Douglas Wilbur, a visiting scholar in the UTSA Department of Communication, sheds light on an important issue regarding the influence of Russian propaganda on popular alternative media sites. Wilbur‚Äôs research, which involved analyzing over 600 articles, provides valuable insights into the correlation between Sputnik, Russia‚Äôs state-owned media, and these alternative media platforms that are believed to present favorable coverage of Russia and its allies in the United States.
The study, ‚ÄúPropaganda or Not: Examining the Claims of Extensive Russian Information Operations within the United States,‚Äù provides a comprehensive content analysis of articles published in four websites that were labeled by Prop or Not as working on behalf of the Russian government. While Prop or Not faced criticism from major U.S. mainstream media for its methodology in labeling 200 sites as vehicles of propaganda, the research conducted by Wilbur demonstrates the strong credibility of the claims made by Prop or Not regarding Russian interference.
In 2017, Prop or Not alleged that Russia was manipulating U.S. public opinion through online propaganda, but their failure to provide compelling evidence left doubts lingering in the air. However, Wilbur‚Äôs research has now validated this claim, shedding light on the extent of Russian interference and its impact on U.S. public opinion. The study delves into the manipulation tactics employed by these targeted websites and explores the strategies used to influence the American narrative.
One of the key findings of Wilbur‚Äôs study is the strong, positive correlation between Sputnik and sites like Zero Hedge, a Wall Street-focused website. The analysis suggests that these alternative media outlets echo Russian propaganda, aligning with the claims made by organizations like Prop or Not. This raises concerns about covert manipulation of the U.S. news agenda, posing a potential threat to national security.
Wilbur researched articles published on several websites: Zero Hedge, New Cold War, Global Research, and The Daily Sheeple. The outlets were chosen using a random number approach. Published articles on those sites between January 2019 and July 2020 were then selected for examination if they contained the following key terms: Russia, Syria, Ukraine, Iran, Venezuela, and North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). These terms were chosen because they highlight important foreign policy issues for the Russian government. Once the articles were selected, their tonality was rated on a positive or negative scale according to how the news stories described Russia and its allies versus the U.S. and its partners.
Wilbur‚Äôs analysis offers a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate surrounding the role of Russian information operations in the United States. By meticulously examining the content of these websites, the study provides insights into the methods employed by Russian actors to shape public discourse and sow discord among the American population.
This research serves as a call to action for organizations and individuals alike, highlighting the importance of critically evaluating the sources and information we encounter online. It underscores the need for improved media literacy and the development of strategies to combat disinformation campaigns that seek to undermine democracy and public trust.
In essence, the study conducted by Wilbur offers compelling evidence to support the claims made by Prop or Not regarding Russian interference in the United States. It provides a valuable resource for researchers, policymakers, and the general public, deepening our understanding of the evolving challenges posed by digital propaganda and the imperative to safeguard the integrity of information in the digital age.
In an era where information is easily accessible and influences public opinion, it becomes crucial for the U.S. media to be aware of and address these propaganda efforts. As Russia creates and utilizes propaganda as a weapon, it is vital for the U.S. media to have effective countermeasures in place, ensuring that accurate and unbiased information prevails.
By highlighting this issue, Wilbur‚Äôs research underscores the importance of media literacy and critical thinking. It reminds us that staying informed and discerning in the face of propaganda is integral to safeguarding the integrity of the news and protecting national interests.
Awareness of the existence and potential impact of propaganda is the first step in combating its influence. The findings of this study emphasize the need for continued research, collaboration, and awareness among media professionals, policymakers, and the general public, as they strive to ensure a vibrant and trustworthy news landscape that upholds democratic values.
Understanding the parallels between Stockholm Syndrome and Russian disinformation and propaganda sheds light on how psychological manipulation can shape public opinion and influence individuals‚Äô beliefs. By drawing this comparison, we can gain insight into the mechanisms at play in both situations, revealing the power of manipulation in shaping individuals‚Äô thoughts and behaviors.
Both Stockholm Syndrome and Russian propaganda involve psychological manipulation and the distortion of reality. In cases of Stockholm Syndrome, captives develop an emotional bond with their captors, defending and identifying with them despite the harm they may have suffered. Similarly, Russian propaganda aims to manipulate public opinion through sophisticated tactics, distorting information and narratives to align with their interests.
In both scenarios, fear and uncertainty play a significant role. In captivity situations, victims experience a sense of powerlessness and dependence on their captors, which can lead to the development of Stockholm Syndrome. Similarly, Russian propaganda preys on individuals‚Äô fears and insecurities, manipulating them through emotionally charged content designed to evoke strong reactions.
Another common factor between the two is the psychological defense mechanism of cognitive restructuring. In the case of Stockholm Syndrome, captives may reinterpret their captors‚Äô actions in a positive light, creating a narrative that justifies their bond. Similarly, victims of propaganda may engage in cognitive dissonance, modifying their beliefs to align with the propagated narrative, despite contradictory evidence.
The role of empathy, albeit in different contexts, is also crucial. In Stockholm Syndrome, victims may develop empathy towards their captors, seeing them as complex individuals rather than solely as perpetrators. In the case of Russian propaganda, individuals may sympathize with the propagated narrative and defend actions that align with it, due to the emotional appeal and manipulation employed.
By comparing Stockholm Syndrome with Russian disinformation and propaganda, we can recognize the underlying psychological mechanisms and vulnerabilities that contribute to individuals‚Äô susceptibility to manipulation. This understanding serves as a reminder of the importance of critical thinking, media literacy, and the ability to question and analyze information from diverse perspectives.
Ultimately, by raising awareness of the tactics used in psychological manipulation, individuals can develop resilience against manipulation and make informed decisions based on reliable information. This empowers individuals to navigate the complex landscape of information warfare and mitigate the impact of psychological captivity induced by manipulation and propaganda.

In 1973, there was a huge bank robbery attempt in Stockholm, Sweden. The robbers held four bank workers hostage for six days. On the sixth days, the police broke inside, trying to arrest the robbers and save the hostages but the said hostages tried to protect the robbers from the police. Later on, the hostages refused giving testimony against the robbers and they even started collecting money to defend them. Within six days of captivity, the hostages had started developing a deep sympathy for the robbers.
As a result, the incident in which captives start developing positive feelings for their captors was named Stockholm Syndrome. This intriguing and paradoxical bond between captors and captives was also found amongst prisoners of war and those being kept in concentration camps as well. But in time, it‚Äôs seen that Stockholm Syndrome is not all about literal captors and captives. For example; Stockholm Syndrome can be found between parents and children or spouses as well as in narcissistic relationships, which is the main topic of our article.
In what conditions do we see Stockholm Syndrome?
Stockholm Syndrome requires four important elements:
Judging by the first one, you might think that Stockholm Syndrome happening in a narcissistic relationship is very unlikely. You might feel like a narcissistic relationship cannot exactly be life threatening. After all, not all narcissists resort to physical violence. On the other hand, living with a narcissist can mean that your life is indeed in danger. This danger can be physical, emotional, psychological or spiritual. Besides, narcissists can throw violent temper tantrums when they can‚Äôt get something they want or when they‚Äôre losing control over someone (narcissistic rage). People on the receiving end of this rage (even if their partners have never abused them physical in the past) may find themselves fearing for their lives or well-being in general.
And the second case is about isolating the victim. Isolating the victim is a typical abusive behavior. In some cases, the victim can practically turn into a hostage due to being completely alienated from the outside world. And in some others, the victim avoids the point of views of other people when under the influence of feelings such as jealousy, paranoia and fear fueled by the narcissist. The isolated person fails to notice the abuse they‚Äôre being put through due to not being able to consult to other people, and they also feel like this small, artificial kindness shown by the abuser is all they have now so they cling to it.
Another reason is that the victim is unable to escape, or so they believe because they were convinced by the abuser. In the Stockholm robbery, it was found out that one of the hostages got a chance to escape and yet she did not. The reason to that may be the fact she believed she could not succeed, perhaps she was simply afraid of the danger this attempt might bring. In this situation called ‚Äúbehavioral despair‚Äù, the victim feels so hopeless that they resign to their fate. In narcissistic relationships, if the victim is financially abused as well, or if they‚Äôre in a relationship where there are children involved, they can be convinced that there‚Äôs no way out for them. And if the abused person also has a narcissistic parent, it‚Äôs quite likely for them to show signs of behavioral despair. Babies are dependent on their parents in order to survive. But when it comes to children who grow up in problematic environments where their needs are not met; the fact they feel dependent and not strong enough as well as the ‚Äúsmall favors‚Äù granted by their abusive parents every once in a while may cause them to develop a sympathy for them.
In our last condition, in order for the Stockholm Syndrome to emerge the abuser should display a certain amount of kindness. A desperate and hopeless person who‚Äôs already in a life threatening situation and utterly at the mercy of the abuser can start trying to rationalize the situation when they‚Äôre shown some kindness by the abuser. These attempts at rationalizing the situation may start with ‚Äúit‚Äôs not that bad!‚Äù and end in deeply positive feelings for the abuser in time. After a while, the abuser stops being a bad person in the eyes of the victim, they‚Äôre simply misunderstood and turned into what they are today due to certain circumstances.
At this point, the abuser clings to the exaggerated versions of the few good memories they had with the abuser and starts seeing them the way they want them to be, not the way they actually are today.
Reasons of Stockholm Syndrome
Stockholm Syndrome is a product and natural result of systematic abuse, and it‚Äôs practically a survival mechanism. People try to save themselves from dangerous situations with ‚Äúfight or flight‚Äù instincts. But running away or fighting it may not always be possible. If we consider the Stockholm robbery, the hostages cannot really overpower armed robbers, and their chances of getting shot are pretty high if they try to run away. As a result, the victim experiences stress and wants to protect themselves, but that doesn‚Äôt seem possible. Also, our brains and bodies are not fit for long-term and continuous stress. Therefore, eventually people tend to focus on the ‚Äúpositive aspects‚Äù instinctively in an attempt to reduce the stress they‚Äôre experiencing. This is practically something that protects them from going utterly insane and it helps them cope with the trauma. People suffering from Stockholm Syndrome have faced something so traumatic that the only way to reduce it was to do this.
The first instinct of the hostages might have been to pretend like they‚Äôre on the robbers‚Äô side in order to avoid angering them rather than ‚Äúfocusing on the positive‚Äù. They can try to please the abuser to avoid violence. In bilateral relationships, if one of the parties is prone to violence and sudden, aggressive outbursts; the other party may instinctively try to keep them satisfied just to avoid their wrath. But after a while, once the hope for escape has completely faded, this situation goes beyond just pretending and the victim can find themselves feeling a genuine sympathy for the abuser.
Long story short, when there‚Äôs no hope for escape and that there‚Äôs no other options (or so you think), you try to fit in and adapt to the new conditions in order to survive. Besides, once you embrace the abuser‚Äôs point of view, you‚Äôre no longer a victim. This situation makes one feel less inferior and more in control of things. As long as the danger of maintaining the relationship isn‚Äôt much higher than the risk a breakup might bring, it‚Äôs quite hard for the victim to acknowledge the situation they‚Äôre in.
All these situations serve the abuser well, because then they‚Äôve successfully created a voluntary victim. Especially for the emotional manipulators, keeping the victim completely under their control is not enough; they want the victim to be willing as well.
Despite all this, you might still find Stockholm Syndrome illogical. You might be having trouble understanding a hostage getting attached to their captor, or a child loving their abusive parent, or a person being unable to leave their violent partner. But do not forget that people who have suffered traumatic things cannot always make reasonable choices. Traumatic incidents are exceptional conditions and desperate times call for desperate measures.
What to do in order to get rid of Stockholm Syndrome in narcissistic relationships?
Breaking the trauma bond on your own might be too difficult, so it would be wiser to get psychological help if possible. You need to make sure the person you‚Äôre consulting to has enough knowledge and experience about narcissistic personality disorder, codependency and narcissistic relationship dynamics.
You need to cut all ties with the narcissist for good and follow the ‚Äúno contact rule‚Äù. In this way, you‚Äôll be able to establish yourself a safe zone.
And in relationships, you should always focus on the big picture rather than small details. These ‚Äúsmall favors‚Äù other people grant you may cost you much bigger things in the long run.
