Title: Night Train to the Arctic Circle
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
4
Listen
Share
More than 100 miles north of the Arctic Circle, our Vy train to Narvik climbed an other-worldly landscape of lakes, rivers and waterfalls, dotted with cabins painted in Scandinavia‚Äôs iconic Falu red with white trim.
I was thousands of miles from home, and I felt as if I were on another planet.
Population and vegetation were sparse as we climbed in latitude and altitude, crossing through the Scandinavian Mountain range that forms the border between Sweden and Norway.
I have logged more than 40,000 miles by rail, and love trains so much that I‚Äôve made slow train travel the subject of my master‚Äôs capstone. I have always been intrigued by the Arctic, drawn to the northern reaches when looking at maps. And for 24 hours in mid-October, I had the privilege of bringing these two interests together with a 637-mile train trip from Stockholm, Sweden, to Narvik, Norway.
After 48 hours in Stockholm with our cousins, my brother Michael and I arrived at Stockholms Centralstation ‚Äî a 151-year-old transportation hub that draws 200,000 visitors every day ‚Äî with about 45 minutes to spare, my bags a little heavier than when I first arrived in the Swedish capital.
Our sleeper train would take us through Swedish forests, over steep mountains and down to the Norwegian port city of Narvik, where we would catch a 4-hour bus ride even farther north to Troms√∏, the third largest city above the Arctic Circle.
I grabbed one last cardamom bun at Stockholms Centralstation ‚Äî my fourth in 48 hours ‚Äî before we boarded. I had always associated cardamom with Middle Eastern food, but Sweden and Norway consume 18 and 30 times more cardamom than the global median, and cardamom buns were everywhere in Stockholm. Not knowing where I would find one again, I couldn‚Äôt resist one more.
When the train rolled in to the station, we found our car and boarded, joining a crowd of passengers from other parts of the world. I heard Italian, Chinese, and a lot of non-native English.
We had booked a couchette, a small space for six people, two benches facing each other by day, three beds on each side by night. I was hoping we‚Äôd have the space to ourselves, but we had the next best thing: just one other passenger, a quiet youngish man in a striped t-shirt and a baseball cap who had a bunk at the very top.
Mike and I didn‚Äôt stay long in the couchette. As soon as the attendant checked our tickets, we headed to the dining car, where we could sit at a table and enjoy some Bottenvikkens brews from northern Sweden and be around other passengers.
For dinner, I couldn‚Äôt pass up the most unique dish ‚Äî reindeer stew with potatoes, mushrooms and lingonberries. Other offerings included folded flatbread with fried egg and Jokkmokk-sausage, and classic Swedish shrimp sandwich. Each boxed dinner bore the words ‚ÄúWe proudly serve food made from scratch in Lule√•.‚Äù
After dinner, I broke into the sampler pack of aquavit that I had purchased at the liquor store in the √Öhl√©ns department store in Stockholm.
One after another, we split four tiny bottles, each one with a different combination of flavors, including dill, caraway, rosemary, citrus, cumin, anise, sherry and cinnamon.
I split each between two glasses, and as we would do throughout our weeklong trip, Mike and I toasted with the Scandinavian ‚Äúsk√•l‚Äù first tapping each other‚Äôs glass, then tapping our own glass to the table as a toast to the house before taking the first sip.
Back at the couchette, we made our beds as quietly as we could, knowing that someone else was above us. I would have hated to be in his position, so close to the ceiling. I slept relatively well, waking up every so often to peek outside, in vain, to see if I could see the Northern Lights.
I knew that the restaurant car would open at 5 am and, wanting to be among the early risers, I got up at 5:30 to head down there.
The train was stopped at the √Ñlvsbyn station, and as I made my way to the restaurant car, I found an open door and stuck my head out for fresh air. There I met a train attendant who told me we were stuck for a bit, awaiting information on when we could proceed. I sat and had my tea, texting with my mom and waiting ‚Äî and waiting ‚Äî and waiting.
I had oatmeal with cardamom, granola and lingonberries, and we waited some more.
After an hour of ‚Äúwe will know soon,‚Äù we were told that due to track problems ahead, we would have to take a bus to Boden and board a new train there, not arriving in Narvik until after 5 pm, long after our bus ‚Äî and a final subsequent bus ‚Äî to Troms√∏ would have departed.
At around 9:30 am, a bus arrived to take us to Boden. It meandered through Swedish forestland, the first of many, many, many miles of it that we would see in the coming hours.
I was disappointed to learn that the train we would board at Boden was a day train, lacking many of the amenities of our night train, namely, my favorite one, the restaurant car. We could buy food and drinks, but with no communal place to eat, we would have to take them back to our seats. We were assigned two window seats, one behind another.
The portion of the trip north of Boden is on a stretch of track known as the Iron Ore Line, which connects Lule√•, Sweden, on the Gulf of Bothnia, with Narvik, Norway, on the North Sea.
The line was completed in 1903 to bring iron ore from Sweden to Narvik. Trains on this line have run on electric power since at least 1923 (while the vast majority of track in the United States remains non-electrified a century later). The line still transports iron ore from Kiruna, Svappavaara and Malmberget, as well as shipments of food, to the north, and fish to the south.
Watching the forests pass us by, I tried to detect changes as we moved north into a different climate. Most of the route seemed to be a dense mix of birches that were losing their leaves ‚Äî a few weeks ahead of the brilliant yellow trees in Stockholm ‚Äî and conifers.
As we neared the Arctic Circle, the birches had lost all their leaves, and they seemed to be fewer in number. The conifers, too, were fewer, as the dense forests grew more sparse.
What was also sparse here ‚Äî noise. I like to chat with other people on trains, but this car was silent. We seemed to be the only Americans on board. Other passengers included a young British couple, a middle aged Scottish couple that we would bump into outside a pub in Narvik later that night, a group of about eight Asian people, and the rest seemed Norwegian, Swedish or German.
A walk to the coach area adjacent to the bistro was a much different story ‚Äî a group of Italians were talking loudly and fast. I loved to hear it and wished we were seated with them.
Crossing the Arctic Circle was not as eventful as I expected. I had marked the spot on my Google maps a couple weeks prior to the trip so that I would know the exact moment we crossed. We passed a sign marking the spot ‚Äî Polcirkeln ‚Äî just before the mark on my phone. In any case, I had never before been above the Arctic Circle, so it was an exciting moment ‚Äî and we still had miles and miles and miles to go.
Most of my long-distance train travel has been in the United States, where I marvel at the vast expanses of open space. With an average density of 35 people per square kilometer, the United States is half as dense as Europe, which has 73 people per square kilometer. However, for this trip, I was traveling through countries far less dense than even the United States: Sweden has 23 people per square kilometer, and Norway has only 17, about half the density of the United States. The land here was wide open.
As we pressed farther north, the train did not take on many new passengers, meaning the train, too, was not densely populated. We mostly discharged passengers, especially at Kiruna, a mining town in Swedish Lapland with about 23,000 inhabitants.
The landscape continued to change. The forested hills of southern Sweden were replaced by flatter land, shorter trees, and lots of lakes. In the distance, we could begin to see the Scandinavian Mountains, the range that runs the length of the border between Sweden and Norway, which we would soon be crossing.
After Kiruna, we could really spread out, which for me meant that I could move from the left side of the train to the right to take photos and video. It was here that we engaged in conversation with some fellow passengers.
Lars, from Bavaria, was going to Abisko, where he planned to take two 20-km hikes before continuing on to the Lofoten archipelago for a few days, and then down to Bod√∏ by bus, and by train farther the south, to be possibly followed by a ferry to Denmark. He was clearly a fan of traveling by land and sea ‚Äî and had the time to do so.
Ann, from Aarhus, was now living in Troms√∏, traveling back north by land because of the detrimental effects air travel has on the climate. She was frustrated by how long and expensive the ride was, and how governments fell short of making it easier for people to make the right choices. Our delay would make her long trip longer and more costly for her. I shared her frustration, but reminded her that much of Europe is light years ahead of the United States when it comes to climate-friendly travel options.
I can‚Äôt say enough about the last few hours of that train ride.
After Abisko, the train began to climb the Scandinavian Mountains, reaching a height of about 1,700 feet above sea level, alongside mountains that towered much higher.
The word tundra always connoted to me some distant exotic landscape, something one finds in a nature book or a textbook. Now, I was riding through it, seeing it with my own eyes.
Mosses, lichens and low shrubs offered some color against the rugged, exposed rock. Birches that had long lost their leaves appeared here and there. If not for the sporadic red and gray cabins, I would have thought that a wildfire had recently wiped out this area.
To be more specific, we were crossing through a biome known as the Scandinavian Montane Birch Forests and Grasslands, a tundra ecoregion that spans much of Norway, as well as parts of northern Sweden and Finland.
Though I couldn‚Äôt identify them at the time, I later learned that many of the low shrubs I was seeing was likely a mix of crowberry, reindeer lichen, cloudberry, bilberry and wolf‚Äôs bane.
The trees were largely downy birches ‚Äî I could easily identify birches by their white bark ‚Äî that would grow no taller than 2 to 3 meters, but also may have included aspen, Scots pine, juniper, grey alder, rowan, goat willow and bird cherry.
We passed many alpine lakes that would soon freeze over under the coming polar night. Under the surface likely swam char, trout, tench and minnow.
In Sweden, the lakes all ended in -j√°vri (B√°kt√°j√°vri, Loktaj√°vri, V√°ssej√°vri) the word for ‚Äúlake‚Äù in the Northern Sami language. Once we crossed to Norway, they ended -vatnet (Brudesl√∏rvatnet, Hansenvatnet, Telegrafvatnet) Norwegian for ‚Äúthe water.‚Äù
The sun hung low near the horizon, and I was grateful that despite the delay, we were not passing through this stretch in darkness. As I publish this in mid-November, sunset in Kiruna is 1:57 pm. On December 10, the sun will set at 11:48 am, and not rise again until 11:25 am on January 2.
In our destination of Narvik, the sun remains below the horizon from December 6 to January 7.
As we continued westward toward Norway, we hugged the side of mountains, going through several tunnels and snow sheds. Across the valley, I could see waterfalls, like ribbons spaced out on the side of the mountains. I spent much of the last hour or so in the back of the train, where I had space to myself to open and close windows on either side, and take video out of the left, right and rear of the train.
We made several stops in remote towns I could neither pronounce ‚Äî L√•ktatj√•kka, Vassijaure, Katterk√•kk, Riksgr√§nsen ‚Äî nor imagine living in.
We crossed the Sweden-Norway border inside a tunnel, with the colors of the Swedish flag painted inside, changing over to the colors of the Norwegian flag.
The rail line from the border to Narvik is known as the Ofoten line, and it brought us from an elevation of 1,700 feet down to sea level over the course of 27 miles, as we made the final stretch to our destination.
Soon, we could see a body of water below, the Rombaken, a 12-mile long fjord that was the site of several naval battles during the 1940 Battle of Narvik. The fjord branches out from Narvik‚Äôs Ofotfjorden.
As we passed the massive suspension bridge that connects Narvik to √òyjorda across the fjord, we knew it was time for us to gather our bags, say farewell to Ann ‚Äî with the chance we might see her on our predawn bus ride 12 hours later ‚Äî and disembark, 637 miles from Stockholm and 130 miles above the Arctic circle.
At Narvik, we walked a half mile through a cloudy mist to the Scandic hotel. At nearly $200, it was the most expensive place to stay, but it was also closest to the bus station, it had a sky bar, and I was fairly confident it could be reimbursed by either the rail company or my credit card insurance.
It didn‚Äôt disappoint. The sky bar was amazing, with a nearly 360-degree view of the city. I can‚Äôt imagine being there to see either the Northern Lights or the midnight sun. But in our case, it was a cloudy and drizzly night, without much to see in the sky, but the view of the town was nonetheless fascinating.
After a drink and a massive charcuterie board, we left for Narvikguten pub, making a small loop up a hill to see what we could of the full moon. As we entered the pub, we ran into a Scottish couple from the train. I felt bad that they didn‚Äôt stick around, saying the prices were ‚Äútoo dear‚Äù for them, and that their pounds were especially weak these days. They were in Narvik just to check out the Arctic, heading back south soon and continuing on to Spain after.
We took seats at the bar, realizing quickly that not food would be served there. Into our second beer, we decided that dinner was not entirely necessary after the charcuterie board. We struck up a conversation with the guy next to me, Gus, originally from Oslo and now living in the north with his fianc√©. He was a bartender at the bar, drinking there on his day off, stepping out occasionally for a hand-rolled cigarette.
It was interesting ‚Äî and refreshing ‚Äî to hear his impressions of Americans. He saw a disconnect between Americans‚Äô personalities and what he reads in the news. We are a welcoming people, he said, based on the conversations he had with Americans on all sides of the political spectrum. But if you judged us based on what you saw in the news, what would you think, I asked? I‚Äôd think you were absolutely out of your minds crazy, he said.
During our conversation, our bartender handed Gus two buttons, meant for Mike and me. They bore the name and logo of the pub. They said it was their stamp of approval on us as visitors, and that they welcomed us back any time.
After three or four or more beers, we called it a night, returned the to sky bar for a nightcap and a bag of chips ‚Äî and then turned in, alarms set for 4:15 am to make our 5:30 am bus ride, an additional four hours to the North.

Have you ever found yourself sympathizing with a known racist person or group of people? If so, this article will provide you with a lantern to make it out of the mental fog. Racism is a form of abuse. While most people do not develop Stockholm Syndrome during an abusive encounter, some do. They produce a psychological response that causes them to develop positive associations with an abuser.
You‚Äôve probably heard about examples of Stockholm Syndrome in bank robberies, kidnappings, and domestic violence circumstances. However, there is no reason why we shouldn‚Äôt analyze how race factors into abusive relationships. I suggest that Black people and people of color who develop positive feelings about racists actually suffer from Racial Stockholm Syndrome.
Consider Uncle Ruckus from The Boondocks animated series. He is a dark-skinned Black man who often denies his Blackness, praises white people while condemning Black people. For example, Uncle Ruckus sang, ‚ÄúColored folks talkin‚Äô about ‚ÄòSave Me!‚Äô / Wasn‚Äôt nothin‚Äô wrong with slavery! / At least we got good food back then ‚Äî uh huh, uh huh! / White man sho could be yo friend.‚Äù

In Los Angeles, the suburbs would always grow boring- a boredom similar to the tiring feeling of hearing the same song played over and over. At Princeton, you feel like you‚Äôre living in Neverland- nothing seems to change, and you always have this warm sense of quiet comfort. In Beijing, the weekends are occupied with sight seeing and night life, and the weekdays always seem to be moving in some direction.
Stockholm, Sweden is the most stable place I have ever lived. It‚Äôs also one of the most beautiful. Here‚Äôs a quick peep of the fountain right outside of my apartment:
Whenever I need a break from life, I always take a few minutes to sit by the water. Every few seconds, the wind blows the mist in your direction and you feel a momentary, gentle spray. It feels nice, like a cool, refreshing blanket that wraps around your shoulders. This is especially comforting when I think about home and the happier, safer days at Princeton.
And here‚Äôs a little view of the bridge connecting the main island with Gamla stan, the ‚Äúold town‚Äù of Stockholm that‚Äôs apparently a tourist trap:
During breaks and weekends, my friends and I would take short strolls around the city, and since the majority of Stockholm is built on water, the beautiful views are never-ending. Occasionally, I would find time to walk around the city on my own. As much as I hate being alone, I could explore this place for hours, aimlessly wandering and appreciating the bits and pieces of Europe.
For those of you who don‚Äôt know, I‚Äôm here interning for a company called Nova Global, a top-talent network that finds talented people around the world and yada yada yada. Work has been amazing, and I absolutely love my coworkers-they‚Äôve been a family to me.
But oddly enough, the memories that I‚Äôve appreciated the most belong to the little lessons of the day-to-day life. Every single morning, I find time to go to the gym and exercise before work. And every single afternoon when I get back from work, I do the same. I‚Äôve cooked nearly every other meal (Nikita, my friend/roommate, cooks the other half), and when the sink looks a little messy I‚Äôll hop right on the dishes. Thanks to Nikita (he used to be a Latvian pro swimmer), I‚Äôve learned how to prepare huge meals that are so healthy, you‚Äôd definitely have plenty left over unless you see the guy next to you scarfing down each last bit. I‚Äôm really grateful he‚Äôs here- he‚Äôs been like an older brother to me.
After reading this over, part of me wants to cringe at how spoiled I probably sound, but I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve been this happy for months. The first week was hard, but I finally feel like the background noise is subsiding and I‚Äôm regaining clarity and focus again. I‚Äôm finally back in my own skin.
Part of me will always be a little sad that I can‚Äôt return to the naive, safe-haven of my Sophomore year at Princeton, but I‚Äôm happy, and I‚Äôm remembering what it means to take life in strides. Week one has done me well, and I know that I‚Äôll always find some way to appreciate each day.
A few notes about Stockholm:
Yesterday, my friends and I decided to take an impromptu cycling trip through Liding√∂, a nature reserve slightly northeast of where we lived. Within half an hour, our surroundings transformed from high-rises and busy city intersections into miles and miles of forest and greenery.
Needless to say, it didn‚Äôt take long for a group of foreigners to get unbelievably lost on a never-ending trail of that. And every time I shouted to Nikita and asked if he knew where we were, we just laughed and shrugged. It was pure exploration, with no direction and no destination. It‚Äôs really been quite some time since I‚Äôve felt so free.
Saturday afternoon, a day prior to the three hour excursion through ‚Äúfucking‚Äù Liding√∂ (sorry folks, it‚Äôs an inside joke), Lucy and Tara convinced me to explore parts of S√∂ldermalm with them. Similar to my little cycling adventure, most of our trip consisted of aimless wandering, letting our minds digest all the ‚Äúnew‚Äù that was around us.
For some reason, the entire time I wouldn‚Äôt stop chirping about how I wanted to walk along the water. S√∂ldermalm was beautiful- arguably the most beautiful area of Stockholm I‚Äôve seen yet- but part of me was drawn so strongly toward the water. And somehow, we eventually found ourselves standing near a cliffside that held the most breath-taking view I‚Äôve ever seen. There was something special about the sight that restored that warm, comforting feeling that I‚Äôve felt lacking for a while. It‚Äôs probably the happiest moment that I‚Äôve had since I‚Äôve landed in Stockholm.
That was when I decided that I wanted my summer to be characterized by serendipity. Week One was characterized by routine and stability, and it‚Äôs done me well. But weeks Two through Ten are going to be filled with aimless exploration and travel. I‚Äôm booked to fly off to some new country nearly every weekend, and I‚Äôm searching for something ‚Äúnew‚Äù everyday. It‚Äôs almost like I‚Äôve grown an addiction to novelty.
If there‚Äôs anything I‚Äôve learned from ‚Äúfucking‚Äù Linding√∂, it‚Äôs that it‚Äôs OK to get incredibly dehydrated and lost in a forest for three hours. We made more than a few wrong turns, but everyone made it out (more-or-less) alright.
Here‚Äôs a list of ‚Äúnew‚Äù things I‚Äôve checked off or have yet to check off:
Part of me wishes that my mind read like a book, and that it would scribble down every moment I encountered just as it happened- a Carpe Diem recorder of some sort, I guess. But it doesn‚Äôt and it can‚Äôt, so I‚Äôll do my best to capture how important this weekend in Amsterdam was to me.
Better yet, let me clarify: I‚Äôll do my best to capture how important this burger-loving fiend is to me (sorry JD, but the picture‚Äôs gotta go online):
On July 15, 2015, JD Case touched down in Stockholm, and that‚Äôs when the (stupid decisions) adventures of Nathan in Europe really began. Europe, or at least the small portion of it I‚Äôve seen, is great, but there‚Äôs always this thin cloak of nostalgia for the lazy, na√Øve days of year two at Princeton. There‚Äôs plenty I miss- the spontaneous trips to Starbucks, the 3 AM League games, the Papa Johns, the 3 AM Papa Johns- and I couldn‚Äôt have been more grateful that a part of that was able to visit me halfway around the world.
Last week, I surrendered my summer to serendipity, and the aimless exploration continued when we landed in Amsterdam. We hadn‚Äôt booked a place to stay until the day of, but JD was able to nab us a few nice spots for a really good price. Here‚Äôs a glimpse of the view outside of the aptly named ‚ÄúRoomMate Hotel‚Äù:
If Stockholm‚Äôs a stable, structured meeting where everyone in the room is prim, proper, and on time, Amsterdam‚Äôs a massive, rambunctious bar where everyone‚Äôs intoxicated by early evening. Perhaps it was the company, but the city of bikes and beer is definitely one of my favorite places to be. For those of you who don‚Äôt know, JD‚Äôs spending this summer traveling the entire world. During our conversations, he mentioned that he never missed home much because with every new place, there was always something new to see and experience. And in Amsterdam, that statement couldn‚Äôt be any more true.
Wherever you go, the bright lights that reflect off the canal waters always seem to follow you- it really makes the city feel alive by night. When we weren‚Äôt lost or eating massive amounts of food, we were in some interesting bar sipping on beers or fancy cocktails. At Vesper Bar (a place that James Bond would go to for cocktails, and with good reason), I noticed their genius motto written on the blackboard after a few drinks in: ‚ÄúSummer is a time when you drink triple, see double, and act single.‚Äù It‚Äôs been a few days since I‚Äôve been back, and I think I can speak for both of us when I say that we respected that quote quite well.
Of course, the trip ended exactly as any adventure with JD Case and Nathan Lam would: food poisoning. The burger place we ate at above was great, but for some stupid reason we decided to hike twenty minutes to this other place called ‚ÄúBurgermeester‚Äù to grab dinner before I left, and that decision absolutely killed us. After an hour of (puking) lying on our beds in the room, we stumbled outside to enjoy a bit of Amsterdam minutes before I had to leave.
We sat by the water and talked about the ‚Äústrange corners of life,‚Äù tossing little pebbles off the edge to see ripples across the surface. Moments before my Uber arrived to take me to the airport, a little lady bug landed on my hand.
They say that‚Äôs supposed to be a sign of good luck, and I sure hope it‚Äôs true. I‚Äôve got eight weeks left to do and see everything.
A few things that serendipity brought us:
P.S. Don‚Äôt worry Chris and Jerry, there‚Äôs no way we forgot about you guys:
Here we have Chris 2Changz, shirtless as ever and with us in spirit and Snapchat. Don‚Äôt worry buddy, I‚Äôve collected a few bottle caps, and JD and I have something way better for you when we get back to campus. Jerry, you lucked out. I couldn‚Äôt find any embarrassing pictures, but I‚Äôll fix that up soon. I can‚Äôt wait to see what happens next year in Brown 423.
As you can see, it‚Äôs well into week five, but I‚Äôm going to do my best to do last week justice. Life in Europe hasn‚Äôt grown any less interesting, but it‚Äôs been raining lately, and the days in Stockholm feel as though they‚Äôre growing shorter and shorter. It‚Äôs not a bad thing ‚Äî rather, it‚Äôs as though time has simply lost the weight that it held weeks prior, and that I‚Äôve stopped counting the days. Novelty is always perfect for tying your mind to the present, and when you travel, you become fixated on exploration. It‚Äôs addicting, really.
Copenhagen, unlike Amsterdam, was peaceful, and I often found myself subsumed by random thoughts and musings about all the things that‚Äôve happened the past few weeks. Even though it really hasn‚Äôt been long, I think it‚Äôs fair to say that I‚Äôve matured a considerable amount. The bulk of the trip was spent with Lucy and Tara, but there were pockets of time where I wandered off, as usual, and stumbled upon those little treasures that make traveling worthwhile.
But I‚Äôll get to that later. First, I want to share all the weird things that happened. I feel like that‚Äôs more fun.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like a theme park, and the theme is weed.‚Äù ‚Äî Tara Ramdonee
Last week, JD and I stumbled into the Red Light District. This week, Tara, Lucy, and I discovered the Green Light District. Taking Nikita‚Äôs wonderful advice, we made it an obligation to explore Christiania, the ‚Äúmost ghetto, but safe‚Äù place in Copenhagen. Two things ran through my mind when I heard that statement. First, everywhere is probably safe for Nikita (the Latvian White Bear), because nobody in their right mind would threaten him. Second, if it was a ghetto, safe place, I imagined that Nikita probably was talking about some hipster hangout.
What we found was exactly as Tara aptly described above. I would‚Äôve taken a few photos, but there‚Äôre signs posted everywhere that have a cancel sign over a camera, indicating that I would probably be badly harmed if I let the camera whore inside of me take over. There was weed. Everywhere. If you bought two burgers, you‚Äôd get a joint for free. I could probably count the number of people who weren‚Äôt high out of their minds on my hand. Don‚Äôt worry mum, we didn‚Äôt smoke. We did, however, grab a few beers and have a pretty great conversation. However, the rest of the night wasn‚Äôt exactly noteworthy. While looking for some clubs in the area, we somehow stumbled upon some eighteen year old‚Äôs Danish birthday party where they played Soulja Boy Tell ‚ÄòEm.
On Sunday morning, Lucy recommended that we go to this nice little cafe called Bankeraat for lunch. She kept talking about these ‚Äústuffed animals‚Äù and how these things were dressed up, and knowing the Hello Kitty die-hard that Lucy is, I expected something similar to Sanrio. What we found was this:
Going to the restroom was an even more interesting experience. First off, the rooms with toilets don‚Äôt have lights. Second, they have jump scares like this around the corner when you go down this steep, curled staircase into the secluded basement that houses the restroom that people use on a day to day basis:
But other than the fact that I felt like I‚Äôve just stumbled upon the set of American Horror Story, the food was good.
All of these experiences were humorous and interesting, in a way, simply because they didn‚Äôt align with expectations. What I‚Äôm learning from all this traveling is that the world becomes unbelievably exciting when you escape expectation and let yourself float off in any direction you feel is right. I‚Äôll talk about one last experience, and it‚Äôll be the more sentimental of the three. Ready yourself for the strange abstractions.
Lucy was convinced- absolutely convinced- that the Little Mermaid Statue would be one of the prime tourist attractions of K√∏benhavn. And she was right, but not for the reasons she thought were right. Here‚Äôs a picture of the Little Mermaid and all its glory:
That‚Äôs it. A dinky boulder with Ariel chilling up top. I think my friend Eric Sohng actually would‚Äôve made a much better mermaid than the statue itself. In fact, I have photographic evidence (Warning: Adult Content). What was amazing about it was that heaps and crowds of tourists huddled around the rock, fighting for a prize spot with the star of Copenhagen.
However, there was value there, and it was in the water. I think I‚Äôve slowly come to realize that if I were to belong to any element in the world, I belonged to the water. Right next to the statue, there was a small, unassuming strip of land where the water met Copenhagen.
For a good while, I sat there alone and retreated far beneath the surface into my thoughts. The water felt so vast and immense, and it kept me entranced during the entirety of Lucy‚Äôs photo-op (probably thirty minutes). And somehow, something unexplainable in me clicked, and I felt a pull from the world to explore everything. By that, I mean parts of South America and the rest of Asia sometime next year, etc. You can‚Äôt really explain moments like these, but they shape you and change you, and they grant you new freedoms that slowly become part of your basic human needs.
Quote of the trip:
‚ÄúShall we summon an √úber?‚Äù
- Tara Ramdonee, our British friend
Perhaps it‚Äôs that I‚Äôve grown too busy with work and travel. Perhaps it‚Äôs that I‚Äôve really just stopped counting the weeks as I have the past month and fully adopted that Carp√© Diem lifestyle. Perhaps it‚Äôs both (it‚Äôs probably both), but for some odd reason, I have been finding it so much more difficult to sit myself down to continue documenting my trip here. But I‚Äôve started it, and I wouldn‚Äôt be proud of myself if I stopped it mid-way. Old Nathan would be fine with that. New Nathan is too, but for some reason there‚Äôs a bit more guilt attached to quitting midway.
‚Äî
Berlin is fucking rebellious, and I love it. In Stockholm, if you act slightly out of place in a public setting, you‚Äôll probably be arrested shortly afterward for disturbing the peace (of course I‚Äôm exaggerating, but you get what I‚Äôm saying). So being in a city where there‚Äôs graffiti on every building, drug dealers at every metro stop, and amazing street performers scattered throughout sidewalks was especially refreshing for me.
Story time: As short-lived as the trip was, it was full of unexpected encounters, and not in the same respect as the other trips have been. Because rather than encountering beautiful vantage points and little local treasures, I shared some odd coincidences with people who I either met or, more or less, shared ‚Äòpeculiar‚Äô ties with.
These coincidences happened a few times, but I‚Äôm only going to talk about the mind-blowing one because, well, who the hell wants to hear about anything else. On the last night I was staying in Berlin, Ray decided to stay at home. Makes total sense for him, because he doesn‚Äôt enjoy going out all that much. But for me, staying in would have been a crime because, well, I was in Berlin. And Berlin‚Äôs insane.
So I had a two options. I could try and make friends with strangers at the hostel and venture through the night with them, or I could go solo and pray that I would have fun and not look like that creepy lonely rando that you make a conscious effort to avoid on a night out.
Option One failed miserably, because everyone I spoke with in the hostel was 30+ years old and talking about heroine/death metal. Left with Option Two, I went off in some random direction and, as per the advice of my brilliant friend Stefan, just followed crowds. When I got off the metro, I saw a group of people speaking English with pretty strong American accents (yes, we have accents), and my first reaction was ‚ÄúThose kids are definitely in high school.‚Äù My second reaction was ‚ÄúThose kids are definitely from California.‚Äù I was completely off with the first guess, but spot on for the second one.
Ironically, when I passed by the group, I overheard one of the girls whisper to her friend that I was definitely from California. I guess cut-off tank tops and joggers throw you right in that bucket. And effectively, me being the desperate, lonely rando looking for friends, I turned around and, well, made friends.
Two of them were from Orange County, and all of them were juniors at Northwestern. And the crazy part is that they‚Äôre all relatively good friends with the group of Northwestern students that I met in Beijing last summer. Details aside, we had a pretty fun night, and I‚Äôm meeting up with a few of them when I get back to California in September. Despite all the wanderlust I‚Äôve been feeling lately, there was always this anxiety attached to the thought of traveling alone. But that night helped me realize that when you‚Äôre more or less screwed with no friends, you‚Äôll find ways to meet people.
‚Äî
Other than that, most of the trip consisted of photo-ops and (even more) aimless wandering. You could probably get the gist of the trip by scrolling through my album, since I upload enough photos to irritate the majority of my friends list, but I‚Äôll skim through a few highlights.
Bonanza Cafe. Cool place. It‚Äôs where I wrote the Week 4 post, so if I seemed over dramatic/sentimental, it‚Äôs because they were playing in Nils Frahm in the background.
I always have these recurring nightmares where I either get hit by a car or drive off a cliff. So, being the grim and morbid child that I am, this photo‚Äôs actually pretty important to me.
For some reason, this section of East Side Gallery made me so happy I almost cried. Not entirely sure why, but I guess it was a short reassurance that even if things go to shit, everything will more or less be OK.
Random Notes:
The thing with counting is that people usually count what they‚Äôre not all too fond of. We count push ups, the minutes of a long, boring meeting, the number of days before we can see a loved one again- we count because, in those few moments, our mind becomes fixated on the passing of time.
And quite frankly, when I first landed in Stockholm, I started counting. I counted the few hours I slept each night when getting accustomed to the early rise and late shine of Stockholm Sun. I counted the number of weeks until JD arrived, and the number of surface-level trips to various countries that I used as superficial fuel to rejuvenate myself. And, by nature of this blog, I counted the weeks. Each week was tinted with its own ordeal that made me mildly uncomfortable at best, and to compensate for the discomfort, I wrote. Every point in your life- even the dry bits- can seem so much more interesting when you put pen to paper and document it all in story. Unfortunately, when that happens, you run the risk of living for photographs and ‚Äúserendipity,‚Äù while casting everything else off as mundane. Trust me, it‚Äôs a pretty miserable perspective to have on life. Happiness becomes short-lived.
Roughly two weeks ago, I had a conversation with Nicole (Andrea‚Äôs Girlfriend! Go Andrea :D!) about how we‚Äôre both restless souls- the way four walls can transform into prison bars if too much time is spent at home. Eventually, we also spoke about how ridiculously unsustainable that is. And thankfully, when I started complaining about the the ‚Äòvanilla-ness‚Äô of Sweden and ranting about my wonderful wanderlust and need for novelty, she called me out on, well, how ridiculously unsustainable I was. Well Nicole, you got through to me pretty well, and I am infinitely grateful for that.
Recently, I haven‚Äôt written much, and I think it‚Äôs because I‚Äôve stopped counting. I still love seeing the world and exploring and wandering, but it‚Äôs no longer what keeps me afloat. It‚Äôs been a process, and I can‚Äôt deny that, but I‚Äôve really learned to find joy in the bits and pieces of life that I would have otherwise disregarded as ‚Äòboring.‚Äô Here‚Äôs a short list to give you an idea:
Come Friday, and I‚Äôll be in London with my supposed ‚Äòfianc√©e‚Äô, and come September 4th, I‚Äôll be home. I can‚Äôt say that I‚Äôve emerged a completely different person, but I can say that right now, I feel happy- sustainably happy- in the way that almost seems infectious enough to drown out the white noise.
How I‚Äôve Changed:

--
My mother calls me Neytin.

‚ÄúIf life were as simple as a day in July, would we honor it so?‚Äù ‚Äî P. J. Gordon
Can we honor the act of doing nothing more often? Would we tire of the nothingness? This reminds me of what some people picture retirement as, and I‚Äôve witnessed many who tire from nothingness; they yearn for regimented days of rules and restrictions. They worked all of their lives to be free, and now that they‚Äôre free, they miss their cage. It reminded me of Stockholm Syndrome. When someone has been held captive, they develop a psychological bond of trust and belonging with their captor. In my poem, I put the captor as our life‚Äôs occupation.
Stockholm Syndrome is what retirees fear.
We worked all our lives waiting on the year
‚ÄúWhat will we do with all the extra hours?‚Äù
‚ÄúGuess we can finally tend the flowers.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat will become of the position I held?‚Äù
‚ÄúWill they remember me? All I regaled?‚Äù
Years gone, time spent being fully engaged,
Almost free, but it‚Äôs hard to leave the cage.
~ P. J. Gordon
Retirement can be likened to graduation from high school. You worked hard for it, you‚Äôve done it, now what?

Title: The Stockholm Syndrome on a Species Level
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Most of the human suffering in the modern world boils down to our fear of death. This is not surprising, since modern mythology stipulates that matter is primary and basically all there is.
If nothing exists beyond, above or beneath‚Äìwhichever spatial metaphor you want to use‚Äìthe physical universe, every physical and practical expression within its confines appears to be very important, such as gender, age, nationality, organizations, career, money, politics, laws, hospitals, formal education, formal science and titles.
Until it is not, because we all die. How unfair.
The good news is that death is merely a transition from one state to another, just like birth is. Death and birth are exactly the same kind of event, only experienced from opposite angles. We come in and we go out. It is like a long breath.*)
Suffering and the idea of an ultimate death both stem from the illusion of time.
The above means that when we are afraid to die, we are actually afraid to go home. We desperately hold on to this temporary existence, as if a temporary sojourn could ever be a true home. We persuade ourselves that the stage play we are in, this video game, this boot camp, is all we have. We anxiously pay attention to the sergeants of the boot camp who shout out their orders
One might even describe our predicament as a prison we fear leaving. This is actually a pertinent analogy, since this phenomenon is well documented ‚Äî the psychology of it is well described in the wonderful film The Shawshank Redemption.
We desperately hold on to this temporary existence, as if a temporary sojourn could ever be a true home
When I look at our nonacceptance of death and unconscious rejection of home from a spiritual perspective, I see a collective Stockholm syndrome. A Stockholm syndrome on a species level, basically.
We have developed an understanding, even sympathy, for our prison guards, who constantly lead us to believe that this physical world with its societal structure, is all there is, and if we want to make the most of life, we‚Äôd better get out there and seize all the goodies we are able to lay our hands on and reach for as desirable a position in the structure we possibly can.
Of course, we can‚Äôt all acquire the same amount of things, and not everybody will be able to gain the most coveted positions. We learn this early on, and with that lesson comes another hard ‚Äùtruth‚Äù: Life is not easy. Who said life should be easy? Some win, some lose, but hey, you just have to learn to bite the bullet and do the best of your situation.
But here is the truth: the essence of life is actually very simple. Life is a continuum.
Deep within, underneath the constant chaos of thoughts and feelings, you can sense that you simply are. You are conscious ‚Äî you are consciousness itself. You experience ‚Äî you are experience itself. Hence you exist, and you cannot not exist, because that is not an experience. This is all you can ever really, truly, know for certain is real.
Life unfolds from there, and that is all there is to it. All else are temporary mental or emotional constructs.
This physical experience is no doubt immensely important and in many ways a marvelous adventure. But it is not the whole story. Not even close. The best way to approach earthly life is with equanimous curiosity and joy. Not as if it were dead serious. When we open the door to our infinity, a weight is lifted from our hearts.
When we dismiss this simple and self-evident inner knowing life appears complicated. That is when we get the false idea we lack something, and we feel miserable and anxious. Neuroscientists have tried for decades to locate where in the brain consciousness is produced, to no avail, of course. It is in that futile physical search for meaning we become depressed, whether we try to find it in the brain or by hoarding things.
A basic prerequisite for upholding this elaborate matrix is the idea that humans are at the core selfish
We all come into this strange and wondrous place with the inner truth intact. An inkling remains for a few years, but we gradually forget who we really are. We identify with a name, a skill, a position, a story.
For thousands of years a plethora of societal structures have been imposed on us. The guardians of these structures ‚Äî teachers, doctors, politicians, civil servants, lawyers, soldiers, journalists, researchers, priests, parents ‚Äî are themselves involuntary pawns in the game, at least the vast majority of them.
A basic prerequisite for upholding this elaborate matrix is the idea that humans are at the core selfish and unreliable, which is why a structural order is needed. We learn that rules and regulations keep this flawed species in check to the benefit of us all. This is a tragic deception. This is, quite frankly, a big lie.
This big lie operates side by side with ‚Äî and is fueled by ‚Äî the widespread fear of death.
Someone might object that people were even more scared of death a few hundred years ago, before the introduction of a physicalist worldview, when almost everybody was religious, at least formally.
This might be true, but the difference would be in degree, not in kind, because that ‚Äùreligiosity‚Äù was a very integral part of the matrix. In some ways the Church, for instance, was more materialistic than modern day atheism, whose proponents emphasize humanism. The Church was deeply in cahoots with the secular powers. Priests told people that God needed them to obey the lords of the world as well.
Adhering to a dogmatic, old-school religion is all about pleasing an external God and acquiescing to the hierarchy of His representatives on Earth. And if you don‚Äôt, you know which place you will be sent to.
The realization that we are all eternal sparks of God/Source/The One Consciousness is the most forbidden knowledge of all in the traditional Abrahamic religions.
We used science to drag us away from a system of outer oppression to a system of inner oppression
Wait, didn‚Äôt we liberate ourselves from all that when science broke with religion? It certainly looked like an attempt. But did we use our new scientific approach to find our way back to our true essence, our core of natural happiness? We did not. We used science to drag us in the opposite direction, away from a system of outer oppression to a system of inner oppression, called materialism.
Either your life is miserable because you are tormented by the constant condemnations of God and the Church, or your life is miserable because you feel the meaninglessness of being a randomly assembled flesh robot. In both cases you feel unfree. Imprisoned.
In the latter case, you may find temporary relief in embracing the system and its rulers, who tell you that all will be well if you just adjust a little bit more to fit into the intricate societal structures. So you try, once more, to do that. And to make the process smoother and less painful, you choose to sympathize with your prison guards.
This is psychologically very understandable as long as you don‚Äôt know that there is an alternative. But imagine the sea change in your perspective on life when you realize you can break out of it whenever you want. That all you have been told, and told yourself, about your identity is a chimera. That the essence of you is completely free.
If we all went there, no one would be afraid of death, and no one would want to control anyone or be controlled. The matrix would dissolve itself. It would be obvious there is no need for it.
*) I assume most readers of this essay are with me on what I state about a non-physical reality. However, if any readers are skeptical, simply imagine for a moment that there is a realm we temporarily leave when we are born into physical bodies and go back to when we leave those bodies, i.e. die. It may help to look into the well-documented accounts by people who have had near-death experiences, which by now count in the thousands; practically all of them say that the realm they have visited during those experiences feels very much like their real home and appears far more real than this physical one. New cases are being documented all the time. And then there is the research at the University of Virginia which, believe it or not, seems to confirm young children‚Äôs memories of previous lives. There is also other research pointing to a verifiable non-physical reality.
***
If you like this text, please check out my other essays on Medium
I have a podcast and a Youtube channel called Mind the Shift
I also have a website

I wasn‚Äôt going to write about the election since it gets exhausting. But if you‚Äôre like me, you find it increasingly difficult to understand how some of your friends, co-workers, and family members continue to support President Trump. Not because of policy disagreements over everything, although there‚Äôs plenty to go around, but because of who Trump is.
Stockholm, Wisconsin is a town of 88 people last time I checked. Almost 70% of them voted for Obama in 2008 and 2012. But most voted for Trump in 2016.
Four years later, it‚Äôs time to take an audit of this president before you vote again.
It‚Äôs not that everything Trump‚Äôs ever done is horrific, although there‚Äôs plenty of that to go around, too.
I‚Äôm not oblivious to the fact that he got NATO to pay their fair share of expenses defending Europe, despite decades of American presidents asking deaf European nations to pay more. Trump defeated ISIS in Syria. I mean, when‚Äôs the last time you even heard of that group since Trump. He brought Israel and numerous Arab countries together. UAE and Bahrain to start, but I have no doubt that we‚Äôll see another four or five peace agreements follow soon. Maybe more.

Title: What is Stockholm Syndrome
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

1
Listen
Share
Many years ago, I used to belong to an online community which is mostly made up of young women in their early twenties. A lot of folks usually send in their questions, queries and stories seeking clarifications and often times, advice.
On a particular day, a lady sent in a long message which signaled that she was pathetic to her abuser and was also very mindful of hurting him.
There were several comments but there was a particular comment which got my attention, the commenter said‚Äô She is suffering from Stockholm‚Äôs syndrome.
I was taken aback because the only Stockholm I knew at the time was a city in Sweden and my curiosity got the best of me. I really wanted to know what Stockholm's syndrome meant.
I decided to dig in and do a thorough research and discovered the following;
Stockholm syndrome explained
Stockholm syndrome is an emotional response which happens when an abuser develops positive feelings towards their abusers or captors.
The name came about by a man due to an incident which happened in Stockholm in the year 1973 It‚Äôs a story which depicts the loyalty of hostages to their captors.
This illness was named after a bank robbery that occurred in Stockholm, Sweden in 1973.Many of the imprisoned bank employees got sympathetic to the bank robbers during the six-day standoff with authorities.Following their release, some of the bank employees went as far as refusing to testify against the bank robbers in court, and even raised funds to defend them.The term ‚ÄúStockholm syndrome‚Äù was coined by a criminologist and psychiatrist(Nils Bejerot) examining the incident to characterize the affinity some bank staff had for the bank thieves.
What causes Stockholm‚Äôs syndrome
1. Overdependent
When you‚Äôve been dependent on your captor/abuser for basic needs, there‚Äôs a high tendency of emotional reliance on them.
2. Fair treatment
When hostages have not been threatened or when they‚Äôre being treated nicely. It becomes a dent of STOP IT, I LIKE IT
3. When hostages haven‚Äôt been dehumanized in any form.
Stockholm Syndrome and children
For situations involving children such as child abuse, there could be an emotional imbalance where the child sees the abuser as a protector especially if the abuser is a close ally or a family. Abuse in this form can be confusing for children because most times, abusers tend to intimidate and threaten their victims from speaking out. At the same time, the abuser also shows love and care to the child. This creates a confusing scenario and can also breed Stockholm syndrome where the child grows up believing the abuser to be a protector rather than a molester.
Stockholm Syndrome and tutors
In the same vein, people who have abusive coaches, tutors and teachers might develop a deep emotional connection with them and rather than see them in the light of the abuse, they create and give excuses for them thereby defending and sympathizing with them.
For Emotional, physical and mental abuse, The victims tend to develop an emotional connection with the abusers because emotional abuse on its own can make a victim develop a trauma bond with the abuser.
A trauma bond is a deep seated bond between an abuser and the person they abuse.
Stockholm Syndrome and sex trafficking
In the movie Gangubai Kathiawadi, which told the story of a young woman who was lured into prostitution and sold off to a sex trafficker, the lady refused to join in the venture because she considered it to be immoral and dishonorable. Day after day, she was subjected to series of inhumane treatment and she knew that in other to survive, she had to join them.
This goes to show that people who are captured and sold off into sex trafficking tend to rely on their dependents for survival. This can create a form of dependence on their abusers.
Is Stockholm Syndrome a mental health disorder?
Even though Stockholm‚Äôs syndrome isn‚Äôt listed as a formal mental health disorder but rather an emotional response to abuse.
However, there are common symptoms for people who have been victims of abuse such as;
1. Withdrawal
They tend to withdraw from people because most of the time, they find it hard to trust others and tend to believe that every other person is out there to hurt them.
2. Post traumatic stress disorder
PTSD is characterized by failure to recover after a traumatic event or in this case, abuse
3. Sleeplessness
4. Denial
5. feeling of hopelessness, failure, helplessness and often times
6. Depression.
If you or anyone you know is suffering from the Stockholm syndrome, please see a therapist as soon as possible so as to curtail any further imminent serious mental disorder.

25‚Äì27 Sep remembered on 8 Oct
After another 12-minute walk from the US embassy, I arrived at Etnografiska Museet, where everything converged.
This was where Peng worked during his time in Sweden, also the home of most of Sven Hedin‚Äôs collection. I spent 150 SEK for the ticket. The size of the museum is slightly smaller than I expected, but of course, it wouldn‚Äôt be fair to compare it with the British Museum or Mus√©e du quai Branly. The first exhibition I encountered on the ground floor was Yokai, an exhibition about the Japanese Yokai culture (something ghostly or monstrous, but not exactly ghosts or monsters). It was well-curated, informational while entertaining. I was not sure if the credit should go to the Etnografiska Museet or other institutions who co-curated it. However, it was recommendable.
Despite its good quality, for a Taiwanese, Yokai culture is not something unfamiliar, and it also wasn‚Äôt the reason of my visit. So I quickly browsed through, and moved upstairs to continue my search.
When I was at the entrance, I saw one of the current exhibitions called ‚ÄúWe are Seediq‚Äù. I thought to myself that ‚ÄúOh, there is an indigenous group in Taiwan also called Seediq. What a coincidence.‚Äù Turned out that the exhibition was about the indigenous group in Taiwan. The exhibition was small, but again, well-curated and informational.
It is hard to describe how moved I was. I believe that it was the first exhibition that I‚Äôve ever liked in any ethnographic museum. I am sure by now you can imagine, as someone like me, it‚Äôs impossible to be completely comfortable, seeing how these items were raided by Eurocentric collectors, explorers, or let‚Äôs be honest, colonisers, in the past, and seeing how the cultures were interpreted, as if there weren‚Äôt, or aren‚Äôt, any actual human beings attached to the said culture. It has always been something fascinating while irritating for me to visit ethnographic museums.
The curatorial concept of this exhibition started with a number of mysterious items as part of the museum collection, from an unsurprisingly problematic source. (What I love about it was also that the ‚Äúproblematic source‚Äù was clearly stated in the exhibition.) The reason I said ‚Äúmysterious‚Äù, was because it was actually wrongly labelled as items from Atayal originally, instead of Seediq, due to the mis-categorization from the Japanese colonisation.
‚ÄúWe are Seediq‚Äù was co-curated among a number of institutions, including the Seediq National Assembly, and the Indigenous Cultural Heritage Master‚Äôs Program of Providence University in Taiwan. The involvement of the ‚Äúsubject‚Äô themselves could be seen everywhere.
First, the title, the ‚Äúwe‚Äù implies the existence of human subjects, instead of merely culture or items. It was coming from the mouth of the subjects, not observers. And all the texts written were in three languages ‚Äî Swedish, English and Chinese. (I know it‚Äôs not Seediq, but at least it‚Äôs a language that most of the Seediq nowadays can understand.) The interviews of Seediq people were presented as one of the major elements in the centre of the room. The faces and voices were unavoidably seen and heard. What moved me the most was that one of the weaved fabrics in the collection was considered the oldest, documented Seediq weaving pattern preserved in the world. And the museum is working with the organisations in Taiwan to study the pattern in order to recreate them. Even writing about these is making me emotional.
The ‚Äúcollection‚Äù here is no longer some ‚Äúdead‚Äù items lying inside a glass vitrine. The ‚Äúculture‚Äù has become alive, moving, working, involving. Then there is a meaning. There is a reason for all of these to happen. I know one might say that the museum should return the stolen items to Taiwan for good. (The texts mentioned that the items were in Taiwan for a time being before being returned to the museum.) I understand it‚Äôs not perfect. But honestly, despite the problematic, upsetting source, can we, as Taiwanese, be confident that the items would be well-stored forever, in a professional context on the island? And just reading the texts in the exhibition of a culture that somehow I found adjacent to (I wouldn‚Äôt dare to say that it‚Äôs mine) in my native language, already gave me goosebumps, which is something I can never dream of seeing in places like the British Museum. I haven‚Äôt even started to mention how Taiwan, as a country, as an island with adjacent islands, was being presented correctly in the exhibition, which is again, something I can not dream of in a European context.
After seeing the exhibition, I couldn‚Äôt help but make an Instagram story, recommending it, tagging the museum. I received a kind message from someone who runs the account. I genuinely hope that all the exhibitions in ethnographic museums could make me feel this way. I also heard that there is someone from Taiwan working at Etnografiska Museet at the moment. I am sure that helped with what I saw.
Finally, at a corner on the 2nd floor, I found something from Sven Hedin, titled Golden Temple. It‚Äôs a model temple he commissioned to make, identical to a temple he encountered in Chengde, China.
I was surprised about how little collections from him were on display, so I asked the friendly staff at the information desk in case I missed anything. She explained that on the ground floor, where the Yokai exhibition is, was Hedin‚Äôs collection. but it was removed for the Yokai exhibition. I asked if the collection will come back after Yokai ends. She replied, slightly awkwardly, with a no. I was curious about her reaction, so I googled afterwards. Turned out that the Swedish historian Tommy Lundmark published a book recently, criticising the display of Hedin‚Äôs collection in the museum. He believed that the way the collection was displayed touched only lightly, perhaps too lightly, on Hedin‚Äôs support of Nazism. Despite that Hedin being a Nazi supporter was not a news anymore, the book seemed to stir more controversies than there was. And the museum, using the coming exhibitions as a cover, removed all the Hedin‚Äôs collection, with only the temple left.
It‚Äôs a complicated issue. I don‚Äôt feel like I have any position to judge. As a researcher, of course I would like to see his collection. However, I also believe that before figuring out a proper way to deal with the problematic history, removing the collection for the time being, was more than understandable.
After the conversation with the helpful staff, I moved on with my day.
The next stop was Hedinsgatan. After I arrived, I found out that ‚Äúgatan‚Äù means ‚Äústreet‚Äù in Swedish, instead of ‚Äúgarden‚Äù, as I originally thought due to its pronunciation. So, Hedinsgatan, is a street named after Sven Hedin in Stockholm. It was just an ordinary street. I couldn‚Äôt find anything special. I also couldn‚Äôt figure out the reason why this street in particular was chosen to be given the name. It was not specially close to where he used to live, or the cemetery, or the museum. It remained a mystery to me till this day.
Finally, it was five. We were back to Historiska Museet. I couldn‚Äôt find anything from Sven Hedin here, however, after knowing what happened to Etnografiska Museet, I doubt if the museum would want to point out which items were actually from Hedin anyway.
A cute anecdote happened was that, when I arrived, there was a celebratory event of the independence day of Armenia. A lady downstairs asked me to sign on the RSVP list, and I was confused, saying that I was only here to see the exhibition, so she let me pass. After going upstairs, witnessing the champaign and catering of the party, I wished I had signed so I could join. I thought about blending in, however, with my cheap, slightly torn out jeans, and the oversized jacket as a charity from my friend in Berlin last year after losing all my clothes in a luggage, I had a feeling that the plan of blending in naturally would fail. So, I tearfully walked away from the champaign and the finger food.
After the museum, I stopped by a supermarket to grab some bread, cold cuts, spreads and a light beer (which had a significant meaning that I only understood in a few days). I sat down by a beautiful harbour, and started my dinner. I was surprised that I couldn‚Äôt see anyone else doing what I was doing. The view was stunning. I remembered sitting by the Seine everyday with friends, enjoying wines and picnic-made sandwich in Paris. After a while, the wind started to blow into my bones, and despite the sunny weather during the day, my fingers started to freeze, and suddenly I realised why I was the only person sitting on the floor at this harbour, picnicking.
The next day, I visited the Konstmuseet in Sk√∂vde by train, to drop my large suitcase, so I wouldn‚Äôt have to travel in Europe inconveniently while paying for the overpriced luggage fee charged by the budget airlines (and not to mention the fear of losing it again). The trip took me almost the whole day. The 10:30am train was delayed for half an hour, so I arrived at Sk√∂vde at around 1pm. After a pleasant chat with David, the technician of the museum, who is also someone from Goldsmiths Fine Art, I went back to the station for my 14:28 train, which was again delayed for 45 minutes, and I ended up arriving at Stockholm Central after 5pm.
With some not-so-worth-mentioning anecdotes happening on the train, I arrived back at the hotel with a sense of relief, since everything I needed to do for work in Stockholm these days was done. To celebrate, I decided to take advantage of the gym downstairs. After spending 30 minutes on treadmills and other machines that I can not name, I felt like a human again. I know the ecstasy was all psychological, as a relief from the anxiety of aging and weight-gaining. Gym is a middle-class fantasy of a healthy life. When I was running on the treadmill, I believed that I was no longer the girl wearing the torn-out jeans, having cheap sandwiches and light beer sitting by the harbour, freezing, fantasising about the free champagne at other people‚Äôs parties. Whatever that was, it helped. I loved going to gyms, delusional or not.
I decided to spend my last day in Stockholm (this time) with art. After my last luxurious breakfast at Hotel Expo, I sadly said goodbye to it, and took a train and a bus to Karolinska Institute. It was where Carl Gustaf Bernhard, the host of Peng during his stay in Sweden, worked. I took some photos, and moved on to the Moderna Museet. Moderna Museet is a modern and contemporary art museum in Stockholm, connected to Arkdes, a design and architecture museum. Luckily, Arkdes offers free admission throughout the year of 2024, so I visited both museums in the afternoon, before heading to the airport, taking my 19:45, SAS flight to Heathrow, London.
I guess it‚Äôs about time to face this.

Aftab
We begin with Aftab (Persian for ‚Äòsun‚Äôs beautiful rays). Let‚Äôs send Aftab to a school friend you‚Äôve lost touch with and would like to reconnect to.
How do you send Aftab ‚Äî close your eyes for 10 secs and send the suns rays to those you have in your heart. And add to this ‚Äú<name> may you be at peace, may you be happy‚Äù and turn that to yourself ‚Äúmay I be happy, may I be at peace‚Äù
For the past 2‚Äì3 years, I‚Äôve had the privilege of coaching a tremendously talented former colleague on and off. Our most recent engagement concluded last Friday, and I‚Äôve come to realize that one of the most valuable words she needs in her life right now is ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù‚Ä¶.and that too for turning clients away who are no longer a match for her. This message is for her and for any of you as it may offer guidance to some of you in similar situations.

Title: Stockholm Syndrome: Capitalism Edition
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

ThoughtMatter is a creative branding, design and strategy studio with an artful perspective

--
1
Listen
Share
Ever had the sneaking suspicion that the corporations you hate have trapped you in an endless buying cycle?
You‚Äôre confronted with sobering stats about the effects of smartphone addiction on mental health, but your phone‚Äôs the first thing you reach for in the morning. You‚Äôve watched that documentary about the true cost of fast fashion to the environment, but you can‚Äôt resist those $10 yoga pants. You‚Äôre appalled by the piles of waste generated by single-use plastic, but you still get your coffee to-go in disposable cups and your food delivered every day. You fully understand how algorithms are designed to harvest your attention online for profit, but you feverishly refresh your Instagram feed.
Why does the captive start falling in love with the captor, who suddenly seems so indispensable and necessary for survival? Why do we hate how brands use and treat us, but keep going back for more? Consider this: your brand loyalty and relationship with monolithic corporations might actually be a version of Stockholm Syndrome.
First, big brands lure you in with the product and create the illusion of scarcity, making you feel like doing without it isn‚Äôt an option. And then, when you‚Äôre finally held hostage, even the slightest act of generosity will get the company in your good graces (see: corporate social responsibility and activist ad campaigns). In time there‚Äôs some scandal or controversy with clear evidence that the brand is causing unnecessary harm to reap immense profits ‚Äî but you remain loyal through it all, even feeling friendliness where there should be fear, admiration where there should be contempt.
This is one of the most despair-inducing aspects of Stockholm Syndrome: in the end, even after being released, the captive defends the captor.
Various scholars and experts have tried to put a finger on why. A book on surveillance capitalism by Shoshana Zuboff here, an explosive Medium article on Capitalist Stockholm Syndrome by Umair Haque there. Trouble is, we often don‚Äôt even realize we‚Äôre being held hostage. The recently viral, user-generated ‚Äú10 Year Challenge,‚Äù where people post then-and-now photos of themselves on social media, is actually an astroturfed meme to train Facebook‚Äôs facial recognition capabilities, speculates Kate O‚ÄôNeill from Wired. In 2009, you logged into Facebook. In 2019, Facebook logs into you.
Worse yet, brands themselves admit they aren‚Äôt good for us ‚Äî it‚Äôs one of the ways they keep us in line, so to speak. Apple wants to help curb your iPhone addiction with Screen Time, a new feature that breaks your smartphone usage down to the specific apps in the hopes of motivating you to spend your time differently. Cigarette conglomerate Philip Morris International just embarked on an anti-smoking campaign as part of their vision of a smoke-free future. And in what sounds like a headline from The Onion, Coca-Cola and other junk food giants in China have successfully been funding the narrative that exercise ‚Äî not cutting down on sugar ‚Äî can fight obesity. They use their role in creating ‚Äúsolutions‚Äù to problems in which they, themselves, are complicit to generate positive PR, reeling us right back in.
Why, despite all this, do we remain brand-loyal? In the 2018 dark comedy Sorry To Bother You, union organizer Squeeze explains, ‚ÄúIf you get shown a problem but have no idea how to control it, then you just decide to get used to the problem.‚Äù
There‚Äôs also nobody else for us to go to. A protest sign spotted at the 2019 Women‚Äôs March highlighted the fact that that there‚Äôs more public trust in gas station sushi than in President Trump, which isn‚Äôt a total exaggeration. Amazon and Google beat political parties and the state government as some of the most trusted entities in an American Institutional Confidence Poll conducted online by YouGov in 2018.
In recent years, capitalism‚Äôs sheen has (finally) started fading. Today only 19% of Americans ages 18 to 29 identify themselves as ‚Äúcapitalists‚Äù, and the trend goes hand-in-hand with the rising popularity of the Democratic Socialist values espoused by Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y.
This week marks the start of the World Economic Forum‚Äôs annual meeting, attended by hundreds of the world‚Äôs most powerful leaders. The United States‚Äô Trump, France‚Äôs Macron and Britain‚Äôs May could not make it because they are busy tending to crises at home with big economic implications ‚Äî the partial government shutdown, Yellow Vest protests and Brexit. It behooves the meeting‚Äôs attendees to acknowledge that our economic systems are in serious disrepair, and that rapidly rising income inequality is a feature, not a bug, of late stage capitalism.
So how do we ensure that we don‚Äôt fall prey to Stockholm Syndrome yet again, making new excuses and justifications for the next generation of brands as we wrestle free from the mega-corporations that control so much of our lives today?
As we enter the fourth industrial revolution, we need to reconsider the role and purpose of the corporation on our planet, and weed out the put-up-or-shut-up variety of consumerism. In his new book Prosperity, Colin Mayer of Oxford‚Äôs Sa√Ød Business School offers a new definition for private companies: ‚ÄúProducing profitable solutions to problems of people and planet.‚Äù Will we keep condoning the harm that some corporations inflict on society and the environment, or will we demand that they do more, do better? It‚Äôs time for the captive to thwart the captor.
This post was written by Shivani Gorle with thinking contributed by Brendan Crain. ThoughtMatter is a creative branding, design and strategy studio in New York City‚Äôs Flatiron District. Find us on Twitter.

Long time no see, or at least on English. I have started to write a bit more on Swedish and more company and It-security focused articles. The reasons behind it is somewhat because of i have started a company! Finally i have teased about it for some time now, am i right?!
So https://lysellssecurityandtech.com aka Lysells Security And Tech AB is live and up and running as a fully working company with stocks and CEO and management and so on, ‚Äúonly‚Äù me and my wife still but it is a real company :D
Therefore i will move and probably write a bit more on my new website, with a bit more focus on Security parts and what is happening within security, more focus on companies and Enterprises. But fear not i will write more here on Medium but probably a bit more like write-ups, personal thoughts and stuff that maybe not is compliant with company blogs and stuff.
So as of 12th of august i am traveling to Stockholm, Solna to be precise, every Sunday i take the train up and Thursday i travel home again, it is a lot of time being spent in Stockholm where i am work as an It-security Architect for a financial company and during the nights i try to be busy writing articles, Talks and trying to get a bit more customers where i can help out with Security work. Just to keep busy and i love to work with Security so it is a win-win situation, and if i can work as much as i want to on the evenings when i am in Stockholm that means i can focus fully on Wife, Dogs and Family when i am home, i may even not need to work on Fridays either, so that means i will have 2.5 days home with family and wifey.
But the thing is because i am working and travelling that much i have setup some timeplanning as well, so Sunday and Saturday is full family time the phone is ‚Äúoff‚Äù and i focus on private time, Fridays will be a mix, i will often sleep in a bit because i often get home at midnight or even later but then on Friday i will be available for calls and some work-meetings, i do have planned some talks and lunch meetings often on Fridays so often half days.
That is one thing i recommend, plan your time so you get recovery and quality time with the loved ones, for me as a workoholic i work best to do some work on Fridays just for my own sanity and that is the time i have NOT being on other assignments so it is the right thing for me do some work and often many clients wind down on the afternoon of a Friday so friday until lunch is a way to get some stuff done.
But then be able to have the Friday evening, Saturday and Sunday off and get that quality time is golden. I will probably do some every other week in the future not doing it every week as i am doing now, because it costs a lot of money living at hotels and being away from family is tough. But for now it is a fun adventure and the travel home 5‚Äì6 hours is often a good way to wind down even if the way home is the worst one, you just want to get home and you cannot get there fast enough!
This was just a word blob, basically a brain dump of my thoughts and some tips and tricks.
But until next time! Be safe on the internet and be safe!
