I love Chigozie Obi‚Äôs artistry and I love her personality even more, so it made so much sense that I desired to have a conversation with her.
Two failed attempts at meeting and a birthday pool party after, Chigozie and I finally linked, and we had a conversation about everything ‚Äî from love to relationship dynamics, fitness, friendships, work and her love for Lagos that may suggest she has Stockholm syndrome. The conversation was so good that we planned a second date.
I walked into Basilico ‚Äî where Chigozie had been working all afternoon ‚Äî some minutes before 4pm. I scanned through the floor but couldn‚Äôt find her until she popped up from the lounge in a corner, wearing a smile so wide and looking so good, as ever, in a lovely dress. She was excitingly taller than I pictured or, if I‚Äôm being honest, I was probably shorter than I thought.‚ÄúOh my God, you look so beautiful in person,‚Äù I said. Chigozie is more beautiful in person.‚ÄúYou too!‚Äù She exclaimed in a smile. ‚ÄúI love your top,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúThank you!‚Äù‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry I dressed down. Had a crazy gym session,‚Äù she said, walking in a limp. Chigozie has been in the gym for a year now and is notorious for tweeting about the woes of exercising, whilst showing up everyday.‚ÄúThat‚Äôs so true! I should have worn slippers,‚Äù I said, looking at my flat heels and then back at her pair of white slippers. ‚ÄúSorry about your pain. You‚Äôre really trying o. I‚Äôve attempted the gym twice and I‚Äôve quit twice,‚Äù I said, chuckling.She laughed. ‚ÄúHow?‚Äù‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt have a trainer and thought I could wing it like people say. Although the first time, a friend was my gym partner until she moved. The second time, I was checking out YouTube and stuff for routines. So both were sort of epic fails. I think I lasted two weeks for both,‚Äù I said, chuckling.Chigozie laughed. ‚ÄúI have a trainer though.‚Äù‚ÄúYea, I saw. How has that been for you?‚Äù‚ÄúI really like it. I like that I can just go in there without having to think of what I want to do, and just let someone else think for me and instruct me. My only job is to just show up.‚ÄùI giggled. ‚ÄúI like that.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI see you have a new hair done,‚Äù I said, looking at her black braids.Chigozie‚Äôs eyes beamed. ‚ÄúYea, I did it yesterday,‚Äù she said, excitedly. Her excitement was so real, it was contagious.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really pretty,‚Äù I continued in admiration.‚ÄúThank you. I like your beads too. You look like an African Queen.‚ÄùI chuckled in excitement. ‚ÄúThank you!‚ÄùCompliments are ten times better when they come from women.
‚ÄúHow are you? How has Lagos been for you?‚Äù Chigozie asked, looking at me.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been okay, it‚Äôs been chill. I miss my family sometimes though,‚Äù I replied.‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs family?‚Äù‚ÄúMy family home‚Äôs at Ekiti.‚Äù‚ÄúOh okay.‚Äù‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù I asked chuckling.‚ÄúNo, Ekiti is very chill.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah, it‚Äôs very slow too, and then Lagos is pretty fast. Too fast.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah, I really love the mountains as well. It‚Äôs very serene.‚Äù‚ÄúHave you been?‚Äù‚ÄúYeah. I went in secondary school to‚Ä¶‚Äù‚ÄúIkogosi,‚Äù I finished her statement and we burst out laughing.‚ÄúExactly, exactly,‚Äù she said in a smile. ‚ÄúThen I went again for an Art Bootcamp. I think that was when I really explored. I went to Ikogosi again, but I also went around town and stuff, and I was a bit older. It wasn‚Äôt like a school thing, so we had more freedom. It‚Äôs a really beautiful place.‚Äù‚ÄúLots of mountains everywhere.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah. When I travel outside of Lagos I discover we‚Äôre not chilling here at all. It‚Äôs so fast-paced and so chaotic.‚Äù Chigozie laughed.‚ÄúVery chaotic.‚Äù‚ÄúBut the thing is that I feel like I have stockholm syndrome. Anytime I leave Lagos, I get homesick and want to come back almost immediately.‚Äù‚ÄúReally?‚Äù‚ÄúYeah. For example, when I went to Abuja, I was homesick in the first couple of days. It was pretty slow and I was shocked because I thought Abuja was like the ‚Äònext Lagos‚Äô or something, but nah.‚Äù‚ÄúAbuja is actually so dead, not gonna lie,‚Äù I said, chuckling.‚ÄúFor real, but apparently, the people who live there like it so much.‚Äù‚ÄúAnd when they come here also, they want to go back. They basically can‚Äôt stand Lagos either,‚Äù I said.‚ÄúExactly. When we tweet about Abuja, they‚Äôre usually like, ‚ÄúNo, don‚Äôt come o. We don‚Äôt want you here.‚ÄùI laughed. ‚ÄúFor real.‚Äù‚ÄúI want to go back again though; just to chill or relax.‚Äù‚ÄúHow many times have you been?‚Äù I asked.‚ÄúOnce.‚Äù‚ÄúMe too.‚Äù‚ÄúIt‚Äôs crazy how I got really home sick when I traveled to London last year for a residency, too. I think the best time to travel to London is summer, maybe June or July, when everywhere is bright. It‚Äôs very beautiful then.‚Äù‚ÄúWhen did you go?‚Äù‚ÄúI went in April. There was a lot of rain and the weather was so gloomy,‚Äù Chigozie said, irritated at the thought of it. ‚ÄúI get. I hate gloomy weather so much. It‚Äôs such a mood dampener.‚Äù‚ÄúExacly! I made a lot of friends though, but depression was really‚Ä¶ was really hitting. I was like ‚ÄòAhahn.‚Äô‚Äù It felt like she was recounting a traumatic experience.I laughed. ‚ÄúI was so happy on the night I got back to Lagos,‚Äù Chigozie said, shaking her head.‚ÄúYou were like ‚Äòfreedom at last!‚Äô‚Äù I exclaimed in a chuckle.‚ÄúYes o. Lagos is very chaotic, but it‚Äôs still home.‚Äù‚ÄúIf you could live in anywhere else asides Lagos, where would you live?‚Äù‚ÄúI think Ghana.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah? You traveled there earlier this year right?‚Äù‚ÄúYeah, I did,‚Äù Chigozie said. ‚ÄúGhana is kind of like Nigeria in some sense. Asides the borders being close, there‚Äôs a lot of similarities between us in some ways, with the people and culture.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah. That makes sense.‚Äù
We continued our talk about how chaotic Lagos is and how comfortable it is to take walks in Abuja compared to how abysmal it is to do so in Lagos without being catcalled or enraged by drivers who threaten to hit you with their cars. Chigozie then tells me that she would love to move to a place large enough to ride a bicycle in.
‚ÄúOh you can ride a bike?‚ÄùShe puts on a slightly judgmental look. ‚ÄúYes I can. Funnily enough, whenever people tell me they can‚Äôt ride a bike, I‚Äôm like how?‚Äù she asked squinting in disbelief.‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù I was almost ready to fight.‚ÄúWhat were you doing when you were younger?‚Äù Chigozie asked, confused.‚ÄúNot riding a bike, I guess?‚Äù I giggled. ‚ÄúWhen did you start riding a bike?‚Äù‚ÄúI can‚Äôt really remember, but I was pretty young.‚Äù‚ÄúDo you have a bike?‚Äù‚ÄúNo I don‚Äôt have a bike right now,‚Äù Chigozie said. ‚ÄúBikes are so expensive now, so I‚Äôve heard.‚Äù‚ÄúYea, I heard too. Me, I was thinking maybe it was like 100k or something.‚Äù‚ÄúMe, I thought it was 30k o, I swear.‚ÄùWe let out a laugh. ‚ÄúEven bikes are expensive right now. Everything is so expensive‚Äù‚ÄúFor real. Funny thing is that I made a tweet one time; something in the line of ‚ÄòHow come you don‚Äôt know how to ride a bicycle?‚Äô That‚Äôs how some people took it personally. I was like please nau.‚ÄùI chuckled. ‚ÄúYou were like ‚ÄòSorry, I didn‚Äôt mean to.‚Äô‚Äù‚ÄúSee. One person said I was classist or something.‚ÄùI laughed out loudly. ‚ÄúHow did we get here?‚ÄùChigozie chuckled. ‚ÄúIt was crazy because my friends and I would joke about it and we‚Äôd laugh, you get? After I gave the girl my reply, I just blocked her. That‚Äôs alright, that‚Äôs alright.‚ÄùI chuckled.‚ÄúIt was obviously a joke, you know? Me, I don‚Äôt know how to swim and I‚Äôm 26 right now.‚Äù‚ÄúI can‚Äôt swim either. I attempted one time and I almost drowned,‚Äù I said.‚ÄúMe too! I‚Äôve almost drowned as well,‚Äù she said in a knowing tone. I gasped like I had just made a fun discovery of shared trauma. ‚ÄúIt was a terrible day. It was very scary.‚Äù‚ÄúExactly. And you wouldn‚Äôt be able to do anything.‚Äù‚ÄúYou‚Äôre just there!‚Äù‚ÄúFor real.‚Äù
We spoke for a while longer about swimming, the injury she sustained on her knee ‚Äî that led to the failure of our first attempt at meeting‚Äî and how random events can make efforts on skincare futile.Chigozie also told me about how she had initially planned to have a birthday pool party at the restaurant we were, until she was told that there was a minimum spend of 500k.‚ÄúThat‚Äôs so crazy because you didn‚Äôt even know what you were going to order for yet,‚Äù I said with a surprised look on my face.‚ÄúThank you. It didn‚Äôt make sense at all. And I was so disappointed because the guy who initially told me it was okay didn‚Äôt apologize for the inconvenience or whatever. I felt bad about it until a friend linked me to another location. It‚Äôs called 37 Lagos, and it was so good! Plus their pool is way larger than the one they have here.‚Äù‚ÄúOh real? Lagos restaurants are really coming up with this minimum spend thing and it‚Äôs so annoying,‚Äù I said, recounting my own experience.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs unnecessarily classist and annoying. I almost cancelled my birthday plans, but a friend linked me to another location.‚Äù‚ÄúDo you have pictures from that day? I don‚Äôt think I saw them.‚Äù‚ÄúOh real? Are you sure?‚Äù ‚ÄúYea. I think I only saw the pictures where you said you had a good day.‚Äù‚ÄúLet me show you,‚Äù Chigozie said, opening her Twitter app and scrolling through her media. I spotted a viral video of Trevor Jackson covering Tyla‚Äôs Water ‚Äî Chigozie had posted the video earlier that day, and we laughed about it, knowingly.‚ÄúYou‚Äôre such a menace,‚Äù I said in a giggle.She laughed. ‚ÄúThat video is so funny. I laugh every time I think about it.‚Äù
‚ÄúHow did you have a pool party without knowing how to swim though?‚Äù I asked on a lighter note while looking through the videos of her pool party, but I was genuinely curious. The pool was truly large.Chigozie chuckled. ‚ÄúSo I basically just stood in the shallow end and was kicking my feet. I don‚Äôt know how to swim, but I love water. I love being in water.‚Äù‚ÄúInteresting.‚ÄùI found it even more interesting because she loved something that she almost drowned in.‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù
‚ÄúSo how are you right now?‚Äù I asked.She hesitated. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just here. I‚Äôm okay. Turned a new age.‚Äù‚ÄúHow does that feel for you?‚Äù‚ÄúIn my head, I feel like I‚Äôm still 22, to be honest. Or 23. Every time, I‚Äôm like ‚ÄòWow, I‚Äôm 26.‚Äô Obviously, I don‚Äôt behave like a 22 or 23 year old, but in my head I feel like a baby. Like I‚Äôm still quite young.‚Äù‚ÄúLike you‚Äôre just a girl,‚Äù I said amused.Chigozie smiled. ‚ÄúExactly! Like I‚Äôm just a girl,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt feel that much different, to be fair, but next year, especially with my work, I want it to be more successful. I feel like this year was calm, basically for resting. It was easy, more about figuring stuff out. I‚Äôm slowly getting into work mode already though, but next year will be awesome.‚Äù‚ÄúWere you excited about your birthday?‚Äù‚ÄúYes, I was, actually. Usually, I‚Äôm not necessarily excited for my birthday, but this year I decided to be. Even when the plans for my birthday location fell through and I was sad, the next day, I got up and decided to be happy,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou only get one day to truly celebrate yourself ‚Äî one day that‚Äôs for you, so I believe we should try to really enjoy those special days.‚Äù‚ÄúYea exactly. You‚Äôre not lying.‚Äù
Chigozie got a call that lasted for about a minute. A call that started with ‚ÄúHi baby‚Ä¶‚Äù and sounded pretty intimate too.
‚ÄúAre you in a relationship?‚Äù‚ÄúSo I got into one recently,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúOh so you‚Äôre new,‚Äù I said chuckling.She smiled ‚Äî or blushed. ‚ÄúYeah. I feel like I‚Äôve known him for a while though. Like I‚Äôve known him for the longest, which is really great because we kind of like eased into it.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah. I feel like going into relationships slowly makes a lot of sense; instead of just rushing into it.‚Äù‚ÄúExactly,‚Äù Chigozie said. ‚ÄúSo it‚Äôs really nice. I feel like it‚Äôs one of those things that make life less difficult and crazy.‚Äù‚ÄúI feel you. Having someone to text on those crazy days can be very sweet.‚Äù‚ÄúFor real,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAre you in a relationship?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I replied almost immediately and we both burst into a long laugh.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the way you replied so fast for me,‚Äù Chigozie said in a laugh.‚ÄúOh my God. I didn‚Äôt know it came out so fast either,‚Äù I said, still laughing.‚ÄúAre you like searching or something?‚ÄùI hesitated. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm actively searching,‚Äù I started. ‚ÄúI enjoy having crushes though,‚Äù I continued in a grin.‚ÄúCrushes can be fun,‚Äù Chigozie said.‚ÄúYeah. I‚Äôm so done with situationships though. Like it‚Äôs enough.‚Äù‚ÄúThank you please!‚Äù She exclaimed in alliance.‚ÄúI want something really sweet.‚Äù‚ÄúYou‚Äôll find it.‚Äù‚ÄúWere you looking for love when you found it?‚Äù‚ÄúNot necessarily. I had gotten out of a thing when it happened.‚Äù‚ÄúOh you got out of a relationship this year?‚Äù‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù Chigozie paused. ‚ÄúWell, no.‚Äù She smiled. ‚ÄúWe were pretty much undefined.‚Äù‚ÄúA situationship?‚ÄùShe laughed. ‚ÄúMore or less. Exactly.‚ÄùI chuckled. ‚ÄúHow was that?‚Äù‚ÄúNever again o!‚Äù Chigozie exclaimed.We burst out into a laugh that said a lot about the crazy experiences we‚Äôve both had.‚ÄúLiterally never again. I tell everyone I know not to go into situationships. Unless you‚Äôre both really okay with it, it‚Äôs fine,‚Äù Chigozie said.‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm a lover, to be honest. I‚Äôm a very big lover girl. So situationships are not my thing. I‚Äôve not had a lot of them so when people talked about them, I was like ‚ÄòI can‚Äôt relate,‚Äô until I related and was like ‚ÄòOmo, this thing is crazy o!‚Äô I can‚Äôt be doing this please.‚ÄùI laughed.‚ÄúAnd I feel like situationship breakups hurt even more than relationship breakups. With relationships, you had that person, you experienced that person, but with situationships, it‚Äôs just something that never was.‚Äù‚ÄúExactly. It didn‚Äôt even happen, but like it was so exciting.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah, like so much impact still. So I don‚Äôt recommend for people who love love and are very soft because they‚Äôll definitely fall in love. It‚Äôs even more risky when sex gets involved.‚Äù‚ÄúFor real. There‚Äôs this bond that‚Äôll be created. A bond that might only be in your head. Like it‚Äôd be only you catching feelings.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah. So I think it‚Äôs best to just save yourself while it‚Äôs still early because the deeper you fall into it, the more hopeful you get and the more tragic the end is,‚Äù Chigozie said.She made a lot of sense.‚ÄúI saw a video one time and it described how, with men, loving occurs in a process, but with women, they most likely have feelings for a man before they even start dating. There‚Äôs this rush already.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah! That‚Äôs so accurate. I think we get too emotionally connected and sometimes we don‚Äôt even know how connected we got until much later and we‚Äôre like ‚ÄòWow. This thing really impacted and affected me.‚Äô‚Äù‚ÄúAnother thing I don‚Äôt like about situationships is how you can‚Äôt hold the other person accountable for the stuff they do that may have offended you, but with relationships, you can sit your partner down and explain in detail,‚Äù I said, tapping on the couch we were sitting on.Chigozie chuckled. ‚ÄúYou would even have the right to have the conversation. Honestly, I feel like I can be so self aware with people, so I always like to check in. I never want to overstep my boundary or feel like I‚Äôm doing too much, so I always try to be clear. That‚Äôs not something I can enjoy doing in situationships.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah, for real.‚Äù‚ÄúAnd when you get into healthy relationships, you realize you wasted so much time holding on to half-assed love,‚Äù Chigozie said.‚ÄúRight?‚Äù
We talked further about how relationships hold so much weight and how important it is to be with someone who, according to Chigozie, would not be one of your 99 problems and would love communicating with you, even during fights.‚ÄúThe worst thing is when you‚Äôre an overthinker and you‚Äôre not with someone who loves listening to you and is interested in validating your feelings. Every action weighs on you,‚Äù Chigozie said.‚ÄúYeah, that‚Äôs so true,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI think that when somebody raises an issue or talks about a weird way you treated them, it‚Äôs not because they hate you. I think that if they tell you that you did this, it‚Äôs because they like you enough to talk about it and they still want you to be in their life.‚Äù‚ÄúExactly.‚Äù‚ÄúAnd most times, how you see things might be different, but it‚Äôs so important to validate those feelings still. They‚Äôre not talking about what you meant or your intent, instead, they‚Äôre talking about how you made them feel.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah. And I feel it‚Äôs so important to be considerate in expressing your feelings too. I also believe it‚Äôs important to lay your feelings down on the table and talk things out ‚Äî my friends have really helped me with this. You know, you might even end up apologizing, but at the end of the day, your connection grows stronger and that‚Äôs better than any ‚Äòwin.‚Äô‚Äù‚ÄúFor real. I really feel you on that.‚Äù
We talked more about conflict in relationships ‚Äî be it romance or friendships ‚Äî and how important it is to address issues with the other person in mind. We also talked about knowing when to let go of certain people when issues keep recurring and there‚Äôs no potential of a better relationship with them.
‚ÄúSo I want to ask a question about your artistry. How come all your paintings look like you?‚Äù My question was almost accusatory.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not even intentional,‚Äù Chigozie replied, giggling. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not even doing it on purpose all the time. A lot of my paintings speak on things concerning me, so yeah those ones, but I actually don‚Äôt do it on purpose.‚Äù She paused. ‚ÄúYeah, maybe I know my face so well and the way I paint sometimes reflects that, but I don‚Äôt mind it though because at the end of the day, a lot of the things I paint speak to me, so I feel like in that way, I‚Äôm just sharing pieces of myself with people and then, even though it‚Äôs unintentional, it makes my art more recognizable. So whenever people see my painting, they know it‚Äôs Chigozie that did that.‚ÄùI smiled. ‚ÄúYeah like ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs Chigozie Obi‚Äôs art!‚Äô I think that‚Äôs unique.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù‚ÄúSo have you ever had a solo exhibition in Lagos?‚Äù‚ÄúSo I had one at the Art X Lagos Fair. That was my first, but I want to have one next year. One that isn‚Äôt attached to an organization or body or something. Just completely mine. So hopefully that goes well.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah, it‚Äôll go well. I‚Äôll come.‚Äù‚ÄúYes, you have to come!‚Äù Chigozie exclaimed. ‚ÄúI have so many ideas I want to bring to life. Four fingers crossed that it goes well.‚Äù She chuckled, crossing her fingers.I laughed.
‚ÄúSo you‚Äôre a first daughter. Did you see those tweets about first daughters and pieces of advice for them?‚Äù I asked referencing a Twitter trend.‚ÄúI saw a few and there was one I saw that said ‚ÄòLearn when to detach from people,‚Äô and it really hit me,‚Äù Chigozie started. I feel like I hold on to people and give them multiple chances and I feel like that may have stemmed from my experience as a first daughter. I‚Äôve learnt that I have to learn how to be myself first, and when I lost my Mum, I think it became a thing of ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre the Mum now and you have to take care of your brother and your Dad,‚Äô but eventually, I was like I still have my own life whilst still checking in and making sure they‚Äôre good.‚Äù‚ÄúWhen did you lose your Mum?‚Äù‚Äú2019.‚Äù‚ÄúOh really?‚Äù‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù she paused. ‚ÄúAfter my Mum died, it sunk in that you can literally die at any moment, and when you die, nothing matters. Not the money, nothing at all. And even if people celebrate you on Earth, you‚Äôll never know. So I find enjoying myself a big deal. It‚Äôs so important to me. I might not do it in the most extravagant way because money is so important, but I always try to find pockets of joy.‚Äù‚ÄúAnd I think you have a lot of fun too,‚Äù I said.‚ÄúYeah, I try,‚Äù Chigozie said. ‚ÄúI think the misconception people have of me though, is that they think my life is so soft, like I have people who will dm me and be like ‚ÄòChigozie, you just dey chop life o,‚Äô but I‚Äôm like, I‚Äôm out here busting my ass o. I might not just show all the processes, but underneath all of that, it‚Äôs still work,‚Äù she said. I chuckled. ‚ÄúYeah, I feel you.‚Äù‚ÄúI take and post a lot of pictures though. When my Mum died, we only had about three pictures together.‚Äù‚ÄúOh my God.‚Äù That was sad.‚ÄúI know right? So I told myself I want to start documenting everything, from my friends, to what I‚Äôm doing, places I visit, everything actually.‚Äù‚ÄúYeah. I‚Äôve seen your Instagram page dedicated to pictures of places and things too,‚Äù I said, referencing Le Journal De Gozie. ‚ÄúYeah. Sometimes, when I‚Äôm feeling down, all I need to do is scroll through my Instagram accounts, and it‚Äôs pretty easy to document on Instagram and Twitter too.‚Äù‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs very intentional. It‚Äôs really nice and I love the concept of it.‚Äù‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù she said, smiling.
‚ÄúI think you‚Äôve really hacked your style too. I notice you love clothes,‚Äù I said.‚ÄúYeah, I do.‚Äù‚ÄúYour outfits are pretty.‚Äù‚ÄúRight? Thank you. I think that I‚Äôm evolving too. One thing I don‚Äôt want to do is feel like I can‚Äôt wear certain outfits because I‚Äôm growing older. I want my style to remain like this forever. One day, I‚Äôm wearing ashewo clothes, the next day, I‚Äôm dressed like a boss lady. The next day, I‚Äôm doing office worker. The next day I‚Äôm doing stripper.‚Äù‚ÄúDoes it depend your mood?‚Äù I asked before realizing the last thing she mentioned, and I laughed.‚ÄúSometimes,‚Äù she said, laughing. ‚ÄúI notice that when I‚Äôm feeling down, I wear black a lot.‚Äù‚ÄúNow I‚Äôm going to be on the lookout for you in black,‚Äù I said, joking.She laughed. ‚ÄúNo no, it‚Äôs not all the time. I‚Äôm wearing black tomorrow for my birthday dinner.‚Äù‚ÄúOkay. After tomorrow, I‚Äôll be on the lookout for you in black.‚ÄùChigozie laughed.
‚ÄúSo you mentioned earlier how expectations have shaped you in some way as a first daughter and how you‚Äôve managed them. Are there childhood events or trauma that you feel have, in some way, affected your current view of the world or how you relate to people?‚ÄùChigozie hesitated for a second. ‚ÄúHmmm not particularly, but I know that growing up introverted, it took me having female friends to open up to certain things. I grew up with so many boys around me and I didn‚Äôt really lean into my feminine side while growing up as well. I think I was a late bloomer too. Growing up like that didn‚Äôt make me feel so great or feminine in a way, but my female friends have helped me to open up more and appreciate my body more. It‚Äôs also much easier to talk to them about topics like sex. I had to become more confident with saying how I feel and sharing how I certain things affect me too,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI did like a 180. Is it 180 or 360?‚Äù Chigozie asked. She was trying to describe the turning point in her life and I found it hilarious.‚ÄúYou sha did something,‚Äù I replied, laughing. My brain was not processing that either, to be honest.She laughed. ‚ÄúI sha did something,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI feel like younger Chigozie would be happy with where I am right now.‚Äù‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure she is.‚Äù
I listened to Chigozie tell me about how growing up introverted made her self aware, and maybe a little too much in some cases, as she has now grown to be more calculative of the things she says, who she says them too and where she says them. It‚Äôs not exactly a problem though because she would never be silent when she needs to speak. It was then I realized that I hadn‚Äôt ordered for a drink or food yet.
‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm ready to have a drink now,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúYou should have the chapman. It‚Äôs really good.‚ÄùI was staring at the menu. ‚ÄúOh really?‚Äù ‚ÄúYeah. People say the pineapple juice is good too though.‚Äù‚ÄúNah, I‚Äôll have the Chapman. What‚Äôs their pizza like?‚Äù‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so good, but disclaimer: It‚Äôs really simple. There‚Äôs nothing much happening with it.‚Äù‚ÄúI love my pizza like that though. Is it flat?‚Äù‚ÄúYeah, it is. I usually have the pepperoni,‚Äù Chigozie said. ‚ÄúMy boyfriend‚Äôs not a fan of it like I am though.‚ÄùI chuckled. We had two pepperoni pizzas to go and the Chapman was really good. I tried not to finish it in one sip. Chigozie said I did a good job for not finishing it all at once.
‚ÄúI really like this space,‚Äù I said, scanning through the restaurant.‚ÄúYeah it‚Äôs pretty chill. Have you been to Goda√Øf?‚Äù‚ÄúNah I haven‚Äôt.‚Äù‚ÄúWe should go there next.‚ÄùI squealed in faux excitement. ‚ÄúIs that a second date?‚Äù Chigozie laughed.‚ÄúYou know those moments when you go out on a date and you get excited when they start planning a second date before the end of the first?‚Äù I asked.‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Chigozie replied, smiling.‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how I feel right now.‚Äù

Stockholm Syndrome, a perplexing psychological phenomenon, has captured the attention of experts and the public alike due to its intricate interplay between captive and captor. This psychological response, which was first observed during a bank robbery in Stockholm, Sweden in 1973, continues to raise questions about human behavior under duress.
When individuals find themselves in situations of extreme vulnerability and captivity, they may develop a peculiar bond with their captors. This bond appears counterintuitive, as one might expect fear and aversion to predominate in such scenarios. However, Stockholm Syndrome highlights the complexity of human coping mechanisms, shedding light on the psychological mechanisms that drive these unexpected emotional connections.
Victims of Stockholm Syndrome often display empathy and loyalty towards their captors, perceiving them as protectors or guardians rather than aggressors. This psychological shift can be attributed to several factors, including perceived dependency on the captor for basic needs, isolation‚Ä¶

Content:

No trip to Stockholm is complete with a visit to the archipelago. Let me guide you to some of my favourite spots‚Ä¶
‚ÄúStockholm i mitt hj√§rta, Stockholm in my heart ‚Äî a city of islands, that is you.‚Äù Those are the words by Lasse Berghagen that fill the air every Tuesday summer night as thousands of people, gathered at open air museum Skansen for the popular singalong TV show Alls√•ng p√• Skansen, take tune. As their words travel across the bay below, the cameras pan over the stunning water landscape and one wonders if the melody manages to reach all of the 14 islands that make up the capital of Scandinavia ‚Äî or indeed the patchwork of 30,000 islands that spread out beyond that.
Stockholm is beautiful any time of the year, but the magical, seemingly endless, summer light sees the capital come to life more than ever ‚Äî and at this time of the year there is only one place to be. Outside.
Whether it‚Äôs a walk through the national park and museum island of Royal Djurg√•rden or a stroll along the picturesque S√∂der M√§larstrand, a run along √Örstaviken or a panoramic tour of Fj√§llgatan, the inner city waterfront views are breathtaking. However, a summer trip to Stockholm is not complete without a trip to sk√§rg√•rden, the archipelago.
To explore the 30,000 islands that make up the Stockholm archipelago (all accessible thanks to the Swedish Right To Roam), simply hop on a traditional white, wooden boat from Waxholmsbolaget or a speedier Cinderella ferry from Str√∂mma. Once on board, the archipelago world is your oyster.
Where to go? Here are a few suggestions.
Fj√§derholmarna is a good start. Located 30 minutes from Stockholm‚Äôs Nybrokajen, this cluster of islands is the closest archipelago destination and it offers both beautiful countryside and bustling town life. Here you can explore traditional handicraft, sample beer at the local brewery, try handmade sweets at the chocolate factory and indulge in delicious ice cream from Systrana Degens Glassstuga. Once you‚Äôve tasted what the town has to offer, why not stroll along the beaches, take a dip in the sea and spend the evening unwinding with a glass of wine and fresh seafood at one of the many restaurants? Life could be worse.
Waxholm is without a doubt the capital of the archipelago. Complete with its own castle, built in 1549 to defend King Gustaf Vasa, this historic old town comes with pastel-coloured houses, art, shopping and good food. It‚Äôs a great option if you want to mix nature with culture and it is also accessible via car or bus, should you prefer getting around on land.
Grinda sits at the heart of the archipelago and is an island that, located about an hour from Stockholm, just epitomises serene Swedish countryside. Step back in time as you step off the boat and find yourself in a nature reserve decorated with idyllic, old-school red and yellow houses, wild nature and beautiful beaches. The art nouvaeu style Grinda W√§rdshus restaurant is open weekends and holidays and you will not struggle to find a blissful place to picnic on the rest of Grinda. Just lush.
M√∂ja is the spot for the active traveller. Ideal if you want to do more than just chill by the beach, this large island is well suited for bike trips and day hikes ‚Äî and do make sure you climb to the top of V√•rdkaseberget and enjoy a stunning view of the surrounding scenery. Beaches are less accessible here, so it‚Äôs not necessarily one for swimming, but you can eat freshly caught seafood at Wikstr√∂ms Fisk, a tavern run by the archipelago‚Äôs only professional fisherman.
Sandhamn is a well-known, idyllic harbour and popular destination for big yachts and their owners. Located about an hour from Stockholm city, Sandhamn offers sandy beaches (as indicated by the name ‚Äî it literally means Sand Harbour), bike trails, kayaking and spa, not to mention plenty of restaurants and bars; this is without a doubt the party central of the archipelago.
Finnhamn is your destination if you want to see more of the archipelago as part of your trip. Getting here takes about 2.5 hours by boat so you want to set off in time ‚Äî but what a journey it is. Expect plenty of photo opportunities on board, and do try to get a good seat outside if the weather is nice; there are few things as peaceful as tanning on a boat gliding through sk√§rg√•rden. (Though it can get windy so do pack a jumper in case.) Bring a picnic blanket, snacks and bikini for a day of ultimate relaxation ‚Äî once on the island you will find perfect trekking conditions and many a private bay to picnic, tan and swim. Just don‚Äôt miss the last boat back, though if you do you can always stay overnight at the local hostel.
Ut√∂, meaning Outer Island, sits farthest out in the Southern part of the archipelago and so offers a very wild, natural experience. A visit here is all about enjoying the elements. Renowned for the many hours of sunshine that it gets, the island serves up white sand beaches, cliffs and various sporting opportunities including canoeing, biking, tennis, beach volleyball and boules. Hike around the island and get the best view from the 18th Century windmill.
As you can tell there is plenty of option in the Stockholm archipelago, but regardless of your choice, you will find yourself unwinding with every breath of fresh sea air ‚Äî and returning back home you may just find yourself singing about your love for Stockholm‚Ä¶
For more information about Stockholm archipelago, or Stockholm in general, see visitstockholm.com. #SwedenYoureWelcome

Title: Stockholm Syndrome
Content:

Freedom is scary.
That is the thought I left you with last time.
As much as we want freedom, getting there requires that we sever the umbilical cord that connects us to the lies and limiting beliefs that we have come to rely on from day to day.
And that is scary.
I believe this is why people cling so tightly to their guns and their religion and their political affiliations.
Fear.
The thing about fear, though, is that, in most cases, it is not based in tangible reality. It is not the result of something that has actually happened to an individual. But, rather, it is centered in some kind of what-if or hypothetical scenario.
Fear finds its sustenance in the straw man.
Let us take guns for example.
People cling extremely tightly to their guns and their right to own them. So much so that they are unwilling even to restrict other‚Äôs access to them, even if those people legitimately should not be allowed that responsibility.
Even at the expense of other‚Äôs lives, these people will defend their guns.
Why?
Because of a perceived need to protect themselves from a tyrannical government or from the off chance that a fully armed intruder will break in to their home. Neither of these things are terribly likely to happen in the grand scheme of things.
But the fear is there. And someone has told them that the solution for these fears is a gun.
And so their beliefs about the world have become restricted and limiting. And therefore how they view the world has become warped.
And that distorted view of the world creates more fear and therefore a tighter grasp on what is perceived as the solution to that fear.
And so on and so on it goes.
Fear causes us to believe only the most limited of things about the world and ourselves. And these limiting beliefs act to keep us chained to a radiator in the dark basement of our souls.
And there we believe we must stay, no matter what.

Title: Stockholm Syndrome, Cults and God-men.
Content:
Sign up

Sign up

When I was in ninth standard, I first came across him. He was from another school. People called him Andrew. He was not the tallest, but was the strongest. He was unbeaten at arm wrestling. There was a certain charm about him that all the boys flocked around him. They all looked forward to be with him. To be in his company, was considered privilege by clueless fourteen-year-olds. He would influence major decisions, dictate terms, bring in new trends and wore the best clothes because his father was a rich man. He always had at least half-a-dozen boys hanging out with him. After school, he would form a circle with those boys and pick two of them and made them fight. Like a referee, he would signal the start of the bout and wait until one of them was completely on the ground, and gave up. He enjoyed while the boys fought and after the fight, both of them would continue to walk around him, like nothing happened. They were just following orders and it didn‚Äôt affect them emotionally, although I‚Äôm sure physical pain lasted.
One day at school, Andrew was caught copying in the English exam. And in those days, punishments were ruthless. Especially, in that school, they had a public-shaming vice-principal who would beat the shit out of the kid in assembly if the crime was grave enough. The next day, before the start of the Maths exam, the vice-principal called Andrew out and announced to the whole school that he had copied in the English exam. And he began to hit him with a cane. After seven or eight blows, the stick broke and the beating continued by hand. There was hair pulling and ear pulling and unlimited supply of swearing. After about five minutes, the beating stopped and everyone was allowed inside the exam halls. After the exam, all the seven or eight boys who hung around him, returned to their duty ‚Äî standing beside him. And the first thing Andrew said to them, ‚ÄòI didn‚Äôt get hurt at all. In fact, the stick broke!‚Äô and everyone hailed him as a legend. That was my introduction to blind followers.
Now extrapolate this story to the current crisis in North India. Everyone knows that their chief has been convicted of rapes without any reasonable doubt and still, they continue to take his side. And they will defend to death, their leader, who is their only sense of self-worth and identity. Young, old, men, women and even young girls have come out in his support in lakhs and they think he is innocent. They don‚Äôt just think, they believe the whole thing to be a conspiracy against him, perpetrated by the state.
In psychology, there‚Äôs a concept called the ‚ÄòStockholm Syndrome‚Äô, where the hostages start liking their kidnappers and form a psychological alliance with them. Sometimes, very strong emotional develop between two persons where one person intermittently harasses, beats, threatens, abuses, or intimidates the other. In this case, although it is legally proved that the so called saint is a rapist, somehow it puts into question, the years of dedication they have displayed towards him. It is like you pet a snake since the day it hatched and one day, it grows big enough to bite you, the the only person who loves it. But then, you like the snake so much that you are ready to die by its poison.
In 2010, I was working with a film director helping him complete a paranormal/horror movie script. During those sittings, we happened to discuss a god-man from Andhra Pradesh who charged about five lakhs for a darshan. That is, you have to pay that money just to see him. And there is a long queue of people willing to do that. In fact, people wait for months for their turn. Then, I asked him, what about poor people, don‚Äôt they have access? He said, ‚ÄòIf you can‚Äôt afford him, you can pay two lakhs and see his wife.‚Äô
His answer blew my mind. Then, I asked him, what is so special about meeting him? Why should one pay that kind of money? To which, he said, ‚ÄòI have a friend who pays five lakhs every now and then. He says, it is his aura. The moment you enter the room, you can feel his aura. And if he touches you, his aura stays with you for a long time and it will attract all the positive things, makes you rich, literally and mentally.‚Äô
To an extent, I believe in the concept of aura and positive vibes. But people willing to pay for it? That was a new. An eye-opener. So while we‚Äôre at it, if you go and tell this friend of the director, that the god-man is a fraud and that he‚Äôs been exploiting the vulnerabilities of gullible disciples, what do you think will happen? He will tell you to get the hell out.
That‚Äôs what cults do. When a person gets indoctrinated into a belief system and start following a guru, or a god-man, what actually happens is that they build a strong, unbreakable bridge with them. And in the process of building that bridge, they shut off all roads toward rationality and ability for freedom of thought. It‚Äôs a tunnel with no other outlets. And that liberates people, because this sense of belonging to that cult, it‚Äôs better than their current life. And what looks like liberation, is actually, a long, endless, incarceration of the mind.
‚Äî Deepak Karamungikar

Title: Data viz challenge #1
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

DVS is a space for enthusiastic designers, developers, artists, statisticians, journalists, and all kinds of other amazing people interested in data to network and getting to know each other.

--
Listen
Share
Hello and Hi!
This is the first dataviz challenge for the Data Visualisation Stockholm (DVS) Meetup group. We‚Äôve been discussing holding a challenge for at least a year and FINALLY we‚Äôve finished the first one!
DVS was founded two years ago when the two original organisers started their own two dataviz Meetup groups just a few days apart in Stockholm, Sweden, but then decided that Stockholm was a one-dataviz-Meetup-group town and joined forces. We both wanted to create a space where we would gather enthusiastic designers, developers, artists, statisticians, journalists, and all kinds of amazing people interested in data to network and get to know each other. We also wanted our members to have the opportunity to grow as data designers.
We have discussed holding challenges for a while now, but it took an enthusiastic member asking us to stop procrastinating (Thanks!) and get on with it. But the discussions were not fruitless; they got us talking about the types of dataviz challenges we liked and the kind wanted to run. We determined that a fun and engaging challenge, one that we would want to participate in, had two equally important parts, an interesting theme and a design constraint. The theme would attract participants and the design constraint would challenge them to be creative.
This first challenge was all about Stockholm winters. The dataset had data on snow depth and temperature in Stockholm stretching from January 2021 all the way back to the beginning of the early 20th century.
I must say that I was quite impressed with the variety of submissions we got!
So in no particular order lets go through the charts and see all submissions. Descriptions were written by the respective authors.
WhoMatthias Stahl. Freelance data visualisation designer with a history in bioinformatics, passionate about the combination of data, code, art and design to craft beautiful and impactful visuals.Twitter: @h_i_g_s_c_hLink to the interactive viz
CommentI wanted to go for a spiral layout as this enables the year-wise comparison of this periodic data. I then transformed the temperature and snow data into binary variables ‚Äî fitting to the overall black-and-white theme. Is there snow: yes/no; and is the temperature higher than 10 ¬∞C: yes/no. The best way to encode the temperature turned out to be the spiral line thickness. The circles for the snowy days are apparently inspired by snowflakes. In order to make it clearer that circles represent snowy days, I added a snowing animation.
Tools: Sketch on paper, then Svelte and D3
WhoAlenka Gucek. Postdoc at Uppsala University, studying diabetes and cell biology. I‚Äôve always enjoyed doing visualisations for research and now I‚Äôm looking for ways to change career to dataviz.Twitter: @alenka_gucek
CommentOriginally I was planning for a gif with falling snow, but it looked like too much of chart junk. Then I switched to do something simple and informative, inspired by Evelina Judeikyte‚Äôs talk [at one of the Meetup events] on simplicity, annotations in The Economist and spark lines by Edward Tufte.
Tools: Excel, Origin and CorelDraw
WhoNina Lindell. Data visualisation engineer at Telia, building products based on mobility data.Twitter: @ninatsutsLink to the code
CommentI wanted to make the data look like piles of snow, and finally create a ridge-line plot (aka joy plot). I have recently started learning D3 and the challenge seemed like a good opportunity to try out my skills on a real dataset. I decided to keep the last 50 years of data and only look at the snow depth. There are still some things I would like to improve upon ‚Äî highlight interesting data points with annotations, mark the scale, and make winters continuous so that at least November ‚Äî March are on the same row. That is something for the next iteration.
Tools: Tableau for prototyping, D3 for the final chart
WhoTyler Wolf. Data visualisation specialist at King Games.Twitter: @tylernwolf
CommentI thought about the question ‚Äúwhat does a month look like?‚Äù And then broke it into the two pieces of data we had in the dataset: temperature and snowfall. But then I wanted to give it context and look for patterns, specifically thinking of the question, are days getting hotter? ‚Äî obviously thinking of climate change. So I ran a moving average on temperatures to break the temperature component into above or below average for that month. I did this because we can conclude that it‚Äôs cold in the winter and hot in the summer already, so a relative comparison gives more context. That made three pieces of data. Finally, I thought about how much I like it when it snows, so it would be nice to get an idea of how many days it was actually snowing in each month. So with those pieces of data and the limitation of black and white only, I experimented with rectangles and lines until I arrived at something that felt right and could condense the data, making each month look unique and allowing their elements to interact with each other. The aesthetic was inspired partially by some of giorgia lupi‚Äôs work.
Tools: D3 to draw the graphics, observablehq to get up and experimenting quickly and Figma for early sketching and to draw the legend and title.
WhoPatrick Wojda. Data visualisation and front-end engineer at Aftonbladet, Swedens largest online newspaper.
CommentLooking through the data I realised that there were too many years in the dataset to visualise without losing the personal perspective so I filtered the data on a personal question‚Ä¶ were my childhood winters snowier than what my kids get to experience? I did all of the data cleaning and formatting using Javascript (lodash and D3). The most fun aspect of the challenge was figuring out the design, but I spent almost all of the time on data processing. I iterated over the design multiple times, both hand-drawn and in code before I got to where I wanted.
Tools: Javascript, lodash, D3, Svelte, Paper app on IOS for sketching.
That‚Äôs a wrap!
Stay tuned for more challenges, we will be announcing them on our GitHub repo (https://github.com/Dataviz-Stockholm/challenges).
Take care and stay safe.

Title: I am definitely maybe suffering from Javascript-related Stockholm syndrome.
Content:
Sign up

Sign up

12
Listen
Share
According to Wikipedia, there are four components that comprise Stockholm syndrome:
I was never a huge Javascript guy. I‚Äôd use jQuery from time to time. Sometimes, I‚Äôd use it to make some AJAX calls and maybe change an element or two on a Rails app I was working on. Life was simple, with jQuery doing most of the grunt work and me doing nothing at all. I didn‚Äôt need to know much about Javascript at all and that was the way I liked it.
I was eventually asked to develop a desktop application for authoring media-heavy multi-language content. Not wanting to descend into the waking nightmare that is Java Swing that I had learned to hate in graduate school, I quickly picked up Angular (1) and Electron. It was magical.
I loved how simple everything was. I could write to disk as often as I wanted using Node‚Äôs NON-BLOCKING IO (very web-scale). Callback hell was a little difficult to deal with, but then I learned about Promises and entered Promise hell. The fires in this hell were a little less intense, so it was all good. Even better, I now reside in the promised (haha get it) land of Async Await.
Anyhow, Angular truly felt like magic the first time I used it. I would change the application‚Äôs state and things would just appear! I didn‚Äôt have to use selectors or iterate through DOM elements like some sort of neanderthal. I didn‚Äôt understand how the lifecycle worked at all, but who really wants to? Not me. I want to keep the magic alive.
Nobody wants (Angular) sausage after they see how it‚Äôs made.
‚Äî a very wise person
Of course, this quickly bit me in the ass. My completely unoptimized code was slow sometimes (all the time). So, like any responsible and capable developer, I arrived at an obvious conclusion: Angular was the problem and there was nothing I could do to fix it. I needed to switch frameworks, to use something faster, more performant, and most importantly, with better benchmark scores.
I moved onto React. With React came stage-0 proposals, Babel, Webpack, boilerplates, functional programming, great hair, Redux, GraphQL, CSS in JS, and much more. I now spend my time away from work preparing for work, reading about the hottest new packages, jumping on every bandwagon I can. Maybe I should use Parcel, it‚Äôs zero configuration and probably knows what‚Äôs best for me. I‚Äôve abandoned all non-Javascript languages for the backend. How else am I going to get my SSR-game on? Javascript is all I need.
I think Javascript is a pretty good guy. You can iterate SO FAST. Compiling? What‚Äôs that? Think of all the time you‚Äôll save not waiting for stuff to compile. Sure, there‚Äôs essentially no native type system and all sorts of dangerous type coercions can happen, but hey, that‚Äôs what Flow and Typescript are for, right? Transpiling is fine and very fast! There are no problems here.
Sure, bugs in the original Javascript implementation have become part of the spec. But look, Brendan Eich had to hack together all of Javascript in a few days. Can you blame him? No. Nobody‚Äôs perfect. Except for Javascript. Javascript is perfect.
Javascript is very human. Most teams I‚Äôve worked with are fluent in Javascript. Look at all of the NPM packages. I‚Äôd wager that it encompasses all of human knowledge. If there was to be a language to transcend all languages and bring all of humanity together, I would bet on Javascript. Is there a Babel transform for Esperanto? That‚Äôd probably be a good start.
To Javascript is human.
‚Äî Alexander Pope
I feel this point about ‚Äòbelief in humanity‚Äô is somewhat tenuous. You can tell I‚Äôm really stretching. Javascript isn‚Äôt a human being. Although, Javascript is pretty weird and unpredictable, as are humans.
The local police have been in a standoff outside of where Javascript and I have been holed up for the last 47 hours. I can‚Äôt be sure if I‚Äôm actually suffering from Stockholm syndrome because I‚Äôm not just a very cooperative person in general. But what I do know is that I‚Äôm not coming out of the deep, dark hole that I‚Äôve dug myself into.
I like it here. There‚Äôs everything I could need or want. I‚Äôm very comfortable here. This is who I am now. If anyone is feeling charitable, please throw some food down here if you can. In the meantime, I think I‚Äôm going to take a nap. I‚Äôm very tired from all of this Javascripting.

This is my 28-day journey of living a temporary life in Helsinki, Tallinn, Stockholm, and Copenhagen.
üá∏üá™ August 5, 2019
Look closely at the present you are constructing: it should look like the future you are dreaming. (Alice Walker)
Finding gratitude in small things and injecting a little randomness into my life is one of my 2018 and 2019 resolutions. And a lot of small wonders coincidently happened every day. Because I am in a different country and experiencing different culture? Well, it might be true, but might not.
I went to Gamla Stan and looked around the old town. Sometimes I stopped by souvenir shops to buy a Sweden flag pin because I‚Äôm collecting flag pins of countries that I visited. But today I had a bigger mission from my niece. We had a chat on Instagram yesterday, and she told me that she wanted to get a beautiful Swedish style pencil case. Well, what is the Swedish style and where can I find that style? I just went around some shops and found a beautiful pencil case. Surprisingly, it was the same style pencil case as the one that she wanted to have. Today‚Äôs small wonder started like that.
While I was looking around, I saw a bunch of people gathering in front of the palace. It seemed like they were waiting for something. So, I joined in the line of people and waited together. Some minutes later, the palace guards riding on horses started marching with music. I never imagined that I could see the Changing of the Guard at Gamla Stan. The second small wonder accidentally happened, too.
I got to a small square and saw old buildings painted with beautiful colors next to the Noble Prize Museum. When I took some pictures and started keep walking, I saw a young boy drawing buildings that I took pictures of just now. I came to him quietly and looked at his painting. It was really beautiful, more beautiful than the original ones. I saw a small donation box beside him, took 20 SEK from my pocket and put it into his box. He looked at me with smile and said, ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù It was a small donation for rooting for his dream. I prayed with all my heart, recalling his big innocent grin that he will be a great artist who will make our world better with his great ability. That was my third small wonder that I came across in Gamla Stan.
After wandering at Gamla Stan, I bought a cinnamon roll, went to Humlegarden, a park near my hotel, sat on a bench, and read a book, eating the cinnamon roll. If a park like this was near my home in Seoul, I would be really happy. Building a library, a park, and a stage that anyone comes and uses for free ‚Äî building a free culture park ‚Äî is one of my dreams, but can I construct this wonder in the future?

Title: P5 Project: Museums of Stockholm
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
For the final project of this 12-week UI sprint, my peers and I were asked to create a passion project based on a travel campaign. This campaign‚Äôs deliverables would be executed through a 4 screen website, branding assets, and printed/digital media marketing; all targeted towards a specific demographic to promote possible visitors to visit that location.
I chose to focus my final project on Stockholm, Sweden. Over the last few years, it‚Äôs one of the cities I‚Äôve set my heart on. With a deep love for all things Scandinavian design (both interior, industrial, and graphic), it was only natural that I wanted to infuse my personal interests into this project. Although I have never been, I asked myself why I would want to visit this city rich in arts & culture, and what my itinerary would possibly include while I was there. In my younger years growing up, I spent multiple weekends off school and during summer vacations obsessing over museums. My brother and I had no problem wasting away the day exploring each exhibit on display ‚Äî he loved learning about dinosaurs, I was interested in arts & crafts. Under the same roof, we always found a middle ground.
During the initial research phase of this project, I came across an article that defined Stockholm as a ‚Äúmecca of museums‚Äù. It is home to over 100+ museums within the city limits. Both national collections, and independent institutions that celebrate an array of topics ‚Äî from ABBA, marine biology, photography, alcohol distillery, etc., Stockholm has a museum that would peak every type of interest for a potential tourist. Here I found the niche demographic I would design for. My goal was to highlight this special collection of institutions (for both museum lovers and those not familiar), and give the general public a streamlined resource for planning their visit in the city.
Moving forward, I created a fictional persona to design for the campaign ‚Äî meet Joel Pryor. He‚Äôs 26 years old, and currently living, working, and playing in the city of Vancouver. He is a recent Architectural Technologist graduate, interning as a junior A/T at a firm. In the evenings he works part time at an East Van cocktail bar, where he connects with other likeminded peers that join his interests in film photography, design, biking, jazz music, and fashion. Listed below is his motivations/frustrations correlating to both travel planning in general, and visiting Stockholm for the first time. My goal was to create a realistic persona with flexible ideals that would be found in his demographic. Joel is knowledgeable in all things niche, and I wanted to create a campaign that reflected that altruistic path.
Before navigating artistic directions for the project, I already knew the route I wanted to take it in in terms of composition in typography. I wanted the project to be an ode to Swiss type, through the applications of poster and print. The Swiss design identity is bold and robust, yet simplified through its modern form and function of sans serif type. Below is the graphic inspiration and composition I collected moving forward in deciding the application of art directions.
Art direction #1: playful, bright, young, quirky, primary
Art direction #2: unapologetic, contrasting, provocative, strong
In the end, I decided to apply the second art direction due to the sensibility of black and white to contrast the colorful imagery that goes along with museums. Looping back to the persona, Joel, it would align with Swedish brands he‚Äôd identify with, and the ‚Äúin your face‚Äù and ‚Äútongue and cheek‚Äù language of the campaign. Museums aren‚Äôt the most exciting attraction at the top of mind for people unlike Joel, and I felt that in order for it to resonate with a larger demographic, it would have to be striking.
For the logo, I played on the symmetry of stacked letters within the word ‚Äúmuseums‚Äù to mimic the level of weights within the site branding. I went through multiple iterations of movement when it came to the letters, and thought that since the site followed a grid system, the logotype should also follow suit.
Circular STD was the singular font chosen for all the branding and application of the campaign. Carrying on with the sans serif typefaces known in Swiss design, it replicates a weighted presence without feeling intimidating. Black and bold is used for all the H1 and H2 headers, with book supplementing body text. All capitals are used on the headers to emphasize the urgency and weight.
As previous mentioned; the art direction I continued with carries a black and white narrative that is minimalistic, modern, and clean. Due to the variety of images hypothetically added by the museums themselves, I wanted a clean slate for the content to speak for itself. The only pattern that would contrast the two tones is a pinstripe; made up of a list of the museums within the city.
For collateral purposes, I chose products that would continue the conversation of the city and the findings at these museums past Stockholm city limits. Travellers would have the capability to carry their discoveries back home with them, and discuss their trip through the points of contact.
Below are the multiple levels of the Design Inception that I created for the campaign. The outer layer describes the environment of all UI assets, and as you go further into the center it breaks down the tone of the campaign through the tone. At the center of the Design Inception is the over arching why; why that target demo would find this campaign useful, and the overall purpose moving forward. My final why is as follows: ‚ÄúConnecting past and present‚Äù. Humanity wants to see a visual representation of change through time. Evolution, progression, succession ‚Äî all documented and on view for the mass public. In the ethos section of the ‚ÄúAbout‚Äù, I created a spiral visual that lists the words ‚ÄúRemarkable. Relevant. Educational.‚Äù These three words summarize the levels of the inception on a digestable level.
Before unveiling the prototype, I wanted to outline the primary user flow that Joel, would walk through on the site. From the home page, the user would have the option to click the ‚ÄúAbout‚Äù page, which tells the ethos of the campaign, a ‚ÄúRegistry‚Äù that lists the filter of museums within Stockholm, and finally, a ‚ÄúWeb Shop‚Äù. For the sake of the prototype, the user would click ‚ÄúRegistry‚Äù if they were interested in seeing the hub of locations, then from there their desired topic would filter their results into an event calendar, social media links, or that 3rd party museum site. The black squares are the screens made for the prototype and the white outlined boxes are future considerations.
As a final deliverable for the project, I compiled mockups for how Google Adwords would advertise the campaign. Keeping in mind the persona, I chose 4 different sites that Joel would frequently visit as his choice of media. The exemplary image below showcases the banner on Dezeen (both upper top and right of the navigation) but similar banners would be displayed on sites like Vice and Monocle. In terms of Instagram, I also wanted to imply that my target user frequents social media to see what‚Äôs current in the media and the influence it has on day to day. The Museums of Stockholm Instagram would emulate the feel of the site, and update users on new exhibitions, events, and restock of product.
To view the full prototype, follow the invision link here.

Title: Stockholm Syndrome
Content:

full Travel Portfolio
Stockholm Syndrome, in case you didn't know, is the phenomenon of a captive becoming attached to, or at least developing feelings of trust or affection toward their captor. It was perhaps fitting/ironic/coincidental then, that as we landed in the Swedish capital our only organised activity for the weekend was a game of RoomEscape ‚Äî a live action, ‚Äúescape-the-room‚Äù puzzle-cum-teambuilding challenge.
However before I digress with this tenuous attempt to fit some sort of play on words into the blog title, let‚Äôs rewind the weekend and run things through chronologically.
‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê ‚Üê
We flew out around lunchtime on Friday. If you book flights an appropriate amount of time in advance you can get from London to Stockholm for as little as ¬£20 return. Which is great, but there are sacrifices to make elsewhere‚Ä¶getting from Skavsta Airport to Stockholm is actually more expensive than the flight (¬£22 return), and for us getting from Surrey to Stansted was even more expensive than that. But the journey is the destination, right‚Ä¶?
I always loathe arriving in a new place at night-time (or rather in darkness ‚Äî it was only 16:30) as it totally inhibits one‚Äôs ability to soak up the local atmosphere ‚Äî the vibe. And on a more practical level it makes it just that little bit trickier to get one‚Äôs bearings. We had no problem finding our AirBnb though ‚Äî located one tube stop from the Central station and then barely 100m from the station to our front door.
The Friday night was not entirely different to our typical London Friday night ‚Äî it was messy. Huge shout out to Helle for curating our insobriety and taking us to the Party Arena. I can confirm, Sweden definitely knows how to get trolleyed. And how to Salsa. I would go into more detail if I my memory would permit it.
Our most impressive feat of the weekend was perhaps waking up in time the next morning to catch Stockholm in the daylight (roughly 08:30 to 15:00). Our cultural custodians, Usman and Jordan (with the aid of Trip Advisor) guided us around the old town, and to Stockholm‚Äôs City Hall, the site of the annual Nobel Prize Banquet, which we missed by one day. Invites must‚Äôve got lost in the post.
A pretty cool thing that was going on was this, an artificial ‚Äústar‚Äù hoisted into the Swedish night sky, generated by solar energy from last summer. Using a sunny summer‚Äôs day to light up a cold winter‚Äôs night ‚Äî neat.
‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ ‚òÄ
Walking through the shopping areas of the city we stopped in at an American-themed clothes shop. For the life of me I can‚Äôt remember the name of the shop ‚Äî but it was somewhere in the Norrmalm region of the city. Anyway I want to plug this shop as there brilliant offer was fill up a shopping bag full of anything in the shop for just 300 SEK (¬£25). The centrepiece of my shopping bag was a bowling shirt/short sleeved lab coat that was previously owned by Fernando, Assistant Logistics Manager at Hostess Brands. Yup.
Saturday night we decided to go on an organized bar crawl. For 200 SEK (roughly ¬£18) you get a free shot in 4 bars, 20% off drinks and club entry. Whilst I‚Äôm usually the first to object to forced fun of any sort there was no denying that this was a pretty good way to explore the nightlife and meet new people. Of note was an English fireman who threw up on the dancefloor in the second bar we stopped in. Sean Kingston knows.
On to Sunday and we again forced ourselves out into the open to maximize the daylight. Whereas Saturday had been chilly but sunny, Sunday was a more overcast affair. We were however blessed with the first snowfall of the season, which felt like another thing checked off the checklist, even if it was just a few millimetres.
After a reindeer sandwich (seemed more interesting than the traditional Swedish meatballs) we headed to RoomEscape (not to be confused with the online role-playing game RuneScape‚Ä¶). Personally (and I think the others will probably agree), this was the hidden gem of the trip. The game was really well-designed so as to be intricate but not impossible, and the level of detail in the room made for a tense and almost realistic experience. Our scenario featured us trying to disarm nuclear weapons in a Cold War bunker. Despite requiring a few hints to cross the finish line we disabled the bomb and saved the world with 6 minutes to spare! You‚Äôre welcome.
So yeah, this was a great trip. No regrets, no ‚Äúwrong‚Äù or ‚Äúright‚Äù decisions, just a bucket load of deeds done. Amen.

Almost jealous of the Swedes
A couple of weeks back I had the pleasure of spending two days in Stockholm, Sweden. As you might already know, Finland used to be part of the great Swedish empire from the 12th century to 1809, so as a Swedish speaking Finn it is always a special feeling to visit Stockholm. It is as close to coming home to as anything that actually isn‚Äôt one‚Äôs home, this feeling being further enhanced by the many close friends I always get to catch-up with in Stockholm.
It is still almost difficult not to be jealous of my Swedish buddies: the Swedish economy is still strong, the Swedes are tall and beautiful, the tech ecosystem overall is vibrant, and some of the most exciting tech start-ups in the world are from Sweden (Spotify, Klarna, King.com, Pingdom, and many more). Although Creandum and Northzone are really great early stage VCs, I do however hear rumblings that there definitely would be room for more active seed stage investment. At least that seems to be the common message at SUP46, the SUPeractive start-up space smack in the middle of Stockholm. On this trip I also got to meet a few really interesting software companies. I really do hope we will soon find another Swedish investment for Open Ocean, our only current one of course being our rapidly growing superstar Truecaller (www.truecaller.com).
Luckily I haven‚Äôt yet had to turn completely green with envy of the Swedes, as my Finnish buddy Mikko Ilonen three weeks ago beat world number four Henrik Stenson in the World Matchplay golf final!

Landed Stockholm and went straight from Arlanda to Viggs√∂ aka ‚ÄúAbba Island‚Äù.
Somehow I‚Äôm right outside ABBA‚Äôs hit-writing cottage on the island. Over the course of days I got subsumed by the breakdown of Bj√∂rn and Agnetha‚Äôs marriage, as documented in ‚ÄòThe winner takes it all‚Äô.
After 3 straight days of listening on repeat, the reductive zero-sum nature of the winner taking it all meaning that the loser *has* to fall weighed me down to exhaustion and I left Sweden, never to return.
Stockholm set off a bizarre mix of city-syndromes in my travels.
Medellin, Colombia: 24 hours in I began to suffer Netflix-induced delusions that I knew more about the #rise #fall of Pablo Escobar than anyone, including locals who actually knew him. I‚Äôd casually hang around the [since] demolished house where he was killed on December 2, 1993 and offer visiting tourists free guidance to the rest of Pablo‚Äôs Medellin. All but 3 refused me.
Beirut, Lebanon: Guns pointed at my head at a Hezbollah checkpoint near the airport after arrival and I developed some kind of fatalistic swagger, as if death could come at any time and I‚Äôd be just fine. So I pushed it. I went to the Bekaa Valley on the Syrian border with an American lady I met in a Beirut lesbian bar. I survived (everything), despite accidentally nudging a soldier‚Äôs Kalashnikov on the way to fly out.
Seoul, South Korea: Apart from the DMZ, all I really wanted to do in Seoul was to consume lots of nakji-bokkeum (super-spicy stir-fried octopus dish). Developing quickly into a tentacle-eating obsession in every form and for every meal. Within 24 hours of my first octopus dish I left my luxury Gangnam hotel and started sleeping rough at the Noryangjin fish market, focused on eating Sannajki (live octopus) as it came off the boats. Hallucinations and misunderstandings followed in that order and I hurriedly flew out of Incheon.
Melbourne, Australia: Obsessing crossing the Yarra river, repeatedly (crossing not obsessing). It‚Äôs not the Yangtze or the Mississippi but after a few days of hearing about the massive logistical challenges of ‚Äúcrossing the river‚Äù, I began to plot out a journey from one end to the other. Also sought out easier crossing points, knowing the stress that these people seem to have about ‚Äúcrossing‚Äù. I biked across every bridge crossing from Princes Bridge to the Johnston street bridge in Abbotsford. Not a single friend appeared interested in my views on where and how to cross the river. So I stopped obsessing and left for Sydney.
Tashkent, Ubzbekistan: Modernist architecture I know. Behren‚Äôs 1909 AEG factory in Berlin, Corbusier‚Äôs 1928 Villa Savoye in France and the Guggenheim here in NYC (guess the year) I‚Äôve all seen. So arriving in Tashkent en route to a road trip around the Aral Sea and the former Soviet chemical weapons testing center on Vozrozhdeniya Island was just transiting. Abrubtly, a parallel world of Tashkent Modernism beckoned. Simple geometric shapes fused with large slabs of reinforced concrete. The exquisite latticework of the State Museum of History and then I checked into something even better from 1974: The Hotel Uzbekistan. I stayed until I ran out of funds and was deported back to Russia.
Granada, Spain: Uncovering what‚Äôs underneath; that was the obsession. Specifically what‚Äôs underneath the Christian surface and digging (figuratively) into Granada‚Äôs rich Islamic and Jewish past. Not just the obvious like the churches built over mosques, but the origins of what locals say. Like when they talk about going to barrio de los gre√±√∫os they actually are referring to the Realejo neighborhood with gre√±√∫o possibly being a reference to Jewish curls. Alas my few friends here got bored with my obsession with the underneath. One in particular caused me to leave town immediately when she suggested that Stranger Things would be a more appropriate place for me to visit The Upside Down.
Memphis, Tennessee: From aspiring vegetarian and practicing atheist it took only 3 days to become obsessed with meat and megachurches (M&Ms). A meat dish was not enough, I wanted my meat to be coated in meat sauce with a side of meat. And then the possibilities of horizontal integration hit me ‚Äî everyone you meet in Memphis eventually tells you that their Grandma makes the best fried chicken you‚Äôve ever had. So of course I ended up cruising megachurches and being inadvertently invited back to suburban Sunday fried chicken lunches cooked by real life grannies. Not nearly as creepy as it may sound and I remain generally welcome there to this day.
Johannesburg, South Africa: A sudden deep and abiding passion for security and for planning escape routes/rooms. Plotting out safe routes through town and excessive thinking about how to respond to carjacking attempts ‚Äî do we floor the car when AK47s are pointed at us or do we immediately go limp and say ‚Äòtake whatever you want just leave us alone‚Äô. Asking in advance about where the safe room is seemed reasonable to me but some locals seemed to think I was overthinking. And then I was carjacked in mid-morning traffic and my continuous thought during the ensuing 24 minute firefight was ‚ÄòI told you so‚Äô.
Ciudad Juarez, Mexico: A day trip from joint city El Paso ended up as a days long foray into excessive medical tourism. I‚Äôd never really loved my chubby cheeks and really wanted a chiseled sculptured face, so day one ended up under that knife. I‚Äôd planned to walk across the Texas border back to El Paso but I spotted a street advertisement for a $100 nose job. That‚Äôs less than a boozy lunch so I tried that. Day 3 involved a $800 tummy tuck ($9,500 cheaper than NYC) and a breast augmentation ‚Äòtaster‚Äô (don‚Äôt ask). I look good.
Kyiv, Ukraine: An unexplained sudden and deep interest in Metro stations and steam baths (Banyas). Peaked in one day spent exploring every corner of ‚ÄòArsenala‚Äô, the deepest station in the Kyiv subway system and the second deepest in the world. Followed by an evening of having the shit beaten outta me with birch twigs whilst sipping on Kozak Ukrainian vodka made from dried wheat bread. This time they let me stay. I‚Äôm still here, red raw and smashed in every sense.
--
--
New York-based global citizen, believer in rationalism, modernity and 80s pop. Global media exec by day, writer and photographer by night.

Title: KARLSBORG! WHY AM I HERE?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Amid thousands of coastal islands and inland lakes
Where boreal forests and glaciated mountains take
Stockholm to the East, Gothenburg to the South
The garrison town lingers on me in the shadows of a vintage movie
I check the ghost white newspapers for occurring theatre dates
Without pre-thought, I remade my African life into a Swedish life
Snapping photos in rare destinations is prohibited
Karlsborg! I am in Karlsborg! Why am I here?
Untouched by all the crowded dances
Fika, are you a sacred religion?
The relationships atypical
Atlas and I, discovering ourselves by the water‚Äôs edge
Spring has sprung, I‚Äôm grateful to be here among the young
In this very moment, I banish all gloom
My mucous membranes inflamed
My clouds scattered in Yahoo hues
May, may my Triumph tulips never die
Here eye to eye, unbound by earth and sky
I cannot lie, I thought by now I‚Äôd left up and fly
The victories have begun
Come along and let‚Äôs abide by the unsung
Many moons will fall my fragile Atlas, but tonight I‚Äôll lull you to sleep
And tomorrow we‚Äôll continue to give it our all
The little moments shared in silence,
thank God there‚Äôs no loud violence
Fika!
You‚Äôve become a sacred religion.

Title: Stockholm Design Week 2018: Five Highlights from the Scandinavian Furniture & Light Fair
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Stockholm Design Week wrapped up yesterday and reports of the amazing designs presented are flooding in. Started in 2002, Stockholm Design Week has become the most important week of the year for Scandinavian Design, where just about everyone in any way connected to or interested in Scandinavian design meet and bring home new trends, contacts and inspiration. The design week runs in parallel to and supports the Stockholm Furniture & Light Fair, the world‚Äôs leading event for Scandinavian design. Today we‚Äôre going to take a look at some of our favorite designs we‚Äôve seen from the even so far.
The Jin Chair
Created by Japanese designer Jin Kuramoto, this chair was named the best product at the Stockholm Furniture and Light Fair. The chair is made using flax fibers which are a completely biodegradable material that is most commonly used for money, tea bags and linen. Kuramoto devised a method that involves building and shaping thin flax fiber layers on top of each other to form both the seat and frame. A resin is then used to solidify the structure. The resin is also a bio-resin which can biodegrade or be burned. Kuramoto designed the Jin chair for Swedish furniture brand Offecct.
Apollo Lamp
Swedish design brand Phloc presented these elegant new lights. The super clean Scandinavian design is highlighted by the beautiful pastel color palette. The line was designed by Swedish architects Mats Broberg and John Ridderstr√•le who were inspired by a plumb bob, a tool with a pointed weight on its end that architects use to ensure a vertical hang. The lights are available in a range of colors and finished and can be hung individually or grouped together.
Sn√∏hetta Lighting Range
The Norwegian architects Sn√∏hetta launched their first lighting range at the design fair. Called the Flik Flak collection, the line is comprised of hinged wooden lamps. The lamps were originally designed for Sweden‚Äôs Treehotel and they were inspired by the building‚Äôs exterior. The lamps feature an LED strip that is sandwiched between black birch veneer and can be opened and closed at 180-degree angle as the planks are held together by a piano hinge. In its closed state, the lamplight is focused and when opened, it disperses across space.
Yoma by Zeitraum
This sleek bed has a very flexible design that we think will be popular as more and more people look for versatile furniture. The long side of the bed serves as a shelf, while the back cushions can be fixed in different positions and arranged to feel comfortable while sleeping, reading or just lounging. The mattress only sinks down a few centimeters, making it appear to be lying on top, giving the bed a sense of weightlessness.
The Barn & Fences
Created by Swedish designer Johan Kauppi, the Barn & Fences were inspired by the winter environment of Swedish Lapland. Intended to be used in office settings, the little houses and space dividers are semi-transparent, yet sound absorbent. Kauppi suggests using the barns for meeting and workplaces, and combining them to suit the office‚Äôs needs. The fences have standalone stability and great flexibility, making the system easy to use when creating temporary areas, walkways, angled shapes or zig-zag corners.
These are just some of the great designs that came out of this year‚Äôs Stockholm Design Week. What are your favorites? Personally we‚Äôd love to have our own personal little work barns. We‚Äôre interested to see how interior designers start using these pieces in their work, and look forward to seeing these designs used in interiors going forward.
