Title: The Nobel Museum, Fusion of Old and New
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
(Reprinted from NUVO Magazine, June 2003.)
There are a few ways to get to the old town square in Stockholm, Sweden. You can walk up from the water, where Lake Malaren meets the Baltic Sea, calves feeling the steep incline up past the palace, a bright tableau of the city framed in a glance over your shoulder. Or, you can walk the twisty paths of Gamla Stan‚Äôs narrow streets (literally the ‚Äúold town‚Äù), cobblestones uneven beneath your feet, past the purveyors of souvenirs, fine crystal and strong Swedish coffee. The practical traveler might opt for the subway (‚ÄúTunnelbana‚Äù or ‚ÄúT-Bana‚Äù for those in the know), emerging on the sunlit southern side of Gamla Stan and retracing steps northward in a straight line uphill. Whatever path you choose, it will eventually open up into the Stortorget ‚Äî the ‚ÄúGreat Square‚Äù ‚Äî and the epicenter of Stockholm‚Äôs ancient self.
Four hundred years ago where a bloody coup was staged is now a bright and bustling square, with camera-wielding tourists and Swedes lingering the caf√©s, faces upturned to the perma-sun in summer or candle-warmed in winter. On their way through, many of them will alight on the steps of a building that bounces sunlight off its coral-coloured walls and classic white pillars, all across the west side of the Great Square. Like Stortorget, it is a combination of the old and the new ‚Äî the eighteenth-century Old Stockholm Stock Exchange, meeting place of traders and burghers ‚Äî to which has been attached a sleek pane of glass, affixed with spare steel rods and bearing simple white lettering, modern and minimalist, that let you know not only that you‚Äôve arrived at the ‚ÄúNobelmuseet‚Äù but that what is contained therein will fuse history with modernity and wrap it all up in a crisp, clean Nordic aesthetic. You may have to be a genius to be featured in this museum, but you needn‚Äôt be one to appreciate what it has to offer.
Officially it‚Äôs called the Nobelmuseet ‚Äî i.e. ‚ÄúNobel Museum‚Äù as written in the agglutinated Swedish style ‚Äî but it consists of a single exhibition, ‚ÄúCultures of Creativity: The Centennial Exhibition of the Nobel Prize,‚Äù which opened in April, 2001 to commemorate one hundred years of achievement. It is a topic of breadth and depth, and the exhibit opts for both, layering headlines and highlights over troves of information and esoterica, easily skimmed for the ADD-afflicted but rich in detail for the more questioning intellect (or for salonistas in search of clever cocktail conversation). Either way, it presents a century of Nobel-winning exploits in the context of the individual and the collaborative creative processes. Some conclusions are neatly drawn for visitor consumption (i.e. ‚Äúcreative milieus breed creative thinkers‚Äù) but most are left to the thoughtful museet-goer, who may or may not leave with an understanding of Pavlov‚Äôs Dog, Schr√∂dinger‚Äôs Cat or how the heck Arafat ever won that Peace Prize.
That is the essence of the Nobel Prize: genius, and controversy. The museum does an excellent job of showcasing the first and alluding to the second. Taking in the cool, airy space, all metallic curves and shafts of light, the eye is drawn upward to a kind of conveyor belt on the ceiling, moving panels along like venetian blinds, each featuring the likeness of a Nobel laureate. Fritz Pregl, Chemistry, 1923. Luis Walter Alvarez, Physics, 1968. Naguib Mahfouz, Literature, 1988. Past the reception desk (50 Swedish krona buys you an afternoon of one-way intellectual hobnobbing) there are options: look straight ahead, and you will see an elegant row of plexiglass panels containing newspaper clippings in English and Swedish, each panel representing a decade of Nobel news. Look to the left and find a theatre showing eight vignettes featuring creative Nobel-spawning milieus (think Hemingway‚Äôs Paris and Bohr‚Äôs Copenhagen); look right and find a theatre showing thirty-two short films about not Glenn Gould but winners like X-Ray pioneer (and physics prize pioneer as the first laureate) Wilhelm R√∂ntgen (1901), writer Wole Soyinka (1986), and Swedish statesman Dag Hammarskj√∂ld (1961). On the other side of this theatre, an interactive multi-media room with headphones and individual flatscreen computers.
Perhaps the best place to begin, though, is at the back of the museum‚Äôs spacious single floor, past the sample banquet place-setting and on to the exhibit detailing the life of Alfred Nobel. It is the Nobel Museum after all, and indeed Stockholm‚Äôs only monument to the industrialist who made his home in many places other than Sweden yet somehow settled on his out-of-the-way homeland to administer and bestow the world‚Äôs most prestigious prizes. The sepia-toned display provides a fairly pristine account of Nobel‚Äôs life ‚Äî his childhood in Stockholm and then St. Petersburg; his difficult inventor/industrialist father and brothers; the tragic loss of his younger brother, Emil, in a nitroglycerine explosion connected to Alfred‚Äôs experiments; his uneven and lonely romantic life; and the innovations he developed that advanced the industrial age and built the fortune that would eventually bankroll five distinguished prizes.
(It should be noted here that the so-called Nobel Prize in Economics is actually not a Nobel prize at all, but rather an award established by the Central Bank of Sweden in 1968 to honour Nobel‚Äôs memory, with a prize purse guaranteed to match that of the other laureates. It is adjudicated by the Swedish Academy of Sciences which is also responsible for the Physics and Chemistry prizes).
Nobel was, by most accounts, a difficult man ‚Äî lonely, caustic, closed, not overwhelmingly happy (one of the best of these accounts is in Burton Feldman‚Äôs excellent The Nobel Prize which is a 489-page treasure trove of Nobel facts and factoids). He was a workhorse, traveling constantly, establishing dynamite factories across Europe and in the United States, where he spoke Swedish, English, French, Italian, or German depending on the locale. He wrote poetry and plays, patented his multifarious inventions, read widely, kept his own counsel. He died in San Remo, Italy, basically alone ‚Äî childless, unmarried, brothers and parents deceased. And then, with his will, he gained an entirely new life in the form of the Nobel Prize.
Closed as he was, who can know what exactly motivated his now-famous will. Perhaps the erroneous obituaries, published on the death of his brother, by a few confused journalists ‚Äî and not overwhelmingly complimentary. Perhaps guilt based on the deaths with which he was associated ‚Äî dynamite accidents, an ill-fated balloon expedition he bankrolled, the loss of his own brother. Perhaps a desire for expiation, or for admiration ‚Äî the kind that escaped him in life.
Whatever his reasons, they were enough to direct his entire fortune toward prizes ‚Äî though only after five years of legal wrangling and painfully-wrought administration of a huge fund with scant guidance. Alfred Nobel‚Äôs Last Will and Testament consisted of a single wordy paragraph directing his accrued wealth to a fund which would annually provide for five prizes to ‚Äúthose persons who shall have contributed most materially to benefit mankind during the year immediately preceding‚Äù in the areas of Physics, Chemistry, Physiology/Medicine; Literature, and one ‚Äúto the person who shall have most or best promoted the Fraternity of Nations and the Abolishment or Dimunition of Standing Armies and the Promotion and Increase of Peace Congresses.‚Äù The first four prizes were assigned to various distinguished Swedish academic organizations; the Peace Prize was to be selected by a committee determined, inexplicably, by the Norwegian Parliament. So indeed, from the very beginning this was a prize marked by drama and controversy (and who knows? Perhaps Nobel had thought of that, too).
Walking through the newspaper-clipping exhibit decade by decade reveals just how fraught with controversy it was. Here was a so-called global prize, being adjudicated by an exclusively Scandinavian body of bodies (and, except for the Oslo-centric Peace Prize, bestowed to this day by the Swedish king in a lavish ceremony in Stockholm on December 10, the anniversary of Alfred Nobel‚Äôs death). Entrusted to judge the forefront but geographically peripheral, the judges were not always fully informed of cutting-edge work (and as a result many prizes across the board were awarded years and sometimes even decades after the ‚Äòwinning‚Äô work had been performed). There was a northern slant, felt almost immediately with a disproportionately high number of Nordic winners (this is seen particularly in the Literature prize, with fifteen Nordic laureates (including Iceland) to France‚Äôs twelve and the US‚Äô eleven). Unlike the prefix ‚ÄúOscar-nominated‚Äù there are no plaudits for runners up. Accordingly, competition was fierce and politics fiercer.
Of course, hindsight is always 20/20 but in a museum celebrating a century of prizes one can‚Äôt help but look back. While the actual exhibit does not render judgment on this prize or that ‚Äî its purpose is to celebrate the Nobel Prize as an institution ‚Äî it does not whitewash its chequered past of backroom politicking, uncredited (and unawarded) inventors, scandals, and shockingly bad choices (though of course you have to look for it!). Moreover, the prizes cannot be rescinded, and the deliberations are secret ‚Äî so the mistakes of history stick. There was the prize for nuclear fission, awarded to German Otto Hahn in 1944, which completely excluded his decades-long partner Lise Meitner (who had fled, ironically, to Sweden at the outbreak of the war). There was the passing over of Dimitri Mendeleev, whose Periodic Table of the Elements hangs in every science classroom worth its salt, for chemist Henri Moissan who discovered fluorine ‚Äî as it had already been predicted by Mendeleev‚Äôs chart! And Banting and Best ‚Äî names that are inextricably linked in the Canadian lexicon ‚Äî were not, in fact, honoured in 1923 for the discovery of insulin ‚Äî that award actually went to Banting and J.J.R. Macleod (though Banting made a big show of splitting the prize money with Best, his graduate student assistant, and sharing the credit ‚Äî not to mention that in 1962, theNobel Foundation publicly admitted that Macleod had erroneously been honoured). These were not isolated incidents.
Also common were dramas surrounding the prizes once awarded, based on the merits. Mikhael Gorbachev‚Äôs 1986 peace prize was hailed globally but received mixed reactions in the Motherland. Ditto Linus Pauling, who besides Marie Curie is the only laureate to have received a prize in two different categories ‚Äî first Chemistry in 1954, and then the Peace Prize for his anti-nuclear agitation in 1962 was seen as an international slap in the face to the U.S. (not unlike how last year‚Äôs prize to Jimmy Carter was seen as a not-so-subtle rebuke of the Bush Administration‚Äôs hawklike foreign policy). Portuguese neurologist Antonio Egas Moniz was honoured with the Medicine prize in 1949 for pioneering the lobotomy, a horrendous procedure that mentally neutered thousands of patients before mercifully falling out of favour within a decade.
Some prizes were even so hotly debated within the supposed coolly objective minds of the adjudicating committees that resignations ensued: in 1989, two members of the Swedish Academy (which judges Literature) resigned over the committee‚Äôs decision not to name Salman Rushdie and take a stand against the Iranian fatwah against him ‚Äî up from one resignation in 1989 for naming William Golding. And back to Arafat: a member of the ‚Äô94 Peace Committee publicly resigned and denounced him as a terrorist. Omissions, too, make up as distinguished a list as any collection of laureates: Sigmund Freud. J. Robert Oppenheimer. Henrik Ibsen. Leo Tolstoy. Virginia Woolf. Dimitri Mendeleev. Mahatma Ghandi.
Even more poignant were other omissions ‚Äî omissions on the dais accepting the award. German-Jewish journalist Carl von Ossietsky was not available to accept his 1935 Peace Prize as he was incarcerated in a concentration camp, where he died. The uproar over the episode prompted Hitler to forbid Germans or Austrians to accept their prizes (beginning in 1938) which resulted in at least three laureates having to forfeit their prize money (still extremely lucky compared to Ossietsky). Controversial, outspoken laureates from the USSR were also precluded from attending ‚Äî Boris Pasternak in 1958, Andrei Sakharov in 1975. The Nobel Prize is bigger than the laureate alone.
That fact is at its most affecting in the corners of the exhibit, quietly regarding the balance Marie Curie used to weigh her newly-discovered radium, the well-worn Underwood typewriter used by Isaac Bashevis Singer, complete with Yiddish lettering, or listening to Toni Morrison‚Äôs beautiful and richly-toned Nobel lecture on headphones in the multi-media room, then Nelson Mandela‚Äôs, then Bashevis Singer in his voice aged with patience: ‚ÄúPeople are asking me often, why do you write in a dying language? Firstly, I like to write ghost stories, and nothing works like a dead language. Ghosts love Yiddish, they all speak it.‚Äù
As fascinating as a wander through the Nobelmuseet inevitably is, the museum-going experience is taken to an entirely new plane by virtue of the gift shop. In addition to a fine array of the usual ‚Äî postcards with distinguished-looking laureates, to whom are attributed elegant-sounding quotes; books about Alfred Nobel, the Nobel Prize and various laureates; posters of exhibited pieces ‚Äî it offers a creative selection of souvenirs. Highlights include the peculiarly Swedish salty licorice treat, ‚Äúsalt lakrits,‚Äù quaintly packaged in the form of a long stick of dynamite (perhaps in a nod to how you‚Äôd feel if you actually ate the whole thing) and gold foil-wrapped chocolate coins fashioned after the Nobel medallions (surely a necessary chaser of the aforementioned lakrits!). Also of note is a particularly charming postcard of Albert Einstein reclining against a rock in summer shorts, looking oddly fetching with his slender calves and strappy summer sandals (the quote ‚Äî ‚ÄúIt is harder to crack a prejudice than an atom‚Äù ‚Äî is pure Einstein, who was a passionate advocate for peace and submitted as many nominations for the Peace Prize as he did for physics).
My favorite Nobel keepsake, however, is a Nobel-inspired cookbook for those who would replicate the ceremonial banquet at home, minus the average IQ (The Nobel Banquets: Modern Recipes from the Classic Menus, by H√©l√®ne Bodin and Stefan Bjur). The book pairs menu selections from various years with information about the laureates being so honoured and the historical background of the era. 1954, for example, was a banner year celebrating German physicists Max Born and Walther Bothe, Linus Pauling‚Äôs Chemistry prize and John Enders, Thomas H. Weller and Frederick C. Robbins, three distinguished U.S. virologists. Had literature laureate Ernest Hemingway been well enough to attend the inter-laureate conversation would probably have been very different. As it was, he missed out on hot smoked rainbow trout with spinach chanterelle mushroom sauce, grilled filet of beef with tagliatelle vegetable and red wine sauce, and green pears accompanied by pistachio nut ice cream (perhaps one of the German physicists ate enough for Bothe of them).
Souvenirs in hand and laureate-worthy thoughts in head, the Nobelmuseet has hopefully provoked thoughts more compelling than weak puns on physics laureates (I hope I‚Äôm not Bohr-ing you). Outside, the sun is surely still shining; it‚Äôs summer after all, and that‚Äôs what the sun does in a Stockholm summer. Stotorget is still bustling and the caf√©s still do a brisk business. Walking out into the square, there are a few ways you can go ‚Äî down toward the water, south to the subway, lazily through the rabbit-warren streets of Gamla Stan. Moving away, you throw a glance over your shoulder ‚Äî framed there is the Nobelmuseet, pillars and glass gleaming in the sunlight, fusion of things old and new from these past hundred years.
Rachel Sklar is the co-founder of TheLi.st. She wrote this in 2003 after living in Stockholm for six months. In addition to writing about the Nobel Museum, Rachel also gained 15 pounds from delicious Swedish chocolate, recorded four tracks for a Swedish dance club and invested in H&M. Her favorite Swedish phrase was ‚ÄúJag har inte pojkvan.‚Äù She thinks Sweden rules.
--
--
Writer, entrepreneur & activist. Founder of TheLi.st and Change The Ratio. Just here to elevate women & sing showtunes. Find me @rachelsklar on Twitter/Insta.

Title: My Adventure in Stockholm: A Mix of Good and Bad
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
In this blog, I want to share my recent trip to Stockholm and all the experiences I had during my journey.
The whole trip started because I wanted to plan something good for a UK bank holiday. Sweden was never on my travel list, and I also had a childhood friend living there with his family whom I hadn‚Äôt seen in more than four years. So, it felt like the perfect opportunity to catch up and explore a new place at the same time.
On the day of my journey, I took a Norwegian flight from London Gatwick to Stockholm Arlanda. The flight had a slight delay leaving Gatwick but still arrived almost on time. From Arlanda, I hopped on a Flygbussarna bus to reach Stockholm central, and the journey was smooth, taking just 50 minutes. It was already past 10 in the evening when I arrived, but my friend, who lives about 20 minutes away, kindly came to pick me up. We used trams and the metro to get to his place.
One interesting thing I noticed was that you could purchase tickets for most forms of transportation using your mobile phone and scan a QR code when boarding. It was a convenient use of technology and saved me the hassle of buying tickets in person or carrying a separate travel card, like in London.
On Day 2, we bought a single SL ticket for 39 SEK (approximately ¬£2.89) to get to Stockholm central and then decided to walk around. We covered around 20 kilometers, exploring significant historical places like Stockholm City Hall, where Nobel Laureates have their dinner after receiving their prizes. We also visited Gamla Stan, the Royal Palace, Parliament, and many beautiful islands. What stood out to me was the Stockholm Archipelago concept, where many small islands are connected by bridges or ferries, creating a vibrant and unique city. It‚Äôs different from many other European cities I‚Äôve been to.
Day 3 took us to Djurgarden. We loved the Open Air museum, where they‚Äôve preserved or recreated life from the 16th-17th centuries. It‚Äôs a fantastic way to keep history alive and attract tourists. Skansen, in the same area, had a cool zoo with Swedish and Nordic wild animals. Our next stop was the Vasa Museum, the highest-rated place on Google and TripAdvisor. It‚Äôs a treasure trove of interesting historical facts, showcasing a 300+ year-old sunken ship and its history. What amazed me was how they turned a ‚ÄúFAILURE‚Äù into a celebration and learning opportunity.
Day 4 was all about visiting Drottningholm Palace and its surroundings in the morning before my evening flight back to London. The palace is where the Swedish Royal family still resides, and it‚Äôs a well-maintained place with beautiful gardens. The whole area is so large that it can take hours to explore.
But, as my great trip was coming to an end, some miseries had to balance the good and bad in life! I received notifications on my mobile that my return flight, scheduled for 21:00, had been delayed until 05:33 the next morning. After contacting British Airways customer care and checking the news, I learned that there was a UK-wide Air Traffic Control ‚Äòtechnical glitch‚Äô causing flight delays and cancellations. The customer care representative advised me to reach the airport as per my original schedule, as they were working to make things right. However, upon arriving at the airport, I found out that the flight was canceled, and no one knew the next steps. The check-in counter gave me an apology letter with vague instructions that essentially said, ‚Äúfigure things out on your own, and we might reimburse you later.‚Äù Other passengers said there were no available BA flights to London for at least the next three days. Customer care calls were rejected, and the British Airways app and website crashed due to high traffic. I was essentially stuck in a city without knowing when I could leave.
Luckily, I was able to return to my friend‚Äôs place instead of searching for a hotel. I continuously followed the news, which reported thousands of UK-bound flights canceled and the chaos continuing for days. In this situation, I started looking for all available options to get back, including buses, trains, ferries, and routes through other cities. Fortunately, I found an available but expensive option with SAS Airlines for the next day via Stavanger, Norway. So, I decided to go for it instead of getting stuck in Stockholm, which would have affected everything, including my work.
On Day 5, I left my friend‚Äôs place with a lot of uncertainty about what lay ahead. Fortunately, the first flight from Stockholm to Stavanger went smoothly. However, before boarding the next flight, I heard an announcement that the flight was overbooked, and they were looking for volunteers to take the next day‚Äôs flight along with a 250 Euro compensation! I quickly moved to the front of the boarding queue, just in case they asked me to volunteer if no one else did. I saw the boarding process begin, and the flight was very full. The flight waited for over 40 minutes due to the overbooking issue, and the pilot announced that they had to remove luggage for those who couldn‚Äôt make it, causing further delays. After all the chaos, I finally reached London after almost eight hours of travel, which was initially planned for just two hours!

The guy with thoughts and 'gyans'!

Title: AWS Summit Stockholm: Learning from the Leaders in AI
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in

We are teams of ACTUM Digital.

--
Listen
Share
On the outskirts of Stockholm, the Stockholmsm√§ssan convention center played host to one of this year‚Äôs much anticipated AWS Summits ‚Äî it was a day packed with innovation, insights, and conversations around what AWS has been most recently working on for the Cloud. With keynotes about generative AI, hands-on demos, and real-world use cases from the some big names, the event offered a deep dive into how AWS is shaping the future of tech, how companies are leveraging LLM‚Äôs and generative AI to build exciting new features, and how they save costs while scaling to a global audience.
I was impressed to see how global companies like Booking.com have already deeply integrated AI into their products and development processes ‚Äî a clear reminder that those who don‚Äôt embrace it, risk falling behind.
Here are a few highlighted talks that I attended with Thibault, my teammate at ACTUM Digital!
We kicked off our packed day of sessions with a talk from Tom Soderstrom, ‚Äî an AWS Enterprise Strategist and former CTO at NASA‚Äôs Jet Propulsion Laboratory! Tom‚Äôs talk was absolutely packed with interesting stories and experiences from his extensive career with NASA ‚Äî he gave some insights on how we can experiment better by optimising for speed, reducing cost and risk, and not aiming for perfection the first time around. I really enjoy the kind of talks that don‚Äôt try to teach you a specific technology, but instead inspire you to go and think about work in a different way, or approach ideas with a different mindset. I found a shorter version of Tom‚Äôs presentation on the AWS Events YouTube Channel ‚Äî I highly recommend giving it a watch!
From less technical to very technical ‚Äî this talk about how Booking.com utilises SageMaker was incredibly in-depth, the team of speakers managed to pack so much into an hour! After a brief introduction explaining the trade-offs between different LLM inference options, we were walked through two new GenAI features that Booking.com implemented into it‚Äôs product, and then how they fine-tuned the specific needs of each with the help of Amazon SageMaker AI. First, how they reduced the cost of their accommodation description generator by 180x, and second, how they made their intuitive, prompt-based filter search tool 15x faster. You can read more about this in their very detailed AWS Blog post.
As part of a cross-functional team responsible for monitoring and investigating ops issues in our environments, we are all too familiar with the art of getting alarm thresholds into the ‚Äúsweet spot‚Äù where they‚Äôre actually alerting for potential issues, and not for some expected window of peak traffic. Alex Livingstone and Mohamed Wali of AWS gave us some great ideas how we can use several ‚Äúanomaly detection‚Äù features of CloudWatch to learn from expected behaviour patterns, and minimise intervention. The models are retrained on AWS automatically without any need for user input, but specific periods can also be excluded from training if you don‚Äôt want them to impact the results.
We also saw a demo of Amazon Q Developer operational investigations, a much anticipated CloudWatch feature currently in preview, that instructs Amazon Q to automatically investigate alarms on your behalf. This way, when you go to your dashboard after an alert, you‚Äôre already presented with key observations highlighted to aid your investigation why an alarm was triggered. You can see the logs of which services Amazon Q inspected, what information it discovered, and what suggestions it has generated to fix the issue. In some cases, it can even provide runbook suggestions in Systems Manager that can execute steps to resolve the issue automatically! Care must be taken to review these before executing ‚Äî but as the models behind detection/resolution get smarter, these could start saving developers a lot of time when investigating root causes of issues.
As usual ‚Äî AWS delivered with a Summit packed full of news, updates, and new technologies to try out, while also sharing some real-world customer success stories as inspiration how we can better leverage AI in our products ‚Äî If you‚Äôre interested in AWS or the cloud at any level, we highly recommend the trip to an AWS Summit near you!
We are ACTUM Digital and this piece was written by Nathan Faulkner, Senior .NET Developer. Feel free to get in touch!

Content:

Sign up
Sign in

Petra Gardafjord, founder of beautiful Swedish kids brand Beton Studios shares her daily life in Stockholm for a little travel inspiration
My family and I live in a suburb to Stockholm called Sundbyberg, or Sumpan as we like to call it. It‚Äôs like its own little town, a little quiet, but still lots going on! Since we live outside the big city we ride the tube everyday. The kids have grown up with it and could probably go by themselves if we let them!
Sumpan is a mix between old and new. It used to be real industrial town but is getting really modern by the years. It‚Äôs growing like mad, housing hundreds of families.
On the weekends we like to play outdoors. There‚Äôs a park called Tornparken, where the kids can play for hours. In the summer there‚Äôs a good sized toddler pool, perfect to splash around in.
Just close by the park is an old water tower rebuilt just recently into a restaurant, Delibruket. They have the most amazing flatbread pizza buffet during weekends and we can sit for hours. Outside is the most amazing view across the town and we can see our house from there.
The library is the perfect spot for changing diapers, nursing, feeding, coffee and just hit the couches with a few good children‚Äôs books. It‚Äôs a great place to get a little down time since the kids know they can‚Äôt be loud in there.
My most favorite place here is Marabouparken. It has a big beautiful park, full of life during the weekends. In the warmer days we bring our towels and picnic baskets and eat fruit and a good fika (Swedish for coffee and buns/cookies) in the grass. Inside is a exhibition hall for all sorts of art and a cool restaurant, Parkliv, that serves the best rhubarb lemonade and lemon pie!
We are a very active family and every chance we get we are out riding bikes or visit the local public swimming pool. We also recently discovered this gorgeous old gym hall just across from where we live. It‚Äôs not open for the public but Martin got contacts from work so sometimes we sneak inside and make ourselves a obstacle course and run around like mad people. The kids love it!
Follow Petra on Instagram at @minimockspetra to find out more about her brand and her life in Stockholm.

Content:

Sign up

So, you may remember that back in September 2024, I was awarded a full bursary to attend an ECR (early career researcher) networking event in Stirling, Scotland. The event was organised by the British Society of Gerontology‚Äôs emerging researchers in ageing group (ERA), in collaboration with SWEAH (the Swedish national graduate school on ageing and health), and hosted at the University of Stirling.
You can read my reflective blog on the ECR networking event here.
So, then in February 2025, the cohort who‚Äôd attended this networking event were invited to join another collaborative event between ERA and SAIN (the SWEAH Alumni Interdisciplinary Network) ‚Äî this time, to join a writing retreat in Stockholm, on the island of L√•ngholmen in the old prison!
The retreat provided the opportunity for: networking, space for co-writing and quiet time, social activities, and also the chance to share our research with the group through short presentations. It was too good an opportunity to miss ‚Äî especially as attendance at the writing retreat was funded ‚Äî huge thanks to ERA and SAIN!
Having arrived earlier than most, for my extended research trip, I was one of the first to check in at the former prison ‚Äî enabling me to settle in over a nice dinner, but fall straight into bed in my ‚Äòcell‚Äô! I was tired, as it had already been quite a full-on week!
The organisation, just as it had been in Stirling, was impeccable ‚Äî we‚Äôd been advised of other mates‚Äô arrival and departure times (to co-ordinate travel together), and had received the schedule in advance so we knew what to expect! What we hadn‚Äôt bargained on was the incredible hospitality of the Swedish, including my introduction to the concept of ‚Äòfika‚Äô ‚Äî see blog post three and sharing three meals a day with the group.
Wednesday morning gave me the chance to catch up with a friend from Stirling, before joining the others for our first shared lunch together and then kicking off the retreat with introductions, short research presentations, and an introduction to ELSA (the English Longitudinal Study of Ageing) by Dr Brian Beach (University College London / Karolinksa Institutet).
I was particularly excited about our short presentations, as this was the first time I‚Äôd had the opportunity to share our co-created postcard blog series, from my Take a Walk in My Shoes research project. Also, in Stirling I‚Äôd use haiku poems for my research presentation, this time I used the postcards‚Ä¶
What‚Äôs always fascinating for me at ‚Äògerontology‚Äô events is the rich diversity of research interests and approaches. We‚Äôre all focused on aspects of ageing, but bring an incredible variety of topics, methodologies and personalities ‚Äî it‚Äôs great!
We heard about the Intersectional Stigma of Place-based Ageing (ISPA) project, explored voices of older people from marginalised communities and women living with the impact of intimate partner violence.
We learnt about end of life care through the lenses of understanding health inequalities towards the end of life with dementia and through the architectural design of hospices in England; and considered emotional and physical wellbeing through psychological studies into depression and future-time perspectives, and the impact of the built-environment design of housing and healthcare on the psychology of its users.
Age-friendly design and social relationships in physical spaces and urban neighbourhoods, environmental design for ageing and cognitive health, and the detection and assessment of dementia in the autistic population also featured in the presentations, as well as how stress in earlier life and impact health and functioning in later life.
Further research projects are exploring health inequalities in ageing through the interplay between genes and socioeconomic environment, and focusing on how life-course factors shape health and work prospects in later life; in addition to a focus on extended working lives, risk and protective factors for cognitive ageing and dementia.
Healthy ageing was explored in relation to physical function, high-intensity interval training, cardiovascular and cognitive health, and psychological health during the retirement transition.
The writing retreat provided equal measures of intense research focus and writing, with time to enjoy our local setting and spend time with friends. This balance isn‚Äôt easy to get right ‚Äî but it was done here with thought, care, and lots of time for eating and drinking together!
Since attending this ERA event in April, I‚Äôve been invited to present at the ERA pre-conference, which takes place before the main BSG conference in June 2025, AND have secured a bursary to attend. Thank you!

Matein Khalid
My generation were teenagers in the late 1970‚Äôs and thus passionate fans of Sweden since Abba dominated the Top of the Pops (God, how I hated the ghastly Dancing Queen since every girl in high school thought this syrupy pop tune was written specifically for her!) and Bj√∂rn Borg dominated Centre Court at Wimbledon as the Men‚Äôs Champion until the trophy was wrested from him in 1981 in a five set marathon by the awful but brilliant American John McEnroe. As I grew older, I learnt to love Sweden‚Äôs amazing social tolerance and cosmopolitan culture, its democratic values, welfare state, its beautiful lakes, ancient cities and effervescent young women whom I met in my fave Hellenic beach resorts like Ayia Napa in Cyprus and Mykonos in the Greek Aegean.
However, in 2025, I have a special reason to love Sweden and it is definitely not the ugly furniture of Ikea my Gen-Z twins adore. The Swedish kroner has been the best anti-dollar FX hedge of 2025 and is up an incredible 17% in the last 6-months. As I expect the Trump Buckeroo to fall 20% before the Big Guy leaves the White house, I hope my Swedish kroner stash rises another 20% and offsets the already exorbitant cost of a Scandi holiday. Since I prefer the Med to the Baltics at any time of the year, why not revert back to the 1980‚Äôs watering holes in the Cyclades and meet nice Swedish people in the Scandinavian love shack rather than actually flying to Stockholm Gothenburg or Malm√∂.
Sweden is also one of the world‚Äôs most successful case studies in innovation and entrepreneurial capitalism, the reason Nasdaq‚Äôs Old World hub is in Stockholm. This $900 billion economy is one of my favourite countries to invest for the next 5-years as long as Putin does not invade Estonia and try to usurp King Charles XII‚Äôs role as the supreme war lord of the North with a blockade of the Baltics. After all, Putin is from St. Petersburg, a port founded by Tsar Pyotr Alexievich to fight the Swedish empire, the superpower of the North in the first decade of the 18th century.
This IT/green tech/export colossus is a goldmine for investors who love corruption free economies dedicated to innovation and talent, a natural for any refugee from Planet Dollar like moi!

Title: How to enjoy Stockholm without breaking your bank Part 3 ‚Äî getting around and my thought on Stockholm Pass.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Travel diaries, tips, foods, people and thoughts. instagram: #travelwithsara / #eatwithsata

--
Listen
Share
Worrying about getting around? getting to and from the airport? want to check out the archipelago but do not want to join an expensive tour?
Public transport is great in Stockholm but it is not cheap. On average, a single ride costs SEK35. As visitor, you can buy a 7 days pass at SEK315 (there are other options if you are staying for only a day or 2, check here for information).
The best thing about this card is, you can actually go to and from the airport with it without paying extra if you do not mind a slightly longer (like 20 mins) commute!
If you go to the train station, they will tell you you need to purchase a SEK120 ticket to go through (which is true). However, we were lucky enough to encounter a staff who is nice enough to tell us the alternative that saved us SEK280/pax (2 more lunches!).
When you are at SkyCity in the airport, go out (and down) from the escalator, you will see a bus stop, get on bus 583 (you can check their schedule here) and ride to the last stop at M√§rsta station. At M√§rsta station, you will get on the train that go all the way to Stockholm City.
The bus ride is about 10‚Äì15 mins and the train ride is about 30‚Äì40mins.
M√§rsta station is the end of the train line, so you can‚Äôt really get it wrong.
(photo credit: Brorsson)
Apart from going to and from the airport, you can also go to (some part of) the Stockholm Archipelago with your Travelcard which easily saves you hundreds of SEK.
Stockholm is made up of 30,000 islands (subject to dispute :P), and it is a large part of Stockholm Swedes‚Äô life to go to the Archipelago during summer/vacation. (To hide away and to not talk to anyone.)
If you want to do some island hopping, you can actually do it with the public ferry which is free with the card. Since I was there in autumn (and didn‚Äôt have time), I did not explore that. However, if you have any specific island in mind, you should check the website of waxholmsbolaget for more information.
It would be a pity to visit a city without seeing it from the water. If you do not have enough time to enjoy that, a short ride on the public ferry maybe a good way to do that. We took a short ride on the number 80. My only advice is don‚Äôt do it after dark. That‚Äôs what we did and we didn‚Äôt really see much.
Stockholm metro station is renown for its artistic decorations (you can see my Part 1 post for some picture and links to plan your trip ;)).
When we were in Stockholm, weather was not the best. With the card, we can easily hop on the train/metro/bus and kept ourselves from the rain.
You know what I think, a Travelcard is well worth it I will urge you to get it. You can get the card in the train station/convenient store in the airport.
Stockholm card is different from the Travelcard. It is a card that gives you free access/discount to paid museums, sights etc.. Different from visitor pass in many other cities, it does not include public transport (you need to buy a Travelcard) on top of that.
The card comes in 3 options, from SEK 595 (1 day) to SEK1295 (6 days). I ended up not getting it and not regretting it.
As mentioned in Part 1 of this post ‚Äî most of the museums have free hours, if you plan accordingly, you can easily save a SEK200‚Äì300; as for transport (which is the most expensive items on their list), the only offer they have is the hop-on-hop-off for one day. The route is basically covered by public transport, and Stockholm is a pretty walkable city without the rain.
Another draw back about thePass is that you can only get your money‚Äôs worth if you plan very carefully. Sometimes, you may end up just seeing everything but paying attention to nothing, not to mention the interesting thing that you might see if you‚Äôre not in a rush.
Lastly, when I took a look at the items, a few of them are very similar (tour around similar places), which you probably would not need to do them all.
The Verdict
I do not think it is worth it to get the pass, unless you are dead set to see all the paid museums (potentially giving up on some of the awesome free museums) and is very strategic about that.
Stockholm is not cheap, but definitely not crazy expensive like people say. I did not have a lot of time to research for the trip, and started looking when I was flights/commute, and I still managed to make the whole trip rather affordable. Doing my research, I found these blogs/site super helpful, hope you can benefit from them too:
And remember, Google is always your best friends and ready to help :)
Have a good time in Stockholm. Follow me here or on instagram @eatwithsara for more posts about food and travel!

Title: All About: Stockholm
Content:

Here at All About Capital Cities we aim to give you an overview of all the 196 capital cities in the world.
Stockholm, the capital of Sweden, has a history that spans over 700 years. It was officially founded in 1252 by Birger Jarl, a Swedish statesman who sought to protect Sweden‚Äôs interior from sea invasions and to control trade along the Baltic Sea. Its strategic location on 14 islands where Lake M√§laren meets the Baltic made Stockholm ideal for both defense and commerce.
The city quickly became a vital trade center, especially during the Hanseatic League era in the late Middle Ages. German merchants and craftsmen played a major role in shaping its early economy and architecture. In the 16th century, under the reign of Gustav Vasa, Stockholm became the political and administrative capital of a newly unified Sweden, marking the start of the Swedish Empire.
During the 17th century, Stockholm flourished as Sweden emerged as a European great power. The city expanded significantly, with grand palaces and government buildings constructed to reflect its growing prestige. However, this golden age was followed by a period of decline in the 18th century after Sweden lost much of its territory.
The Industrial Revolution in the 19th century revitalized Stockholm, transforming it into a modern city with railways, factories, and growing suburbs. It continued to evolve through the 20th century, becoming a hub for innovation, culture, and diplomacy.
Today, Stockholm is known for its beautiful mix of medieval and modern architecture, its progressive social systems, and its role as a leading city in technology, sustainability, and Scandinavian culture.
Stockholm is famous for its stunning natural setting, rich history, and modern innovation. Spread across 14 islands connected by over 50 bridges, the city is often called the ‚ÄúVenice of the North.‚Äù Its blend of medieval charm and cutting-edge design makes it one of Europe‚Äôs most attractive capitals.
The city is also renowned for its well-preserved Old Town, Gamla Stan, where cobbled streets and colorful 17th-century buildings surround landmarks like the Royal Palace and Stockholm Cathedral. Stockholm is the cultural heart of Sweden, home to world-class museums such as the Vasa Museum, which houses a 17th-century warship, and the ABBA Museum, celebrating Sweden‚Äôs iconic pop group.
As the home of the Nobel Prize ceremonies, Stockholm is a global symbol of intellectual achievement and innovation. The city is also recognized for its sustainability and environmental efforts, often ranking among the world‚Äôs greenest cities.
In addition, Stockholm has a vibrant food scene, cutting-edge fashion, and a strong tech industry, earning it the nickname ‚ÄúUnicorn Factory‚Äù due to its high number of billion-dollar startups. With its mix of history, nature, and modern living, Stockholm stands out as a unique and influential European capital.
Greta Garbo ‚Äî Iconic silent film actress of the 1920s and 1930s
Avicii (Tim Bergling) ‚Äî Influential electronic music producer and DJ
Alfred Nobel ‚Äî Inventor of dynamite and founder of the Nobel Prizes
Ingrid Bergman ‚Äî Oscar-winning actress (Casablanca, Gaslight)
Benny Andersson ‚Äî Member of the pop group ABBA, who were formed in Stockholm
Gamla Stan (Old Town) ‚Äî Historic heart of Stockholm with cobbled streets and colorful buildings
Vasa Museum ‚Äî Maritime museum showcasing a fully intact 17th-century warship
Skansen ‚Äî Open-air museum and zoo with traditional Swedish buildings and animals
The Royal Palace ‚Äî One of Europe‚Äôs largest palaces, still in official use
ABBA The Museum ‚Äî Interactive museum dedicated to the iconic Swedish pop group
Fotografiska ‚Äî Contemporary photography museum with exhibitions and a top-floor restaurant
Djurg√•rden ‚Äî Green island full of museums, parks, and family attractions
Stockholm City Hall ‚Äî Host of the Nobel Prize banquet and home to the beautiful Golden Hall
Moderna Museet ‚Äî Sweden‚Äôs top modern art museum
The Archipelago ‚Äî Explore by ferry or boat; popular islands include Vaxholm and Sandhamn
If you‚Äôre planning on travelling to the city then make sure you‚Äôve got some travel insurance in place. Our partner EKTA offer travelers health insurance for worldwide destinations for all travelers.
If you‚Äôre keen to visit soon, then head to Trip.com and plan your visit.
--
--
From Abidjan to Zagreb, Abu Dhabi to Yerevan, capital cities are great places to visit, whether for a weekend break or a longer stay.

Take a stroll through the charming streets of Gamla Stan and visit the incredible Vasa Museum. Don‚Äôt forget to explore Djurg√•rden, the lush green island, and indulge in the world of modern art at the Fotografiska Museumet. Get ready for an unforgettable adventure in this vibrant city!
Here are five top tips, from a true Stockholm native, on what to do in Stockholm! Want more tips from me? Feel free to leave a comment!
You should check out Gamla Stan when you visit Stockholm ‚Äî it is a charming neighborhood with narrow streets and colorful buildings. This historic district is located on the island of Stadsholmen and is one of the best-preserved medieval city centers in Europe.
As you wander through its winding cobblestone streets, you‚Äôll come across beautiful architecture, quaint cafes, and charming shops selling Swedish handicrafts. Gamla Stan is also home to several notable landmarks, including the Royal Palace, Stortorget (the main square), and the Stockholm Cathedral.
Don‚Äôt forget to explore the narrow alleyways and hidden courtyards, where you‚Äôll find hidden gems and unique surprises. Whether you‚Äôre a history buff, an architecture lover, or simply looking for a picturesque setting, Gamla Stan is a must-visit destination in Stockholm.
Located in Stockholm, the Vasa Museum exhibits a well-preserved 17th-century warship. It is a fascinating destination for history enthusiasts and maritime lovers. Upon entering the museum, visitors are greeted by the majestic sight of the Vasa ship, which was salvaged from the depths of the Stockholm harbor after sinking on its maiden voyage in 1628.
The ship‚Äôs intricate carvings and ornate details are a testament to the craftsmanship of the era. As you explore the museum, you‚Äôll learn about the ship‚Äôs ill-fated journey and the remarkable efforts made to recover and restore it. The Vasa Museum offers a unique glimpse into Sweden‚Äôs naval history and serves as a reminder of the country‚Äôs seafaring legacy.
Wandering through Djurg√•rden, the green island, allows you to escape the hustle and bustle of the city and immerse yourself in nature‚Äôs tranquility. Djurg√•rden is a true oasis in the heart of Stockholm, where you can stroll along lush green pathways and breathe in the fresh air.
The absence of cars on the island adds to its charm, making it the perfect place for a leisurely walk or bike ride. As you explore Djurg√•rden, you‚Äôll come across beautiful gardens, picturesque waterfronts, and even a charming little village. There are also several museums and attractions to visit, such as the Vasa Museum and the ABBA Museum.
Whether you‚Äôre a nature lover or a culture enthusiast, Djurg√•rden offers something for everyone, making it a must-visit destination in Stockholm.
The Fotografiska Museumet is a great place to explore if you are interested in contemporary art and photography. Located in Stockholm, Sweden, the museum showcases a vast collection of stunning photographs from renowned photographers around the world.
With its sleek and modern design, the museum provides a perfect backdrop for the captivating artworks on display. From thought-provoking exhibitions to interactive installations, Fotografiska offers a unique and immersive experience for visitors of all ages.
Whether you are a photography enthusiast or simply appreciate the beauty of visual arts, the museum offers a diverse range of exhibitions that will leave you inspired and amazed. Don‚Äôt forget to stop by the museum‚Äôs gift shop, where you can find a variety of photography books, prints, and other unique souvenirs to commemorate your visit.

(disclaimer: this post is long overdue, as the trip happened in February. But better late than never!)
Me two months ago: Dear Santa Claus & birthday fairy lady, all I want for my birthday is to experience a white winter for my 30th before I head to Singapore. I‚Äôm talking a white winter, with glistening snow as far as the horizon stretches and air so crisp and cold that it takes your breath away. But not so debilitatingly cold that we won‚Äôt go outside‚Ä¶ Sweden and Iceland, you say? Alright I‚Äôm in!
Turns out Stockholm and Iceland were the perfect retreats to get a refreshing dose of true winter before I move to a country with hot, hot, hot and hotter as seasons. The weather was a brisk 0 degrees C/32 degrees F, which was cold, but gave us beautiful flurries of snow every other day. In Sweden, we slowly acclimated to the cold and learned about the viking history of this Nordic country in museum after museum. Then in Iceland, we became outdoor adventurers, summiting glaciers and hiking ice caves. Even for warm-blooded Californians, these two northern spots were the ideal winter vacation.
Sweden highlights:
Iceland highlights (Part 2) is here.
Sweden runs so efficiently. The ARN airport has wifi, the express train that takes you to Central Station has wifi, and the busses run promptly every few minutes. Our Airbnb was in the adorable Old Town district, with narrow cobblestone streets that housed everything from tacky souvenir shops to quaint boutique stores that sold artisan chocolates and fancy wool textiles. It was right next to the riverwalk, where stately old buildings boasted their prowess along the water.
In true American form, we sought out the Swedish things we already knew and loved: Swedish fish, Swedish meatballs, Swedish pancakes, and Swedish massages. Our kind Airbnb host welcomed us with Swedish fish, so we immediately sought out #2: Swedish meatballs. We popped into an adorable cafe on the street corner and ordered meatballs, salmon and soup. The meatballs came in a rich cream sauce but had the appearance of Mexican mole. It was even better than all our Ikea meatball memories combined.
Warning: Swedish food is expensive. Icelandic food is even more expensive. Be prepared to drop $30 for breakfast and lunch and anywhere from $60‚Äì100 for dinner, especially if you order drinks. Thankfully (?) the SF restaurant scene has immunized me from sticker shock when I open menus anywhere in the world.
Swedish pancakes were reserved for breakfast the following day at Greasy Spoon (delicious), and it turns out Swedish pancakes are just‚Ä¶ pancakes. But when topped with ricotta cheese and pistachios, you really don‚Äôt miss the ‚ÄúSwedish‚Äù at all. We also ordered eggs benedict and a salmon dish atop what can only be described as chunky potatoes.
And Swedish massages aren‚Äôt really a thing. Swedish massages were really invented by the Danish, but misattributed to the Swedish. So we scrapped that idea altogether and found a Thai massage place on Night 2. A warm Thai massage in freezing weather beats a massage in Thailand any day, even if we did pay $50 for an hour :X
Vasa Museum, 5 stars
This was one of the coolest museums I‚Äôve ever been to. Upon entering, you‚Äôre greeted by a massive 70-meter ship (225 ft) that‚Äôs 95% of its original form. Back in 1621, Sweden was at war with Norway and the king had the ship built in two years. After just 10 minutes on the water, 1.5 km away from the shore, the Vasa ship tipped over and started to sink. She was too top-heavy and narrow in the middle to withstand a gust of wind. Of ~200 people on board, 30 died a tragic (seemingly unnecessary) death. It wasn‚Äôt until 333 years later that Sweden had the technological prowess to pull the ship up from the bottom of the ocean. The water was so cold that it was able to preserve the bones, and even the brains and shoes, of the some of the deceased aboard!
Nobel Prize Museum, 5 stars
Exhibit 1 of Swedes being incredibly nice and generous: the Nobel Prize museum was closing in 30 minutes, but the front desk man graciously allowed us in, as long as we promised not to tell anyone (he said with a wink). The museum offered an excellent crash course in all the Nobel prizes, including the Junglebook by Rudyard Kipling for literature, penicillin in medicine, and many other scientific concepts that went straight over my head.
I was frustrated by the US education system that failed to teach us about all these spectacular inventions, but also inspired to read all the Nobel-prize winning literature. Though I had read books by a few of the prize-winning authors (Beloved by Toni Morrison, Lord of the Flies by William Golding), I had barely scratched the surface of authors to read. The museum was also a crash course in learning about Alfred Nobel, a serial inventor, most known for his dynamite and explosive inventions. This was probably more world history I had retained than any class in school :X
Fotografiska Museum, 5 stars
The museum offered three powerful exhibits:
Royal Palace, 4 stars
‚ÄúRoyal‚Äù is a bit of a stretch to describe the Swedes‚Äô Palace, but it is a lovely building, and aptly representative of the humble nature of the Swedes. Oddly enough, all the Swedish royalty pictured and ornately framed are brunettes, not at all like the blonde/blue-eyed people I had imagined. There are 3 main buildings ‚Äî I recommend buying the ticket that gets you into all three. They‚Äôre worth checking out.
National Library of Sweden and Stockholm Public Library, 4 stars
Cause we‚Äôre #nerds. The bibliophiles in us couldn‚Äôt help but make a stop at *both* libraries. The Stockholm Public Library boasted a gorgeous rotunda on its top-level with thousands of books encircling us. As I browsed the shelves, my eyes immediately went to the Isabel Allende section where I saw the exact book I was reading on the trip: In√©s of My Soul, but in Swedish. Talk about serendipity! Who needs John Cusack and Kate Beckinsale‚Ä¶
The National Library of Sweden had a slightly more interesting inventory. The library‚Äôs basement contained ‚ÄúCodex Gigas‚Äù, literally meaning ‚Äúgiant book‚Äù, or The Devil‚Äôs Bible. It‚Äôs the largest known medieval manuscript at 36x20x8.7 inches.
Nordic Museum, 3 stars
The exterior is stunning and looks more royal than the Royal Palace, with its turquoise sheen-ed roof atop sturdy concrete walls and multi-panel glass windows. Statues of imposing men riding horses guard the building to create a sense of awe when you enter the museum. And did I mention free entrance from 1‚Äì5pm? Apparently this is the happenin‚Äô place on weekday afternoons with the older Swedes (aka senior citizens..), who comprised 80% of the visitors. And I don‚Äôt blame them. The atrium alone provided the most beautiful luncheon backdrop.
Eat in the museum cafe! I ordered the traditional meat and cabbage lasagna-esque dish (no noodles), and Jenn and Jenn got the salmon and mushroom soup. Keep in mind that we all grew up eating family-style, so we had the benefit of getting to try three different entrees at every meal. Plus the cafe provides all-you-can-eat bread, coffee and tea.
The rotating exhibits included Fashion through the Ages and A Nordic History, both of which were an enlightening glimpse into Nordic history through a fun, interactive lens. One exhibit provided paper for us to draw our 2050 fashion predictions and weave a giant tapestry with colorful threads that evoked different emotions.
Sodermalm Square and King‚Äôs Garden, 5 stars:
This was a beautiful garden and city center in the middle of Stockholm. There was a giant performance venue plus an ice skating rink decked out in twinkling lights, where parents and their kids swirled around unsteadily and didn‚Äôt mind taking a tumble. A small food stand served hot chocolate and even had fireplaces to roast marshmallows. If you could sit long enough in the cold, you could watch the ice sheets float down the river passing by magnificent buildings like the Grand Opera House and International Riviera Grand Hotel. It felt like Christmas in February.
Skansen ‚ÄúMuseum‚Äù, 2 stars
The world‚Äôs oldest outdoor museum is a fascinating microcosm of Sweden. The founder brought or modeled buildings of all trades to Skansen to showcase the different industries, including glassblowing, carpentry, and other crafts. These craftsmen and women were smart and apparently decided to stay home from the cold because most of the shops were closed the day we went. There were outdoor venues, like an ice skating rink, and restaurants that were open, but we skipped. Luckily, the animals were still open for business, and we got to see wolverines (not Hugh Jackman, but honeybadger-like animals), bison, snow wolves, bobcats/lynx, and reindeer! The 2-star rating is a bit harsh, but it was pretty darn cold to spend all day at an outdoor park.
Gondolen Bar, 4 stars
Go for the views, stay for the drinks. We arrived a bit late (30 min before closing so we only had beer and wine offerings available. No matter, I immensely enjoyed my IPA.) We also were able to admire the great views from Katarinahissen, the 12-story elevator that takes you to an outdoor balcony for stunning views of the city.
Sturehof restaurant, 4 stars
Seafood lovers: go here. Again, it was expensive, but worth the price tag. We ordered a seafood platter with shrimp of all sizes, plus crab and Canadian lobster. The shrimp were incredibly tasty. The toast skagen, which is what they‚Äôre known for, is mayonnaise-y shrimp on top of toast ‚Äî a bit overrated in my opinion. However, their scallop appetizer (yes, scallop singular, not plural) was to die for, but will set you back $17.
Grand Escalier, 4 stars
We tried to head to the Spy Bar, which loomed surreptitiously outside the Sturehof restaurant, but we eventually gave up trying to get in. We luckily walked inside the ‚Äúgaleria‚Äù (mall) right next to the restaurant and stumbled upon the Grand Escalier bar, which came highly recommended from a friend. Deeee-licious cocktails.
√ñstermalm Food Hall, 4 stars
I had already had moose medallions, so I was in a meat kick, looking to sample the primest cuts of Sweden‚Äôs finest. As we walked around the stalls that offered meats, seafood, pastries, and other goods, we asked a nice gentleman what the most popular meats were. He offered a sampling of their various meat cuts. We had the moose hind, moose salami, and reindeer heart and shoulder. Each had varying levels of smokiness and were all delicious.
When we attempted to pay, the man (Wes) refused and said it was his treat. And the sampling wasn‚Äôt just a piece of meat per animal, there were probably ten slices of each meat! Such. Nice. People. For a light lunch, we had their famous cheese quiche and cardamom cinnamon bun with a light hot chocolate. They really love their cardamom in Sweden. Perhaps cardamom is a natural happiness pill??
Slingerbulten restaurant: yummy restaurant. Order the moose medallions.
Da Peppe: If you want a break from Swedish restaurant, check out this very authentic Italian joint in the Old District. They were kind enough to provide free dessert plus a sufficiently embarrassing Italian rendition of ‚ÄúHappy Birthday.‚Äù
Didn‚Äôt get a chance to visit-
Continue on to part 2 for Adventuring in the Land of Ice
--
--
California girl gallivanting around the globe, writing about travel, food, life, and everything in between

Title: A queer girl‚Äôs guide to Stockholm
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

1
Listen
Share
Stockholm ranks high on many queer people‚Äôs favourite cities list ‚Äî and it‚Äôs plain to see why. This waterfront city is a hub of fashion, music, food, nature and progressive queer culture. Let me guide you to my Stockholm.
As soon as you arrive, whether it‚Äôs at Arlanda or Skavsta airport, you will be met by the views many associate with Sweden; green pine forests, yellow fields and blue lakes, with red little houses dotted all around. As you approach the city (grab Arlanda Express for the smoothest journey) the houses, as well as the vast open waters, grow in size, revealing the unique character of this capital city. Stockholm is where domestic lakes meet the Baltic sea, and whilst this is the centre of the tech, music and fashion innovation that Sweden is well known for, the city also celebrates nature, tradition ‚Äî and LGBTQ rights. Let‚Äôs dive in.
Stockholm is built on 17 islands and as a visitor you simply must make the most out of this unique feature. My first tip, therefore, is: find your sea legs.
There is nothing quite like island hopping in the archipelago. Get on a traditional archipelago boat ‚Äî or it‚Äôs high-speed equivalent ‚Äì and take it out to Waxholm, M√∂ja, Finnhamn, Ut√∂ or any one of the other gorgeous little stops along the way. Here you will be able to stop for a bite to eat, have a dip in the sea, and explore the Swedish forestry. Thanks to Allemansr√§tten, the Right of Public Access, you are free to roam the land (with only a few exceptions). If bigger boats are your thing you could get a ferry from Slussen, taking you to Finland or Estonia for the day.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S_sBip9mUYc
Take time to soak in the waterfront in Stockholm. Whether it‚Äôs a walk on Djurg√•rden, a stroll along the picturesque S√∂derm√§larstrand, or a panoramic tour along Fj√§llgatan (where my girlfriend asked me to marry her on New Year‚Äôs Eve!), I find it is impossible to get enough of the the Stockholm waterfront views. You can count on many a #selfie moment here.
What‚Äôs more, on a warm summer‚Äôs evening you will find theatre performances in R√•lamshovsparken, high profile gigs at theme park Gr√∂na Lund, romantic picnics at Skinnarviksberget, burgers and boules Boule & Bers√• at Danviksbro, national sing-along at open air museum Skansen and beer gardens filled with Swedes enjoying a well-earned ‚ÄúAW‚Äù, after-work. Following a long, dark winter Sweden embraces summer like few others.
Regardless of whether you are visiting in summer or winter, make sure you indulge in a dip. In the warmer months Stockholm‚Äôs many beaches fill up with local holiday makers, and during the rest of year (but also in summer) the many bathhouses create a relaxing oasis. Check out well-renowned Sturebadet, situated in the city centre, or Japanese sanctuary Yasuragi, located in the forests outside Nacka, to experience perfect relaxation. For an added twist and a truly Swedish experience, head out to Hellasg√•rden for a dip in the sea ‚Äî don‚Äôt worry, they cut a hole in the ice for you in the winter.
Stockholm is due to co-host EuroPride together with Gothenburg in 2018 and the city celebrates a huge Pride party every summer ‚Äî but I have found it to be just as welcoming to queer people all year round.
Strolling through the streets of Stockholm I am always struck by rainbow flags, non-conformative design, boundary pushing initiatives and out gay people just being themselves. Last I was over I just happened upon a small yet mainstream jewellery shop proudly advertising rainbow marriage ‚Äì that‚Äôs just one example. Swedes generally don‚Äôt even blink at the thought of same sex couples and when the Pride parade comes to town, the streets fill with people celebrating equality.
Worth noting is that the lesbian scene in Sweden is political; outspokenly feminist and trans inclusive. With lots of lesbian artists and initiatives increasingly gaining recognition across Sweden, the scene is growing particular in the Swedish capital ‚Äî check out artists such as Silvana Imam, Beatrice Eli and Kakan Hermansson and you get the idea.
And whilst holding hands with my girlfriend (now fiancee!) has never caused me any grief regardless of the time of day, it is at night that the gay scene really comes alive‚Ä¶
Stockholm nightlife thrives particularly between May and August, when the sun doesn‚Äôt set and the summer rays stretch on into the early hours. Honestly, it‚Äôs magical.
One of the most popular establishments during this time of year (and again, one of my faves) is M√§larpaviljongen, a chic waterfront bar and restaurant buzzing with LGBT clientele, DJs, and staff. Worth noting is that the venue works with LGBT charity Regnb√•gsfonden and employs LGBT refugees.
Tr√§dg√•rden is another summer club hugely popular with the queer community. Set under the bridges near the waterfront by Eriksdalsbandet, this club invites some of the biggest acts and DJs and it is definitely one to visit. Make sure you go early, though, as queues can be long.
There are lots of club nights aimed specifically at a lesbian/bi clientele. Look out for Moxy, Bitter Pills, Hotellg√§nget, Club Wish (for the kinky) and keep a keen eye on Gunn Lundemo Events ‚Äî this Stockholm-based DJ regularly does clubs around the world but she often also plays on home turf and her latest project with the L Word‚Äôs Daniela Sea looks seriously cool. Speaking of new, SPACE Stockholm is a recent initiative by lesbian icon and longtime Stockholm DJ Pamela, promising house music and underground decadence.
Many of the gay clubs in Stockholm attract a mixed clientele and ‚Äúqueer‚Äù is the buzzword here, as exemplified by the brilliant-looking Klubb H√•ngel, playing retro tunes and serving a no-attitude-pure-joy kind of vibe.
DATE is a club night run by underground music superstars Ji Nilsson and Julia Spada and whereas it isn‚Äôt advertised as queer, it‚Äôs a night I‚Äôd personally always try to make.
Mainstream gay clubs, where I might expect to see more men than women, include King Kong, Wonk and party boat Patricia. Bar/restaurant/club Marie Laveau, which is mixed and has a very cool vibe, puts on a queer party, Club Laveau, every Friday.
Queer friendly but not explicitly gay clubs include Debaser, Berns and S√∂dra Teatern - but then again you will struggle to find somewhere that isn‚Äôt welcoming in Stockholm. For the latest queer events, see Visit Sweden LGBT as well as the Facebook timeline of JagVillG√•P√•QueerFest ‚Äî the information is in Swedish but it gives a good idea of new upcoming nights. You might also want to check out Facebook‚Äôs list of gay bars here.
Say Swedish music and one band will come to mind regardless of where in the world you are. And now, finally, we have a museum dedicated to their greatness! Whether you are a huge fan or not, the ABBA museum is a Stockholm must as it lets you step back in time and rediscover pop history. Record your own song, perform in your own music video and (my favourite) learn about the music history that followed on from these super trooper dancing queens. Go, go, go!
Music thrives in Stockholm and the list of hits created here, thanks to producers such as Denniz Pop, Max Martin, RedOne, Nijs and Ji Nilsson, is endless. Spot some of the stars, including Zara Larsson, First Aid Kit and The Cardigans, live in Stockholm this summer ‚Äî and do consider heading over for Popaganda, Stockholm‚Äôs coolest pop festival held early September at outdoor swimming bath Eriksdalsbadet. Years and Years and FKA Twigs were incredible last year.
Fans of modern art head to Moderna Museet or Liljevalchs, where each spring their exhibition V√•rsalongen showcases the latest artists and pieces for a small entry fee. Fotografiska, the photography museum, is another must as they never fail to put on incredible and thought-provoking exhibitions, often by queer artists.
It is no secret that Swedes love IKEA as much as the rest of the world, but there is more to Swedish interior design than that. On a trip to Stockholm make sure you check out the Svenskt Tenn and Svensk hemsl√∂jd in the city centre and discover the origins of Scandi hygge.
Stockholm Fashion Week takes place twice a year but this city breathes fashion 24/7. Home to brands such as ACNE, Stutterheim, Dagmar, Whyred, Swedish Hasbeens, Anna Holtblad, Filippa K, Hope, Nudie, Happy Socks, COS, Polarn O. Pyret as well as high street hits Weekday, Monki and of course, H&M, Stockholm makes for great shopping, especially as many of these big names actively challenge both hetero and gender norms. ‚ÄúNormkritik‚Äù, norm criticism is an important concept in Sweden, not least in fashion.
For high street fashion head to Drottninggatan and the city centre area between tube stops T-centralen, H√∂torget and √ñstermalmstorg. Whilst you will find specialised (and very good!) H&M stores on almost every corner, Monki and Weekday are other Swedish-owned high street brands well worth checking out. Department store √Öhl√©ns has a good fashion department with many Swedish designers and Nordiska Kompaniet, a five minute walk from there, is excellent for your high end shopping. MOOD department store around the corner serves up a cool hipster vibe (with incredible toilets) and Biblioteksgatan, Sturegallerian and Sturegatan is where you find your luxury shopping. Do pop into Efva Attling jewellery shop on Biblioteksgatan ‚Äî Efva is without a doubt one of Sweden‚Äôs biggest lesbian icons.
On S√∂dermalm I would recommend a stroll along √Ös√∂gatan where you can discover smaller boutiques by Swedish designer stars such as Acne and Stutterheim but also nip into the shop and studio of Caroline Hjerpe, an up and coming jewellery maker with a great Instagram following. Her work has been spotted both on pop star Tove Lo and Sweden‚Äôs biggest vlogger Clara Henry (who, btw is openly bisexual and well worth checking out ‚Äî YouTube here) and for good reason. If you‚Äôre lucky her adorable little dog will come say hi, too.
For vintage fashion check out Beyond Retro and Myrorna, the latter is essentially our version of Oxfam but with huge fashionista status.
There is more to Scandi cooking than meatballs and the capital of Scandinavia is well known for its culinary flair. Regardless of your budget, you can eat very, very well in Stockholm and here are a few of my favourite eateries.
Urban Deli ‚Äî serving local, organic, proper classic Swedish food in a relaxed atmosphere. They have several locations but the Nytorget one is my favourite ‚Äî possibly because it co-functions as a food shop and also happens to be a big queer hot spot.
Paradiest ‚Äî a combined organic food store and food court where local produce is at the heart of the operation.
Green Queen ‚Äî M√§larpaviljonen‚Äôs green little sister. This restaurant/deli focuses on ‚Äúclean‚Äù eating, serving up delicious rainbow salads, juices and raw snacks.
Nalle o Kroppkakan ‚Äî for something very Swedish and rather different, head to this restaurant near Telefonplan. They serve traditional Swedish ‚Äúkroppkakor‚Äù, robust potato dumplings with different fillings. Served with lingonberries and a cold beer, it hardly gets more Swedish than this.
Vig√•rda ‚Äî gourmet burgers at budget cost. With an ever changing menu and at least one mean veggie burger at a time this small scale burger chain is the bomb.com. (I will say that mainstream burger chain Max isn‚Äôt bad either ‚Äî they do not one but six veggie options.)
S√∂dra Teatern/Mosebacke ‚Äî with one of the best views of the city, this classic S√∂dermalm establishment serves Swedish tapas, small courses making the vegetable the star of the show (worry not, you may add meat or fish if you so wish).
A Swedish must is the tradition of fika, meaning coffee or tea with a small snack (preferably a cinnamon roll if you ask me). Your fika options are endless but these are some of my favourites:
The classic fika: Vetekatten
The posh fika: Wienerkonditoriet
The healthy, soulful fika: Koloni
The LGBT tourist fika: Chokladkoppen (ideal for an Old Town sightseeing stop)
The hipster fika: Vurma
The political, vegan fika: Femtopia
The raw fika: STHLM RAW
The Instagram worthy fika: Pom & Flora
The mainstream fika: Wayne‚Äôs
And on that sweet note, it is time to round this guide up. Do leave your favourite Stockholm tips in the comments below and hit me up on social media if you have any questions about queer life in Stockholm.
Last but not least‚Ä¶ the practicalities.
The main inner city areas to bear in mind are S√∂dermalm/SoFo (for a relaxed and very cool hipster vibe), √ñstermalm (high end shopping and first class food), gorgeous old town area Gamla Stan (the cobbled streets see you literally step back in time ‚Äì make sure you visit the castle), down to earth Kungsholmen and green museum island Djurg√•rden.
When I visit I try to walk as much as possible, just because it means I get to see more of the city, but getting around via public transport is easy. The Oyster-like SL card gives you access to the tube, bus, tram and boat ‚Äî all of which feel safe and clean. Many of the tube stations are decorated with lovely bits of art and a recent addition is that the escalators are lit up by rainbow lights. You can plan your journeys here.
SAS, British Airways, RyanAir and Norwegian all fly non-stop to Stockholm from London. If you fly into Arlanda I would recommend going via Arlanda Express, Flybussarna coach or Taxi 020 ‚Äî beware of individual taxi drivers trying to grab your attention at the rank and instrad pick the big taxi names, asking for a fixed price.
Stockholm Pride is taking place 31 July ‚Äî 6 August 2017. See you there?
--
--
1
A queer girl living in Stockholm. Former Travel Editor at DIVA Magazine.

Title: Our Bike Trip in the Stockholm Archipelago
Content:
