This was written by me and my spouse, Yoav Luft.
This summer we didn‚Äôt want to use planes, busses, or trains, due to the Corona. So we decided to go on a bike trip in the Stockholm archipelago.
We planned 5 days of biking and one additional day to rest on our final destination. We booked everything through an agency called ResGladh, that we‚Äôve found through Sweden By Bike. We could have rented through ResGladh the bikes, but we wanted to keep them, so we purchased two bikes with 8 gear at Decathlon.
We received a map from Sweden By Bike with official bike paths, and prepared our riding plan according to recommendations from them and different attractions (like museums) from Google Maps. In the maps below, each square is 5 km. When planning our route, we wrote down when we will have access to restaurants and supermarkets.
We took two instant rice bags with us and some sandwiches and fruits for the first day, as well as energy bars, nuts, kn√§ckebr√∂d and tahini for the entire trip. We also took two bottles of water, 1 litre each.
We had one backpack of 35 litres, and one bike bag of 40 litres. We switched them during the trip according to our physical condition.
We took a ferry from Stockholm to V√§sbystrand, Ljuster√∂ with the bikes. On Summers and weekends queues start early, there is limited space for bicycles (11 on bigger ferries) and its first arrived, first served. We arrived some 45 minutes ahead of time and there was already a queue. We sailed for 2.5 hours.
Before the trip we were sure we‚Äôre going to cycle on pastoral gravel paths, so the first day was a bit shocking ‚Äî although we used official maps for cycling, pretty quickly we‚Äôve found ourselves cycling in a road for cars, without dedicated bike lane, nor shoulders. I haven‚Äôt been training recently because of the Corona, and Yoav hasn‚Äôt cycled since childhood, so cycling next to car driving 70 kmh wasn‚Äôt ideal for us. Luckily all the drivers were very careful, and waited behind us if another car was coming from the other direction.
We ate lunch after crossing from Ljuster√∂ to the main land. We crossed on a floating road, this ferry doesn‚Äôt cost money and there‚Äôs no visible personnel on it, so it was a bit weird because we didn‚Äôt know exactly what to do, so we just went on board together with the cars, and then got off on the other side.. it arrives every 20 minutes. We ate lunch on the other side in the all ubiquitous Swedish ‚Äúpizza-kebab".
We continued cycling and stopped at Wira Bruk, a 17th century forge and weapons smithy. It‚Äôs a free open museum that we enjoyed, and we also filled our water bottles there and used the toilet. There‚Äôs also a coffee place there that we haven‚Äôt tried.
We started cycling at 11:30 and arrived at our B&B at 4:30. The owners recommended go bathing at Underskug, but we were exhausted and even missed the supermarket which closed at 18:00. So we went to eat yummy middle-eastern food at Caf√® Bergshamra & Pizzeria.
In the morning we ate breakfast with Margaretha and Bosse from Carlberg B&B, chatted with their other guests, and started our longest day of the trip. In Bergshamara there was a bike lane, and next to Karl-Ols we took the side road and finally cycled in the woods on a gravel path. We then continued through Grovstan√§s, which is really beautiful. We paused there for a short break by the water. We also got lost there a bit and it added 1‚Äì2 km to our original plan.
We paused for lunch at Spillersboda, were there is a caf√© by the water, and we also filled water there, used the toilet, and purchased soap and some cans at the small supermarket there. At all the places we stayed there were towels, but none had soap or shampoo.
We continued then north and had a coffee break at R√•dmans√∂ Bakery Shop. The way from N√§nninge to Bj√∂rk√∂√∂ren was again pretty intense with the cars of many people coming back to Stockholm on the last weekend of the last vacation week of August. We started to cycle in route (1) that‚Äôs marked in azure in the above map, but were stopped by a family arguing that it‚Äôs a private way that is blocked. So we switched to 2 and ended the day at STF (Svenska Turistf√∂reningen) Kapellsk√§r hostel in Riddersholm. There is a kiosk there with some microwave dishes, but we cooked some of the food we‚Äôve had with us. At that point we were very sour. Our thighs muscles as well as butts hurt from cycling for two days and we decided to take it easy the next day ‚Äî planning based on satellite images rather than only the map, and walking uphill instead of paddling.
We‚Äôve decided to go through (4), (5) and (6) in the S√∂dersvik map above. There‚Äôs a cycling path parallel to E18 that is unfortunately not marked in the map. It wasn‚Äôt very inspirational, but it was safe and easy. Around Insj√∂v√§gen we got on to the official path again, which was very beautiful. From there it was very fast and nice to get to Norrt√§lje, and we arrived at noon, which was nice because we had time to enjoy the town.
We stayed in Berglings B&B, which was really nice. We ate at Looi sushi and Ed‚Äôs burger, and walked to the pier. In the morning we got ourselves more comfortable bike chairs at Cykelservice i Norrt√§lje. We also got knee elastic band for Yoav. Yes, we still suffered from the second day‚Äôs effort. We had a discussion whether we should come back home or even get a ferry to the final destination with the bikes and then get buses between the places we were supposed to stay for the nights until then. But we decided to give it another chance ‚Äî and it was worth it, because the fourth day was the most beautiful.
It wasn‚Äôt supposed to be M√§lby. It was supposed to be Wik B&B in Soderby-Karl, but a few days before the trip something happened and they cancelled all the reservations.
ResGladh found us a place further north, and we thought it‚Äôs going to be very tiring, but the road was really nice and quick, and there were four wonderful pauses on the way.
The first break we took was at a church in Roslags-Bro, which was pretty and re-charging.
The second is marked with (1) on the map was a really nice public bathing area with grass, sand and beautiful lake. There were a few people there except for us and it was also nice to see them because we rarely saw people on the paths in this trip.
The one marked with (2) was a coffee place we really enjoyed and also a cool store where I got lovely earrings and neckless, which made me feel much better :D.
The last leg of this day, marked with (3), was a big and nice surprise, cycling along a beautiful artificial canal.
And then we got to our night destination ‚Äî Livsuniversitetet. This is a special place that we appreciated, and we were almost alone here, similarly to the situation on the second night. Lena Kristina helped us to settle down and then gave us a ride to ICA. She told us a little about this place and about herself ‚Äî a pioneer psychologist who‚Äôd researched and developed methodologies around breathing. They have different retreats for groups of adults and youth. The farm is very cozy with a large kitchen and yoga room, and many secret fun corners.
In the evening we went to Ortala bathing park, which was amazingly beautiful with crystal clear water which were also too cold for us to get in.
Finally we were on our last cycling day. Feeling refreshed and excited about the rest day we planned to spend on Arholma, we started our way south-east.
We stopped at Barnens √ñ for a short break, and then at Simp√§s. We took the ferry in the afternoon after eating a delicious Thai lunch at the pier.
In Arholma there‚Äôs a small supermarket and a couple of restaurants that require reservation. We stayed at another STF hostel that was wonderful (and with lots of fun stuff for kids).
The best decision in preparing this trip was to take a resting day in Arholma. We toured the island, booked an hour at the sauna (private, including the water next to it), and had a really nice dinner at Arholma Dansbana. There weren‚Äôt many animals on the island, except for cows and tiny frogs. We were surprised to find a cold war bunker on the island that is now a museum with tours. The day after we hiked in the forest in the north, which was full with blueberries and linden berries, and then took a ferry back in the afternoon, a 4.5 hours trip directly to Stockholm.
--
--
Engineering Manager at Volvo Cars. Co-Founder of Baot.org.

Title: ‚ÄúLost‚Äù in Stockholm
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Guac is an award-winning travel publication run by an interdisciplinary group of students at Cornell University. This organization is a registered student organization of Cornell University.

--
1
Listen
Share
There are three amazing things about Stockholm: its history, people, and cuisine. It is the capital of Sweden, a Scandinavian nation with centuries of heritage and thousands of coastal islands and inland lakes. Connected by more than 50 bridges and built on 14 islands, Stockholm houses 2.3 million people in its metropolitan area. It was settled during the Stone Age and was founded as a city in 1252. When I got the chance to visit, fueled with excitement and curiosity, I ventured on without knowing what was waiting for me.
My first stop, the Stockholm City Hall, is the building of the Municipal Council for the city. Famous for its grand ceremonial halls and unique pieces of art, City Hall is most well-known for hosting the Nobel Prize banquet each year. The guided tour is a must, and be sure to check out the Blue Hall (which is actually red), the Prince‚Äôs Gallery (with the mural pointed by Sweden‚Äôs Prince Eugen), and the Golden Hall (which is decorated with over 18 million mosaic pieces of glass and gold).
My next destination, the Royal Palace, was equally mesmerizing. The tremendous palace, built in the 1700s and painted pastel brown and yellow on the outside, holds more than 1,400 rooms. Even without a guided tour, the Palace still offers an irresistible chance for a taste of royal life. Two unique features of the palace which differentiate it from other grand palaces in Europe are the exhibition dedicated to royalty‚Äôs ceremonial outfits and a chamber furnished in 70s styles. Both share insight into the life and duties of the modern royal family.
One good thing about sightseeing in Stockholm is that a lot of the famous architecture and historical sights reside near one another within the city. Coming out from the backdoor of the Royal Palace, I was directly facing Gamla Stan, the medieval old town. Ochre-colored houses sit close to one another while busy restaurants, cafes, boutiques, and souvenir shops occupy the aged, cobblestone streets.
Just as I ventured into Gamla Stan, jet lag suddenly hit me. Unable to keep my eyes open and my body properly functioning, I needed a good, strong coffee americano to continue my journey. And that was when the ‚Äúaccident‚Äù took place.
‚ÄúCan you pass me my wallet in the bag?‚Äù
‚ÄúYeah, sure. Just one second. But wait‚Ä¶where is my bag?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat do you mean, ‚Äòwhere is your bag?‚Äô You put it right under the table.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not there anymore‚Ä¶‚Äù
After resting a bit in a small caf√© in Gamla Stan, while going through the photos I had taken throughout the day, my mom and I noticed that our bag, which I had left under the table, had disappeared. Yep, that‚Äôs right, I lost the entire backpack on the first day of travelling. Deprived of wallets, travel documents, sunscreen, sunglasses, and basically everything needed for travelling, we were left with the one credit card that I had kept in my pocket.
Though upset at the situation, I was nevertheless surprised and comforted by the warmth of the locals. After hearing about what happened, the owner of the caf√© ran out to comfort my mom and communicate with the local police. As I was running around the medieval alleys, circulating back and forth between fountains, statues, and small churches, looking into trash cans to see if our travel documents were at least thrown out, two shop owners sitting along the streets joined my search and started digging through the trash cans as well. However, our effort was futile in the end.
Frustrated and tired, we wandered aimlessly from Gamla Stan to the city‚Äôs central port. It was already around 6 PM, but the sunshine showed no trace of dimming, and it cast a golden tint over the entire cityscape. With an average height of five stories and a unified yellow-orange color theme, the buildings, which were mostly constructed in the 17th century, resembled each other in architectural style. Between the buildings, cobblestone paths ran across the city plane while locals immersed themselves in thoughts and conversations alongside the river.
Suddenly, upon spotting a group of people dressed in suits and gowns congregating in front of a tour boat, we decided to find out what was happening. One of the crew members explained that this was a weekly cruise tour that served fresh shrimp and seafood platters but also required a reservation at least one month in advance. Disappointed and ready to leave, we were once again surprised by ‚Äúfate.‚Äù Another crew member who overheard our conversation called us back and told us that one couple had canceled their reservation last-minute due to an emergency, and that we could hop on if we wanted. Without a second of hesitation, my mom and I advanced.
After boarding the ship, we were welcomed by an ivory tablecloth, crystal wine glasses, and a sweet floral aroma in the air. The waiters soon seated us along the window and displayed the menu, which included shrimp scampi, salmon, and champagne. It was around 8 PM when the cruise sailed out of the port and started roaming gracefully through the islands during golden hours. Surrounded by fresh seafood, sunset, and nature, the lost bag was already out of my mind. From the reflective river, to the cottages hidden in nature, to the modern luxury apartments, everything seemed like an impressionist painting under the violet-blue infused sky.
Ever since I came back, I have been wondering what was so mesmerizing about Stockholm. What made me want to revisit again and again, even after my little ‚Äúaccident‚Äù? The answer is clear to me now, as I am recalling the memories and images in my mind: it‚Äôs the infinite possibilities one can encounter in this magical city.
* * *
About the Author: Kevin Jiang is a sophomore majoring in History of Art and Economics from Shanghai, China. Outside of school, he is passionate about fashion, photography, and karaoke. His favorite cities are Copenhagen and Florence because of their rich artistic culture and unique aesthetic values, demonstrated by the people, fashion, interior design, and architecture there.
* * *

Title: How to enjoy Stockholm without breaking your bank Part 2 ‚Äî Eating well and affordably
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Travel diaries, tips, foods, people and thoughts. instagram: #travelwithsara / #eatwithsata

--
Listen
Share
Everyone will tell you eating out in Stockholm is expensive, but is quite manageable if think more about how locals eat. After exploring some great free activities, this part of the post will be more focused on the affordable eats :) :
As a foodie, I did not go all the way kebab and sandwich (like I did when I first traveled in Europe 10 years ago). You can also see my reviews about restaurant (actually, pretty affordable, even feel cheap from my Hong Kong perspective) and eating tradition (fika ‚ù§) in my other post here with a map of restaurants that I ate at.
Lunch is the main meal where locals would eat out, and for a good amount of them, it is the main meal for them (eat more at lunch, and skip dinner‚Ä¶ this reminds me of my parents). All-you-can-eat are actually not an uncommon option for them and available around the city and decent price (from SEK100 to mid SEK range if you‚Äôre eating during the lunch time; some places have discount for early diners).
We went to two all-you-can-eat and one of them we just love! (The other is very good for value, too).
As mentioned in Part 1 of this post, I found this place a heaven on earth! It has also come top in most of the (English) reviews. This is the first buffet where I could taste the difference in each dish and within each dish, each ingredient!
My brother and I are both picky eater, and it is the only place where we love everything (my brother hates pickle and I dislike beetroot in general, but we enjoyed them there). They do have some interesting combination of spices that I would not have thought about but turned out well.
My personal favourites are the lasagna (they made me break my low carb diet a bit), the curry and their BUTTER (I mean margarine).
Apart from great food, you can also enjoy a great view of the city from Hermans, they are pretty popular, so good luck in finding a good table.
After a day being a vegetarian, we went back to our meat lover mode. We went to another highly rated all-you-can-eat that specialized in grilled meat for lunch. Everyday, they will have 3 mains (on our day, it was beef, lamb meat loaf and fish). with a salad selection.
Taste wise I‚Äôd say it is not as flavourful as Hermans. However, you can taste the meat (it is not a rare thing here in HK where you can‚Äôt taste what you eat). I like all the 3 mains, but like the fish the most. Among everything there, my favourite is the grilled carrot and the mushroom sauce.
I read that the food is prepared from a charcoal grill. I honestly couldn‚Äôt tell, but then, they definitely deliver a good meaty, hearty lunch in the CBD at a low price.
For more options (especially if you wouldn‚Äôt mind Asian), you can take a look at this and this.
If a sit down lunch is a bit out of budget or simply out of time, you are lucky. Stockholm is a great place for street food with a lot of good roadside grills, food stand and food trucks offering American, Mexican, Middle Eastern food and more.
If you‚Äôre determined to look for the food truck, I will definitely recommend you to follow this article and download the apps. We did not do it, and have wasted like an hour‚Äôs time to search for truck that are not out on the day.
After one hours‚Äô walking we decided to go for the stand. Our original pick was Nystekt Stromming; however it moved (damn you Google) and we did not know the new location was actually very close‚Ä¶ (like across the bridge kind of close). Just walking across the bridge to the old town and you‚Äôre there.
Instead of walking across the bridge, we walked to the metro and went to Ostermalms Korvspecialist.
Although not our first choice, this small hot dog stand where chef eats did not disappoint. It has a generous amount of freshly grilled and tasty sausage, but the best part is the bread.
Unlike your regular hot dog, the bread wrap the sausage like a pocket. It makes it easier to eat and also easier to eat both bread and sausages together. The baguette is rightly toasted, very crispy on the outside and still soft on the inside (however much that‚Äôs left for the inside).
Another thing that I like about them is their sauerkraut does not taste too strong and would not overpower their sausage.
One hotdog is around SEK50‚Äì70, and is enough to feed one adult of reasonable appetite. The staff is quite friendly and I would recommend you to ask for recommendation.
Apart from the fried herring burger, some other fast food that I planned to eat but missed this time are kebab, kebab pizza and falafel. I will be back for you guys (waving)!
This one I can only contribute a little bit, as I did the research but didn‚Äôt try that our myself.
There are 2 types of food halls in the world ‚Äî expensive one and affordable ones. If you go to a food court not because of price but the variety or experience, you could go for more upscale food hall like √ñstermalms Saluhall.
It might be a good idea if you are planning to buy some fresh food to cook at home.
For the rest of us who are looking for cheap in food halls, the following comes up in my research (in order of popularity):
Ok, if you are really on a budget, picnic is a great idea when the weather allows it.
There are plenty of beautiful green area and parks in Stockholm and you can leisurely enjoy your food in a park. Go for a cheaper supermarket and some of them, like urban deli, also have hot food for sale (if you don‚Äôt have anywhere to cook).
Essentially, afterwork is like happy hour, except that some bar would have a small (free) buffet of food. Check out the bars on your way!
For every city, there is definitely places that are affordable if you search for it. Generally, Middle Eastern food (check out my post on my Turkish dinner!), and Asian (which I did not take) would be cheaper. Bar maybe a good options, too. I had 1/2 kg of reasonably good mussels at around SEK165. Also, not to forget you always have your beloved IKEA as an option (although it‚Äôs a bit out of the way‚Ä¶ who cares with the free shuttle?).
One thing I notice is that, do not follow Tripadvisor (and Yelp!) as most of the reviewers are from a few countries (unless you are their fellow country people), and most of the time, the price tag and review is skewed. I skipped all the results from Tripadvisor.
Another interesting find is Facebook does make decent recommendations! I actually discovered 2 of the places I like through them!
On to the next and last part of this series: how to get around Stockholm cheap (apart from walking and swimming).
Feeling full just from reading? You can also go back to the first part to take a look at all the free activities :)
Just to let you know, I relied on the following posts to gather idea on food :) :

Bj√∂rn St√•hl, Founding Partner, Uncommon Stockholm said: ‚ÄúWe will focus on brands that people in the real world are glad exist. These brands are uncommon and they can make a difference like never before. I‚Äôve admired what Nils, Lucy and Natalie have been building at Uncommon for some time and we can‚Äôt wait to continue their impact and partner together in Stockholm.‚Äù
Natalie Graeme, Co-founder at Uncommon Creative Studio added: ‚ÄúBj√∂rn, Mia and Max have the perfect balance ‚Äî they each bring a unique quality and their collective experience is impressive. They see the world the same way we do and match our ambition at Uncommon. We‚Äôre thrilled to welcome them into the fold and couldn‚Äôt think of better partners to venture into Stockholm with.‚Äù
Six years in, the studio continues to make awarded and stand-out work winning its first Grand Prix at this year‚Äôs Cannes Lions for its groundbreaking campaign with British Airways.
Notably work also includes creating the most recognised mental health initiative in the UK with ITV, to creating a globally infamous free suit hire initiative for H&M ‚Äî The One Second Suit, to help young men find work, to redefining what the Nike Jordan brand means today launching during the 23‚Äô NBA All-Star Weekend through the eyes of an aspiring female baller.
The studio has always believed in creativity ‚Äî applying its founding principles of building brands that matter ‚Äî acts rather than advertising. The studio has built successfully portfolios across experience, CX, design and production ‚Äî with Uncommon producing its first feature documentary with renowned director Andrew Dominik for Nick Cave and Warren Ellis‚Äô ‚ÄòThis Much I Know To Be True‚Äô premiering at Berlinale and SXSW and achieved critical acclaim including The Guardian‚Äôs Film of the Week as well as being listed in NME‚Äôs top films of the year. Its second feature ‚ÄòIn Camera‚Äô is in the running for Best First Feature at the upcoming annual BFI London Film Festival.
Though the Studio was set up with a clear point of view and purpose, it also wanted to explore a new business model. Rather than just working for clients, if the studio saw a concept that deserved to exist, it would back it. So far the studio has launched the world‚Äôs first fully compostable coffee capsule Halo Coffee, a sexual wellness brand SEX BRAND launching with the UK‚Äôs most sustainable condom and most recently Communion ‚Äî a new money saving app on a mission to unlock the freedom associated with the act of saving.
Uncommon also invested in the purpose-driven accelerator Unrest ‚Äî to support diverse and sustainable businesses. Since its launch two years ago, it has helped 47 startups, raising ¬£7.2M with a total valuation of ¬£110M.

Title: 5 differences between Stockholm and Singapore (in my eyes)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Accounts & Recounts of my thoughts during my stay here in Stockholm, Sweden.

--
Listen
Share
( This piece started in February, finished in June.)
Day 34. It has been more than a month since the experiential heat in the Lion City.
I don‚Äôt quite miss home yet, but it‚Äôs long enough for me to see stark differences between both cities and culture.
Facial features. Architecture. Museums. Weather. Snow. Winter.
2. Transportation
Metro. Subway. T-bana. Pendelt√•g. Train. Escalator. Reliable. Not reliable. like SMRT? And not everyone has a car.
3. Working culture
Fika means put down your stuff and gather for Coffee Break. Phone-usage is a no-no, Socialising is encouraged.Lunch is Lunch. Work is Work. Party is Party. Work-Life Balance. And we take out our shoes when we are in office.
4. Social norms
More reserved. Strangers rarely say Hi. Yet seemed nice after the ‚Äòice has been broken‚Äô. Cashiers are the friendliest.
5. Standard of Living
Singapore is expensive. Deal with it. Stockholm is expensive too (including student hostels). In fact one of the most expensive in Scandinavia/Europe. High taxation. High expenditure on food, drinks, party. Then again, their wages are high as well.
I have met a couple of Singaporeans who got married and settled/is settling in here at Stockholm. Their stories are pretty amazing.
The city is beautiful, Swedes/locals lead less stressful lives, welfare and happiness are never taken for granted.
Perhaps Singapore can learn more from them.If I do have some form of political/social power, I will attempt to change some things back home. Change, is the only constant.

I take the blue line, change to the green one in T-Centralen, and go down in Slussen. I glance through the windows of the galleries while walking through Hornsgatan. I was planning to watch the sunset from the viewpoint at Skinnarviksparken but the weather is not on my side and by the time I get there, dark clouds fill the horizon. I sit down on a bench to watch the snowflakes descend.
At five twenty, I go down and walk along the empty sidewalk next to the water. At some point, it stops snowing and I decide to continue my stroll to Gamla Stan, the old city in the center of Stockholm. The view of the Kungsholmen shore is gorgeous. It has been about a year and a half since the last time I passed through here. One gets too caught up in the routine and life goes by fast.
I continue walking to R√•dhuset to take the blue line back home. By the time I am halfway, the dense dark clouds completely erase the lights of the S√∂dermalm district. I can barely see the tower of the Stadhuset next to me. A blizzard covers the city on a white veil. My footprints don‚Äôt last more than a few seconds and I stop several times to clean the ice from my glasses.
I finally make it to the blue line and I am back in the warmth of my room a few minutes later. The snowstorm continues outside as if it was to last forever. I sit down in front of my desk and find refuge in the pages of my journal.
I like to write. I have been compiling journals for fifteen years. I write to put my thoughts into words and bring structure and clarity to my mind. I write to immortalize my memories, my beliefs, my stories. We are storytellers after all. We need stories to communicate, to give meaning to the world, and to make sense of our existence.
I leaf through the soft ivory paper of my journal and realize how the last months have been embedded into just a few pages. In contrast, when I go further back to my time as a traveler, several pages are needed to capture a single day of wander: the things I do, the places I visit, the colorful streets, and the different tastes and aromas of a new city, and the conversations I have with the people I meet. Paragraphs pile up and my hand write deteriorates as I rush to capture these experiences before they are altered or, even worse, forgotten by my fragile memory.
I look through the window as the ephemeral snow particles dance to the sound of the wind. I don‚Äôt want my days to go by helpless, at the mercy of the wind of life. I fear the moment I wake up and realize that decades have passed and I am still the same person.
I think about Memoirs of Hadrian, a novel by the Belgian writer Margarita Yourcenar. On his deathbed, Hadrian writes a letter to Marcus Aurelius, his future successor. The text recounts the wisdom the Roman Emperor has accumulated throughout different episodes of his life. Particularly, Hadrian declares that there are three ways to learn about human existence: through our own experience, through the experiences of others, and through books.
As a travel enthusiast, I cannot help but relate Margarita‚Äôs words to traveling.
By traveling, we leave behind our comfort and dive into the unknown. We expose ourselves to different environments and diverge from our beliefs, values, and prejudices. By traveling, we interact with the people we meet. We engage in conversations and dive into their stories. We learn to see the world through their eyes and add their experience to our own. By reading, we travel to different narratives. We learn from the stories of those who lived in distant times. We are entrusted with their stories to make them our own.
And yet all these perspectives remain incomplete. We see the world from the narrow lenses created by the conditioning our environment has provided. Even books carry the prejudices of the pen. Nevertheless, a rich life is born out of the combination of these incomplete stories.
Life is about feeding our stories through new experiences, rich conversations, and good books that change our narratives. To lead a life that cannot be reduced to just a few pages.
--

Title: Discovering Stockholm: A Charming Nordic Gem
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Stockholm, Sweden‚Ä¶.A few weeks ago I hopped aboard a plane and headed to Sweden for the weekend. The truth is that Sweden has never been high on my wish list radar, as a destination, so I just have been skipping it year after year. However, living in Poland, Sweden has a huge advantage as a holiday destination. It is located so close to my homeland that it is easy to visit. I only need to cross the Baltic Sea and I‚Äôm there. The plane tickets to Sweden are usually bloody cheap ‚Ä¶ if only the weather there could be better.
Weather is always a strange thing. Every time I visit the Polish coast and look North, it seems that Sweden has better weather, as there are usually no clouds on the horizon. But the reality is far different. The weather in Sweden is cold and windy most of the year, except in summer. I didn‚Äôt want the Scandinavian weather to deceive me as I booked my ticket. I hoped that the sun would have mercy on me and would appear in Sweden during my stay. Sure enough, the weather had its way! I left sunny Poland and landed in quite a cloudy Sweden. During my stay, the sun tried to defeat the clouds but failed. My consolation was that it did not rain.
My motto is ‚Äúlike the places to which you travel and appreciate that you can visit them, no matter what‚Äù. Seems to me, as a traveller, that we should want to go everywhere and find something interesting anywhere. Consequently, I always try to see the best in each country I visit. Before going to Scandinavia my number one wish, while there was to experience the fjords! But that‚Äôs in Norway. Thinking which Scandinavian city would be my number one choice, I had a feeling it would be Stockholm. Now, after returning home, I can confirm 100%, that to me, Stockholm is absolutely the number one city in Scandinavia.
Nordic cities in my opinion are hit or miss. You love or hate them. They don‚Äôt have many landmarks, are very expensive and at first glance, they look just boring. Nordic cities such as Oslo, Helsinki, Copenhagen, Stockholm, and Reykjav√≠k share one thing in common. They are coastal cities. I usually love cities bordering on a body of water, as a relationship with water adds a whole new dimension to city life ‚Ä¶ and Stockholm has lots of water!
People say that Stockholm is the Venice of the North. The city is spread out over 14 islands, that are connected by 57 bridges, with an eye towards my beloved Baltic Sea to the East. There‚Äôs something incredibly soothing about almost always having water in sight and that makes Stockholm a nice destination to explore on foot. It is pleasant to stroll when you are never more than a stone‚Äôs throw away from the water. There‚Äôs so much water everywhere that sometimes it seems like there‚Äôs more water than land. Hence, it may seem that there are more boats than cars, in the city. They are moored to the shore and sway on the gentle waves.
But such a picturesque location has also cons. A few times I found it slightly annoying to not be able to get somewhere, located just a few meters away from me, just because there was no bridge exactly where I needed it, and I had to walk around a channel, that made the way much longer.
All in all, I think that water is what makes Stockholm charming. It makes the air feel fresher and clearer. Waterworks for Stockholm especially when the day gives way to the evening. Sunset in Stockholm is a magical time. It is so nice to be near the water when the sun is setting and see Stockholm in its magic hour.
The second thing that struck me the most about the city was the colour. Everywhere, from the gems of the Old Town to more modern architecture, colour seems to be present on every surface. I think that the colours are Stockholm‚Äôs heaviest weapon against gloomy and cloudy weather. There is no logic or scheme to the colours of buildings, as they would have never been treated as a wholeness, but as individuals.
It‚Äôs more expensive than Paris and London, but it‚Äôs not as expensive as people expect. I spent most of my money on food. I‚Äôm glad that I had a hotel breakfast at the price of my room because going out for a meal more often than once a day would have ruined my budget.
The silence in Stockholm really hits you when you arrive. The cars seem to move in a silent mode and there is almost a hushed feeling everywhere.
Sweden‚Äôs capital city is a 700-year-old European city. It attracts many visitors each year looking to experience Sweden‚Äôs largest city, however, there were fewer tourists than I expected. Thanks to that Stockholm has a very relaxed feel. There are not many people on the streets and sometimes it seemed to me, that I had Stockholm, just to myself.
The city has an atmosphere that is very calm compared to other European capitals. Perhaps it is the people living here. Most Swedes seem patient and quiet. Maybe it‚Äôs because there are so many open spaces and of course water. Maybe it is because of the history felt in the air. Or maybe because the buildings are so colourful and in some way, they force you to stop and stare at them. Maybe it‚Äôs all of this put together‚Ä¶..

Title: Stockholm, Copenhagen, Berlin, Amsterdam : Our trip and how we did it
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I just got back from my two-week trip across most of Northern Europe. This is my third trip back to Europe. (My first was a summer abroad in Italy nearly 8 years ago and my second was another two-week trip in 2014 where we explored Dublin, London, Amsterdam, and Paris.) I daresay this was the best so far! Thom and I visited Stockholm, Copenhagen, Berlin, and again, Amsterdam this time around. In order to share our experience and to create a living record of its details, I‚Äôve decided to write across a few posts on each city and its adventures. This first post serves to detail our overall travel plans, information on flights/places to stay, tips on light packing, and general advice for good travel. I should mention that I‚Äôm not an expert on any other these things but it‚Äôs worth sharing the little knowledge that I gained before, during, and after this trip.
To begin with, here are a few starting facts about our trip:
Let‚Äôs begin by discussing budget flights. Nine months before this vacation even happened I found some non-stop flights from Oakland to Stockholm for $600 a person. These flights kicked off the entire trip and made everything possible. I recall the very first time I ever flew to Europe. (Which was 8 years this summer!) It was to Genoa, Italy from Buffalo, NY. That flight had three stops (Buffalo to NYC, NYC to Frankfurt, and Frankfurt to Milan) and one train (Milan to Genoa) in order to get to my destination with a total of over 20+ hours at a hefty price of $1500. (Thanks Aer Lingus! üñï) So to come across a flight that was only 10 hours and non-stop to my choice destination, it felt like fate...
Doesn‚Äôt that last sentence feel so inspiring? Statements and facts like those are the gold and shiny wrapper on the cheap bar of travel chocolate. Here‚Äôs the nitty-gritty of budget flying:
With some of the add-ons and extra taxes, our $600 tickets actually came to $711.30 a person. Our in-between flights from city to city were around $50 a person. (As compared to a train from Berlin to Amsterdam which was $120 a ticket.) In the end, you have to deal with the minor annoyances for that üí∞deal.
Let‚Äôs move on to transportation.
Thom and I took public transit for the most part. (I‚Äôll discuss the bicycling and Uber rides a bit later in some of my city posts.) For us, it‚Äôs a fun challenge learning a new city‚Äôs public transit. And unlike American public transportation, European public transportation is fast, convenient, and very, VERY reliable. Upon arriving at the Arlanda Airport, which is located just outside of Stockholm, we took the Arlanda Express Train that runs directly to the city center in just 20 minutes. (As compared to my 1.5 hour MUNI and BART trip to Oakland International Airport. üòë) Out of the four cities we visited, Berlin boasted the fastest and most reliable transportation (dat German innovation) with Amsterdam coming in at a close second. (Trams, trams everywhere!) All the trams, trains, and buses that we took were clean and clearly marked. My only complaint was the summer heat which was especially felt in the enclosed and non-air conditioned trains.
I plan to discuss each Airbnb in detail for each city post but in general our decision to use this service came from a few points:
Finally, let‚Äôs talk about packing. Much like my last Europe trip, I took a single backpack and personal bag with me. That was it! Now that this trip is over, I can say, quite proudly, that it was the best decision that I made for packing. After each city we visited, Thom and I both got a little better at packing our bags. It was a very efficient way to travel, IMO.
Here are some pros:
I admit that there are some cons involved with this kind of packing. While I can pack a mean bag, it doesn‚Äôt exclude the fact that the weight gets to you‚Ä¶no matter how light. If you‚Äôve ever landed at an airport and took public transit into a city, the transfers mean a lot of walking between terminals and stations. The weight of the bag can cause a lot of stress on your neck and shoulders. Even this year, I packed a bag that weighed about 8 lbs total and after a while, say 20 minutes of walking, it can really push down on you. I should mention that my bag isn‚Äôt meant for hiking or true backpacking and therefore isn‚Äôt super ergonomic. I‚Äôm sure if I had chosen a small hiking backpack, my experience would be different. The bag that I took is just an everyday backpack for commuting which is why long walks with a lot of weight can easily become a small burden.
Backpacking can also force you to make some crucial decisions as to what you pack. One small error (should I bring a bathing suit?) and you‚Äôll be forced to carry that item throughout the entire trip with much resentment. The last time we were in Europe, it rained for most of the trip. Thom brought an umbrella this year. He never needed it! üòÇ üôÉ Lessons learned.
A few surprising things that we did bring this year are:
I‚Äôve only really traveled internationally in the summer months so packing has always been dictated by the warmer weather. I took mainly dresses with a single pair of jeans and shorts. A few shirts to mix it up and a hoodie with a jean jacket for cooler evenings/days. I took a pair of black flats since they‚Äôre so versatile and my Keds for comfort as I walked/biked everywhere. I kept toiletries to small sizes and bought anything else that might have run out.
Thom and I failed to exchange any currency prior to the trip. But I would recommend making that order with your bank if possible since ATMs abroad will charge you a fee for any withdrawals. Also, make the obligatory call to your bank letting them know that you are traveling abroad so that they don‚Äôt lock your card and account.
A kind co-worker provided us an extra SIM card and we had another already from past trips, so this year we both had data/service for our phones. Thankfully our SIM cards were both purchased in the Netherlands with Vodaphone. These cards worked in all the other countries we visited and we didn‚Äôt need to purchase new cards along the way.
Finally, I‚Äôll add that we obtained Global Entry prior to the trip. It made entering the US very easy and fast when going through customs. If you are a frequent international flyer, consider getting Global Entry. Global Entry includes TSA PreCheck. So if you fly around the country frequently (which I do), it‚Äôs very convenient and handy for jumping those long security lines.
This post is a part of a series based on my recent two-week trip to Europe.

3C for describing Stockholm: cold, cool, culture. Its historical background, architecture, fashion, style, traditional foods, and of course ABBA, all make it so cool! It can be also called ‚ÄòNorth Venice‚Äô because of the 14 islands.
We went to Stockholm by Flixbus departed from Copenhagen. It was night and long ride, besides I spent the night awake because of my flu and I really terrified about the journey. The road was empty without lightning‚Ä¶ Also, our bus was moving fast. Uh, terrifying‚Ä¶
We started the city tour with Riddarholmen Church which has a thousand years of history.
We sat on the benches around the church, watching Stockholm architecture.
We watched the iconic S√∂dermalm view. Like a postcard‚Ä¶
Gamla Stan: best for the time traveling‚Ä¶
Narrow streets, yellow colors, cinnamon smells‚Ä¶ It makes me feel like I am in a different zone.
Me and my friend exploring the city by walking, climbing hills and from the beginning of the city tour, we constantly arguing about which city is better‚Ä¶ Copenhagen or Stockholm? We are counting the pros and cons. However, it is an inconclusive debate. After wandering around the Gamla Stan‚Äôs old streets, another debate‚Ä¶ Does it look like Florence? Then, we are sitting on a bench watching the Baltic Sea, talking about how can we do more efficient things, and be successful in our aims. I guess, this is Stockholm energy. Not syndrome‚Ä¶ but this city has effects on people.
I ticked eating Swedish Meatballs in Sweden and going to Ikea in Sweden off on the bucket list. It was the first time I‚Äôve eaten meatballs with sweet lingonberry jam (it was great). I also had Kladdkaka, Kanelbulle and irrelevantly, fortune cookies. All of them were delicious‚Ä¶
We passed through the √òresund Bridge which is so impressive, like diving into the middle of the sea. We are surrounded by only blue: sea and sky. Furthermore thanks to our Flixbus Driver, he was playing the Swedish Eurovision song: Loreen ‚Äî Tatto. It was pretty unforgettable for me since I listened to this song hundreds of times and never thought I would be listening to this in the main country. (I know the photo is not very good, but I recorded videos and enjoyed the moment.)
Overall
Stockholm is so suitable for a student budget. I was expecting extreme prices, but I was wrong. Especially the souvenirs‚Äô and Ikea‚Äôs food prices were acceptable. I want to visit Stockholm again with a rich budget and at that time I must stay at least 3 nights, attend to Stockholm Ghost Walk and Historical Tour, go to the Skansen Open Air Museum and ABBA Museum, appreciate subway art, go to Birka the Viking city, having Fika in a warm, cozy place with enjoying the Northern snow.
Regards, Ozlem.

Content:

Follow publication

Listen

by Josefine Hedlund
To be honest, I wasn‚Äôt too pleased when I saw the temperature in Stockholm was going to be -5 degrees celsius. But I‚Äôm not one to turn down an opportunity to experience different cultures and meet new people. The view from the plane window pretty much confirmed that I was in for a cold couple of days. Sweden from the sky was pretty much blanketed in snow, with forests, motorways and buildings adding speckles of colour to the pure white landscape. Stockholm‚Äôs temperature was as expected ‚Äî FREEZING ‚Äî but admiring the beautiful architecture as we walked to the office made me temporarily forget this fact.
One of the great things about using Slack at Manifest is how it renders borders immaterial. It‚Äôs not perfect and working in different time zones does present its challenges, but being able to meet up with a colleague in a different country and pick-up where you left off on Slack is a great plus.
We like to believe everything is better in Sweden, and while that‚Äôs mostly true (I say mostly because the weather ain‚Äôt better) I have to say, the coffee machine at our Stockholm office is straight out of Star Trek. To hell with cafetieres and capsules, this baby uses an iPad touchscreen to brew you some of the best tasting Americanos I‚Äôve ever had. We need to figure out a way to set one up in London too. It might even make me do a tea round‚Ä¶.once or twice.
Our short time in Stockholm was spent darting from meeting to meeting. We had a couple of new business meetings interspersed with meeting existing clients. I‚Äôve got to say, the half day we spent with Houdini was probably the most inspired I‚Äôve been in my five years at Manifest. It‚Äôs not often you sit in a room where everyone is extremely passionate about what they do and where they want their company to go. I‚Äôm proud to be working with such a visionary brand, and you can bet you‚Äôll hear a lot more from them in the coming months.
I cannot write a blog about Sweden without mentioning delicious Swedish meatballs and aquavit. Aquavit (literal meaning: water of life) is an important part of Scandinavian drinking culture. We were treated to a Swedish folk song by Anna and Josefine before downing a shot of the drink. Much to the surprise of the Swedes, Alex and myself did not seem at all perturbed by the 37% ABV beverage. We both have strong constitutions, and attempting to drink us under the table is never wise.
After meetings were done, I had the opportunity to explore more of Stockholm over the weekend- it‚Äôs truly a stunning city, one I hope to be visiting often‚Ä¶ during warmer months.
Manifest has offices in Stockholm, London and New York and we‚Äôre recruiting. So, if you fancy joining our international family check out our careers page.

Restaurants:Swedish food

Choose Uber over cabs when in the city (seriously might be faster to take a scooter though üôÉ). If you must use a cab only use these companies: Taxi Stockholm 150000, Taxi Kurir, Sverigetaxi. Title: Designing with AI: Reflections from a Night with Miro‚Äôs CEO in Stockholm
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
On Tuesday, 24th of June I attended an intimate fireside chat in Stockholm with Miro CEO Andrey Khusid, alongside Armin Catovic (Head of AI at Aloi and Vice Chair at Stockholm AI) and Elena Verna, Head of Growth at Lovable. Andre spoke about creativity, product leadership, and what it means to build with purpose in the age of AI. This blog is my attempt to capture that moment: for myself, for other designers navigating similar questions, and for anyone trying to make sense of where we‚Äôre all headed next.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a dance. A dance between humans and AI.‚Äù
I liked how Andrey used the word dance and not collaborators. It blew my mind when Andrey introduced the new AI features of Miro and introduced this concept of Canvas as a prompt.
‚ÄúSome of us think in text. Some think in tables. Some in images. Some in handwriting. AI can translate between all these formats.‚Äù
It made me reflect on my own process. How often do I get stuck on one way of seeing things ‚Äî one visual, one narrative, one iteration. This new dance invites us to explore the edges, to try ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù scenarios we might not have considered. That‚Äôs not just productivity. That‚Äôs power. It‚Äôs not about outsourcing creativity. It‚Äôs about augmenting our intuition with speed, synthesis, and scale. And maybe, just maybe, creating space for more meaningful work.
This night wasn‚Äôt just about Miro. It was about the larger wave of transformation pulsing through the city, and one of the clearest signals of that was from Lovable. It was exciting to hear from Elena Verna about how Lovable as an entire company is AI-first, not just the product, but the tooling, workflows, culture, and even mindset.
They recently ran a weekend hackathon where anyone could use Lovable‚Äôs tools to build with three major LLMs. More than 2.5 million people created something just in a weekend. It was a strong message to startup founders to scale to the top. And simply, people are looking for a simple and easy product when it comes to digital experiences. Lovable is simple and people love it.
And perhaps that‚Äôs what makes Stockholm special right now: it‚Äôs not just building tools; it‚Äôs building momentum. Hmm, what a great time to be here at the center of tech innovation!
When I was working on the book Catch the Feeling, we discussed a lot about ‚Äòsameness‚Äô. With AI-generated content, there is a general play of sameness in designs, products and content that is out. With this thought in mind, we had a question from the room,
What happens when everyone uses the same tools, the same AI models, the same prompts? Will we all just end up building the same thing?
Andrey replied,
‚ÄúWhat makes the difference, is human empathy, point of view, and taste.‚Äù
It can accelerate your process, suggest alternatives, and synthesize patterns, but if you don‚Äôt show up with a strong perspective, it‚Äôll just give you more of what everyone else is getting. In a world of infinite output, originality comes from the courage to have a point of view. Being human!
My friend Jaydatta is doing his Master's Thesis about decision making in Swedish startups. We were having a brief discussion about his findings and how actors and factors influence a major decision in a product. Later in the evening, MIRO CEO touched on his decision-making and leadership style.
‚ÄúI was scared of adding complexity. I didn‚Äôt want to overwhelm the user.‚Äù
His vision in 2011 was to build the first browser-based whiteboard, and he kept the product as simple as possible. Andre shared how his leadership style had shifted over the years.
From top-down decision-making in the early days, to bottom-up ownership where teams shaped features based on user needs. He held back a key feature, not because they couldn‚Äôt build it, but because he believed simplicity was more important. But when the pandemic hit and MIRO was used heavily, he made a drastic shift, focusing on synchronous collaboration.
And now, as Miro matures again, they‚Äôre returning to a model where teams can own and shape their areas. But what stays constant, Andre said, is the need for a strong product vision, otherwise, you end up with 25 products inside one. This was a really powerful insight.
There was a question about what are the emerging skills and the right mindset to survive in a transitioning face in tech.
‚ÄúThe companies that thrive will be full of T-shaped people. Those who go deep in one craft, but also know how to connect the dots across disciplines and prompt machines to get the job done.‚Äù
That means being a designer who understands marketing. An engineer who thinks in UX. A PM who can sketch a landing page, run a prompt, and launch it in hours. And increasingly, these people won‚Äôt be full-time hires. They‚Äôll be fractional experts, brought in for short bursts of high-impact work.
Lovable is already ahead of this curve. With under 50 full-time roles and revenue approaching $100 million, they‚Äôre proving what‚Äôs possible when AI augments the builders and everyone is trusted to own more.
Andre even predicted something that caught the room off guard: ‚ÄúCompensation will look different. In a few years, the same job title could pay 5x more to the person who brings exponential impact.‚Äù
Not because of tenure. But because they know how to leverage tools, think across domains, and ship value fast. The more impact you create in the company, the more compensation!
With big giants in the picture, someone asked a question,
‚ÄúWhat if OpenAI builds your product tomorrow and destroys your business?‚Äù
Andre simply smiled and said something that brought a lot of hope and smiles in the room.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not building because we think OpenAI won‚Äôt do it. We‚Äôre building because we love what we do.‚Äù
A truth that often gets lost in metrics, frameworks, and the pressure to always be future-proof. It reminded me that the joy of creation doesn‚Äôt disappear just because the landscape changes.
‚ÄúWe might all be a little f**ked,‚Äù Andre joked, ‚Äúbut we‚Äôre in it together. And we‚Äôre still building.‚Äù And that, to me, is what this night in Stockholm was about.
Hope it inspired you too, dear reader. Connect with me on LinkedIn to follow my journey.

Title: The Incredible story of the Vasa and the lessons it teaches us
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
On 10th August, 1628, the Swedish navy launched the maiden voyage of the Vasa .The Vasa was part of the military expansion and an expression of Swedish naval power: It was explicitly built at the order of the King of Sweden Gustavus Adolphus, and was richly decorated to show off Swedish might and wealth. No expense was spared. One of the rooms was made to look like the royal palace. There were numerous Roman statues on board, ‚Äî King Adolphus was sending a message that ‚Äòhey, Sweden is the modern Roman empire‚Äô. Upon completion, it was one of the most powerful armed vessels in the world.
August 10 was a calm day, perfect for a launch, with a light breeze from the southwest. It passed the Royal palace, and the gun ports were opened for a Royal salute. When doing so, a gust of wind -nothing crazy ‚Äî filled its sails and it heeled to the port. It passed some bluffs to the south (S√∂dermalm, for those familiar with the geography). A little later, at Tegelviken, a stronger gust caused it to again heel to the port side ‚Äî and went past the point beyond which the ship could right itself. The gun ports were open because 1300 meters past its launch, the Vasa sank, and about 30 people died (it included women and children as well, since it was a ceremonial trip around the harbor). It took all of 5 minutes to sink, and a major reason was the lower gun ports were open and water poured in as it heeled. But more on this later.
The Vasa lay on the bottom of the Stockholm harbor for 333 years, before it was successfully raised and the Vasa museum captures its stunning story of mismanagement, in a fashion eerily similar to mismanagement as seen in some modern software companies. I was lucky enough to have a tour through this museum while on a work trip to Stockholm. I would visit Stockholm again just to go back to the museum (though Stockholm has so much to see and do)
The Vasa‚Äôs story serves as a powerful metaphor for modern software companies, particularly in how organizational dynamics can lead to technical disaster. Just as Vasa‚Äôs builders continued with a fundamentally flawed design due to royal pressure, software teams sometimes proceed with architectures or technical decisions they know are problematic due to executive mandates or market pressures. The tragic part of Vasa‚Äôs story is that it was known that it was unlikely to survive its launch. In 1628, the captain arranged for the Vice Admiral to demonstrate its stability. 30 men ran back and forth across the upper deck, and the ship started to roll. The Admiral stopped the test because he was afraid the ship would capsize in the harbor. Does this sound familiar to anyone?
Consider how often we see software projects that are ‚Äútoo big to fail‚Äù ‚Äî platforms or products that have had so much investment and executive attention that stopping to address fundamental issues becomes politically impossible. Like the Vasa‚Äôs gun ports being open for a royal salute (a political requirement) directly contributing to its sinking, we often see technical compromises made for business optics that ultimately undermine the product‚Äôs stability.
The parallel extends to modern engineering organizations where technical experts ‚Äî much like the shipbuilders of the Vasa ‚Äî might recognize fundamental flaws but feel unable to effectively raise these concerns up the chain of command. In both cases, the culture of deference to authority and the pressure to deliver can override technical wisdom. Today‚Äôs ‚Äúroyal demands‚Äù might come in the form of arbitrary deadlines, feature requirements that compromise system stability, or architectural decisions made to align with executive presentations rather than engineering realities. There is a tendency to ‚Äòdrift to failure‚Äô in organizations that show up only when it blows up in their faces.
Most tellingly, just as the Vasa‚Äôs builders had proven experience with smaller ships but ran into trouble when scaling up to a larger, more complex vessel, software companies often face challenges when scaling from successful smaller systems to more complex platforms. The same principles that worked at a smaller scale can become catastrophic liabilities when applied without adaptation to larger, more complex systems.
This is a standard practice in product development (my writeup on it can be read here). Well, certainly at every place where I had influence over the process. It is entertaining to turn the 5 Why‚Äôs framework on the Vasa to get to root cause: King Adolphus was furious, of course, and the loss of his statement piece, and the loss of the many cannons that were on the Vasa (2 gun decks that can be seen in the photo above ‚Äî it had 64 cannons). There was a royal inquiry, and no one was found guilty ‚Äî it would be foolhardy ‚Äî deadly ‚Äî to point the finger at the king, who was responsible for the tragedy.
So what would the 5 Why‚Äôs for the Vasa look like?
The ship capsized and sank about 1,300 meters into its maiden voyage in Stockholm harbor on August 10, 1628. A light gust of wind caused it to heel (tilt) severely to port. Water rushed through the open gun ports, which were only 1.2 meters above the waterline, flooding the ship and causing it to sink within minutes.
The Vasa was dangerously unstable due to its top-heavy design. The ship carried 64 heavy bronze cannons, mostly on the upper gun deck. More critically, the ship‚Äôs ballast (72 tonnes) was insufficient to counterbalance the weight of the upper structure, guns, and heavy decorative sculptures. Stability tests before launch showed the ship was dangerously unstable ‚Äî it heeled severely when just 30 men ran from side to side.
Despite shipbuilder Jakobsson noting the stability problems during construction, and despite a stability test where the ship dangerously heeled, no significant changes were made. Admiral Fleming, who oversaw the test, feared reporting the full extent of the problems to the king. The shipbuilders and naval officers knew of the issues but proceeded with the launch anyway.
In Swedish society under King Adolphus, challenging royal authority was unthinkable. (Note: This is of course not particular to Swedish culture). The king had personally ordered multiple changes during construction, including the second gun deck and additional heavy bronze cannons. He was deeply involved in the design, viewing the Vasa as a symbol of Swedish naval power. No one, including the shipwright, dared question the kings demands.
Sweden in the 1620s operated under absolute monarchy where the king‚Äôs word was literally law. King Adolphus had transformed Sweden into a major military power, leading successful campaigns in the Thirty Years‚Äô War. The hierarchical culture of 17th-century Sweden, combined with the king‚Äôs reputation as a militant leader, created an environment where professional expertise was subordinate to royal authority. There was no cultural framework for ‚Äúspeaking truth to power‚Äù ‚Äî the concept itself would have been alien to most 17th-century Swedes.
The fundamental issue was a cultural environment that prioritized deference to authority over technical expertise and safety concerns. This cultural dynamic made it impossible for technical experts to effectively challenge decisions that compromised the ship‚Äôs safety, even when they recognized the dangers.
The tragic irony is that Adolphus, despite his direct involvement in the ship‚Äôs design changes, never saw the Vasa ‚Äî he was away on campaign in Poland when it sank. The culture of absolute deference to royal authority operated even in his absence, preventing necessary corrections to a fatally flawed design.
Well, that is the Vasa. And we have many modern day examples. I‚Äôd love to hear about your experiences!

Title: Stockholm Through My Eyes: Another Journey Begins
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Stockholm. A city I had heard of since childhood.
I associated its name with major international agreements, particularly the Stockholm Declaration of 1972 ‚Äî the very first large-scale world conference to make the environment as a major global issue. It marked the beginning of international environmental governance and laid the foundation for what would later become the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). This conference shaped the world‚Äôs approach to sustainability and climate action, yet I never imagined that one day, I would walk its very streets where such historic discussions took place.
Never in my wildest dreams did I think I would experience this city firsthand. It still feels surreal that I am here.
What struck me the most when I arrived was the contrast ‚Äî the weather, the atmosphere, the way of life. Coming from Indonesia, where temperatures soar to 35¬∞C with high humidity, adjusting to Stockholm‚Äôs crisp air and freezing winters was a challenge. Even in summer, I find myself trembling while Swedes enjoy the sunshine in shorts and tank tops. The shift from tropical heat to below-zero temperatures was an entirely new physical adjustments and rhythm of life.
But despite the cold, I fell in love with this city. There is a sense of calm, an unspoken rhythm that blends modernity with nature. Stockholm moves at its own pace ‚Äî not too fast, not too slow.
And then, there‚Äôs Fika ‚Äî the Swedish tradition of taking a break over coffee and pastries. At first, I thought it was just a casual coffee break, but I soon realized it‚Äôs much more than that. It‚Äôs a moment of pause, of connection, of simply being present. In a world that constantly pushes us to be productive, Fika is a reminder that it‚Äôs okay to slow down. This ties into something else I admire about Sweden ‚Äî their emphasis on work-life balance. Here, taking a break is not seen as laziness but as an essential part of life. People respect their time off, and there is an understanding that rest is just as important as work.
The other thing that fascinated me was the language. The moment I heard Swedes casually chatting in their melodic Swedish, I felt a strange excitement. It was unfamiliar yet intriguing.
But, beyond the language, what truly inspires me about Sweden is its commitment to sustainability. Swedes don‚Äôt just talk about being environmentally friendly; they integrate it into their daily lives. Recycling, efficient public transport, and waste reduction are not just trends but ingrained habits. It‚Äôs no surprise that the world‚Äôs first environmental conference was held in Stockholm in 1972, leading to the establishment of the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP).
One of the biggest realizations I had was about landfills. My perspective on landfills was shaped by what I had seen in Indonesia, where waste management remains a major challenge. Landfills there often emit a strong odor, appear overwhelming, and lack proper handling. But here, it feels different ‚Äî the landfill doesn‚Äôt smell as strong, the area is well-managed, and waste is systematically processed.
I also learned a lot about organic waste. If we truly want to combat climate change, organic waste should never end up in landfills. Food waste releases methane, a greenhouse gas many times more potent than carbon dioxide. This realization made me see how small actions ‚Äî like composting or waste sorting ‚Äî suddenly felt much more significant.
Living in Stockholm has made me reflect on many things. It has challenged my habits, reshaped my mindset, and broadened my perspective. I‚Äôve learned to embrace silence and to enjoy solitude without feeling lonely. I‚Äôve come to appreciate the power of simplicity ‚Äî how less can be more and how slowing down can actually bring more meaning.
Nonetheless, this is just the beginning of my journey in Stockholm.
‚Äî Fingers crossed for what the future has in store! ‚ù§
--
--
A wonderer and wanderer, exploring life and sustainability in Stockholm.

Report of the Go Global Mission to Stockholm (25 - 28 October 2017)
As an entrepreneur, it is important to broaden your perspectives and keep an eye out on the world, even more so in this digital world we live and work in every day. Hence, I was very excited to join the Go Global Mission to Stockholm, an organization of startups.be and Jong VOKA Oost-Vlaanderen.
Sweden has been an inspiration for me ever since I became involved with technology and startups. The country has an impressive track record: after Silicon Valley, Sweden has the highest number of unicorns per head of population in the world. Iconic companies like Skype (sold to Microsoft), King (the maker of Candy Crush, IPO), Mojang (the company behind Minecraft, sold to Microsoft) and Spotify (you know Spotify), have all been founded in this Nordic country.
How is this possible? What are the reasons behind Sweden‚Äôs overwhelming success? Is this story future proof? 3 days in the country‚Äôs lovely capital Stockholm would provide all the answers.
A 2 hour flight from Brussels led us to Bromma, a cozy airport about 20 minutes from downtown Stockholm. Hard to imagine this is the main entrance to a European capital where so much value has been created over the past decade.
First stop on our trip was the Stockholm Fintech Hub, a huge co-working space located conveniently above Stockholm‚Äôs central train station. Besides the fancy decoration, I noticed a couple of interesting things here:
Off to a good start!
Our visit to Invest Stockholm gave us a lot of insights on the success of Stockholm. The seeds of the Swedish tech boom were planted in the 90s, when the government subsidized the required infrastructure for the digital age.
First, every household in Sweden was granted a personal computer. Every successful tech entrepreneur of today grew up with a PC! Digital natives avant la lettre.
Second, almost every household in Sweden has fiber internet access. Hard to imagine in Belgium, where to this day the public and private sector are still arguing who is going to make the required investments.
It is clear that government initiatives in the nineties have laid the foundations for the incredible success of the past decade.
The impact of these exits cannot be underestimated. As often happens with successful entrepreneurs, they do not rest on their laurels. After selling Skype, Niklas Zennstr√∂m went on to found Atomico, now one of the most famous venture capital firms in Europe. Same goes for the founders of King with their fund Sweet Capital.
As a result, there is plenty of capital available to invest in promising startups that might become the unicorns of the coming decade. Success often creates even more success. The future of the Swedish tech ecosystem seems bright.
Some (fun) facts about Sweden:
Day 2 started with the highlight of our trip: a visit to Spotify. The music streaming service has over 50 million paying subscribers and is valued at 16 Bio USD in the private markets. Even though it is still making a loss, it is reportedly preparing its long-awaited IPO for somewhere mid 2018.
Spotify is one of those iconic tech companies of this age. The company, led by the enigmatic founder Daniel Ek, has proven to be an exceptional innovator on multiple levels:
1) Business model innovation: in the wake of illegal P2P networks like Napster and Kazaa, Spotify sought to find a legitimate way to revolutionize the music industry.
2) Technical innovation: the secret sauce to Spotify‚Äôs early success was the incredibly fast loading of songs. This was an engineering challenge of enormous size and difficulty. The majority of people at Spotify are still deep tech engineers working to make sure load times stay at this amazing level, even at such a huge scale.
3) Organizational innovation: much has been written and said about Spotify‚Äôs organizational model. The concepts of autonomous teams (grouped in squads, tribes & alliances), the agile way of working, the flat organization, ‚Ä¶ have been widely documented and copied by other tech startups. Many attribute the success of Spotify to this special culture of continuous experimentation and improvement, cultivated by the founders from day 1.
It will be very interesting to see what happens to this culture when Spotify goes public. Not making a profit yet, investor pressure might force it to tighten reigns and start cutting costs.
Later, we paid a visit to Detectify, whose founder notoriously hacked Google and got access to a huge amount of customer data. He received a bounty of 10.000 USD and went on to start a successful company in ethical hacking.
I arrived at the hotel at around 10 pm. Having some energy left in the tank, I put on my running shoes. I really enjoy jogging in big cities. Since there is always something new to discover, you hardly notice you are running after a while.
I ran to the Gamla Stan island where I accidentally bumped into the changing of the guards routine at the royal palace. Quite hilarious and way over the top if you ask me!
This run wasn‚Äôt only for sightseeing, though. Last week, I decided I am going to run my first marathon in 2018! There you go, the word is out, no coming back to it now. I couldn‚Äôt really miss the second training on my schedule, right‚Ä¶
Day 3 started at Klarna, another Swedish unicorn, active in online payment processing. A couple of years ago, it also received a banking license. We got a presentation about the major branding exercise this company had undertaken earlier this year. The result was fascinating: from a dull banking brand to an extravagant colorful identity. Klarna wants to be a bank focused on the consumer‚Äôs experience, not on its own payments product. It definitely stands out in its sector with this bold and brave move I can only applaud.
Next stop was the Goodbye Kansas Gaming Studio. Stockholm has an enormous amount of talented gaming engineers, resulting in big hits like Minecraft, Candy Crush Saga, Angry Birds 2 and a host of other console and PC titles. We were told the long dark nights might have something to do with this.
Final stop was at EQT Ventures, one of the top tier venture firms in the Nordics. EQT Ventures is owned by Sweden‚Äôs wealthiest family, the Wallenbergs. Over the past century (!), the Wallenbergs have accumulated an enormous portfolio of global industrial players, including Electrolux, Atlas Copco, ABB, SEB, SKF, ‚Ä¶ to name a few. Add Volvo, Scania and IKEA to the Sweden‚Äôs list and you get a sense of how many successful international corporations this country produces. Same goes for its music industry: ABBA, Roxette, Ace of Base, Europe ‚Ä¶ and more recently Avicii, Robyn, Swedish House Mafia. Due to the small internal market, anyone aspiring a big entrepreneurial or artistic career just has to move abroad as soon as possible.
EQT Ventures is the venture capital firm of the Wallenberg conglomerate. Besides funding (with its 565 Mio EUR investment vehicle), it also offers active guidance to its entrepreneurs (growth, engineering, marketing,‚Ä¶).
EQT Ventures invests in scale-ups that have reached product market fit and about 100k MRR. It sweet spot investment size is between 8 and 10 Million EUR.
EQT gave us a demo of their internal data processing tool called Motherbrain. This platform gathers all publicly available data on technology companies (e.g. Crunchbase, Pitchbook data,..) and enriches them by adding trends in social media activity, number of followers, press coverage, ‚Ä¶ EQT believes this gives them a competitive advantage in discovering promising startups earlier and getting into deals faster.
4 startups had the opportunity to present their company:
The trip ended with a nice dinner in the city center of Sweden‚Äôs lovely capital.
My key takeaways from this Go Global Mission to Stockholm:
Looking forward to getting back into the action at Hyperlane on Monday, fully energized and inspired by 3 awesome days.
--
--
CEO & Co-Founder @ Hyperlane - Triathlete

Title: From Stockholm to Sinai: Jewish Conscience in an Age of Fear
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
