Title: A Short Rant About Our Collective Stockholm Syndrome for Snacks
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Every school day, I send my kids into a building where other people take on a role in loco parentis, meaning in place of a parent. In many ways, this is a wonderful oppotrunity for them. In others, it‚Äôs kind of like sending them to that ex-spouse whose views vary so widely from yours that it‚Äôs a wonder your kids haven‚Äôt fallen into a chasm of confusion yet.
This particular rant is about the chasm of differences between our heroic attempts at engaging in good nutrition at home v. the notorious, the storied, the hallmarked‚Ä¶.SCHOOL LUNCH.
Yes, the ominous school lunch has received its due reputation over the years ‚Äî often appearing in more than just a cameo in our favorite coming-of-age TV and movies, rued for its terrible taste and dubious ingredients. It even became the star of one of the best comedic outputs from Adam Sandler and Chris Farley (say it with me: sloppy, sloppy Joe).
But it‚Äôs not just the taste or the ingredients that I feel urged to rant about today. It is the two-strike punch that is its lack-luster nutritional value plus my utter lack of control over it.
What caused this most recent bout of rage, you might ask? A simple review of our school‚Äôs menu of the day, in order to help my kids decide whether to bring home lunch or school lunch. And what did I find upon venturing into that dark¬†abyss?
Our school district feeds our kids ‚Äúentrees‚Äù of ‚Äî I kid you not ‚Äî cinnamon rolls. And these are served with a side ‚Äúvegetable‚Äù of ‚Äî no, really ‚Äî tater tots.
This is not a joke.
Then they talk to my kids about the dangers of peer pressure on forming unhealthy habits‚Ä¶
The object lesson comes when my kid brings their broccoli and chicken to school and watches all ten of their friends eat cinnamon rolls next to them, so then they have broccoli, chicken, and cinnamon rolls (which, who wouldn‚Äôt?).
I have no idea who came up with the meal plan, who put it into writing, who reviewed it, who approved it. I do understand that there are limitations that those persons are working with, including systematic problems and budgetary issues. I also think they were either uninformed or wholly uncreative, un-adaptive, and unresourceful. Or, they also make bad choices for themselves and don‚Äôt want to admit it, so they just perpetuate the problems. Now I shall venture into the swamp of that latter estimation:
A few days ago, I came across a social media post (not exactly reality, I know) pleading with folks in a Type One Diabetes group to ‚Äúagree and acknowledge‚Äù that Type Two Diabetes is not caused by diet. Because I am a glutton for punishment, I went to the comments. I expected to see at least some folks kindly or courteously disagreeing, (because this particular group is generally kind and courteous) but‚Ä¶I didn‚Äôt. Instead, I saw a whole lot of ‚Äúyeah, it‚Äôs a complex issue,‚Äù or ‚Äúyeah, it‚Äôs unclear‚Äù nonsense. Why are we telling ourselves this story (at least online)?
Our insulin sensitivity becomes less sensitive due to overuse, and how do we cause overuse? Um, by overusing it‚Ä¶e.g., by feeding it lots of things that require insulin (cue cinnamon rolls and tater tots).
I‚Äôm getting pretty sick of people in our culture trying to excuse away suboptimal choices because they feel bad about themselves for making those choices. The truth is this: will power is hard (especially at first) and much harder when it also involves counter-culture, and right now, our culture is a punk kid with a green mohawk and leather coat who is not only dogging us, but whom our parents actually hired to watch us, so we can‚Äôt get away from him, and he‚Äôs constantly egging us on to do stupid shit in the form of terrible nutrition. We don‚Äôt have to lie to ourselves in order to cut ourselves slack about this.
But instead of saying ‚Äúthose donuts sitting feet away from me in the staff room, every single Monday, without fail, with their pink frosting and happy-go-lucky sprinkles, make it much more difficult for me to not eat them,‚Äù we tell ourselves this story instead: ‚Äúthose donuts in the staff room aren‚Äôt actually bad for me.‚Äù Both statements cut us some slack, but the first one is true and the second one is a lie.
And only the first one has the added benefit of reminding us that the culture around us is a problem, and that we could actually address it, at least little by little. The lie, on the other hand, just perpetuates the system that continues to peer pressure us into making choices that deteriorate the mid- and end-years of our lives.
So what to do about it. First, cut yourself slack in the form of actual truth. You are living in Foodcourtia, and that makes it very dificult to make good choices.
Second, don‚Äôt be the person who brings donuts, or who puts candy on your desk, or who brings mounds of shareable snacks to events (did you know the word ‚Äî the very idea ‚Äî of a ‚Äúsnack‚Äù was invented by the food industry in order to sell you more stuff? I shall refer you to Invader Zim for a lighthearted way to laugh about this). It‚Äôs unecessary to add to the problem. Do be that person who dares to bring single-ingredient foods, vegetables, protein, etc. to the world‚Äôs staff rooms, desks, and events instead.
Because, you, too, can be a punk kid with a mohawk peer pressuring the people around you.
‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî
If you liked or learned from this story, please clapüëè üëè üëè, highlight, share with anyone who‚Äôd enjoy it, and follow my page. Thanks for reading!

Title: Dwelling in the Anchored Topophilia of Stockholm
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
‚Äú Topophilia is the love of place, a deeply felt affective response to the environment. It is more than a preference; it is a visceral attachment to a locale that resonates with memory, identity, and aesthetic or cultural meaning.‚Äù ‚Äì Yi-Fu Tuan, Topophilia: A Study of Environmental Perception, Attitudes, and Values (1974)
The term Topophilia, coined by geographer Yi-Fu Tuan, refers to the emotional bonds between an individual and a certain place. When examined philosophically, Topophilia may be understood as more than emotional attachment; it becomes a lens through which existence is structured and understood. This essay develops a first-person philosophical reflection on my Topophilia, grounded in personal experience of Stockholm as a city whose atmospheric restraint and spatial quietude have reshaped my understanding of happiness, time, and selfhood. In the city where I have encountered what I refer to as Nordic Euphoria, which I define as, a sustained condition of existential balance and interior coherence, and not just a euphoric peak of sensory pleasure. My intention here is to articulate how specific geographies can participate in the formation of lived meanings, and how they function as existential orientation.
The notion of Topophilia is often reduced to sentimental longing or cultural nostalgia. Yet when viewed through the lens of existential philosophy and phenomenology, it appears as a far deeper relation. Hence, a mode of attunement between inner and outer worlds. In other words, the experience of being in a place may signal a deeper ontological fit, where the external rhythms of a landscape mirror or harmonize with one‚Äôs inner structure of feeling. In the context of Stockholm, this alignment revealed itself not through dramatic moments, but in a quiet and recurring realization of coherence. The slow unfolding of time, the softness of urban soundscapes, and the restraint in visual stimuli all contributed to a sense of interior deceleration. Time, in this place, did not push forward ‚Äì to me, it deepened. This temporal stillness allowed for a psychological settling, where being became less fractured and more whole.
The specific characteristics of Stockholm is in its Northern flavour, muted colors, and measured pace that engage the phenomenology of place in unique ways. These elements invite a form of presence that is not about stimulation but about stillness. This is not the absence of movement, but the presence of calm. Besides, the city‚Äôs space becomes an aesthetic and affective medium through which one experiences a non-anxious, grounded form of subjectivity. The condition of Nordic Euphoria is not commonly described in either philosophical literature or urban theory. It is neither hedonistic nor ecstatic. Rather, it is my sustained experience of equilibrium. It arises from the city‚Äôs spatial ethos; the silence of winter, the rhythmic calm of public spaces, and the sense of contemplative detachment embedded in the architecture itself. This spatial environment subtly constructs a psychological atmosphere in which self-conscious striving diminishes, and being-in-the-world becomes sufficient in itself.
In this context, Topophilia becomes more than a desire for familiarity or beauty. It is a structure of belonging that roots identity not in biography but in spatial resonance. Stockholm, in this reflection, becomes not a setting but a co-constitutive element of identity. The city‚Äôs stillness mirrors and shapes a form of joy that is not externalized, but interior. This mode of happiness resists conventional definitions not depending on progress or fulfillment, but on presence. It is the joy of walking without purpose, of looking without need to possess. In Stockholm, the relationship to space becomes one of trust, or a confidence in which no performance is needed to justify one‚Äôs being. In this trust, I found a form of happiness that I had never known before, and which I refer to as a form of ‚Äúexistential arrival‚Äù.
In essence, place is not a neutral backdrop to human experience, but it is often a silent participant in shaping who we become. When understood deeply, Topophilia is not about place alone but it is about the self-in-place, and about the transformation of subjectivity through spatial experience. The experience of Stockholm as examined here is not anecdotal but archetypal; it shows how space, when aligned with one‚Äôs existential rhythms, becomes a silent teacher of stillness, presence, and coherence. The eternal Topophilia to Stockholm is not nostalgia for a fixed past, nor fantasy of escape. Therefore, it is an ongoing, lived alignment between external geography and internal structure. Simply put, my Nordic Euphoria is not a memory but it is a way of being, where my sense of self ‚Äì no longer fragmented by acceleration or noise, finds rest in the fold of place.

Essayist | Poet | Humanist | Cultural Observer ‚Äî " I merge personal essays, philosophical musings & cultural commentaries with a keen eye for observation."

Title: Stockholm Syndrome: Lab Equipment Edition
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Every researcher has that one piece of lab equipment they‚Äôre irrationally attached to, the old centrifuge that rattles like a lawnmower, the cracked beaker they refuse to throw away, or the pipette that‚Äôs seen them through every late-night experiment.
For me, it‚Äôs a pipette. And if it could talk, it would probably file a complaint.
This is the story of a partnership that started with respect and careful handling‚Ä¶ and spiraled into something much more chaotic. A love-hate relationship built on duct tape, bad habits, and stubborn loyalty.
Back when I first got this pipette, it was love at first click. It fit perfectly in my hand ‚Äî sleek, shiny, ready to help me conquer experiments one microliter at a time.
‚ÄúAh, yes, the glory days,‚Äù my pipette would say now. ‚ÄúRemember when you used to respect me?‚Äù it would sigh. ‚ÄúYou used to calibrate me. Now you just pray.‚Äù
In those early days, I carried it around like a newborn. I placed it gently on foam pads, wiped it down after every assay, and whispered silent apologies if I accidentally tapped it too hard.
‚ÄúI did have feelings,‚Äù it would say. ‚ÄúNow I just have scratches and abandonment issues.‚Äù ‚ÄúYour pipetting technique is why my therapist says I have trust issues.‚Äù
But fast forward to year two of grad school. I‚Äôm tired. It‚Äôs tiring. We‚Äôre still pretending we‚Äôre fine.
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre one coffee spill away from dropping me again. I know it. And I‚Äôm not emotionally ready.‚Äù ‚ÄúNow you throw me around like I wronged you personally.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm in my third existential crisis this week ‚Äî and that‚Äôs just from your PCR setup.‚Äù
These days, I barely think before I grab it. I jam tips on like I‚Äôm trying to break a world record. Calibration? A distant memory. I tell myself I‚Äôll ‚Äúdefinitely do it tomorrow,‚Äù knowing surely that I won‚Äôt.
‚ÄúYou used to warm me up,‚Äù it grumbles. ‚ÄúNow you treat me like a glue stick with a grudge.‚Äù ‚ÄúPrecision? Sweetheart, I‚Äôm eyeballing volumes at this point.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a pipette anymore. I‚Äôm an emotional support stick.‚Äù
Sometimes, when my experiments fail and the pipette aspirates weirdly, I glare at it like it personally betrayed me.
‚ÄúYOU forgot to pre-wet the tip,‚Äù it would hiss. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt gaslight me.‚Äù
Maybe ‚Äî just maybe ‚Äî I‚Äôm the problem. ‚ÄúOh, you think?‚Äù the pipette snaps.
There are newer pipettes in the drawer. Calibrated. Smooth. Reliable. But I don‚Äôt reach for them. It‚Äôs always you, old friend.
‚ÄúStockholm syndrome. Look it up,‚Äù my pipette mutters, rolling its imaginary eyes.
At this point, we‚Äôre both hanging on by willpower, static electricity, and two pieces of lab tape.
‚ÄúYou think your data‚Äôs unreliable? Buddy, I‚Äôm running on trauma and duct tape,‚Äù it says, deadpan.
And yet, I can‚Äôt throw it away. We‚Äôve been through too much. It‚Äôs more than a pipette now, it‚Äôs part of my PhD trauma. ‚ÄúOne more semester,‚Äù it whispers. ‚ÄúThen I ghost you.‚Äù
Maybe science is also like life, it is about learning to love the broken things that still show up every day, even when they talk back.
--
--
Neuroscience PhD candidate @TAMU. First-gen grad student from India. Passionate science communicator making research inclusive, engaging & impactful.

Title: The Ersatz Elevator to Stockholm‚Äôs Snowy Skyline
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Stockholm‚Äôs skyline from S√∂dermalm is something special that ensnares your senses with the same sort of soft-spoken estranged quirkiness you‚Äôve seen in similar European cities or in the smaller surrounding suburbs encircling them. You know the kind of suburbs I mean. The ones where you end up celebrating the New Year because your long-distance girlfriend‚Äôs friends live in city-skirting cottages. The ones where you‚Äôre quickly forced to accept that the WiFi just isn‚Äôt gonna work so you connect to Baileys instead. The ones where people mostly don‚Äôt speak English and you finally file that three-day Duolingo streak you achieved in 2013 under ‚Äònon-functional‚Äô.
Also filed under ‚Äònon-functional‚Äô is the Katarina Elevator, the second thing to catch your eyes when you‚Äôre treading November puddles across the bridge into S√∂dermalm ‚Äî the first is an impromptu paste-up anti-Trump exhibition tied to the hashtag #PensForFreedom. When you‚Äôve had a sensible chuckle at The Donald redrawn as various memes and fascist figures, you hop on the free roaming data your phone plan has blessed you with, Google ‚Äòbridge elevator soda mall‚Äô, and tap ‚Äòdid you mean: bridge elevator s√∂dermalm‚Äô. You read that the local hard hats closed the lift in 2010 because it had rusted into a death trap. Sounds fun, you think.
Though the lift itself is closed, the span of bridge between its peak and the heights of S√∂dermalm is still open and littered with throngs of tourists as awkwardly monolingual as yourself, so you summit the substitute lift-shaft: a string of wooden steps zig-zagging from the lowly lock up to where the lookout kisses the cliff. Walking out into the elements, you instantly start to visualize all the photos you‚Äôre gonna take, and the double-tap-baiting hashtags to go with them. There are lengths of metal wiring above the hip-height barriers, so you grip your iPhone extra tight and slip it between the safety cables.
Why is there a large Coca Cola sign fastened to the fa√ßade of that building? It doesn‚Äôt look like a factory. If it is a factory, well, damn, cute factory. There‚Äôs a huge Heineken sign a few buildings over, too. It makes you want to go buy a pint, until you remember Stockholm booze prices. Either way, you‚Äôre gonna do some cool shit with the red and green of the signs when you edit these photos in Lightroom and VSCO later. Snap, snap, snap. Oh, and there‚Äôs the Stomatol sign you read about on Atlas Obscura. It‚Äôs the oldest animated sign in Sweden. It still lights up at night in the same way it has since 1909. It‚Äôs a tube of toothpaste.
You‚Äôve never been this excited by an animated illuminated tube of toothpaste.
Yellow and orange have always been your favorite colors. You‚Äôve convinced yourself it‚Äôs because they‚Äôre attention-grabbing shades which make people stop and look at your photos on Instagram, but deep down inside you know it‚Äôs because a few of your crushes have had the slightly manic pixie dream girl tendency to wear bright colors. Now it‚Äôs time to crush on some buildings, because the Stockholm city skyline you see from the bridge is a beautiful blend of fall hues. Why the endless layers of yellow and orange architecture? You‚Äôd Google it but your phone has died because the battery got too cold.
There‚Äôs something bothering you about a few of your cityscape photos, and you realize it‚Äôs a construction site in the corner. A jagged hole at the center of a crossroad bordered by a clashing blue tarp. You look out, and notice for the first time that the cityscape is dotted by a whole web of these pockmarks. It‚Äôs like taking a selfie and gradually counting all the spots on your face. People regurgitate the clich√© that living life through a camera or a screen stops you from seeing the beauty in the world, but if anything, it just helps you see the shitty stuff faster.
The dot-to-dot of building works reminds you of Berlin. That time your other long-distance girlfriend said the German capital‚Äôs like one big eternal construction project. That‚Äôs a cute and endearing observation, you think. It‚Äôs a shame you only saw Berlin from one of those open-top double-decker tour buses. Why did you do that? You‚Äôre better than that.
You made up for it, though, by completely eschewing public transport in Sweden. You and your travel companions walked everywhere. Heck, you didn‚Äôt even ride the funicular to the top of the open-air museum-zoo hybrid Skansen, and funiculars align perfectly with your love of ageing quirky technologies, Tom Scott videos, and not climbing hills. You even skip the metro when the snow settles and turns the ground into an icy deathtrap on your final day in Stockholm. You throw on your warm clothes, right? Nope. Somehow, you‚Äôve become known as the guy who always wears shorts, and you can‚Äôt just break a two-year streak because global warming isn‚Äôt doing its job properly.
Your friends fly back to the US. Two days later, Trump gets elected. No amount of warm clothes can help with that coldness.
You‚Äôve still got seven hours in Stockholm by yourself before you board the Arlanda Express and head to the airport, and you‚Äôve made plans to meet up with another friend in Sweden. She‚Äôs Latvian, and you‚Äôve only met her once, at a garden party back home in Portsmouth. You‚Äôre pretty sure you got really drunk and miscommunicated an opinion about national stereotypes in a way that insulted her, but she still wants to see you, so that‚Äôs nice. You flick your access card into the old suitcase the hostel have fashioned into a deposit box and walk out into the snow, and for the first time in two years, you feel like it isn‚Äôt working out between you and your shorts.
It quickly becomes apparent that your thinly-soled Dunlop canvases have no grip, and your feet threaten to quit their job and let gravity fill the vacancy. You start walking slowly and carefully, but realize this probably makes you look cold. Cold? You can‚Äôt be seen to be some weak human with feelings and senses. You‚Äôre a hardened shorts veteran. So you speed up, even though this triples your chances of slipping up and breaking an arm. You‚Äôre aware this is stupid, because the European Health Card in your wallet expired in 2014. But the Nando‚Äôs loyalty card in front of it is still valid, so there‚Äôs a silver lining.
You‚Äôve got your go-to response to ‚Äúaren‚Äôt you cold wearing shorts in this weather?‚Äù locked and loaded on your lips: ‚Äúnah, it‚Äôs a warm summer‚Äôs day every day in my life.‚Äù You‚Äôve been saying it ever since it made a guy smile while you waited for a train in Amsterdam one time. Nobody asks, though. They laugh from afar instead, sometimes at you, sometimes with you. One guy mutters something that sounds like ‚Äúidiot‚Äù under his breath, but he was probably saying something in Swedish, like the Swedish word for ‚Äúidiot.‚Äù Another guy says he‚Äôs from Bulgaria and follows you down the street asking for money. He doesn‚Äôt even acknowledge your shorts.
Drottninggatan, Riksgatan, and V√§sterl√•nggatan slip into one another, and you unsteadily slalom between tourists stopped in their tracks by Gamla Stan‚Äôs glowing maze of souvenir shops. ‚ÄúConsumer whores,‚Äù you mutter under your breath, making a mental note of a Dala horse you simply must come back and buy later. Soon, you shuffle into Slussen, S√∂dermalm several slippery steps away. Your eyes flicker between the Katarina Elevator and the architectural lasagne behind you in Gamla Stan. There‚Äôre still two hours before you‚Äôre due to meet your Latvian friend, so you clumsily clamber uphill like a kid going the wrong way up a slide.
The Coca Cola (‚ÄòDrink‚Äô is spelled ‚ÄòDrick‚Äô, you realize), Heineken, and Stomatol signs, the endless layers of orange and yellow, skyrocketing spires of verdigris patinas, the caverns of construction cryogenically comatose, and the railway bridge threading through. It‚Äôs all capped in a thin film of frost and snow, and the part of your brain which cries at Love Actually every Christmas sheds a little tear at the sight of the once-fiery fall-colored fa√ßades doused to a blend of beiges by the icy whites and chilling blues of this overnight refrigerator of a city.
You‚Äôre what people who ask ‚Äúis your email address all one word?‚Äù call a ‚Äòmillennial‚Äô, so you abide by your natural instinct of instantly Instagramming the view, forcing yourself to tap out a caption despite the fact that your frozen fingers are refusing to move with the same stubbornness as you insisting on avoiding long pants.
After quickly dismissing the idea that the Stomatol sign might make a rad tattoo, you turn to walk off the Katarina Elevator bridge, venture into S√∂dermalm, and hunt down the coffeeshop your friend has picked out. Your final lone thought is that ‚ÄòStomatol‚Äô and ‚ÄòS√∂dermalm‚Äô might very well sound similar, but you daren‚Äôt tell anyone in case that sneaky umlaut screws everything up.
Over matcha lattes and sweet teas, you and your friend open up new worlds to one another. You drown her in social media advice that‚Äôll help with the launch of a humanitarian podcast she‚Äôs working on, and she unlocks an interest in fine dining you didn‚Äôt know you had parked in your brain‚Äôs overflow garage. Her interest in artistic cuisine is partially sparked by her boyfriend working as a chef at Buckingham Palace. Your interest in social media is partially sparked by that one time a picture of you sitting on the kitchen floor clutching a toaster to your chest went moderately viral.
You fly home, slip on some jeans, nod with satisfaction at the 83 Likes you got on the snow-capped cityscape photo, sit down to watch Chef‚Äôs Table, and wonder why you didn‚Äôt ask your Latvian friend whether her boyfriend ever petted the Queen‚Äôs corgis.
I originally published this post over on my blog at JeevesWilliams.com ¬ª

Title: How do the homeless survive during Stockholm‚Äôs winter?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Originally published by The Local Sweden on Jan. 15, 2016
Amayd, a Nigerian mechanic, Thomas, a Swedish former bus driver, and Zina, a Roma magazine vendor, have one thing in common: struggling to find a place to sleep in Stockholm.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hellfire,‚Äù Amayd described life on the streets. A short man with a slow gait, grey-speckled beard, and blood-laced eyes, Amayd is a 42-year-old father from Nigeria. After 13 years as a permanent resident in Spain, he arrived to Stockholm two weeks ago.
Every night, he‚Äôs entered the lottery for a bed at a Salvation Army-run centre with success. But on Sunday, his name wasn‚Äôt drawn ‚Äî and Amayd had nowhere to sleep. He stayed in the Central Station until it closed, then spent the night walking through snow-blown streets.
‚ÄúI only have one coat,‚Äù Amayd said. ‚ÄúI was afraid to die of the cold.‚Äù
Amayd‚Äôs story is extreme. While he‚Äôs one of at least 2000 people defined as homeless in Stockholm, the city categorizes homelessness on a spectrum that extends to those living in government-assisted apartments. It also boasts a unique ‚Äúroof-over-your-head‚Äù guarantee ensuring that no resident has to sleep outside.
As a European Union migrant, though, Amayd doesn‚Äôt fall under this guarantee. Stockholm‚Äôs homeless population is starkly divided between Swedish citizens and permanent residents versus EU migrants. Although the two groups share similar needs, registered citizens and residents receive social services, but unregistered migrants aren‚Äôt entitled to government benefits.
‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre not registered and you don‚Äôt have any money, we‚Äôll give you economic help and shelter,‚Äù said Lena Sv√§rd, director of the city‚Äôs emergency homeless reception. ‚ÄúYou can stay here for three months, but if you don‚Äôt find a job or nothing happens after that, we can‚Äôt help you and you can‚Äôt stay.‚Äù
While Stockholm‚Äôs social services fund non-profit organisations to help temporary migrants, they focus on tackling Swedish homelessness.
‚ÄòRoof Over Your Head‚Äô Just A Start
In 2015, Stockholm‚Äôs unit for the homeless helped 1475 clients ‚Äî 84% of whom were males, most between the ages of 45‚Äì65. The city runs six shelters with space for 207 clients, but a bed is just the first step.
‚ÄúOnly around 10% of our clients live in shelters,‚Äù explained Jenny Sw√§rd, director of the unit for the homeless. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs not a long-term solution. Shelters can hinder your ability to overcome homelessness. Some people get adjusted to staying there, and when we offer them an apartment with support, they wonder why they have to go and pay rent.‚Äù
Social workers like Sw√§rd attribute homelessness among Swedes to three main causes: lack of housing, substance abuse, and mental health. To address the first cause, Sw√§rd and her team try to get clients into a permanent place ‚Äî a tough job in Stockholm‚Äôs competitive housing market.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs difficult to get an apartment, and if you have problems, it‚Äôs difficult to stay if you don‚Äôt get support,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIf clients get good support, around 90% can stay in their apartments. If they live there for one year and everything works out fine, they get the contract for themselves.‚Äù
46% of the clients who left Sw√§rd‚Äôs unit last year now live in their own place. But Bodil Nilsson, director of the Salvation Army‚Äôs drop-in centre for homeless Swedes, doubted whether this would solve the core issues.
‚ÄúOur guests are living on the edge of society,‚Äù said Nilsson. ‚ÄúMany of them have a place to stay, and some have their own contract, but that doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre happy. Getting their own apartment is not the solution, and they can lose it because of old habits.‚Äù
Core Issues Mental Illness and Addiction
‚ÄòOld habits‚Äô are drug and alcohol addictions that estrange clients from their families, cause health problems, and hinder individuals from keeping jobs.
Karin Perak, a social worker with the city‚Äôs outreach team that meets the homeless on the streets, claimed substance abuse and mental illness are the main causes of homelessness among a majority of Swedes.
The latter is true for Thomas Ljungberg. A self-depreciating but good-humored 50-year-old with sparse ginger hair, Thomas commandeered a table with two friends at the Salvation Army Monday morning. He‚Äôs been unemployed and homeless because of mental illness since 1997.
‚ÄúI experienced traumatic things in the past that I couldn‚Äôt process, and it broke my mental health,‚Äù he explained. ‚ÄúI worked as a bus driver for 7 years, it was the best job I ever had, but my brain was overloaded. When I get tired, I can‚Äôt control myself, and I didn‚Äôt want to have a busload of people behind me, so I chose to stop because I was broken down mentally.‚Äù
For 13 years, Thomas slept in temporary shelters until getting his own apartment, supported by the government, five years ago. He now regularly sees a psychiatrist.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think of it as helpful, but I guess it is,‚Äù he said. ‚Äú4 years ago, I was like a walking zombie; I could have never sat here and had a conversation.‚Äù
Whatever the cause of homelessness, many homeless individuals simply need help navigating their way through the complicated social system.
Nilsson explained: ‚ÄúThey come to us because they lack the ability to take responsibility, or they‚Äôre away from the system and they don‚Äôt have the strength or energy or knowledge to get back. Often they want help, but they‚Äôve been in the situation for so long, they say there‚Äôs no point. It takes a lot of courage to turn your life around.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs possible,‚Äù Sw√§rd said. ‚ÄúThe city is expanding every day, but we have fewer homeless people.‚Äù
While homelessness among Swedes has steadily decreased in recent years, though, the number of homeless EU migrants skyrocketed.
Migrants Survive on the Fringe
‚ÄúIn the past four to five years, it‚Äôs gotten worse,‚Äù said Bj√∂rn Taikon, a community worker with 25 years experience in the municipality. ‚ÄúMore people are coming because all of Europe is closed.‚Äù
Social services estimate there are now between 600 to 1000 EU-migrants without regular income or proper housing in Stockholm. 40% are Romani people, or gypsies.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very difficult to work with this population, because the long-term solution is in their home country,‚Äù said √Ösa Lindhagen, Stockholm‚Äôs vice-mayor for social affairs who represents the Green Party in the national parliament. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a shame and tragedy that we haven‚Äôt succeeded better in Europe to distribute the wealth to everyone. So we have to do everything we can to make it easier for their stay here, especially during winter.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhen we found out that people were sleeping on the streets and it was very cold, the city offered shelters,‚Äù said Sw√§rd, ‚Äúso that people won‚Äôt die.‚Äù
In November 2014, the city began funding non-profit organisations, including the City Mission, Salvation Army, and Philadelphia Church, to provide shelter during winter nights.
Taikon and his colleague Moishe Besokadap, also a Romani who grew up in Stockholm, took up the project. Nearly every day since then, the pair gather at designated times in central locations throughout the city.
Within minutes of the two men entering T-Centralen on Saturday morning, bearded men in parkas and dark-braided women in swishing skirts flocked to them, warmly greeting the two in the Romani language. Besokadap took each person‚Äôs ID card and wrote down his or her name and personal number. It‚Äôs his job to assign the person to a bed in one of the four night shelters on a first come, first served, basis.
‚ÄúThere are always too many people, but we try and find them other shelters,‚Äù Besokadap said. The only exception is if the temperature is below -7, when churches open their doors for people to stay without registering.
On Tuesday night, the temperature hovered around the limit. Thick snowflakes swirled in street lamps as a group of Roma trudged past deserted warehouses to the city‚Äôs largest EU migrant shelter.
At 9 pm, the doors opened. A volunteer checked each guest‚Äôs number, then took their 10 kroner ($1.75) entrance fee. Once registered, guests can stay five nights ‚Äî then they must re-register, find a new place, or enter the lottery for one of the free beds.
Upstairs, volunteers dished out mounds of food and served steaming cups of coffee or tea. After eating, the guests settled into their bunk beds, took showers, started a game of chess, or showed off pictures of their children.
One married couple Gratian, 24 and Zina, 26, left their two children in Romania with Gratian‚Äôs mother to come to Sweden four months ago.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs much better,‚Äù Zina said with a vivacious smile. ‚ÄúWe get work here and our family gets food on the table.‚Äù
Gratian has found sporadic moving jobs while Zina cleans, sells magazines, or recycles cans. Without language skills and permanent residency, though, they‚Äôve struggled to find permanent work, and they asked Besokadap for help to find better jobs.
‚ÄúThey trust us because we‚Äôre family,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt trust the government, they think they want to do something to them or take something from them, but they trust us because no gypsy would want to hurt another gypsy.‚Äù
Downstairs, registration was complete, but two men still waited outside the front door, hoping there were empty beds left. There were not.
A volunteer told them to try another one of the shelters, explaining the location and pointing them in the right direction. The two men turned back into the snowy dark, hoping they‚Äôd get lucky that night.

Global nomad. Storyteller. Journalist. Currently discovering and sharing stories of refugees in Sweden.

Title: My experience with Avicii museum in Stockholm
Content:

Sign in

A personal blog by a fellow 20-something¬†!!   Experiences are something which makes us stand apart as well as connect with each other too. This blog aspires to connect to every 20-something who shares similar kind of experiences and provides a take on these stories from a fellow

--
Listen
Share
Travel Diaries
Today I am writing about one of the most awaited experiences of my life ‚Äî Visit to Avicii Experience museum. Being a huge Tim fan, I was eager to visit this place since it opened in 2021. I love visiting all kinds of museum because we get to know so much by looking at the history, the amazing artifacts and just get an experience of what it was like back then. But now in the developed parts of the world, museum is no longer a seeing experience but it‚Äôs more of feel experience. And this one is nothing short of that.
For me, there are two most favourite elements of the world ‚Äî Music and Technology. The Avicii Museum brings both of them together and I just loved it. The museum is aptly named as it IS an experience. There was no rules for photography and videography and I realised why was that. You can click pictures and take videos as much as you want because when you experience it yourself, it‚Äôs absolutely different than seeing pictures or videos. That‚Äôs why I feel no regrets to share my memories with you about the most loved EDM artist ever. And I hope that everyone who is reading this blog gets to experience this amazing work at least once in their life.
Let me give you an idea of what the experience is like by sharing some keywords to help you decode.
Music Production ‚Äî EDM ‚Äî FL Studio ‚Äî Ostermalm ‚Äî Virtual Reality (VR) ‚Äî Artificial Intelligence (AI) ‚Äî Travel ‚Äî Popstar‚Äôs Life ‚Äî Concert Experience ‚Äî Le7els ‚Äî Life
Still confused? I can understand that for some of you who haven‚Äôt visited Sweden yet, might not know what ‚ÄòOstermalm‚Äô is. That‚Äôs okay. Based on my experience, I can try to summarise what the museum holds and may be you can decide then if it‚Äôs worth the visit or not.
LIFE OF TIM
@aviciiexperience beautifully showcases the whole life of Tim Bergling, starting with a glimpse of his first apartment at Ostermalm and they placed the objects in the room so meticulously that it looks like a 20 year old Tim is really living there. The whole museum is filled with headsets where you can just listen to different people who he worked with exclusively, about his early days as a music producer to an established global DJ and producer. They also showcased the trips he took in US and you can actually click your own picture int he same setup as her did when he went backpacking through US with his fellow musicians.
HIS ACHIEVEMENTS
If you are a huge fan of Avicii, then you would have already known about his top hits, Swedish Grammy and much more. But it‚Äôs a surreal experience to see all those accolades on the wall. This museum is started with the idea that things he achieved shouldn‚Äôt be locked in the box and must be shared with everyone. Apart from accolades, his achievements in my opinion are also the songs, synths and riffs he created and gave some legendary hits.
USE OF TECH
This is one of a kind experience due to the use of technology. Most of the tour is experienced through audio clips, interviews and exclusives which can be listened through headphones and that too in English as well as Swedish. Also, there are some VR experiences where you can be inside the studio along with some prominent musicians and sing along with them.
One of the very creative experiences is to go into a mirror cave which represents the downside of success and fame at a very young age. It depicts the reasons for Tim‚Äôs struggles through maintaining his mental health due to his schedule. Another one such experience was to go through his meditation journey in eastern Asia and just relax in a soothing environment with chime sounds.
Last but not the least, for those who missed his tribute concert in Stockholm, the museum has a short video from the concert in a large hall which gives you the exact vibe of that specific concert. It shows the most memorable tribute to Tim Bergling along the sounds of his epic EDM anthem Le7els.
Overall, my experience was nothing short of surreal with a mix of emotions ‚Äî from happy to sad to just accepting. There was a signbook at the end in which we filled a page with our thoughts about the experience and as true fans
For the fans of EDM, I would totally recommend to visit.
Check it out for more official information here: https://aviciiexperience.com/
Read my book review of Tim‚Äôs autobiography here: https://medium.com/everyday-life-of-a-20-something/avicii-tim-bergling-a-true-account-on-edm-mental-health-and-stress-f05fcc2715ec

Title: Stockholm to Seattle: When My Hero Became My Captor
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I used to think I understood fear. The kind that sends your heart racing before an exam, the kind that creeps in like a shadow while you‚Äôre alone with a thriller on a stormy night. But nothing ‚Äî absolutely nothing ‚Äî prepared me for the visceral terror that engulfed me when the van door slammed shut behind me in downtown Seattle. In that instant, my world flipped upside down; I realized I had just been kidnapped by the very man I had idolized for years.
My fascination with Diljit began at the tender age of ten, sparked by a grainy YouTube video that crackled with raw energy. A renegade coder, a digital outlaw ‚Äî he was everything I aspired to be. While other kids plastered their walls with posters of Marvel superheroes, I meticulously printed out screenshots of Diljit‚Äôs viral hacktivist interviews, taping them next to my bed like sacred relics. As my friends dreamed of college acceptance letters, I fantasized about finding him, connecting with the genius who danced on the edges of legality and morality.
And I did.
Years of subtle stalking ensued ‚Äî Reddit threads dissecting his every move, late-night IRC chatrooms filled with whispers of his exploits, and an underground tech talk in Portland where I finally saw him in the flesh. I followed him, obsessed, worshiping at the altar of his brilliance. So when he threw a burlap sack over my head near Pike Place Market and shoved me into a rusted Sprinter van, I wasn‚Äôt angry. I felt honored.
His songs, the anthems of rebellion and defiance that once resonated with my youthful ambitions, now echo in my mind as haunting ballads of a fractured soul. Each lyric, once a rallying cry for freedom and individuality, now feels like a cryptic commentary on the very nature of obsession and the thin line between genius and madness. I find myself dissecting the metaphors he wove into his music, the raw emotion that spilled from his heart onto the page, and I can‚Äôt help but wonder if they were prophetic tales of his own descent into darkness. His melodies, which once inspired me to dream big and challenge the status quo, now serve as a chilling reminder of how easily the pursuit of passion can spiral into chaos. The notes linger in the air like ghosts, tugging at my consciousness, forcing me to confront the unsettling reality that the man whose voice ignited a fire within me is also the one who plunged me into the depths of fear. In this tortured symphony of admiration and horror, his songs have become both a soundtrack to my liberation and a lament for the hero I thought I knew.
He kept me locked away in a concrete basement that reeked of wet copper and lost dreams. The dim light flickered ominously from a single bulb, illuminating a metal toilet and a floor mattress so thin it felt like sleeping on a bed of nails. My meals were sparse ‚Äî canned beans, stale granola, and bitter black coffee ‚Äî but each morsel felt sacred, like communion with the divine.
Through the wall, I heard his voice ‚Äî muttering code, typing furiously, yelling at himself in fits of rage and genius. I could feel the madness radiating from him, and I loved it. My childhood idol had transformed into a mythic ghost, and I found myself inside his lair, an unwilling accomplice in his chaotic world.
Every evening, he would enter, and our conversations evolved. Initially, they were riddled with insults and paranoia, but soon they blossomed into discussions of philosophy, hacktivism, identity, freedom, and fear. Yes, I was his prisoner, but I was also his audience, hanging on his every word.
One night, driven by an insatiable curiosity, I asked him, "Why me?"
He didn‚Äôt meet my gaze. You were always watching. I figured you‚Äôd understand.
Just like that.
No dramatic farewells. No epic showdown. I walked out into the rain-soaked night, drenched and shivering, yet alive. But as I stepped into the world, it felt hollow, void of the vibrancy I once knew. The city around me felt fake ‚Äî the noise too deafening, the people too‚Ä¶ normal.
I wandered for hours, disoriented, until I stumbled upon a payphone. With trembling hands, I dialed the police, omitting any mention of Diljit. I simply said I was lost.
I think about him every day. Not in fear. Not in hatred. But in awe.
My kidnapper wasn‚Äôt just a monster lurking in the shadows; he was a dark mirror, reflecting back the fragmented pieces of myself I had long been afraid to confront. Each day, I grapple with the chaotic duality of my feelings ‚Äî an intoxicating blend of reverence and confusion that twists in my gut like a serpent coiling tighter around its prey. How could someone I had idolized with such fervor, a figure who once embodied my wildest aspirations, morph into my captor, ensnaring me in a nightmare woven from the very fabric of my dreams?
I find myself caught in an emotional tempest, where every recollection is a jagged shard of glass. On one hand, there‚Äôs awe ‚Äî a haunting admiration for the brilliance that fuels his madness, a genius that ignited the flames of my own ambitions. On the other, there‚Äôs bewilderment, a spiraling sense of betrayal as I wrestle with the horrifying reality that the man I revered became the architect of my imprisonment.
In the quiet hours of the night, when the world is draped in darkness, I replay our conversations like a broken record, trying to decipher the riddles of his psyche. What did it mean that I was drawn to him, captivated by his chaos? Was I merely a victim or an unwitting accomplice in a twisted tale of obsession and desire?
This internal struggle is suffocating. I‚Äôm left questioning everything: my values, my dreams, my very identity. The lines between admiration and horror blur until they become indistinguishable. I feel like I‚Äôm standing on the precipice of an abyss, teetering between the longing for understanding and the fear of what that understanding might reveal.
As I navigate this labyrinth of emotions, I realize that the true horror lies not in his actions, but in the reflection he casts upon me ‚Äî a reminder of the shadows within, the dark corners of my soul I‚Äôve yet to illuminate. In this surreal dance of captor and captive, I am left forever altered, trapped in a paradox of fascination and dread, haunted by the question: how could a hero become a villain, and what does that say about the hero I thought I wanted to be?

Title: The Woodland Cemetery (Skogskyrkog√•rden) in Stockholm
Content:

Member-only story

I could not remember exactly how I got to know Skogskyrkog√•rden. I guess it was because I wanted to visit Avicii‚Äôs grave. And then I got the wrong information on the internet, saying that it was resting in this cemetery. So I googled it and found out that it has been on the list of UNESCO World Heritage since 1994.
Finally, I got the chance to visit it in late September this year. I went there with my Couchsurfing host. He has a great deal of knowledge regarding the history, architecture, art, music, movie, and so on. Besides, he is a huge fan of Greta Garbo, whose grave is also resting in this peaceful land. Thus, he became my private tour guide in Skogskyrkog√•rden. And thanks to him, I had the chance to look at the corner that belongs to the legendary Hollywood star.
According to my host, the spirit of the design was to create harmony between nature and the burial ground. As such, the visitors may enjoy a sense of respect and tranquility. To quote the words of the flyer from the visitor center:
‚ÄúThe design is shaped around the experience of mourners, with a focus on the landscape and the capacity of nature to reconcile mourners with‚Ä¶

Title: Traveling from Amsterdam to Stockholm: Part 1
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up

Listen

I was in Amsterdam, at the end of my journey, feeling very tired. I‚Äôd been traveling alone for over two months, carrying my bags. My hands and flat feet were hurting. I was tired of sleeping in strange beds and sharing rooms and bathrooms with strangers.
On that Sunday, my first job was to leave the hostel to buy some snacks and groceries for my long train ride to Stockholm.
After shopping, I went back to my hostel room and started packing my bags again‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsomething I was very good at by then. I could pack my bag in less than 20 minutes without thinking about it. I collected the blankets, left them for cleaning, and left my room with my bags, heading to the reception.
Looking back, I can feel how much I wanted to go home. But I didn‚Äôt let myself give up. I was determined to keep traveling, to keep moving, with a clear mind and strong will.
I left the hostel and walked through the streets of Amsterdam, listening to Berlin techno on my earbuds, and never looking back.
For more content, follow me. I‚Äôll also be constantly publishing photography on my IG account.

I must have done something good in a former life, if you believe in that sort of thing. Because, even though I‚Äôm not a healthcare provider or over the age of 65, I was invited to get the COVID-19 vaccine just four weeks after it was released in the U.S.
I made my appointment with mixed emotions. Others need it more than I do. I work as an administrator at a university medical school. I never interact with patients; I‚Äôm a desk jockey, 100%. Yet, all healthcare and med school employees have been invited to receive the vaccine ‚Äî probably because it‚Äôs too onerous to sort out which of the 26,000+ employees see patients and which don‚Äôt.
My first instinct was to pass ‚Äî let others get it. I‚Äôd rather my mom or significant other or brother get it. Or your grandfather. Anyone. They are all in higher risk groups than I am. But, apparently, people who defer (with good intent) are causing bottlenecks and lags in distribution.
The prevailing opinion is: get it when you‚Äôre invited.
I arrived at the famed football stadium at the appointed time. A very orderly process had been set up. People‚Ä¶

Hey you, sitting on your sofa, drinking wine and eating an old Easter egg at 4 pm in the afternoon while tweeting ‚ÄúHate this lockdown #openbackup‚Äù ‚Äî I‚Äôm here to tell you you‚Äôre a fraud.
That‚Äôs right, you‚Äôre a big fat liar. You love lockdown. Go on, admit it.
Right now you‚Äôre meant to be working from home but you‚Äôre still in pyjamas wiggling your mouse every 5 minutes so it looks like you‚Äôre online.
Don‚Äôt tell me lockdown is worse than your old daily commute, the traffic jams, crowded trains and getting up 90-minutes earlier than you currently do to shower and pretend you‚Äôre a respectable human.
Sure, you might miss the pub and seeing friends, but because deep down in places you don‚Äôt talk about at parties (that you‚Äôre no longer allowed to go to), you want the lockdown ‚Äî you need the lockdown.
All that guilt about not seeing friends and family has magically disappeared. No longer does every email and phone conversation have to end with ‚ÄúWe must get together soon.‚Äù The game is up, no one even pretends anymore, it‚Äôs amazing. You‚Äôre finally free of social obligation.

Content:

I was born and raised in a democratic and capitalistic country but my parents imposed a socialist approach on me because that‚Äôs all they‚Äôve known their whole life.
Contradictions and mixed messages left my generation confused and lost. My parents were not able to travel without a permission to leave Czechoslovakia. And usually that permission was not given if asked. And my only goal from early age was to travel and discover different cultures.
I wanted to live somewhere else, but my parents saw this as a danger, something I shouldn‚Äôt do and I should be happy where I am. This was purely a socialist approach and I don‚Äôt blame them.
Interestingly, my grandparents who shortly experienced their freedom after WWII and then they lost it in the Soviet invasion in 1968, they see communists as evil people and regime that made them fear for their life. And that‚Äôs the part my parents haven‚Äôt experienced. The main reason was a softer approach to communism which was called socialism.
My dad told me a story about my granddad. He was driving a train to Polish border in 1968 and out of nowhere, there was a Soviet tank on the rails that made him stop. Both my grand dad and the Soviet soldier didn‚Äôt know what to do so they just stared at each other for 3 days. My grandma feared the worst when she didn‚Äôt‚Ä¶
